HEADLINE: A Third Bidder for Auction World Heft;
Phillips, With a Rich New Parent, Seeks to Join Sotheby's and Christie's Cozy Club

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL 

 BODY:
As the Justice Department investigation into Sotheby's and Christie's unfolds, the world's largest auction houses are proceeding as if it is business as usual, gathering all the best Impressionist, modern and contemporary art they can for important auctions planned over the next two weeks. But the historical tug-of-war between Sotheby's and Christie's has turned into an expensive three-way fight.
Both Sotheby's and Christie's have their share of exceptional works, but their catalogs of Impressionist and modern art seem bloated with second-rate paintings, drawings and sculptures that carry high estimates. The explanation is simple. Since LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton bought Phillips, the London-based auction house a year ago, it has been going after property at any cost, dipping into LVMH's deep pockets to become a major player. 
 Long a distant third in the auction world, Phillips has 29 works by masters like Cezanne and Renoir, Matisse and Picasso in its evening sale on Monday. Although this is the kind of art that experts at Sotheby's and Christie's would have liked to include in their sales, they were unwilling to risk guaranteeing sellers the high prices necessary to snag them. As it did last spring, Phillips has given most of its sellers either substantial guarantees -- an undisclosed sum promised to a consignor regardless of a sale's outcome -- or other financial incentives to get their business.
Christopher Thomson, chief executive of Phillips, said that "in every instance where Phillips has a financial interest, we have disclosed it."
Last year the auction house ran big ads proclaiming "Phillips, the other way to do auctions," a deliberate dig at Sotheby's and Christie's business practices. Yet this season the Phillips catalog of Impressionist and modern art has dealers, auction house experts and collectors buzzing about some of Phillips's auction methods.
Instead of clearly marking the works in which it has a financial interest on the catalog page where they are shown, Phillips has noted it in small print in the back of its catalog, specifying its stake in nine lots. The usual auction house practice is to note the company's interest on the page displaying the work, to alert buyers that the company has a financial stake in the outcome of the sale. (The New York City Department of Consumer affairs requires auction catalogs to disclose any financial interest a house has in the art it sells.)
Mr. Thomson would not comment on the catalog notation.
Two top works in the Phillips sale, part of a group of paintings being sold by Wafic Said, a Saudi billionaire of Syrian origin, are landscapes by Cezanne and Renoir. Phillips has not said it has a financial interest in the works, but experts familiar with Mr. Said's collection say that it was bought by a third party on behalf of the auction house. This form of financing, known as a third-party guarantee, is unconventional but not illegal and is frowned on in the art world because an auction house could tend to promote that material over other offerings.
Asked about third-party guarantees in this instance, Mr. Thomson added: "There can be occasions when other parties have a financial interest. These companies are independent of Phillips, and this is consistent with legal requirements and market practice."
Auction experts and dealers also say that Phillips has confused buyers by identifying the owner in different ways on different works, making it seem as if they come from different collections and that there are more consignors than there really are. Mr. Said's Renoir, "In the Garden," is listed as "Property of a Gentleman." But his Cezanne, "Hill of Galet, Pontoise," has no property title.
Mr. Thomson declined to comment on the property titles.
Phillips has also hired Simon de Pury, the former chairman of Sotheby's in Europe and now a private art dealer and adviser, as auctioneer for its two big evening sales. While Mr. de Pury is a top auctioneer, several dealers who asked for anonymity because they do business with Phillips argued that this gives Mr. de Pury an unfair advantage. Mr. de Pury, a big auction buyer, they say, will be privy not only to the reserves -- the secret minimum price agreed upon by the seller and the auction house -- but he will also have confidential information on the strategies of the bidders and the auction house that he can use in his own dealings.
Mr. Thomson said that Mr. de Pury would have no access to client records and had not been party to contractual negotiations with consignors, and that the auctioneer's book will have no reference to sellers and he will have no access to the names of bidders who register for the sales. Mr. de Pury will have access to the reserves, but they will be made available to him just before the sale. "Most importantly," Mr. Thomson said, "neither he nor his firm will be allowed to bid at the sale."
The Phillips incursion promises a harder battle this season for Sotheby's and Christie's, which have been consumed by the federal price-fixing investigation. Last month Sotheby's pleaded guilty to violating antitrust laws, as did Diana D. Brooks, its former president and chief executive, who has agreed to cooperate in a continuing investigation of her boss, A. Alfred Taubman, Sotheby's largest shareholder and its former chairman. Officials of Christie's turned over documents to the Justice Department in January and received conditional amnesty.
To fend off Phillips, the major auction houses have been making higher estimates. On top of that, no large estates have come on the market this season, so most of what is on sale has come from discretionary sellers who are betting that a robust economy will encourage collectors to continue buying art.
But a strong economy can be a two-edged sword. When people don't have to sell, it is harder to find good things to put up for auction. "That we still have a strong market is reflected in the fact that while we've seen rising prices over the last few years, there is not the rush to sell that there was in the late 1980's," said Christopher Burge, honorary chairman of Christie's and its principal auctioneer.
Sotheby's and Christie's each have a few exceptional works of Impressionist and modern art. Next Wednesday Christie's is offering a rare painting from Picasso's Blue Period, "Woman With Crossed Arms." The portrait, which depicts a glum-looking woman seated against a background of rich blues, was painted in Barcelona in 1902. It is being sold by Mr. and Mrs. Chauncey McCormick, Chicago collectors since 1936, and had been on loan to the Art Institute of Chicago since 1972. Blue Period Picassos rarely come on the market, and experts estimate that this one will fetch upwards of $25 million. The last Picasso from this period, a portrait of the artist Angel Fernandez de Soto, was bought by Andrew Lloyd Webber for $29.1 million when it was sold at Sotheby's in 1995.
Experts are betting that the Picasso will be this season's most expensive painting. But another big-ticket work, Manet's "Young Woman in a Garden," may give it competition. This rich Impressionist landscape is unusually large -- 60 1/2 by 46 inches -- and shows an American woman, a friend of the artist known only as Mademoiselle Marguerite, reading in the garden behind a Paris house that Manet rented in the summer of 1880. Last shown 47 years ago in an exhibition in Minnesota, it is expected to sell for $20 million to $30 million.
Many works for sale this season are familiar to auctiongoers. Every painting being sold by Mr. Said at Phillips has been on the market recently, and in most cases he paid more than the low estimate in the catalog. Similarly, Sotheby's has four paintings being sold by the Bellagio Gallery of Fine Art in Las Vegas. Its former chairman, Stephen A. Wynn, one of the biggest buyers at auction for himself and for the Bellagio for the last five years, sold his company, Mirage Resorts, to MGM Grand Inc. in March. For months MGM Grand has been selling its holdings both privately and at auction. Among the best being sold by Sotheby's is a Modigliani portrait of the art dealer Paul Guillaume, which brought $3.1 million when it was sold at Christie's four years ago. Sotheby's now estimates it will bring $3.5 million to $5 million.
Provenance is always something seasoned collectors carefully note, and this fall Christie's is offering several works being sold by the heirs of Auguste Pellerin, the French industrialist who died in 1929 after amassing one of the world's greatest collections of Cezannes. The artist's "Riverbank of the Marne" from 1888, a landscape of the river with two fishermen in the foreground, is one of the collection's highlights. The painting is expected to sell for $7 million to $10 million.
Sotheby's also has some unusual Picassos, although none are as important as Christie's Blue Period painting. "Rest," a 1932 head of his mistress Marie-Therese Walter in profile, is expected to bring $3 million to $4 million. (It was last on the market at Christie's in London seven years ago and brought $2.2 million.) "The Studio," from 1956, is a nearly monochromatic painting of the artist's studio with a bare canvas as an exclamation point in the foreground. The painting brought $2.8 million in 1988 in a sale at Sotheby's from the collection of the New York collectors Victor and Sally Ganz. Now Sotheby's says it should sell for $3.5 million to $4.5 million.
Sculpture has been particularly popular for the last few seasons, partly because it has been undervalued and partly because of the number of public sculpture gardens being formed. This season Christie's has several rare sculptures, one of the finest being a Cubist bust by Picasso, "Head of a Woman (Fernande)" from 1909, which is expected to sell for $4 million to $6 million. "Few Cubist sculptures exist," said Franck Giraud, head of Christie's Impressionist, modern and postwar art departments. "And this is the biggest and the most important. It's also a very early cast dating from around 1910."
Sotheby's contemporary art catalog also features some important sculptures. "We tried to get sculpture because it appeals to today's tastes," said Tobias Meyer, head of Sotheby's contemporary art department worldwide. Besides works by by Alexander Calder, Robert Gober and Donald Judd, three rare Noguchi sculptures from the Lannan Foundation in Los Angeles are being offered.
Sotheby's defines contemporary art as works made after 1945, and while its sale on Nov. 14 begins with work by some younger artists, most are by established masters like Jasper Johns, Andy Warhol and Donald Judd. While Mr. Meyer declined to identify the sellers in his sale, contemporary art experts have spotted one interesting consignor. Sotheby's former chairman, Mr. Taubman, a well-known collector, is selling a painting by Mr. Johns, "Disappearance I," and another by Francis Bacon.
On Nov. 15 Christie's will offer puts its classic contemporary art in a separate sale it calls "Post War." After grouping these works with early 20th-century artists like Matisse and Picasso in a sale it had called 20th-century art, Christie's restructured its sales this season, putting early modern masters with Impressionist and modern art, and moving postwar artists into another sale and art from the last 30 years in what it calls its contemporary art sales.
Christie's contemporary art sale on Nov. 16 has drawn much of the attention. The catalog, whose cover displays a naked sculpture of a life-size Ken doll by Charles Ray (estimate, $700,000 to $900,000), has a host of images that range from the explicit to the pornographic by artists of the moment like Jeff Koons and Yasumasa Morimura.

HEADLINE: Rocket Lifts 3 Astronauts To the Station Built in Space

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: BAIKONUR, Kazakhstan, Oct. 31

 BODY:
One American and two Russian astronauts rocketed into orbit today on a quest to become the first residents of the international space station and begin fulfilling the once-fantastic dream of permanent occupancy in space.
"Let's go do it!" shouted Capt. William M. Shepherd of the United States Navy, the space station's first commander, before climbing into a Soyuz rocket and blasting off from the same pad where the Space Age began 43 years ago with Sputnik. 
 "It's history again repeating itself, in a different way," said Joseph H. Rothenberg, head of the human space flight program for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. "Space shouldn't be the same again."
The $60 billion-plus station, a joint project among the United States, Russia, Canada, Japan and 10 member countries of the European Space Agency, is the largest technological enterprise ever undertaken on a global scale.
"It will be a laboratory like every professor wishes he had here on Earth, and open 24 hours a day," said Jorg Feustel-Buchl, director of manned space flight for the European Space Agency. He monitored the launch with Russian and other space officials at Russian Mission Control in Korolyov, near Moscow.
The 17-story green rocket, transformed into a frosty white by the super-cold fuel, vanished into dense fog three seconds after liftoff from the Baikonur Cosmodrome. Its brightly burning engines were visible several seconds later as the rocket gained speed and altitude. The roar, by then, was deafening to the more than 500 gathered at the cosmodrome.
Nine minutes later, Captain Shepherd and his crew mates, Yuri Gidzenko and Sergei Krikalev, were in orbit and giving chase to the international space station. The complex was soaring 240 miles above the Sahara when they took off, more than two years late as a result of Russia's economic troubles, which stalled space station assembly.
The three men will reach their new home on Thursday and settle in for a four-month stay. The station's official language is English, though Russian is expected to be used when communicating with ground controllers outside Moscow.
There was no countdown, only occasional curt reports blaring from loudspeakers. Several seconds before liftoff, the command "zazhiganiye!" (ignition) was given and the 20 engines burst into flames. Clouds of dark smoke rolled across the desert.
NASA's administrator, Daniel S. Goldin, waited until Captain Shepherd and his crew were safely in orbit before hugging top Russian officials and giving a high-five to Mr. Rothenberg, his deputy.
The deputy director general of the Russian Space Agency, Valery Alaverdov, pressed a goblet into Mr. Goldin's hands and poured scotch from a bottle. "Success!" Mr. Alaverdov toasted. "Here's to a great space program," Mr. Goldin replied.
"There are so many people who felt maybe we couldn't do it," Mr. Goldin told reporters moments later, referring to the years of agonizing delay. "But it's happening, it's here. We're going to be in space forever with people who are circling this globe, and then we're going on to Mars, back to the moon and with bases on asteroids."
Captain Shepherd and his crew, which NASA calls Expedition 1, face a busy and difficult few weeks. As soon as they arrive at the space station, they will activate all the life-support systems and start tackling all the maintenance and repair chores that have been piling up since the new living quarters joined the rest of the complex in July.
Visiting space shuttle astronauts took care of as many chores as they could in September and again in October, but most of the work had to wait for the experts, Captain Shepherd, an accomplished home mechanic, and his crew.
Space shuttle crews will visit two more times, delivering giant electricity-producing solar panels and the American lab Destiny, before Discovery arrives in February to bring the crew back to Earth. They will be replaced by a fresh crew. And so it will go, for the next 15 years and possibly even longer.
NASA hopes to finish building the space station in 2006 and keep using it for scientific research for at least a decade beyond that. Current progress can be tracked at a Web site, www.spaceflight.nasa.gov.
"There's so much more to do," said C. Michael Foale, a NASA astronaut who is in charge of the expedition crews. "But it's a transition for all of us psychologically to think that we're doing something real rather than something we've always imagined."
Dr. Foale added hopefully, "I have often thought this may be the last time that there were no humans in space, and I really believe that could be today."

HEADLINE: A 'Techno-Peasant' Goes Internet

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
Frederick Forsyth, the British author who made his name in the literary "old economy" of spies, mercenaries and assassins, hardly seems a likely candidate to blaze a trail through the literary thickets of cyberspace.
Eschewing word processors, he uses an electric typewriter and sends his manuscripts to be retyped for publication, correcting proofs by hand. He calls himself a "techno-peasant at heart." 
 But having sold 60 million old-fashioned paper-and-ink books in 30 languages, Mr. Forsyth, 61, plans to become the first brand-name British author of best sellers to publish his work on the Internet. Starting on Wednesday, the first of five short stories will be sold for $2.99 a download from electronic retailers like Barnesandnoble.com and Bol.com.
E-commerce, he said today, may not be all that it is talked up to be. "If you want to order a book on the Internet, it still has to come in a jiffy bag," he said. "There are limitations." But for all the Internet technology that eludes him, the Web does have some advantages, he said: "Words are something this thing does handle well. And words are how I make my living."
Of course, the venture into e-publishing is not new. Stephen King led the way among American best-selling writers this year with a novella, "Riding the Bullet," and his current 10-chapter novel, "The Plant."
But Mr. Forsyth's move into electronic books is "very much a pioneering first step" in Britain, said Catherine Jones, head of marketing at Online Originals, which is publishing Mr. Forsyth's series of stories.
Among British authors, Mr. Forsyth and Fay Weldon are among the few to have prominently embraced electronic publishing, while Online Originals, founded in 1996, says one of its writers, Patricia le Roy, is the first electronically published British author to be nominated for a major award -- the Booker Prize -- for her novel "The Angels of Russia."
From a literary perspective, Mr. Forsyth's venture offers the latest twist in what seems a search for a new identity in the aftermath of the cold war. A previous work, "The Phantom of Manhattan," published a year ago, was a cross between fantasy and romance and was not a best seller in the tradition of earlier thrillers like "The Day of the Jackal" or "The Odessa File."
Yet spies and superpowers no longer intrigue him. "There are no Russians, no K.G.B.," he said of his Internet series, titled "Quintet," which will begin with a 20,000-word novella called "The Veteran."
The series, Mr. Forsyth said, stemmed from a conversation last September with his agent, Ed Victor, during which he was considering five separate ideas, none of them big enough for a novel. But, he said, they did seem to work as short stories, all on different themes. Mr. Forsyth acknowledged that Mr. King's example had prompted him to think about the possibilities of electronic publishing, although he does not think the Internet formula works with a 10-part novel like "The Plant."
"A lot of people in our day and age don't want to wait 10 months" to finish a single book, he said. But short stories and novellas, he said, are better suited to the speed of the Internet. The five stories in "Quintet" will be published every 21 days through February. He is now writing the fourth of the series.
From a business perspective, the debate about electronic book publishing is far from resolved. Certainly, Mr. Forsyth's imprimatur will raise the profile of Online Originals, a privately held company whose margins will be reduced by discounts to retailers, encryption costs and Mr. Forsyth's royalty. The standard royalty paid by Online Originals to authors is 50 percent of the retail sale price, Ms. Jones said, compared with the usual 10 percent in traditional book publishing.
Even electronic publishers say the devices available for downloading e-books are at an early stage. "It's not yet at a level where it's cheap enough and pleasant enough for large numbers of people to want to substitute" electronic books for traditional books, said Phil Rance, the managing director of Online Originals. "But it's getting there."
And though some online publishers have stables of lesser-known authors, revenue is likely to be tied to big-name authors. "This will only work for the big blockbuster names which have an established brand name," said Simon Mays-Smith, a media analyst at UBS Warburg.
On the eve of publication, Mr. Forsyth said he was uncertain where his leap into cyberspace would take him, except that success or failure would be measured at the speeds of cyberspace rather than traditional publishing.
"It's very quick," he said. Internet readers "will either hit within five days -- or they won't."

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1630 words

HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT;
When Top Jobs Go Begging

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
About 18 months ago, Harvey M. Greenberg, the Polaroid Corporation's vice president for human resources, looked around and hated what he saw -- or, more accurately, what he did not see. Many of the best and brightest of Polaroid's top people were no longer there. Some had retired early, many more had defected to Internet start-ups.
These were the people with the institutional memory, the customer relationships -- and the prime slots in what Polaroid had thought was a well-cushioned succession plan for top management jobs. 
 Polaroid jumped into action. It promoted younger people who, by its old standards, would not have been deemed ready for another three years. It looked deep into its organization for up-and-comers that it could develop quickly and plug into its succession plans. And it is now surveying all employees to find the hot buttons -- high pay? flexible hours? quicker promotion? -- that will make them stay.
"We've recovered well," Mr. Greenberg said. "But it's a darned shame that it took this upheaval to make us look harder at developing high-potential people."
Polaroid's is not an isolated tale. As the first wave of baby boomers turn 54 -- prime time for the second-career itch -- more of them are bailing out of corporate jobs. They are joining dot-coms, starting their own businesses, working for charities or simply calling it quits and enjoying life.
"The retirement of the older people is leaving the younger people without mentors," warned E. Ralph Biggadike, a management professor at Columbia Business School.
The younger people are not necessarily complaining. James S. Davey joined Polaroid less than two years ago; he has been promoted twice, and at 35, is director of global marketing for Polaroid's hugely successful i-Zone pocket cameras.
"I've had the opportunity to prove myself quickly," he said. "From what I've heard, that's a lot different than it would have been in the past."
Still, departures are creating gaping holes in succession plans. "Companies took for granted that they'll have the talent when they need it, so they invested more in technology than in developing people," said Donna H. Davenport, a consultant with the Empower Group, a New York management consulting firm. "Now they have huge talent gaps."
The management trends of the 90's left many companies ill equipped to fill the holes. Mergers and downsizings pulled a lot of talent out of the lineup. As overburdened survivors did triage on their responsibilities, mentoring underlings was often the first thing to go.
The push to divest everything but core businesses, meanwhile, reduced the number of divisions where people could be groomed. The drive to cut management layers and to farm out ancillary functions further shrank the training grounds.
"It's become harder to move people to jobs outside their technical expertise, where they can learn to get things done by managing people," said Michael Beer, a professor at Harvard Business School.
Thomas J. Neff, chairman of United States operations for the executive recruiters Spencer Stuart, says that the problem is likely to get worse. Until recently, he said, the executive population has grown in line with gross domestic product. But these days, supply and demand are going in opposite directions.
Assuming economic growth of 2 percent a year for the next 15 years, Mr. Neff predicted that demand for executives will increase by a third, while the number of those 35 to 44 will decline 15 percent. "The growth of the economy and of management jobs is outstripping the number of people developing in the right age range," he said. "Some companies will wake up one day and say, 'Lord, we don't have the right people anymore.' "
Slowly, more companies are hearing the warnings. They are beefing up retention and development programs, hoping to keep top talent long enough to groom a replacement layer.
In June, Deloitte Consulting promoted eight veterans into the new slot of senior partner, and let them carve out their dream jobs. One chose a three-day week, another decided to work for nonprofit clients.
All have been assigned as mentors to fast-track younger partners. Now Deloitte plans to create more senior partners. Why? Deloitte realized that, by 2001, nearly a quarter of its 850 partners would be 50 or older, prime candidates for a midlife career change. It worried that an exodus of older partners would not only strip the firm of talent but would send a signal to younger partners that Deloitte was not a home for life.
"The retention of our more senior people is a critical element in the retention of our early-year and midyear partners," said Charles L. Biggs, 59, and one of the new senior partners. (He chose to forgo assignments that required travel.)
At least Deloitte has a wealth of younger people to train. Other companies are finding that past downsizings are coming back to haunt them.
In 1992, the United States Postal Service cut the number of executive positions to 650 from 1,500. Recently it looked at its executive roster, which has expanded back to 850 top jobs, and faced a grim truth: "In a few years, between 35 and 40 percent of our executives will be eligible to retire, and we could be up the creek," said Stephen A. Leavey, manager of corporate personnel management. Mr. Leavey said that 35 senior executives had left in the last 18 months alone.
The post office now lets executives do stints in different departments, in hopes of staving off boredom. It will soon offer coaching to all executives, "so that if they are suddenly promoted they can hit the ground running," Mr. Leavey said. It is now expanding its management training programs to 20,000 midlevel managers, and it is starting an internship program for new hires with graduate degrees who can be pushed into management within four years.
Even companies that claim immunity from boomer flight are putting in preventive programs. Johnna G. Torsone, chief human resources officer at Pitney Bowes, insists that Pitney is suffering only normal turnover, and that its staff is not age-skewed. But, she said, Pitney recently undertook a "rigorous assessment of our talent pool," just in case. It spotted a troubling shortage of people who could readily move into general management jobs.
So Pitney made a list of about 30 potential fast-trackers, compared their strengths and weaknesses to those of Pitney's most senior executives, and put them through customized 12-month programs to help each more closely mirror the strengths of the existing senior team.
Pitney is now taking its "be prepared" attitude farther down the roster, looking to groom switch-hitters who can fit into any Pitney division. It is sending 3,500 managers through leadership sessions, at which Pitney's top executives will serve as guest lecturers.
And it has identified a smaller group of high-potential managers, and assigned them mentors from other divisions who are strong in their weak areas. "If people learn about other divisions now, they can be plugged into those divisions if a job opens up," Ms. Torsone said.
Of course, some companies insist they have been doing such training all along.
When the Xerox Corporation dismissed G. Richard Thoman, its chief executive, in May, it had plenty of longtimers to pick from. (It chose Anne M. Mulcahy, 47, a 24-year Xerox employee, who now is president and heir apparent.) And, despite turmoil in its businesses, and a precipitous slide in its stock, Xerox insists its succession plans are intact.
"Every year we do the 'what happens if you're hit by a bus' type of review with all our managers," said Jeffrey J. Simek, a Xerox spokesman, who noted that during the last round of cuts Xerox did not allow plant managers to accept a buyout package unless they had already groomed their successors. "Managers who let that process fall through the cracks get dinged at their own reviews," Mr. Simek said.
Even companies that prefer to fill gaps with outsiders are finding that strategy hard to pursue.
SuperValu Inc., the nation's largest distributor of groceries, used to go outside for nearly a fifth of its top management talent "because we've always felt we need fresh ideas and experiences," said Ronald C. Tortelli, senior vice president for human resources. "But mergers and acquisitions eliminated a lot of the senior management jobs at the companies that once provided our future leaders, and it became apparent we had to plant more of our own acorns."
SuperValu has stepped up recruiting at colleges and is putting the recruits through training that Mr. Tortelli says will let them move into management quickly. Conversely, it is sending experienced people back to school to broaden their knowledge. And it has backed away from such efficiency moves as centralizing customer service functions. "We stopped when it looked like we might lose people whose responsibilities were lessened," Mr. Tortelli said.
Demographics being immutable, the pressure of the aging baby boom should go on for many more years. But, there are bright spots unrelated to age that may yet ameliorate the talent-gap problems. Ever since the Nasdaq went tumbling in April, the temptation to flee to a dot-com has diminished. And more women and minorities are coming into the management pipeline. "That may not solve the problem, but it will ease the brain drain," Mr. Neff of Spencer Stuart said.
Paradoxically, though, the offsetting trends may cause problems of their own. If high-level people do not leave, how easy will it be to retain newly trained replacements who are champing at the promotional bit?
Mr. Leavey of the Postal Service has asked that question. He has no pat answer. "I don't think you can ever be ahead in this game," he said.

HEADLINE: College Initiates Program to Give Back to Its Neighbors

BYLINE: By ERIC GOLDSCHEIDER 

DATELINE: HARTFORD

 BODY:
Carlos Espinosa remembers when the wrought iron fence that envelops the Trinity College campus was extended across Vernon Street to insulate the liberal arts enclave further from its neighbors. That was in 1994, during a time of drive-by shootings and youth-gang turf wars in a community undergoing a long, steady decline.
Now Mr. Espinosa is a community organizer involved in an effort by the college to reverse course and immerse itself in the neighborhood, in his case by trying to help its neighbors cross the so-called "digital divide." The idea for the experimental program he runs is that the college has much to offer its neighbors in terms of access to and expertise in computing and the Internet. And the community can provide Trinity students with rich experiences, people and viewpoints they might not have encountered before. The question is how far this and similar efforts by Trinity will go in transforming not only the community but the college as well. 
 It is the prospect of mutual growth that has animated not only the project, known as the Smart Neighborhood Initiative, but the entire multimillion-dollar development of the neighborhood set in motion by Trinity's president, Evan Dobelle.
In 1996 Trinity took the unusual step of dipping into its $208 million endowment to invest in the neighborhood in the form of a $5.5 million, no-strings-attached contribution to a large urban renewal project called the Learning Corridor. That contribution bore fruit this year with the opening of four public schools, including a Montessori school and two high school magnets -- one for math and science and the other for the arts -- across from the college's lush athletic fields. The location had been the site of a city bus depot.
If the goal had been to make money, the college would have done better by investing in more traditional enterprises, like shopping malls in Atlanta, said Dr. Dobelle, but doing something to help the neighborhood, he said, would yield more durable dividends.
When Dr. Dobelle assumed the leadership of Trinity College in 1995 he was acutely aware of the symbolism of the barrier that had just been erected across Vernon Street, in effect making it a road open only to the college community rather than the city thoroughfare it had always been. "It was done for all the wrong reasons," he said. It represented "a circling of the wagons."
He frames the college's new, more welcoming attitude toward the neighborhood in terms of enlightened self-interest. The community is definitely hurting, said Dr. Dobelle, citing statistics like the fact that 92 percent of the families are headed by a single parent. But by investing in the neighborhood rather than trying to shut it out, he said, the college is not only living the kinds of "virtues and ethics" it tries to teach its students, but in the long run it makes the campus safer.
Dr. Dobelle also believes that engagement with the community has begun to enrich academic life. Now that word is getting out that Trinity is trying to mesh its liberal arts mission with a new socially conscious attitude toward its surroundings, enrollment applications as well as the quality of the applicants are up, Dr. Dobelle said. "What was supposed to be our greatest liability has turned into our greatest asset," he said.
In 1998 the W. K. Kellogg Foundation made a five-year, $5.1 million grant to further the integration of the campus and the community. About half the money supports the Smart Neighborhood Initiative. Other components of the grant include endowing a professorship of comparative urban studies and creating a center that provides students and faculty with data on the urban experience, particularly in Hartford.
Mr. Espinosa, the son of Cuban immigrants who moved to Hartford from Florida, grew up in the neighborhood and experienced its steady deterioration, starting in the 1980's with the exodus of many property owners who were replaced by lower-income families. By the time the black wrought iron fence went up across Vernon Street, he was a Trinity College student straddling the worlds of privilege and deprivation.
Since April, Mr. Espinosa has been part of a team that is contacting all the nonprofit organizations and small businesses within a one-mile radius of the campus to offer them free or at-cost connections to the World Wide Web. The team also has stationed more than 50 new and refurbished computers in small labs where community residents can gain access to the Internet. Every residence in a 15-square-block area adjacent to the Trinity campus is eligible for a free connection to the Web.
And recently the Trinfo Cafe, the hub of the Smart Neighborhood Initiative, opened its doors to the public. It is housed in a former ice cream shop, which for a while was turned into an evangelical storefront church, just outside the gated perimeter of the Trinity campus. The cafe offers drop-in access to computers and a 17-unit lab where classes in everything from how to point and click a mouse to maintaining a Web site will be taught.
An apprenticeship program to teach teenagers how to salvage components of obsolete computers will be housed in the basement. Donated machines are already piling up there, waiting to be upgraded for a recycling drive aimed at getting hardware into the hands of people who could otherwise not afford it.
Mr. Espinosa, 26, who holds two degrees, including a master's in public policy from Trinity, wears a carving of a clenched fist around his neck signifying, he said, "power to all the people." He refers to the apprentices who will learn basic technical skills as the "farm team." Unless people in small, meagerly financed organizations are eventually able to repair and upgrade their own equipment, the benefits of the Smart Neighborhood Initiative will be short-lived, he said.
Benjamin Todd, also a Trinity alumnus, is the director of the Trinfo Cafe. He remembers as a student getting concerned calls from his mother after a gangland murder near a women's rugby game he himself was attending. The crime affected the college at all levels, said Mr. Todd, 25, not least that students were afraid to venture off the 100-acre campus.
The "smart neighborhood" idea provides ready opportunities for Trinity students to share their knowledge directly with people in the neighborhood.
Mr. Espinosa, who says he feels blessed to have learned how to think at Trinity College, remembers the "social and academic barriers" he was fighting around the same time that the college was physically separating itself from his neighborhood.
He has become a crusader in the drive to distribute computer technology in the areas where he grew up. Skills such as word processing and knowing how to build a computer are of obvious benefit to job seekers. But crossing the digital divide is also about being able to think more expansively, he said. "The folks who don't have access to technology can't even perceive what it can give them," he said.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
According to the Dow, Gore's worries are just about over.

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
THE verdict of the Dow Jones industrial average is in, and it says Al Gore is headed for the White House.
The Dow closed yesterday at 10,971.14, up 4.3 percent since the end of July after a roller coaster period that saw it soar during August and then sink in September and early October, only to put on a strong rally in the final two weeks of the month. 
 The Dow's verdict flies in the face of the conventional wisdom of the polls, which show George W. Bush with a narrow lead. But the Dow's record of presidential election forecasting is such an excellent one that it commands respect. It has correctly forecast 22 of the 25 presidential elections since the Dow industrials made their debut in 1897.
The historical pattern is that when the Dow rises from the end of July through the end of October -- the period when the attention of voters is becoming most fixed on the presidential election, the incumbent party keeps the White House. But when the Dow goes down, the insiders are thrown out.
This year the Dow has seemed to be a leading indicator of the polls, at least of the most widely followed tracking poll, the CNN-USA Today Gallup poll. In early August, just after the stock market began its August rally, Mr. Bush enjoyed a 17-point lead. That soon began shrinking, and by Sept. 6, a few days after the market's summer high was reached, Mr. Gore held a 3-point lead. That widened to a 10-point gap, Mr. Gore's biggest in the poll this year, on Sept. 20. By then, however, the rally had petered out, and the market had come down a bit.
The Dow fell sharply through Oct. 18, and by then Mr. Bush was back to a 10-point lead in the polls. That lead then evaporated by Oct. 23, while the stock market was rallying. But within a few days, even as the Dow continued to move up, Mr. Bush's lead reappeared, peaking at 13 points on Oct. 26. But it has since been shrinking as the Dow rallied again, and the latest result gives Mr. Bush a three-point lead.
The likeliest explanation for the Dow's success as an election indicator in the past is not that voters react to the stock market, but that both the market and the election are measures of how Americans feel about the future. A rising market indicates optimism, and such a good feeling can benefit the incumbent party.
The most recent failure of the Dow as an election indicator came in 1968, a year that in some ways is similar to this one. Then, as now, the Democratic candidate was an incumbent vice president whose Republican opponent's last name had been on the ballot -- and lost -- eight years before. That election pitted Vice President Hubert Humphrey against Richard M. Nixon, who had lost the election in 1960. Now Mr. Gore is opposing the son of President George Bush, who was defeated in 1992.
Perhaps more important, the country was in what was then the longest economic expansion in American history, a period of growth that would not end until late 1969. That expansion now ranks second, having been eclipsed by the current one that began in 1991. If Mr. Bush wins this year, perhaps it will be right to conclude that voters are less focused on the economy after a very long period of prosperity dulls the memory of recession.
The other times that the Dow failed as a forecaster were in 1932 and 1956. In 1932, a recovery in the Dow was tiny compared with the fall from the 1929 peaks and had no chance to restore Herbert Hoover's reputation or popularity. In 1956, Dwight D. Eisenhower cruised to re-election despite a dip in the Dow.
On all those three failures of forecasting, the Dow did reverse itself in the couple of weeks before the end of October, rising in 1956 and falling in 1932 and 1968 -- a move that could be seen as qualifying the otherwise incorrect election forecast.
This year, however, the last couple of weeks in October were strong ones for the Dow, and if Mr. Gore nonetheless loses, it would seem to indicate a clear failure for the Dow as an election indicator. Nor does the weakness of the Nasdaq provide a convincing contrary forecast. Even after yesterday's 5.6 percent rally, the Nasdaq composite is down 10.5 percent since the end of July.
Unfortunately for Republican hopes, the Nasdaq's record as a market forecaster is not very good. In the seven presidential elections since it began in 1971, the Nasdaq has correctly forecast just four of them. It rose in 1980 and 1992, when incumbents were nonetheless defeated, and fell in 1988, when the incumbent party kept the White House.

Bush has done well despite a rising Dow.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Competition Is Too Much For Treasuries

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices fell yesterday as rising stocks and Fannie Mae's sale of $7 billion in new debt overshadowed earlier reports pointing to a slowing economy.
"The stock market is becoming a very tough competitor for bonds again," said Frederick Cavanaugh, who has bought high-yield corporate bonds for the $1.2 billion John Hancock Strategic Income Fund in Boston. The average yield on a subinvestment-grade corporate security is 7.68 percentage points higher than that of a 10-year Treasury note, according to a Merrill Lynch index. 
 The 10-year Treasury note fell 5/32, to a price of 100. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.75 percent from 5.73 percent on Monday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 13/32, to 106 19/32. The bond's yield rose to 5.78 percent from 5.75 percent on Monday.
Stock gains sapped demand for government debt with the Nasdaq composite index surging 5.6 percent, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rising more than 2 percent, and the Dow Jones industrial average gaining 1.3 percent.
The 10-year note and 30-year bond led the market lower as Fannie Mae, the No. 1 buyer of mortgages in the United States, began selling $5 billion in 10-year notes and $2 billion in 30-year bonds, according to people close to the transaction.

HEADLINE: Consumer Confidence Drops, but New-Home Sales Surge

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Consumer confidence dropped sharply in October, to its lowest level in a year, but sales of new homes in September surged past Wall Street expectations, two reports showed yesterday.
The Conference Board, a private research group in New York, said that its consumer confidence index fell sharply, to 135.2 in October from 142.5 in September, well below the record of 144.7 registered in May and January. 
 The Conference Board index, based on a monthly survey of 5,000 households, is closely watched because consumer spending accounts for about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity.
The report offers concern for retailers, said Sung Won Sohn, executive vice president and chief economist with Wells Fargo in Minneapolis.
"I'm sure some of the retailers are sweating a bit, too, if consumers will come back shopping," Mr. Sohn said. "This could mean that we could see more discounts and promotions to move the merchandise early."
The October drop in the consumer confidence index was set off "by a cooling economy and apprehension regarding soaring oil prices and volatility in the financial markets," said Lynn Franco, director of the Conference Board's consumer research center. The last time it was this low was in October 1999, when it stood at 130.5.
Recent developments, including stock market jitters, a rise in jobless claims and interest rates, and the uncertainty of next week's elections made the slump in confidence almost inevitable, economists said.
Even so, a separate report from the Commerce Department showed that sales of new homes soared in September by a surprising 9.2 percent to the highest level in six months as cheaper mortgage rates encouraged buyers to lock in deals.
Mr. Sohn said there were still signs consumers remained in a buying mood, albeit a more cautious one.
"If consumers are willing to buy more homes and cars, they must have fairly strong confidence, otherwise they would not be making commitments for these big-ticket items," he said.
The economy remains strong, with growth slowing to a more sustainable pace and consumers still relatively confident, said Gary R. Thayer, chief economist for A. G. Edwards & Sons Inc. in St. Louis.
"People may not be saying things are quite as rosy as they were, but I think they still feel pretty good about the overall economic picture," he said.
The 9.2 percent increase in new- home sales, the largest since an 11 percent rise in July, was not expected. Many analysts were predicting new-home sales would fall 0.7 percent.
Americans bought new single-family homes at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 946,000 in September, the highest level since a rate of 947,000 in March, the Commerce Department said.
New-home sales fell 5.8 percent in August, according to revised figures, a weaker performance than the 3 percent drop the government reported one month ago.
Declining mortgage rates contributed to the rise in new-home sales, economists said.
In September, mortgage rates continued to creep down as the moderating economy reduced pressure on long-term interest rates. The average interest rate on a fixed-rate 30-year mortgage was 7.91 percent last month, down from 8.03 percent in August, but higher than the 7.82 percent rate in September 1999.
Even so, consumer optimism about the economy has begun to wane somewhat, with more expressing doubts about business conditions and their ability to find new jobs, the Conference Board said.
Just 16.5 percent of people polled in the newest survey expected an improvement in business conditions over the next six months, down from 19 percent in September. The percentage anticipating conditions to worsen rose from 5.6 percent to 7.2 percent.
In addition, 13.1 percent of consumers surveyed said they expected fewer job openings, up from 10.9 percent last month. In another sign of dimming expectations, just 24.2 percent expected their incomes to rise, a steep drop from the 28.1 percent who shared that viewpoint in September.

HEADLINE: Mexico's Border Industries Facing Some Import Taxes

BYLINE: By GRAHAM GORI 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 31

 BODY:
Mexico's maquiladoras, the thriving assembly-plant industries, have received the news they have been dreading for years -- they will now have to pay taxes on some of the imports used to assemble finished goods for export.
The Mexican government has given the maquiladoras two months to learn and apply a labyrinthine tax system, the structure of which has yet to be announced by the treasury department. 
 The news has led some industry leaders to wonder aloud if they should move elsewhere -- to a country that can guarantee them long-term legal and fiscal certainty, something Mexico is not famous for.
The new tax regulations, announced by the commerce secretary on Monday, say that maquiladoras, barring certain exemptions, will have to pay tariffs ranging from 2 percent to 25 percent on imported components from countries other than the United States and Canada -- Mexico's North American Free Trade Agreement partners. This radically changes the landscape in which maquiladoras have operated in Mexico for decades.
Most of the maquiladoras are situated in the north of Mexico, close to the United States border and have helped drive the growth of the Mexican economy in the six years since Nafta was approved.
The incentive for multinationals to base their operations in Mexico had stemmed from a lack of import duties. But now confusion abounds over what kind of tax system will be imposed when the changes go into effect on Jan. 1.
Rocio Ruiz, the director of export services for the commerce ministry, defended the new taxes at a news conference on Tuesday.
"The bad news is that maquiladoras are going to have to start paying tariffs," she said. "The good news is that the tariff will be zero in most cases," adding that only 20 percent of the maquiladoras would have to pay the new tax.
But the chief complaint from the industry is not that it will have to pay taxes on imports. The companies have known that since 1994, when the trade accord took effect. But they maintain that they needed more notice of what the new regulations would entail -- a longer period, presumably, than the two months they have been given.
Representatives of the maquiladoras say the greatest fear is in having to deal with the treasury department bureaucracy, which has also not announced what kind of system it will use to collect the taxes.
"We don't think we have to be subject to controls that incur added costs to operations," said Humberto Inzunza, president of the National Maquiladora Industry in Mexico. "The maquiladora industry has to have legal certainty to be able to plan ahead and forecast operations in 5, 10, 15 years from now. If we don't have this, it's going to be hard to compete in Mexico."
The timing could not be much worse for President-elect Vicente Fox Quesada, who takes office on Dec. 1, and does not want to jeopardize the industry, which generates more than $10 billion in foreign income. It represents 46 percent of the country's exports -- billions of dollars in sales -- and employs 1.3 million people in 4,000 plants. The maquiladora industry has been credited with creating 3 of every 10 new jobs in the last six years.
Members of Mr. Fox's transition team say they are working closely with industry leaders. "Our overall policy is that Mexico's industry should be competitive," said Carlos Angulo Parra, a member of Mr. Fox's international economic affairs team. "If taxes prevent the maquiladoras from being competitive, the tax system should be fixed." Mr. Angulo said Mr. Fox might undo changes made by the current administration if he thinks they will inhibit these exporters' competitiveness.
Mr. Inzunza said Mr. Fox's advisers "guarantee they will change the rulings if they are wrong." He added, "We have an open door with these guys to continue operating with competitiveness."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Technology Breeds Volatility and All Major Gauges Advance

BYLINE: By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
Stocks moved sharply higher yesterday, continuing the turbulence of recent weeks, as investors bid up many of the same technology shares that they sold heavily last week.
For at least one day, investors put aside worries that the economy is slowing and rediscovered the allure of technology stocks, especially high-growth networking equipment companies like Cisco Systems and JDS Uniphase. Led by Cisco, which rose 12 percent yesterday, the Nasdaq composite index soared 178.23 points, or 5.6 percent, to 3,369.63. 
 The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 30.74 points, or 2.2 percent, to 1,429.40, while the Dow Jones industrial average rose 135.37 points, or 1.3 percent, to 10,971.14. In the Dow, Procter & Gamble fell $5.06, to $71.44, but other blue chips more than made up for it. J. P. Morgan rose $6.13, to $165.50; General Motors gained $2.31, to $61.19; and I.B.M. climbed $5.06, to $98.38.
The Nasdaq's gain was the 10th-largest rise in the index's three decades. But analysts were reluctant to call the move the beginning of a long-term rally because wide swings in the Nasdaq have become commonplace. On Oct. 9, the Nasdaq ended at 3,355.56, almost exactly the level at which it ended trading yesterday. In the three weeks since then, the index has had three of its biggest one-day gains and lost 2 percent or more of its value seven times.
Many technology issues have faced even greater volatility. Yesterday, for example, JDS Uniphase, the leading manufacturer of fiber optic components used in high-speed telecommunications equipment, rose $10.13, or more than 14 percent, to $81.44, after falling 25.3 percent last Wednesday and rising 13.8 percent on Oct. 20.
Uncertainty and volatility are likely to continue for some time, money managers said yesterday, because investors are uncertain how quickly the economy and corporate profit growth are slowing.
"We're closer to clueless than another spot in the knowledge spectrum," said Jim Weiss, chief investment officer of State Street Research in Boston, which manages $56 billion. "There's a high degree of confusion as to what's going on with the economy and what's going on with corporate profits." Yesterday's rally in technology was unrelated to any fundamental change in the outlook for the economy, Mr. Weiss said. He noted that Oct. 31 is the end of the fiscal year for many mutual funds.
As a result, mutual fund managers had sold shares of beaten-down technology stocks throughout October to realize capital losses they could use to balance capital gains that their funds posted earlier this year. That tax-loss selling pressure had artificially depressed the shares of many technology companies, and when it ended yesterday morning, the stocks rallied, Mr. Weiss said.
Because the rally was technical rather than fundamental, "it's going to be very difficult to have strong follow-through tomorrow," he said.
Still, Mr. Weiss said he was cautiously optimistic for 2001, saying he thought corporate profits would rise 7 to 10 percent for the year. "I believe that productivity is going to continue to surprise people with its strength and be a help of corporate profit growth," he said.
Charles L. Hill, research director of First Call/Thomson Financial, which tracks analysts' profit forecasts, said he was worried that money managers like Mr. Weiss might be overly optimistic about next year's earnings.
Analysts are still predicting profit growth of 13.3 percent for the S.& P. 500 in 2001, Mr. Hill said. But they have recently been slashing earnings predictions for the fourth quarter of 2000 and the first quarter of 2001, and those cuts are likely to continue as economic growth slows, he said.
For all of next year, earnings growth for the S.& P. 500 "could be 2 or 3 percent," Mr. Hill added.
Hank Herrmann, chief investment officer at Waddell & Reed Financial in Overland Park, Kan., which manages $40 billion, said he was also pessimistic. Yesterday's rally "is going to prove to be a head fake," Mr. Herrmann said. "I think in the end you're going to have to deal with the reality of pressure on profits."
Byron Wien, chief United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, said investors had been unable to find a market sector that seemed worth buying. High-growth technology stocks have fallen sharply but are not cheap by historical measures, especially because their profit growth appears to have peaked.
Cyclical stocks, whose profits are especially sensitive to economic growth, are cheap on a price-earnings basis, Mr. Wien said, but few investors want to own them with the economy apparently slowing. Financial stocks, which are a natural choice if the Federal Reserve plans to lower interest rates, have risen this year and are also no bargain, he said.
"The market is not predicting anything in particular," Mr. Wien said, "the market is fully priced."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: MICHIGAN;
In a Tossup State, This Town Turns Inside Out

BYLINE: By JODI WILGOREN 

DATELINE: LANSING, Mich., Oct. 31

 BODY:
Never has this place meant so much to so many.
"This state has the ability to decide this close election," Vice President Al Gore told a throng of 5,000 here on Sunday. "You have the ability to decide what this state decides." 
 Lynne Cheney, the wife of the Republican who wants Mr. Gore's job, seconded the motion this afternoon, telling volunteers stuffing envelopes that "every stamp you're putting on there could make the difference."
Bob Dole is coming to rally the troops at V.F.W. headquarters on Wednesday. John McCain is scheduled for Saturday. Tipper Gore may show up on Thursday. Laura and Barbara Bush were here last week, Ralph Nader last month and George W. Bush back in primary season (don't cross him off the guest list for this weekend).
Such is life in a tossup city in a swing district in a battleground state. Not only is the presidential race neck and neck here, but Lansing is the home of the Democratic challenger in one of the nation's tightest races for the United States Senate, and the center of one of the country's most fiercely contested open House seats. There are also two knock-down fights for open seats in the Michigan House, a bunch of judgeships on the ballot and a county commissioner or two running for re-election. Plus a statewide initiative on school vouchers.
All of which means, in the words of Rusty Hills, the Republican state chairman, "more pizza, less sleep."
Or, from the vantage point of Dimitri's, a diner downtown: "We don't get anything except bored," said Mark Anderson, a breakfast regular.
Lansing, a town of 125,000 normally swathed in the green and white of the Michigan State University Spartans, is pocked with red, white and blue yard signs, its airwaves packed with political advertisements that residents can recite by heart. It is hard to find people who have not been polled -- twice. You wouldn't be the first to call it ground zero.
"The amount of activity and the amount of money being spent is a couple of orders of magnitude beyond what we've ever seen," said the Democratic state chairman, Mark Brewer, a 25-year veteran of Michigan politics. "Number of volunteers, paid staffers, phone calls -- everything is just up, significantly."
Smack in the middle of the palm of the hand that is Michigan's map, Lansing is normally a somewhat sleepy state capital that has confounded generations of schoolchildren. (No, the capital is not Detroit. Or Ann Arbor.) About 20,000 local people work for the state government, 16,000 for three G.M. plants in town and 12,000 for the university, in neighboring East Lansing.
The area's unemployment rate registers barely 2 percent, and median income is $32,000, solidly in that middle class every candidate loves to talk about. The city itself is heavily Democratic, and about 19 percent black, but the surrounding suburbs and farms are white and Republican; hence the tossup politics. A recent survey suggested that as many as 1 in 4 people remained undecided about the presidential race.
"I don't really like what Bush stands for, but I like what Gore stands for even less," said George Campbell, 62, a lawyer nursing a coffee at Dimitri's, home of the governor's favorite rice pudding.
"I don't trust any of them," added Mr. Campbell's table mate, George Tesseris, 69 and retired. "Don't let anybody stay in office too long: they learn how to steal better that way. Stir the pot, stir the pot."
And so Mr. Tesseris and Mr. Campbell plan to vote for Mr. Bush, perhaps part of the trend that has the Republicans inching up in the polls in this swing state recently.
Indeed, interviews with about two dozen voters here over the last two days -- at Dimitri's and at Kelly's, a Capitol watering hole, as well as at the Flap Jack Shack in a shopping center nearby -- suggested a slight advantage for Mr. Bush.
There are lots of Roman Catholics here, many of them Reagan Democrats who prefer Mr. Bush's anti-abortion stance, and plenty of hunters afraid of Mr. Gore's advocacy of gun control. People are talking about the marriage tax and the estate tax, and wanting to choose how their Social Security is invested. But this is also state headquarters for the A.F.L.-C.I.O., and local unions plan a huge blitz to get out the vote.
With so many hot races, there is something for everyone.
Lenny Burns, the owner of Kelly's, can't wait to pull the lever for Dianne Byrum, a Democrat, for the Congressional seat; she's a regular, and, as a hardware store owner, "she knows business," he said.
The guys at Dimitri's have eaten frequently with Spencer Abraham, the Senate incumbent, and besides, they think the challenger, Debbie Stabenow, "will say anything to get the vote," as Mr. Tesseris put it.
Bea Payne, a 60-year resident of Lansing who was having a coffee at the Flap Jack on Monday, is focused on the voucher initiative, which looks as if it is headed for defeat.
Meanwhile, David Rohde, a political scientist at Michigan State, gave his 287th interview of the year this morning.
In a word, it's intense.
As the campaigns enter their final week, Lansing is aching from all the attention, residents' groaning about airwaves overloaded with lies, motorcade-induced gridlock, mailboxes packed with mudslinging. But for every person who just wishes it would end, there is someone like Mike Kossey or Linda Henderson, both of whom are turning their schedules over to the season.
Ms. Henderson, 46, has a a family-law practice but cannot afford health insurance. Her knees are too weak for door-to-door canvassing, so on Monday night -- and most nights last week -- she spent four hours in the trailer of an 18-wheeler, wearing a headset, one of a dozen volunteers in a high-tech operation that dialed 5,982 numbers of Democrats and independent voters.
"Helen?" Ms. Henderson said, sounding as if she were calling an old friend. "I'm a resident of Lansing, Mich., down the road from you. This election is so close, I decided to put some personal time in."
There was a script, but Ms. Henderson ignored it, gesticulating wildly at the wall as she tried to persuade a man to trust Mr. Gore to keep the economy going, convince a woman that the vice president would protect her Social Security check and get an undecided voter to commit, or an apathetic one to turn out.
"There is something very enriching about communicating with people who you don't know but who are your neighbors," she said. "The whole point is not just to get the message out, but to get them to think about it. The way to get them to think about it is to show somebody who cares."
Mr. Kossey has no script at all.
For about two months now, Mr. Kossey, 51, who retired from the Marine Corps Reserve as a lieutenant colonel in 1993, has spent some 13 hours a day answering phones at Bush statewide headquarters in the basement of a shopping mall here. "Whenever the phone rings, it's an adventure," he said, then interrupted himself to answer the phone.
"Everybody out there in the political process thinks they're a political consultant: why doesn't Bush do this or say that?" Mr. Kossey said. "It's like being an armchair quarterback in a Monday night football game. Except this lasts much longer than a football game."

HEADLINE: Trade Dispute More Likely as Telmex Sues on Connection Fees

BYLINE: By GRAHAM GORI 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 31

 BODY:
A long-simmering telecommunications dispute between the United States and Mexico appeared to be heading more rapidly toward a World Trade Organization arbitration panel today.
The dominant Mexican phone company, Telefonos de Mexico, announced late Monday that it would ask a court to overturn a recent ruling by Mexican federal regulators to reduce by nearly two-thirds interconnection fees, which the company charges competitors to begin and end international calls in Mexico. The ruling would allow foreign rivals of the big carrier, known as Telmex, greater access to Mexico's telecommunications market. 
 Earlier this month, Mexico's telecommunications regulatory panel, Cofetel, ordered a 63 percent reduction in interconnection fees, to 1.25 cents a minute from 3.36 cents. The new regulations are scheduled to go into effect on Jan. 1.
Rivals like AT&T and WorldCom have repeatedly complained that the interconnection fees make competing for a slice of Mexico's $12 billion telecommunications market a losing battle. They also argue that these practices violate trade agreements.
In July, United States trade officials threatened to take Mexico before a W.T.O. arbitration panel unless regulators ordered Telmex to abide by agreements signed by both countries. Earlier this month, a deputy United States trade representative, Richard Fisher, traveled to Mexico and said he left hoping that Mexican officials would force Telmex to reduce its interconnection fees. At the time, Washington had relaxed its public stance, saying it would resort to a W.T.O. trade panel ruling only if needed.
"This is a giant step backward in the process," Mr. Fisher said today, after learning of Telmex's decision to try to overturn the fee reductions. "This is what we were worried about -- that Telmex would use the judicial system to thwart the independence of the regulatory agencies."
Now, he said, Washington must wait to see how the courts would deal with Telmex's request. But "this does not relieve Mexico from living up to its commitments under W.T.O. telecommunications agreements," Mr. Fisher said. "Let's see what the Mexican government does."
Telmex, a former state enterprise, has sometimes been accused of operating above the law -- repeatedly tying up regulatory decisions by filing court appeals and exploiting the Mexican government's weakness in enforcing antitrust regulations.
The company, controlled by one of Latin America's richest men, Carlos Slim Helu, was deemed a private monopoly two years ago by federal regulators. The decision, if enforced, would have resulted in a significant easing of the company's grip on the telecommunications market. Its share of long-distance traffic in Mexico has rebounded to 81 percent after falling to about 70 percent. It still has more than 95 percent of local service.
President-elect Vicente Fox Quesada, who takes office on Dec. 1, has said that regulatory agencies will have to be strengthened to allow more competition across the board.
A legislator from Mr. Fox's National Action Party, Emilio Goicoechea Luna, said he was working with the transition team to prepare legislation that would increase regulatory agencies' power, notably in enforcement. The proposed law would limit the appeals process and prevent companies from skirting regulatory decisions with endless judicial appeals. "We need in this country better laws for competition and for telecommunications," he said.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: CAMPAIGN COSTS;
Air Time Is at Premium As Election Draws Near

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
Thomas R. Carper, the Delaware governor who is running for the United States Senate, is finding what many other politicians across the country already know: that the closer it gets to Election Day, the more expensive it is to get campaign commercials on the air.
Two months ago, the Carper campaign paid $1,250 for a 30-second spot on a nearby Philadelphia station. Now, the same spot costs $1,650. And when the Democratic Party wants to advertise on Mr. Carper's behalf, the price is an even stiffer $3,250 per spot because of federal regulations allowing broadcasters to charge political parties more than candidates. 
 With time running out before Election Day, candidates and interest groups across the country are waging bidding wars over the dwindling supply of television air time. As a result, rates for campaign commercials -- and broadcasters' revenues -- are reaching eye-popping levels.
In addition, federal rules designed to provide discounted television time for candidates are proving to be of little help as anxious candidates are willing to pay top dollar for prime television spots and have driven up prices for everyone.
Television stations are estimated to gain $600 million to $1 billion from the bumper crop of political advertisements this year, according to industry and Wall Street estimates. The money is coming directly from candidates and issue groups, desperate to win and flush with cash. Moreover, with campaign media buyers earning 5 percent to 10 percent of every commercial placed, the more they air, the more money they make.
"The political system is flush with money and there is a win-at-any-cost mentality that finds its way into political races," said Paul Taylor, executive director of the Alliance for Better Campaigns, a Washington group seeking free air time for candidates. "But also, you have a broadcast industry that is putting a price on democracy and gouging, and no one has called them on it. These are folks who know how to turn a buck."
In Seattle, one Republican media buyer said that at the end of August, he could buy 30 seconds of air time at $400 per ratings point. A ratings point is the percentage of television-owning homes tuning in to a given program. The price rose to $530 a ratings point three weeks ago. Now it is $800 per ratings point and, according to the buyer, "going up."
And Kyle Osterhaut, who places advertisements for Democrats, said rates have tripled since August, especially in battleground states. "It's getting extremely tight and extremely expensive," said Mr. Osterhaut, vice president at Media Strategies and Research in Lakewood, Colo. "And, it's also radio. Campaign money is creating a bidding war and television stations are benefiting."
Federal regulations require television stations to provide political candidates with special low rates. In the 60 days before an election, candidates are able to receive air time at the "lowest-unit rate," which is equal to the lowest price of any commercial in that same time slot that week.
But there is only so much air time available before Election Day, Nov. 7, and the demand for it is intense. So like the price of seats on a crowded airplane, the lowest-unit rate for commercial time slots has been rising steadily. "It's the lowest-unit rate based on what is available today," said Louis Schultz, chief executive of Initiative Media, a media buying company in Los Angeles.
In addition, many stations say politicians are forgoing the lowest-unit rate and instead are paying premium prices to ensure that their commercials are not pre-empted by higher-paying advertisers.
"Lots of candidates could care less about lowest-unit charge," said one Federal Communications Commission regulator.
Moreover, government regulations providing candidates with discounted air time does not apply to political parties or to the hundreds of other interest groups airing commercials. These groups pay the same as any other broadcast advertiser -- and sometimes more -- because political organizations cannot negotiate the same volume discounts as commercial advertisers.
These interest groups, too, are relatively undeterred by rising prices. Jonathan Lichter, a media buyer in Chicago for several conservative groups supporting Gov. George W. Bush, said that television stations were charging three times the normal rate for air time -- and that his clients are not objecting.
"I'd tell some of these clients that we could get air time, but we'd have to pay three times the normal rate," Mr. Lichter said, "and they'd say, 'We understand, no problem. We want our message out.' "
The bulk of this money is falling to local broadcasters in battleground states and is seen as helping to buoy a broadcast industry whose revenues have been stagnant in the last few years. Political advertisements in the current campaign represent 10 percent of all commercials, putting them behind those for auto and retail, but ahead of those for fast food, consumer products, telephone and beer, according to the Wall Street firm Bear Stearns.
"We're seeing monstrous growth," said Victor Miller, a broadcast industry analyst at Bear Stearns. "The bottom line is that political advertising is becoming a higher and higher category of ads -- and a lot of the money coming in, obviously, is not being sold at the lowest-unit rate."
Leland Westfield, a broadcast analyst with PaineWebber Inc., estimated that television stations will get $1 billion in revenues from political advertisements this year, while the Television Bureau of Advertisers, a trade group, puts the number closer to $600 million. During the 1992 presidential election year, $300 million was spent on broadcasting, and $400 million was spent in 1996, according to Bear Stearns.
This fast growth rate has left some campaigns fuming.
"Television stations are gouging political campaigns," said Neil Oxman, the media buyer for the Carper campaign. "They are really, really gouging. We have this huge, wonderful economy, so the costs of television ads are at an all-time high."
Television stations point to politicians, who they say have so much cash and are so desperate for air time that they are pushing up rates for everyone. Moreoever, they say not everyone is getting rich. National broadcasters are being bypassed by candidates looking to buy only in specific states, as are local stations in states where races are not close.
Besides, broadcasters say, this sudden wealth happens only during election years.
"I'm not saying that there is not an incredible and obscene amount of money out there," said Ken Goldstein, a professor of political science at the University of Wisconsin. "It's appalling and that's why rates are rising. It's not something I get worked up about though. That's the marketplace working and if interest groups are stupid enough to spend it -- well, God bless them."
Scott Hayner, sales manager for KOMO-TV in Seattle, said that it is "getting difficult, getting extremely difficult" for some political groups to get the air time they want. Mr. Hayner said that his station is providing whatever it can, but that to some groups "we have to say what they want is not available."
Mr. Hayner noted that "had it not been for political ads, our September would have been disastrous" because many regular advertisers stayed away during the Olympics.
In Detroit, where the presidential race is tight and there are many hot local races, the demand for air time is "horrific," said Grace Gilchrist, station manager at WXYZ-TV. Ms. Gilchrist said that both presidential candidates are buying last-minute air time, which is the most expensive form of advertising.
