HEADLINE: Comments on AIDS Weaken Mbeki

BYLINE: By RACHEL L. SWARNS 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 31

 BODY:
For months, President Thabo Mbeki doggedly endured a relentless shower of censure, refusing to agree that H.I.V. causes AIDS and dismissing his critics as "blind defenders of the faith." The government's announcement two weeks ago that Mr. Mbeki was reducing his role in the debate came too late to lift many South Africans' deepened confusion about AIDS and its origins.
The real question now may be how seriously he has damaged himself. 
 In the past year, Mr. Mbeki's approval ratings have dropped to 50 percent from 70 percent. While that may be due as much to the faltering economy as to his views, it is his stance on AIDS that has garnered major attention, at home and abroad.
His public musings on AIDS have led senior American officials and legislators, privately, to question his judgment. South African trade and banking officials fear his stance may be troubling skittish investors. The press has become increasingly critical, with one commentator asking in The Sowetan, "Is Mbeki Fit to Govern?" Government officials are finding it hard to hide their dismay at the shadow that the H.I.V. controversy has cast on the Mbeki presidency.
The presidential minister, Essop Pahad, flew to London recently to meet with newspaper editors to try to stem the stream of negative stories about Mr. Mbeki. And Tito Mboweni, chairman of the Reserve Bank, has urged government officials to watch their words because they might deter potential investors.
On Monday, the government announced the creation of an international marketing council, made up of government officials and business people, to counter a host of negative perceptions about crime, AIDS and Mr. Mbeki's response to the troubles in neighboring Zimbabwe. "It is worrying," Mr. Pahad said. "For us it is important that we should attract quality investment to South Africa. If there is a negative message that is going out, if it is the reason why we're not getting as much quality investment as we should, obviously that would be worrying."
Mr. Mbeki has also, increasingly, reached out to the public, acknowledging that the government must improve South Africa's image. But last week, in a wide-ranging interview with foreign reporters, he repeatedly declined to say whether he believed that H.I.V. causes the disease that is ravaging this country. And while he emphasized his passion for fighting AIDS, he made it clear that despite the negative reaction, he did not regret entering into the debate on AIDS's causes.
"Whatever the controversy, people are dying from AIDS," Mr. Mbeki said at the Sheraton Hotel in Pretoria on Wednesday. "People are dying from AIDS and there is no vaccine. This is a very serious problem. And if the attention by the president to a matter of that kind is being described as unhinged, I'm afraid I can't help you. But I certainly am not going to be discouraged from helping to confront this catastrophe as best as I can."
Taking steps to rebuild credibility this month, the government finally began an anti-AIDS advertising campaign, which stressed the importance of condoms, fidelity and abstinence. Officials have also decided to expand research into the effectiveness of the anti-AIDS drug Nevirapine in combating mother-to-child transmission of the virus.
Last week, Mr. Mbeki issued his sharpest condemnation yet of the continuing occupations of white-owned farms by black squatters in Zimbabwe and the political violence condoned by its president, Robert Mugabe. "These things are wrong," Mr. Mbeki said. "These things must stop. They must be addressed. And we'll continue to say those things."
The Sunday Times of Johannesburg praised those moves, taking particular note of Mr. Mbeki's decision to scale back his role in the AIDS debate and his tougher talk on Zimbabwe. "In the past few weeks," the paper said in an editorial this weekend, "President Thabo Mbeki has done what South Africans have been pleading with him to do for months."
Political analysts say he had no choice. "The AIDS policy and the communication of that policy was simply an unmitigated public relations disaster," said Chris Landsberg, a political analyst and lecturer in international relations at the University of the Witwatersrand here. "I really think he is coming to the belief, and rightly so, that whether he's right on his AIDS view or not, it has caused such a stir now that his mind, his integrity, his very presidency has been called into question," Mr. Landsberg said.
Mr. Pahad -- though he blames the media for distorting Mr. Mbeki's message -- acknowledges that the government has not handled the AIDS furor very well. But officials say they believe the drop in Mr. Mbeki's popularity may have more to do with the struggling economy than with the AIDS debate.
On Monday, Finance Minister Trevor Manuel reduced his growth forecast for the year to 2.6 percent from 3.6 percent, citing the troubles in Zimbabwe, depressed gold prices and soaring oil prices.
Still, Mr. Mbeki has often been his own worst enemy, repeatedly disregarding the advice of his government's doctors and seemingly oblivious to the impact his statements were having on efforts to prevent the spread of the virus. AIDS counselors say they now encounter people who assume they can engage in risky sexual behavior, because the president and scientists he supports have minimized the role of H.I.V. and suggested that poverty, more than a factor contributing to AIDS in Africa, is its direct cause.
Last month even Mr. Mbeki's partners in government, the Congress of South African Trade Unions and the South African Communist Party, stated publicly that H.I.V. causes AIDS and called on the president to make the same statement.
So far Mr. Mbeki has not done so, going only so far as to tell Parliament last month that the government's AIDS policies are based on the "thesis" that H.I.V. causes AIDS. The distinction has only compounded the frustration of some critics.
At the Wednesday news conference, the president emphasized his desire to grapple with the virus, which infects an estimated 4.2 million people here, or about 20 percent of the population -- more than anywhere else in the world. But he showed no signs of backing away from the issue that stirred the furor in the first place.
"I'm not quite sure what use it serves, the question," he said, when a reporter asked whether he had said that H.I.V. does not cause AIDS. "If you are looking for pop answers, you are not going to get them from me. Because the science is not reducible to campaign slogans in the street.
"What you and I read is that the greatest possible threat to the future of this continent is H.I.V./AIDS. This is the one thing that is really going to destroy this continent. We had to respond to this thing. How does the president of South Africa say, 'I stay away from this great catastrophe?' "

HEADLINE: Angry at U.S., Arabs Widen Contacts With Iraq

BYLINE: By SUSAN SACHS 

DATELINE: CAIRO, Oct. 31

 BODY:
A growing number of Arab entertainers, intellectuals, politicians and business people have been flying off to Baghdad over the last two weeks, thumbing their noses at international sanctions and giving the Iraqi government a shower of publicity after its 10 years of near isolation.
The support for Iraq is a spillover from the recent outbreak of Palestinian-Israeli violence, which has prompted a resurgence of public support for the idea that the West, led by the United States, behaves badly toward the Arab world. 
 That has never been far from the oratorical surface. But once again, in a way that must please the Iraqi president, Saddam Hussein, the rallying cry for people from across the Arab political spectrum is "double standard," a shorthand reference to what is seen as American reluctance to hold Israel to account for its treatment of Palestinians.
To express their disaffection, in a dozen instances people in Lebanon, Egypt, Syria, Libya, Yemen and Jordan have not only embraced the Palestinian cause but have also chartered airplanes to fly to a hero's welcome at Saddam International Airport. Iraq reopened the airport in August as a challenge to the United Nations sanctions imposed after its invasion of Kuwait in 1990.
The latest to bow to the public mood and sign up for a flight was the Jordanian prime minister, Ali Abu al-Ragheb. He said he would fly to Baghdad on Wednesday to attend a trade fair aimed at "promoting the good relations between the two countries." Mr. Abu al-Ragheb, who will take 100 Jordanian journalists and politicians with him, would be the highest-ranking Arab official to arrive by air since the embargo went into effect.
In the view of the Clinton administration, some of the flights have violated the sanctions because they did not deliver aid for civilians or did not receive advance United Nations clearance.
Other countries, notably France and Russia, have argued that civilian flights were never specifically banned, although no one tested the point until recently.
Some who have recently made the journey say the point now is to contrast American support for the Israeli government of Prime Minister Ehud Barak with American opposition to lifting the embargo on Iraq and to make a point to Ariel Sharon, the leader of the right-wing opposition Likud Party in Israel.
"We are sending a message to Barak and Sharon that we shall not stand with our arms tied while you are killing Palestinians," said Muhammad Monieb, a Cairo lawyer who organized a flight to Baghdad last weekend for about 150 Egyptian celebrities.
Flying to Iraq is not meant to show personal support for the Iraqi president, added Mr. Monieb, a former chairman of the Egyptian Organization for Human Rights.
"We fully support the return of Iraq to the Arab family," he said. "All Arab regimes are dictatorships. All Arab leaders commit mistakes against their own people. If the Americans consider Saddam a dictator, then let them tell us who is not a dictator in the region."
Iraq has responded to the recent political support from Arab countries by stepping up its campaign to have the sanctions lifted or to undermine them. It announced Monday that the state-owned airline, Iraqi Airways, would resume some domestic service on Nov. 5.
The airline canceled all internal flights in 1992 when the United States and Britain instituted no-flight zones aimed at protecting rebellious Kurds in the northern part of Iraq and Shiite Muslims in the south from attacks by Iraqi military planes and helicopters. American and British aircraft still patrol the zones and Iraq says their attacks on antiaircraft installations since the end of the gulf war have killed more than 300 people.
With stronger Arab public support, Iraq has also found a newly receptive audience for its assertion that it is the only true defender of Arab and Palestinian interests.
During the last week, as Arabs from other countries have been flying into Baghdad with food and support for Iraqis, Iraq has been sending food and supplies for the Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. As Arab doctors have flown in with medicines for Iraqis, the Iraqis welcomed a Palestinian plane that brought several people wounded in clashes with Israelis to Baghdad for medical treatment.
Still, the public support is unlikely to translate into open sanctions-busting by Arab governments, most of which have urged the United Nations to lift sanctions but have pledged to follow the international rules.
Arab governments also have decidedly mixed views on Saddam Hussein. While several of the smaller Arab states have quietly re-established diplomatic relations with Iraq over the past few years, the West's main allies, like Egypt, have not reopened their embassies.
The Iraqi president's constant badgering of his fellow Arab leaders has not helped relations. After the emergency Arab summit meeting this month to respond to the Palestinian-Israeli violence, Iraq urged the overthrow of Arab governments. The bellicose demand was particularly stinging because the Arab League's invitation to Iraq to attend a summit meeting was the first in nearly 10 years.
Arab governments will nevertheless be obliged to take account of the public mood and to offer support for the Iraqi people, said Soliman Awaad, director of multinational relations in the Egyptian foreign ministry, adding, "We are under tremendous pressure from public opinion -- and I'm not confining this to Egypt only, but all through the region as well as from our civil society -- which is being promoted by the West and the U.N."
Mr. Awaad, who advocates lifting the sanctions, said his office had been inundated with requests from private groups to fly to Baghdad to show support for Iraq, while normally apolitical taxi drivers and shopkeepers have been badgering him about the sanctions.
"They are wondering about the silk glove used by the U.N. and its organizations in dealing with Israel, and comparing it to the clumsy rough hand with regards to Iraq," he said.
The sanctions on Iraq have become a constant irritant at the United Nations, particularly between Security Council members with different views on how to measure Iraqi compliance with the requirement that it no longer produce or store any weapons of mass destruction. Iraq has refused entry to inspectors.
Various United Nations bodies now have a number of sanctions-related issues before them.
Iraq recently announced, for example, that it would accept only euros in payment for the oil that the United Nations allows it to sell, instead of dollars, which it described as the currency of its enemy. The United Nations officials who oversee oil sales as part of the embargo rules said Monday that they have asked Iraq to delay carrying that out so they can study the idea.
For months, Iraq has also refused to accept an independent monitoring team proposed by the United Nations to survey civilian living conditions. To try to overcome its objections, Secretary General Kofi Annan proposed Monday that Thorvald Stoltenberg, a former Norwegian foreign minister and United Nations high commissioner for refugees, lead the survey committee.

HEADLINE: A Bitter Race in Connecticut Reflects National Platforms

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

DATELINE: WATERBURY, Conn., Oct. 31

 BODY:
In a subdued debate, the major candidates in the closely fought race for Connecticut's Fifth Congressional District cast their contest today as a microcosm of the presidential campaign. The Democratic incumbent, James H. Maloney, and the Republican challenger, Mark Nielsen, each firmly aligned himself with his party's nominee on the core issues of the economy, taxes, Social Security and education.
"This is a terrific way to get a glimpse on how this race connects up with the national race," Mr. Nielsen said in response to a question about tax policy. 
 "The difference between us on this vital issue is that I would go to Washington and I would vote for President George W. Bush's tax cut. My opponent would not."
Mr. Maloney quickly replied, "You are right; I would not, because it would send us back down a road of red ink and budget deficits."
The debate, at a luncheon sponsored by the Waterbury Chamber of Commerce in the Mattatuck Museum here, was the third meeting of the two candidates, who are locked in a bitter rematch of their contest in 1998.
In that race, Mr. Maloney barely fought off a challenge by Mr. Nielsen and won re-election to a second term by just 2,343 votes. They were joined today by a third candidate, Joseph Zdonczyk, of the Concerned Citizens Party.
The race is being watched closely at the national level by both parties, because it could be a factor in the fight for control of Congress. So far, no independent poll has been conducted in the race, giving the candidates and the public little feel for who may have the edge.
The Fifth District, which stretches from Danbury in the west to Meriden in the center of the state, is nearly evenly divided among registered Democrats and Republicans, with most voters in the district unaffiliated.
So even as they expressed basic party loyalty today, the candidates sought to shed partisan stereotypes, with Mr. Maloney portraying himself as an aggressive tax-cutter who favors some limits on abortion rights and Mr. Nielsen describing himself as an advocate of both abortion rights and gun control.
The campaign has been bitter and angry, with the candidates viciously attacking each other's ethics and broadcasting harsh campaign commercials. And for a brief moment at the start of today's event, it seemed the debate would be similarly ill tempered, as Mr. Nielsen used his opening statement for an attack, criticizing Mr. Maloney's position on taxes and accusing him of being beholden to special interests.
"I believe that our inability to make better progress in a number of important areas -- education, the environment, health care -- is traceable to excessive special interest influence in Washington," Mr. Nielsen said.
Mr. Maloney, however, began by praising the city and boasting of his own efforts in Congress. "It's not a coincidence that I-84 from the New York border to Southington, through Waterbury, is all under expansion and construction," he said, referring to the district's largest highway.
He also fired back: "There are differences between Mr. Nielsen and myself. One is that he starts his presentation to you with the negative and false information that he has permeated his campaign with."
At that, the candidates settled into a relatively sober 75-minute discussion of the issues, responding in turn to 11 questions posed by a panel of local journalists.
Both Mr. Maloney and Mr. Nielsen pointed to education as the most important issue, though they disagreed on how to improve schools. Mr. Nielsen called for an end to teacher tenure. Mr. Maloney urged investing more money to reduce class sizes and repair school buildings.
On the economy, Mr. Maloney accused Mr. Nielsen of catching "the fuzzy math disease," employing the phrase used by Mr. Bush to criticize Vice President Al Gore in the first presidential debate.
Mr. Zdonczyk, who described himself as a "constitutionalist," frequently injected humor into the debate, at one point criticizing his opponents for raising more than $3 million, a state record for a Congressional campaign. "I don't have any money," he said. "I don't have soft money. I don't have hard money. I don't have any money in between."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
Focusing on Gore Hyperbole

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS 

 BODY:

There is an air of mischief in the Bush campaign advertisement that began running on Halloween night in highly contested states in the East, Midwest and Pacific Northwest. The 30-second spot replies to a recent attack advertisement by the Gore campaign by needling Vice President Al Gore on his reputation for exaggeration.
 
PRODUCER -- Maverick Media
 
ON THE SCREEN -- Framed by a television screen within the screen, Mr. Gore is seen in video footage greeting a pharmacist in his store. The scene freezes, and an article from The Washington Times, headlined "Aides Concede Gore Made Up Story" is superimposed. Cut to another shot of the vice president and the word "nonsense." Scene shifts to Gov. George W. Bush of Texas in a hard hat, talking to factory workers, and finally, back to Mr. Gore, in mid-debate with Bill Bradley. 

SCRIPT -- Announcer: "Remember when Al Gore said his mother-in-law's prescription cost more than his dog's? His own aides said the story was made up. Now Al Gore is bending the truth again. The press calls Gore's Social Security attacks 'nonsense.' Governor Bush sets aside $2.4 trillion to strengthen Social Security and pay all benefits."
 
Mr. Gore: "There has never been a time in this campaign when I have said something that I know to be untrue. There has never been a time when I have said something untrue."
 
Announcer: "Really?"
 
ACCURACY -- The commercial is a rebuttal to a pair of spots the Gore campaign broadcast in recent days in which economic experts are said to have found Mr. Bush's proposal to partly privatize Social Security "does not add up." As for the reference to his mother-in-law and the dog, the Gore campaign was indeed forced to acknowledge that the anecdote was not gleaned from the candidate's own experience, but from a Congressional study. (Versions of the "dog" story, in fact, have cropped up in commercials by Congressional candidates who are emphasizing the prescription drug issue.) The "nonsense" citation -- attributed generically by the announcer in the commercial to "the press," is from an editorial on Thursday in The Wall Street Journal, whose editorial page is known for its conservative leanings. Mr. Bush has been promising audiences that he will put aside $2.4 trillion from the budget surplus to protect Social Security in the future. Mr. Gore's sound bite is from one of his debates with Mr. Bradley in the Democratic primaries.
 
SCORECARD -- The spot is funny, devastating -- and clearly intended to zing Mr. Gore more than to defend Mr. Bush. It only indirectly addresses the criticism in the Gore advertisements, one of which cites conclusions drawn by "eight Nobel laureates" that Mr. Bush's plan promises the same $1 trillion to young people and the elderly. But it cleverly changes the subject by suggesting that Mr. Gore's attacks are merely further evidence of a propensity for stretching the truth. The spot's payoff is the mocking clip in which Mr. Gore asserts that "there has never been a time" when he uttered an untruth, and the announcer's cynical comeback. The commercial deftly shifts the focus from whatever doubts voters may have about Mr. Bush's proposal to questions about Mr. Gore's character. PETER MARKS

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: ECONOMIC PROSPERITY;
Few Voters Credit Democrats for Gains

BYLINE: By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

DATELINE: UNIVERSITY CITY, Mo., Oct. 25

 BODY:
Twice as many American families own mutual funds as in 1992, when Al Gore was first elected vice president. That might seem a plus for Mr. Gore in his race against Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, since the stock market has quadrupled during Mr. Gore's time in office.
But interviews with voters in the last week in the suburbs of St. Louis -- the sort of politically mixed region that has become so important in this year's unusually close presidential race -- show that many of these voters, including Gore supporters, credit other factors for the nation's prosperity and market gains. 
 For some of these voters, the increase in stock ownership and the time spent fretting over 401(k) choices and other investments has brought a greater fluency about the market and economics. They repeatedly cited factors such as gains in worker productivity from the technology boom, and the success of Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, in engineering a smooth monetary policy.
And while few gave a lot of credit to the Clinton administration, a number of voters said that having one party capture the White House and the other controlling at least one chamber of Congress could help prevent the government from going overboard on spending or tax cuts.
In University City, an enclave just west of St. Louis, Larry McClendon, a train conductor, said he supported Mr. Gore but gave Democrats only partial credit for the good economy.
"When Clinton came into office is when a lot of e-commerce started to come into effect," Mr. McClendon said.
And Bill Fortenbury, a lawyer in Olivette, another close-in suburb, plans to vote for the vice president because he likes his positions on abortion, the environment and other social issues, not because of the strength of the economy. Whoever is in the White House "makes no difference" to the stock market, he said.
The failure of Mr. Gore to capitalize on the nation's prosperity perplexes many of his supporters, who have encouraged the vice president to spend this last week of the campaign hitting that theme hard. Some supporters even fear this may be one negative effect of Mr. Gore's distancing himself from Mr. Clinton for much of the campaign.
Still, to some experts in politics and economics, the health of the economy is playing a surprisingly small role in the race -- especially compared with 1992, when the Clinton-Gore campaign used fears about the economy to win many middle-of-the-road voters who felt President Bush was not doing enough to pull the country out of recession.
"Every econometric model I know of relates the presidential election to the state of the economy, but if Bush wins, they're all going to be wrong," said Charls E. Walker, an economist and former tax lobbyist who has served in several Republican administrations.
Susan Flom, a retiree in Ladue, another suburb close to St. Louis, favors Mr. Gore. But she said the stock market might do better under a Republican government -- just not Mr. Bush, who she feels is too inexperienced. "If Bush gets elected, I think the market is going to go down."
It is harder to find that sentiment in the more conservative areas further west of St. Louis, where most people interviewed said they felt Mr. Bush would be better for the stock market. At the same time, however, for many of them the future of the stock market is not as important as how each candidates' economic proposals would affect their own line of work.
Mark Ratterman, who lives in St. Charles, about a half-hour west of St. Louis, and owns Domino's Pizza franchises, said he is still disturbed by the health care plan pushed by Hillary Rodham Clinton early in her husband's administration, which he said would have greatly hurt his business. Mr. Gore's populist rhetoric is eerily reminiscent of Ms. Clinton's statements on health care back then, he said.
"I like Bush because he would let the market prevail, while I feel like Gore wants to give money to everybody," he said. At his business, his biggest problem has been rising labor costs, though he says that has been offset, to some degree, by improved technology that has brought streamlined order-taking, accounting, and other functions. Such productivity gains from technology get much of the credit for the strong economy and stock market, Mr. Ratterman said. "That's what's done it," he said. "I can't believe politicians try to take credit for it."
Tom Slater, another small business owner in St. Charles, favors the Bush tax proposals, particularly the repeal of the inheritance tax. Trying to get his daughter, who lives in California, interested in the election recently, he said he spoke to her over the telephone and put things in a practical light: "I asked her, 'Do you want half my estate, or do you want all of my estate?' "
If Mr. Gore is not benefiting from the economy with a lot of voters, this may also mean the market volatility of the past two months, which has seen the Nasdaq drop 20 percent, is not hurting him, either.
Polls still show very high levels of confidence in the economy. A New York Times/CBS News poll taken last week in Florida, another battleground state, found that 78 percent of registered voters who are investors felt the stock market would be the same or improved in six months, while only 12 percent thought it would be worse.
In Jacksonville, Fla., one poll respondent, Marilyn Leachman, a registered nurse who works as a paralegal, said the market could still get bumpy, depending on tensions in the Middle East and oil prices. "But we're not going to see the bottom fall out or anything," she said. Though she said she will vote for Mr. Gore, she does not attribute the strong economy to him, or to Mr. Clinton. "I guess I credit other factors, though I think they allowed some natural progression in the markets to take place," she said.
Many voters may be relatively sanguine over the future course of the stock market in part because stocks bounced back so quickly from the last big dip in the market, in October 1998, when the near-collapse of the Russian economy and a large hedge fund roiled stock and bond markets worldwide: Since then, the Nasdaq has more than doubled, and the Standard and Poor's 500-stock index has risen more than 40 percent.
At a restaurant in St. Charles last week, members of the First Capital Investment Club, a group of 35 investors who meet every month to review their portfolio, shook off any fears about a continued market downturn and voted to buy more stocks, including shares of Motorola, Intel and Worldcom.
One club member, Dan Barklage, an attorney in St. Charles and a strong supporter of Mr. Bush, favors drug stocks and shares of Microsoft. Drug stocks will get a boost if Mr. Gore is defeated, as investors will no longer have to fear Mr. Gore's rhetoric against the pharmaceutical industry, Mr. Barklage said. Microsoft, which is battling the Justice Department and a court order to break up the software giant, would also get a boost, he said, because "once Bush gets in, they'll stop picking on it."
To a number of the Missouri voters interviewed, the best situation for the stock market and the economy would be a divided government, where each party captures either the White House or at least one chamber of Congress, as has been the case in Washington since 1994.
According to Alan F. Skrainka, the chief market strategist at Edward Jones, the retail brokerage firm based in St. Louis, during the past century stocks have performed best under a Democratic president and Republican Congress, while they did the worst when Republicans held both the White House and Congress.
That rings true to Neil Clavers, an advertising salesman in Richmond Heights, a close-in suburb of St. Louis, who said he would probably vote for Mr. Bush. "I basically think Republicans are better for the market." But a split government may be even better, he said, "to balance each other out."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN;
In His Own Words

 BODY:

AL GORE
Remarks yesterday at Portland Community College, in Portland, Ore.:
"I have to assume that my opponent's tax plan was designed in some kind of supply-side vacuum. Because, no matter how you add it up, it means a return to massive deficits. According to the American Academy of Actuaries, his plans make paying down the debt -- and I quote -- 'impossible.' 
 I will not let us be dragged back into a cycle of big tax giveaways to the wealthy, big deficits, big debt and repeat recessions.
That wouldn't just be bad for our budget and our economy, it would be potentially devastating for America's families and American business. That huge tax cut would mean higher interest rates, which would make it harder to buy a home and which would choke off borrowing and investment in the private sector. And that, in turn, would mean lower productivity and lower levels of economic growth.
Don't take my word for it: eight Nobel Prize winners have concluded that the Bush plan is an economic loser for America.
Our people have worked too hard and achieved too much to waste it on the wrong kind of tax cut that puts the economy at risk. We need targeted, affordable tax cuts for families that keep our budget balanced and keep our prosperity growing.
My opponent likes to criticize my tax cuts for being targeted. So let's be clear on this. Both of us have proposed targeted tax cuts.
The difference is, the Bush plan targets the benefits primarily to the top 1 percent -- families who make, on average, $1 million a year. My tax cut targets the benefits to middle-class families. And that's the second big difference between us.
Senator McCain said it best when he raised concerns about then governor's plan during the primaries: "I don't think Bill Gates needs a tax cut, but I think you and your parents do."

HEADLINE: Flower District Considers a Repotting;
Wholesale Market Feels Pressure As Neighborhood Is Transformed

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
For much of the past century, wholesale flowers have been sold amid the fur fabricators of the West 20's. But in recent years, many wholesalers have closed up shop, and those that remain in the flower market, now concentrated on two blocks of 28th Street, say they may soon be pulling up roots.
Reacting to a wave of new construction in their neighborhood, worsening traffic congestion and a scarcity of parking spaces, the wholesale florists banded together last year and formed the Flower Market Association of NYC. Not long ago they began meeting with city officials to try to identify a site where the dealers, who are determined to move en masse, can set up a market together. 
 "It's better if everyone is in one place," said Pete Sutton, the owner of Mutual Cut Flowers, a company that carries a broad line of what he described as "middle of the road" flowers. "No one wholesaler can carry every type of flower."
Although it has never carried an official designation like the Hunts Point produce market or the Fulton Fish Market, New York's flower district once had a bigger footprint, stretching from 26th to 28th Street and running along the Avenue of the Americas.
Today, many of these family-owned businesses are gone. The market has shrunk to about half its former size, now numbering 31 wholesale florists and several purveyors of pots, planters and baskets spread out along two blocks of side streets.
Before 5 a.m. on a recent weekday, the sidewalks and curbs on 28th Street between Broadway and Seventh Avenue were already lined with orange dahlias and other seasonal products -- pumpkins, of course, but also branches of red-and-brown maple leaves and green gourds shaped like snakes, bottles and horns.
As workers unloaded a refrigerated truck, flower buyers holding paper coffee cups and cell phones were circulating, indicating their choices with a pointed finger or a quick word. Vans were beginning to clog the narrow street.
By 6 a.m., Luis Collazo, decked out in black leather, had already settled on $2,000 worth of merchandise for Lotus, his Greenwich Village flower shop. His van was filling up with varieties of flowers: the agapanthus from California, the eucharis lily, the hydrangea and the amaryllis from the Netherlands. He bought orchids that only a day or two before were growing in Thailand. The predawn visit to the flower market is a ritual for Mr. Collazo: he is there three times a week. "You get an early start," he said, "you pick up the best stuff."
No official sales figures have been compiled, but Gary W. Page, the president of the Flower Market Association, estimated that the market takes in about $100 million to $120 million a year in sales to retail florists, floral designers and buyers for restaurants, hotels, special events, parties and weddings. The market employs about 300 people, many of them immigrants from Spanish-speaking countries. (Another 300 or so people are employed by wholesalers in other boroughs, according to figures from the State Department of Labor. There are about 500 retail florists in New York City, employing about 1,800 people.)
Heavy pressure on the flower market has come from rezoning on Seventh Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas over the past five years; the changes permit residential development in places that were once restricted to industrial uses. In an area that had little new construction for nearly a quarter-century, 2,100 units of housing are being added in seven buildings, ranging in size from 10 to 37 stories.
Commercial rents in the area are climbing rapidly, raising fears among wholesalers like Mr. Page, the owner of G. Page, a company specializing in exotic flowers, which has only two years left on its lease.
As retail florists and floral designers grow increasingly frustrated with the traffic and parking problems, the market is sure to suffer, the wholesalers predict. They worry that retail florists will be tempted to give more of their business to the dozens of dealers who travel door to door and sell directly off their refrigerated trucks, a competing source of wholesale flowers that emerged 15 years ago. They are also concerned about the potential threat from the Internet and competition from wholesalers in the suburbs.
Rob Houtenbos, the president of Dutch Flower Line, a tenant on 28th Street for 11 years, said the wholesale market has to move and modernize in order to survive. "If we stay here," he said, "we are suffocating ourselves. We need to create a market that sells flowers in a modern way."
Pronouncements like this one have been heard before. In the 1980's, the wholesalers said their market was facing extinction, and some talked about moving to College Point, Queens. A decade later, the focus shifted to the Harlem River Yards in the South Bronx. The market's largest wholesaler, Kiamos & Tooker, moved to Zerega Avenue in the Bronx, but that company was the only defector from 28th Street.
Jim Lebberes, the president of Kiamos & Tooker, which now occupies 54,000 square feet of space and has three-quarters of an acre for parking, said that many of his Manhattan customers who used to go in person to 28th Street now buy from him by telephone or shop somewhere else. "I would prefer for my own purposes that more come here and buy," Mr. Lebberes said. "If they see the product, they would buy more."
While a few people in the industry are open to moving to another borough, most say that the high-end florists and the floral designers will not travel outside Manhattan.
"I know where my customer base is," said Mitchell Vlachos, an owner of Harry Vlachos Inc., a company started by his father in 1930, when 70 percent of the flowers sold at the market were grown within 100 miles of the city.
Michael George, a veteran floral designer, agreed that it would be a mistake for the market to move to another borough. "I'm not schlepping to Hunts Point," he said. "I'm not in the fruit business. If you're not in Manhattan, you might as well be in Hong Kong."
City Councilwoman Christine Quinn, whose district includes the flower market, said there are several sites that might be suitable, although she stressed that the discussions were only in the preliminary stages. Among the sites being mentioned are Pier 57 along the Hudson River, just south of Chelsea Piers; the wholesale meat market near Gansevoort Street; the Fulton Fish Market; La Marqueta, the marketplace in East Harlem; and the market on Essex Street on the Lower East Side.
"As much as everyone would like to keep the flower market where it is," Ms. Quinn said, "that isn't really viable anymore. At the end of the day, we need to find them a new space."
Ricardo Soto-Lopez, a former city planning official who recently became the director of planning and economic development for the Flower Market Association, said that the wholesale florists should be housed under one roof, with easy access to loading docks, and that they should have the capacity to pool services like maintenance, trucking, refrigeration and billing.
If the wholesalers were housed in one place, said Juliette Babincak, the flower buyer for Surroundings, an Upper West Side florist, they could ban customers without proper identification, as is done at the flower market in Boston. She said this would address a common complaint among retailers: that wholesalers undercut their business by selling to the public. Wholesale prices can be one-third of retail prices or less, depending on the variety of flower.
In its current location, said Lesly Zamor, the owner of Bloom, a florist in the Flatiron district, the market is too accessible to retail customers, including hotels and restaurants. "I'd say we lose $250,000 to $400,000 a year just in restaurant business," Mr. Zamor said.
People who shop for hotels and restaurants, however, can obtain resale licenses that entitle them to buy flowers wholesale, and most actually do function as floral designers, said Mr. Page, the association's president. Like other wholesalers, Mr. Page said he does very little retail business. But he said that if a new market is built, it should be closed to the public.
"It's ridiculous to have an open market in New York," he said. "People should be required to have badges to enter."
Mr. Page and the other wholesalers said they hoped to get help from the city. In their view, the city needs to recognize that even though the flower market is small, it plays an important role in the city's restaurant and tourism industries. Officials at the City Economic Development Corporation did not respond to a telephone request for comment.
But Mr. Lebberes, the wholesale florist who moved to the Bronx, said his former neighbors on 28th Street were deluding themselves if they thought that city officials would be eager to help an industry that employs so few people.
"I think the people that are left in the market have unrealistic expectations," he said. "They can sit there forever waiting for the city to give them something they won't ever get."
Others in the industry are more hopeful. "The flower market has been overlooked and taken for granted," said Mr. Sutton, the owner of Mutual Cut Flowers. "This is one of those little sectors that adds so much to the city. People walk into a lobby and see the flowers -- and it never occurs to them how the flowers got there."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
More Acquisitions Narrow the Field

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT 

 BODY:
Several agencies and specialty companies are being acquired.
Roper Starch Worldwide in Harrison, N.Y., acquired Langer Associates in New York, a research company, for undisclosed terms. Langer, with clients like Pitney Bowes, Prudential and J. Walter Thompson, is being renamed the Roper/Langer Qualitative Research division of Roper Starch. Judith Langer, president at Langer, becomes a senior vice president at Roper Starch and director for the new division. 
 True North Communications in Chicago acquired Genus Media in London, the parent of MBS Media and Expert Media, which specialize in media planning and buying. Terms were not disclosed.
Genus will operate as an autonomous unit of TN Media, the True North media services agency; Glenn Burton, 50, continues as chairman at Genus. MBS has about 55 employees handling media duties for accounts with billings estimated at more than $225 million from clients like Deloitte & Touche and Michelin. Plans call for combining the media buying handled at MBS with the media buying handled at Banks Hoggins O'Shea/ FCB in London, part of the FCB Worldwide unit of True North.
Finally, Itemus Inc. in Toronto, a so-called incubator, agreed to acquire an 80 percent stake in the multimedia operations of Shooting Gallery Inc. in New York in a stock transaction valued at $56 million.
Shooting Gallery, which provides high-speed Internet access, Web site design and interactive multimedia production services as well as strategy and creative work, has more than 200 employees at offices in Los Angeles, Miami, New York, Toronto and Vancouver, British Columbia. Revenue is estimated at $24 million from clients like DDB Worldwide and Saatchi & Saatchi. In addition, the film, television and music development and distribution businesses of Shooting Gallery will be spun off to current shareholders as a stand-alone company called Shooting Gallery Entertainment.
The top executives at Shooting Gallery -- Larry Meistrich, 34, chairman and chief executive, and Stephen Carlis, 34, president -- will continue in those posts at both Shooting Gallery and Shooting Gallery Entertainment.

SECTION: Section A; Page 34; Column 4; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Where Are the Elysian Fields of Yore?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In "What's in a Stadium Name -- Tradition or Money?" (news article, Oct. 29), about selling the right to name the Denver Broncos' new stadium, Mayor Wellington E. Webb is quoted as saying, "Not everything should be for sale." 
 We may be in the midst of the longest economic expansion in history, but what is it worth if we sell our souls?
Bravo, Mayor Webb! What he said should be the Quotation of the Day -- every day.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
Gore Accuses Bush of Waging 'Class Warfare'

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: BURBANK, Calif., Oct. 31

 BODY:
Turning his opponent's language against him, Vice President Al Gore delivered a stinging rebuke of Gov. George W. Bush's tax-cut plan today, calling it a redistribution of wealth that amounted to "class warfare on behalf of billionaires."
Mr. Gore also continued a new line of attack on Mr. Bush, saying that his pledge to get along with people in Washington really meant that he would go along with the special interests. 
 In a speech to supporters in Portland, Ore., the vice president said Mr. Bush's proposed $1.3 trillion tax cut would be a disaster for the economy and "potentially devastating for America's families and American businesses."
Mr. Gore said Mr. Bush's proposed elimination of the estate tax would give $25 billion a year to the wealthiest 3,000 families in America, a plan that he branded "unbelievable."
"What he is actually proposing is a massive redistribution of wealth from the middle class to the wealthiest few," Mr. Gore said. "It is in fact a form of class warfare on behalf of billionaires."
Mr. Bush has accused Mr. Gore of conducting class warfare by appealing repeatedly to "working families." And indeed, the vice president has been sharply denouncing the "special interests" with a populist message that his campaign has long hoped would attract independent voters from all along the political spectrum, from supporters of Senator John McCain, a Republican, to those of former Senator Bill Bradley, a Democrat, and perhaps most critically, supporters of Ralph Nader, the Green Party's nominee.
In fact, Mr. Gore, speaking today to a couple of hundred people in the gymnasium of Portland Community College, summoned the name of Senator McCain -- who campaigned with Mr. Bush yesterday -- in heaping scorn on Mr. Bush's tax proposal. Mr. Gore said: "Senator McCain said it best when he raised concerns about the governor's plan during the primaries: 'I don't think Bill Gates needs a tax cut, but I think you and your parents do.' "
Mr. Gore continued: "Again, nothing against Bill Gates or the folks who are in that category. But if you focus almost half of all the benefits on folks in that category, the wealthiest 1 percent, who make on average $1 million a year, then there is not enough money left to give good middle-class tax cuts, balance the budget, pay down the debt and invest in our priorities, like schools and health care and the environment."
Mr. Gore also took Mr. Bush to task for saying he would "get along with people in Washington."
"The real question is, Who does he want to get along with?" Mr. Gore asked, before answering the question himself. "The special interests who want to pry open more loopholes in the tax code? The H.M.O.'s? The insurance industry?"
Mr. Gore said that he would not go along just to get along at any price and that he would stand up to the powerful interests.
Mr. Gore arrived on the West Coast this morning after an overnight flight from Milwaukee, where he had just finished a two-day bus tour in the Midwestern swing states of Michigan and Wisconsin.
"I love the West Coast," the vice president told reporters flying with him to Portland in the wee hours this morning. "I look for any opportunity to go there."
It is not as if opportunities abound in the final week before the election. But Mr. Gore has carved out time from his intense stumping across the industrial Midwest to tend to California and Oregon, two states that have been good to Democrats in recent years.
State polls show Mr. Gore's lead over Mr. Bush in California dwindling and put him neck and neck with Mr. Bush in Oregon. Mr. Bush, smelling blood -- or at least the chance for a theatrical head game on Democratic turf -- scoured those same states for votes today, flying from California to Portland and passing Mr. Gore somewhere midair on his way from Portland to Burbank.
Mr. Bush had been in Burbank to appear on "The Tonight Show." Mr. Gore taped a segment to appear tonight.
Mr. Gore was in a relatively buoyant mood, expressing confidence about his campaign and shrugging off the suggestion that, given the nation's economic prosperity, he should be coasting to victory in the election.
"I have made up a 15-to-20 point deficit," he said. "I think we clearly have the momentum. I feel good about the race. Until recently, the other side had a two-to-one advantage in finances and chose to use it in a way that focused on negative personal attacks."
He also said voters had yet to really focus on the race. "There are some signs that in statewide races, voters are waiting later and later to make up their minds," Mr. Gore said. "This may be happening on a national level." Voters, he said, are "working harder, longer hours, are stressed out, and I think they're waiting."
Asked on "Tonight" whether he would campaign with President Clinton, Mr. Gore said no, he had to win the election on his own. But he said he was happy to be campaigning later tonight in Los Angeles with the actor Martin Sheen, who plays the president on the television series "The West Wing."
As for the Nader voters, Mr. Gore has publicly tried to play down his pursuit of them, but reporters keep asking him how he is going to blunt Mr. Nader's appeal, and his campaign has put on a full-court press in Oregon and elsewhere to convert Nader votes into Gore votes.
And the fact that Mr. Gore was spending time in Oregon and California this late in the campaign was telling in itself.
Carter Eskew, a top Gore strategist, said today that the fact that Mr. Gore was in Oregon at this point was extraordinary, but added: "I would say it's also extraordinary that George Bush is only four points ahead in Nevada and only four points ahead in New Hampshire and is losing Florida."
Mr. Eskew said the topsy-turvy nature of the race reflected the fact that this year was "unlike any other," adding: "We're going to follow a strategy that gets us to an Electoral College victory, whether or not we have to go to places that people thought once should have been in the bag. Who cares? This is not about pride. This is about winning votes."

HEADLINE: Job Contracts With Noncompete Teeth

BYLINE: By MELINDA LIGOS

 BODY:
A year ago, Dr. Pamela Mancini was pulling in six figures as a pediatrician at a Fredericksburg, Va., medical center.
Today, she's bankrupt, emotionally deflated and desperately searching for a job elsewhere in Virginia. "This has been a hell of a year," said Dr. Mancini, who has been a pediatrician for more than 18 years. 
 The cause of Dr. Mancini's misfortune was an agreement she signed at the request of her employer, Pratt Medical Center, when it was bought by another company in 1998 -- eight years after she had begun her employment there. The new contract stipulated that she would not be able to practice pediatrics within 25 miles of the center for one year if she left Pratt.
But last April, Dr. Mancini said, she had numerous conflicts with management, so she took a risk and left the company, opening her own practice in downtown Fredericksburg. In six months, working alongside her husband, David, the office's manager, she accumulated nearly 2,000 patients.
But all that changed in September. After a lawsuit by Pratt, which contended she was in violation of the noncompete agreement, Dr. Mancini was ordered by a Virginia court to close her practice pending the outcome of the case. Now, she can no longer afford legal counsel. "This whole thing has been a disaster," Dr. Mancini said.
Officials from Pratt Medical Center are unsympathetic. "She voluntarily signed this agreement and is therefore bound to its terms," said John R. Walk, Pratt's lawyer.
The career limbo that Dr. Mancini finds herself in is ensnaring an increasing number of professionals these days. In the current hot economy, companies are taking a harder line against former employees who signed noncompete agreements -- and not always to prevent them from stealing their business away. In many cases, employment specialists say, they want to send a warning to their current employees that the contracts they signed have teeth.
"Employees are companies' hottest commodities right now," said Michael B. Carlinsky, a lawyer with Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe in Manhattan. "More and more employers are using noncompetes, and similar tactics, to hold onto their workers."
Many noncompete agreements prohibit employees from working in a specific geographical area -- or for a specific competitor -- for a year or more after the end of their employment. Others restrict employees from taking clients with them when they resign or from revealing trade secrets.
Such pacts are thriving in all industries, Mr. Carlinsky said, but particularly in high technology, where an extremely mobile work force and the high value of intellectual property have some companies drafting and trying to enforce strict noncompete clauses for employees at all levels.
In certain cases, companies are suing to restrict employees from moving to competitors even when there is no noncompete agreement, citing the need to protect their trade secrets.
Lucent Technologies recently filed a suit against 10 former employees in its optical manufacturing site in North Andover, Mass. The employees resigned earlier this year to join Cisco Systems, which was opening a competing optical networking plant in Salem, Mass. They ranged in experience from one of the top-tier managers at the Lucent plant to a 23-year-old employee. The suit asserts that the former employees -- none of whom signed noncompete agreements -- were making off with proprietary information and should be prevented by court order from working at Cisco.
To the employees' relief, a federal district court in Massachusetts recently issued an order allowing them to continue working at Cisco pending the outcome of the suit. "This case has put a lot of stress on my family," said Daniel Tymann, a former manufacturing director at Lucent who is named in the suit. Before the August court ruling, Mr. Tymann said, he had to sit down with his wife and 14-year-old daughter "and discuss the possibility of us relocating; that was extremely upsetting."
Mr. Tymann said when he left Lucent, his superiors never said they might sue him. "I was certainly aware of my obligations to keep any proprietary information of Lucent's proprietary," he said. "I'm disappointed that they questioned my integrity."
The lawyer for the former Lucent employees, Gregory L. Lippetz, contends that Lucent filed the suit to send a message to other employees who might be thinking about jumping ship. "There are some companies who use noncompetes as a retention tool to hang over employees' heads," Mr. Lippetz said.
A Lucent spokeswoman, Mary Lou Ambrus, maintains that the 10 employees agreed to a noncompete clause that was included in a stock option grant. "We feel the company has a right and an obligation to protect confidential information," she said.
Although more companies are trying to enforce noncompete agreements, not all are victorious. In a recent lawsuit, Heartland Securities filed a claim against several employees for violating noncompete agreements. In one situation, an employee, Jared Gerstenblatt, signed an employment contract with Datek Online Brokerage Services (now owned by Heartland), promising to pay back up to $200,000 in "training costs" if he left the company before completing four years of employment. He left shortly before his four-year anniversary to become a day trader. A federal district court in New York ruled in March that the contract was overly restrictive. "It was a clever attempt to create a disincentive for people to leave," Mr. Carlinsky said.
Heartland's lawyer declined to comment.
Experts say that unpopular as noncompete contracts are with workers, when used properly, they are a legitimate way for employers to protect their interests.
"I encourage all my clients to have employees sign noncompetes, especially those who work in the tech arena," said Michael D. Golden, a partner at the Atlanta law firm, Arnall Goden & Gregory. "Why should you let somebody run off with your clients or your intellectual capital?"
Kathleen Gadd, one of Mr. Golden's clients, and senior managing director of Office Innovation, an office products company based in Lawrenceville, Ga., agrees. Her company makes sales representatives agree in writing not to take accounts with them when they leave. In addition, senior executives are asked to sign a pact promising not to reveal portions of the company's business plan. "I've spent the last four years building this business from scratch," Ms. Gadd said. "I have a right and a responsibility to protect it."

HEADLINE: Working at Home Today?

BYLINE: By KATIE HAFNER 

 BODY:
TWO days a week, Christine Parupia, an executive at Charles Schwab & Company, drives for five minutes from her house in Walnut Creek, Calif., to a towering office building and starts her workday. Her spacious corner office overlooks one of the San Francisco Bay area's most congested freeways, which Ms. Parupia can gaze out on with all the smugness of someone beating the system.
Each Wednesday and Friday, instead of making the hourlong commute to Schwab's headquarters in downtown San Francisco, Ms. Parupia works from what Schwab calls a "hoteling" center, also known as a telework or drop-in center. The suite of 42 offices is available to Schwab employees trying to reduce the strain of a long commute. 
 For years, telecommuting has been a topic surrounded by hope, hype and disappointment. The word itself has grown musty, smacking of yesterday's trend. The work-at-home utopia for all has not materialized, but the nightmare of two-hour commutes has led to the necessity of people working away from the office, either at home, at satellite offices like the Schwab center or at an ever-changing series of shared desks.
More than 16.5 million people in the United States, or about 12 percent of the work force, now work at home one or more days a month, according to the International Telework Association and Council, an industry group in Washington.
A few large companies in San Francisco and around the country are now pushing the concept of drop-in centers, which provide employees with a desk, a computer workstation, a telephone, administrative support and plenty of parking. Employees make reservations, check in and check out. Regulars like Ms. Parupia try to reserve the same office each time.
The push is being felt hardest in California, but remote work is growing more popular around the rest of the country. For several years, 17 telework centers in the Washington, D.C., area have been used primarily by federal employees but are gradually attracting interest from the private sector. The centers are run by a variety of organizations, including community colleges, economic development commissions and two private companies, Lockheed Martin and IBA, a technical consulting company in Falls Church, Va.
For the first several years, said Darryl Dobberfuhl, the executive director of the Washington telework sites, the centers were not filling up, but that is changing. "We have some people who spend one and a half or two hours commuting one way," he said. "By the time they get to work they're pretty high strung. People really look forward to the days they can work from the center."
Mr. Dobberfuhl also pointed to federal legislation that was signed last month offering the telecommuting option to all eligible federal employees. "The timing is better now," Mr. Dobberfuhl said. "More managers are understanding the concept."
The Schwab drop-in center in Walnut Creek, which the company calls Hotel Schwab, has many of the same amenities as a hotel, including a fitness center and a "concierge," who carries out basic administrative tasks and makes the occasional deli run. It is also every bit as sterile, with few personal touches. If people want to store files, they use hallway lockers. Ms. Parupia said she usually brought in a framed photograph of her 13-year-old son to put on the desk.
Two years ago, Sun Microsystems opened three drop-in centers scattered around the Bay Area as an experiment. The decision as to where to put them was based purely on demographics.
"Instead of chasing space, we're chasing people," said Ann Bamesberger, Sun's director of workplace effectiveness. "Instead of thinking, 'Where can we get a big chunk of land?' we're thinking, 'Where do people want to work?' "
Sun's drop-in centers have grown so popular that the company is planning to open others around the region. Some employees stay at the centers all day, while others go early in the morning and wait for the traffic to thin out before continuing on to the office. Schwab is opening two additional centers to the north and south of San Francisco.
Traffic is not the only reason companies are looking for alternatives. The paucity and expense of office space have forced some companies to require that employees share a work space. Sun now has some 10 percent of its 40,000 employees, including Ms. Bamesberger, permanently "unassigned."
"It means you're virtual everywhere," said Ms. Bamesberger, who works in a group of 30 people who share 15 seats at Sun's offices in Mountain View, Calif. She can also travel from Sun office to Sun office and use any of a number of drop-in "stations."
Brent Daniel, who works for Ms. Bamesberger, said that once a week, instead of making the 1 1/4-hour drive to Mountain View, he worked from Sun's drop-in center in San Francisco, a 15-minute ride on public transportation from his house.
"Whatever seat I would have used in Mountain View can be used by someone else," Mr. Daniel said. "Compare that to the scenario where I have an assigned seat in Mountain View. If I'm in San Francisco that day, that seat would be empty." Mr. Daniel welcomes not only a day without driving but also the change of pace and the chance to spend a day in the city.
The concept of a telework center isn't new. Between 1991 and 1997, in various experiments to gauge the change in air quality if commuting time was reduced, 40 or so publicly subsidized telework centers opened throughout California. When the subsidies expired, however, nearly all the centers closed because they were not being used very much.
But five years later, with traffic congestion worse than ever and real estate prices soaring, employers are increasingly open to exploring alternatives to the workplace norm.
Of 2,700 Sun employees who responded to a recent survey, nearly 80 percent said they worked from home at least part of the time. Telecommuting is popular at Cisco Systems, too. Half the company's 35,000 employees work from home at least one day a week. The company will provide a high-speed line to the Internet in employees' homes if requested.
Bill Finkelstein, a senior partner at Cisco, often spends Fridays working from his home in Santa Rosa, Calif., 100 miles north of Cisco's San Jose headquarters.
"It increases productivity enormously," Mr. Finkelstein said. By eliminating time in the car, he can start his workday at 6 a.m. with a conference call with the East Coast or Europe. During the calls, he can put on his headset and wander over to his large picture window to watch a covey of quail that lives in his yard.
Mr. Finkelstein's high-speed data line, supplied by Cisco, makes computer work as fast as it would be if he were in San Jose. "The problem I have is disciplining myself to get out of the office," he said. "I'm in there for 10 hours plus." When he does take breaks, he goes into his kitchen to make a cup of tea or he walks out to the mailbox.
One alternative to expensive corporate real estate is none at all. Alan Gunshor, chief executive of Passpoints.com, a company that runs an online loyalty program, works from his apartment in San Francisco. He stays in touch with his 13 employees, who are scattered from Lake Tahoe to Los Angeles, via instant messaging, e-mail and frequent conference calls. "We decided very early on that we wanted to spend our money on people rather than office space," Mr. Gunshor said.
Harriet Donnelly, president of Technovative Marketing, a public relations firm, directs 23 employees, all of whom, like Ms. Donnelly, work from home Ms. Donnelly said her employees all preferred the flexibility of working from home. One employee, she said, had set up her schedule so that she could ride her horse in the morning before starting work. "If someone wants to stop at 2 p.m. to take their child to a soccer game, as long as they take a cell phone or call in every hour and a half for their messages, that's fine," she said.
In her own home office in Berkeley Heights, N.J., Ms. Donnelly said, she had created just the right atmosphere for herself. She keeps the television on behind her, with the volume turned very low, not so that she can watch "Oprah" but so that "it feels like people are in the room with me." She keeps her office door closed so that telephone conversations aren't disrupted when her three dogs start up a chorus of barking.
Corporate clients, Ms. Donnelly said, are more accepting of her creative workplace arrangement than they were four years ago, when she began it. "People used to ask about it, but now they don't really care," she said.
Trust is a topic that frequently arises around the topic of remote work. Employers lose a sense of control over employees who work remotely. But telecommuting proponents discount the concern.
"Employers are very hung up on the fact that if they see people at their desks, they can assume they're working and not doing their personal Internet browsing, which is a false assumption," said Joanne Pratt, a consultant in Dallas who does research on telework.
"One of the basic tenets of the Cisco culture is trust," Mr. Finkelstein said. "If you can't tell what an employee is doing without seeing them physically planted in a chair, how are you running your business?"
Ms. Donnelly said she did a minimum of employee monitoring, and she agreed with Mr. Finkelstein's assessment. "If companies have to police their employees, then they've hired the wrong people," she said.
Still, working from home is not for everybody. Ms. Parupia said she had a home office, but she preferred to use the Schwab drop-in center, partly because she was less easily distracted and partly because the telework center provided her with a fax machine, a photocopier, a high-speed computer line and other office requirements.
At lunchtime, Ms. Parupia usually goes home, where she does some gardening, then returns to Hotel Schwab, rejuvenated and happy to resume her spot overlooking the freeway she doesn't have to be on.

HEADLINE: TURF;
At the Top, Prices Have Flattened Out

BYLINE: By Tracie Rozhon 

 BODY:
PRICES of upper-end properties, the creme de Manhattan's creme, have eased in recent weeks, according to a report to be released next week. The report, by Brown Harris Stevens, known for its white-glove listings, examines a series of sales on the Upper East Side, from Third Avenue to Fifth Avenue, along with Central Park West, Sutton Place, Beekman Place and assorted doorman buildings on East 86th and East 57th Streets, as well as the sales in some of the newest condominium loft buildings in TriBeCa.
The report on Manhattan's high-end segment found that this year's 35 percent jump in the average price of a co-op apartment was the highest in the last 11 years. 
 "But most of it happened this winter and spring," said Lawrence Sicular, the Brown Harris Stevens statistician, who emphasized that the real estate market -- especially for these top-end properties -- is still steaming along, although not skyrocketing the way it was earlier in the year.
"For months, we have seen stability across the board, except for the very highest end, and now we are seeing it there, too," said Deborah B. Beck, executive vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York, which is in the process of compiling its own statistics. Traditionally, she said, the biggest spenders -- those buying Park Avenue triplexes or Duane Street luxury lofts -- "were more insensitive" to the fluctuations of the economy as a whole. "Now, at least, they have one eye open and they are not going to overbid," she added.
Ms. Beck, Mr. Sicular and brokers interviewed were quick to emphasize that Manhattan's real estate market remained strong.
"There are buyers out there with tremendous money, buying at tremendous prices," said Susan Renfrew, director of East Side sales for Douglas Elliman, the city's largest residential real estate brokerage firm. While the market as a whole may be flattening, Ms. Renfrew says she believes that prices for specific sectors of the luxury market are still rising sharply, especially for the newest condominiums, like Donald J. Trump's new tower across from the United Nations.
Mr. Sicular said he was surprised when he compared a series of individual apartments -- not the brand-new condominiums now being introduced, but the buildings with established resale records -- sold between the hot spring market and now. His conclusion: There was little change in price. Because his report examines apartments just put under contract -- as opposed to closed sales in which prices were set several months earlier, when the contract was signed -- his information is the most current look at today's market.
One TriBeCa condominium loft, at a location he described as good but not great, sold in June for $1.4 million. On Oct. 5, a loft two floors higher (and therefore more valuable) sold for $1.5 million. If prices were still going up, the loft sold most recently would have gone for a higher price, Mr. Sicular said.
At 103 East 84th Street, the statistician said he found that several six-room apartments, all in the same line in the rear of the building, sold between spring and fall. Their prices were all around $800,000.
On Park Avenue in Carnegie Hill, the price of a nine-room co-op was just negotiated for $4.8 million. A nearly identical apartment sold in August for $4.75 million.
In all three buildings, prices had soared for the two years prior to this spring.
In TriBeCa, in buildings comparable to the one Brown Harris examined, similar-size lofts were selling for less than $1 million a few years ago.
For the East 84th Street building, two comparable six-room apartments had sold in the last two years: one for $587,000, another for $500,000.
In the same Park Avenue building, one similar apartment sold for $3 million and another for $3.5 million, both in August 1998.
About his analysis, Mr. Sicular concluded: "For this end of the market, prices are at least stable, maybe a bit higher. But to say prices are stable is totally supportable."
Reports released by other brokerage firms have painted a similar picture for the real estate market as a whole. They also used closed sales, not signed contracts, as their yardstick.
All the reports, however, have noted an increase in the number of apartments that have been on the market. Brown Harris Stevens reported that on average, there are 20 percent more apartments for sale on the Upper East Side than there were in the winter and spring. (There were, for example, 16 prewar six-room co-ops on the Upper East Side for sale in March; 34 were listed in October.)

HEADLINE: Jordanian Struggles to Keep Ties to Israel

BYLINE: By WILLIAM A. ORME Jr. 

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan

 BODY:
Omar Salah, the 33-year-old chairman of the Century Investment Group, a diversified Jordanian holding company, was sitting in his office surveying the wreckage of the new Middle East.
Suddenly there were no regional investment conferences on the horizon; no more Arab trade offices quietly setting up shop in Tel Aviv; no Jewish-American delegations touring Jordan in search of bridge-building business opportunities. 
 After a month of violence across the Jordan River claimed more than a hundred lives, almost all of them Palestinians, nearly every Arab nation except Jordan had announced a freeze in their already minimal trade relations with Israel. Scores of fledgling Israeli business partnerships from North Africa to the Persian Gulf were instantly and angrily severed.
And in Jordan, where most people are Palestinian refugees or their children, there is intensifying pressure to roll back plans for border industrial parks, a new shared Red Sea airport and other collaborative projects with Israel.
"It took so long for Israel to build up these relationships, and they are so fragile," Mr. Salah said. "This is not in Israel's own interest."
One of the few relationships that has survived, he said, is his own.
Mr. Salah's business has been built on cooperation with Israel. Half of his company's 5,000 employees work in joint ventures with Israeli partners or in factories that depend on Israeli suppliers. Under continual public attack by Jordanians who oppose any normalization of ties with Israel, he takes great pride in his friendships with Israeli business and political leaders.
He began visiting Israel after the 1993 Oslo peace accords, and now travels there so often that he has rented an apartment in Tel Aviv. Israeli business leaders sit on the boards of his companies, while he has become a ubiquitous figure at regional seminars sponsored by Israeli universities and dovish research institutes.
"I am the poster child for normalization," he says with a wan smile.
But for the first time, he is angry, he said -- angry at the violence across the border, and angry at the toll it has taken on friendships and business partnerships alike.
"This is the worst tension and racial animosity I have seen in seven years of doing business," Mr. Salah said. "The damage is not irreversible, but it may take years."
The conflict has also made Mr. Salah feel more Palestinian. Like many Jordanians, his family came originally from the West Bank and what is now Israel, and he has driven along the coast north of Tel Aviv looking wistfully at high-priced seaside property that once belonged to his grandparents.
"I was raised, like all of us, to be anti-Israeli," he said. "But I have tried very hard in business to see how the world looks through their eyes, how they feel that they are this small society under seige, surrounded by enemies. But this, all these deaths . . ."
The phone rang, interrupting him. An Israeli business associate was calling from Jerusalem to cancel a long-planned meeting in Amman. He no longer felt safe there, he said. Mr. Salah was politely incredulous.
Battles between Israeli tanks and Palestinian sharpshooters were raging around Jerusalem, yet his friend was afraid to visit sleepy Amman?
But uncharacteristically violent demonstrations outside the Israeli Embassy here the week before prompted Israel to warn its nationals against visits to Jordan. A few days earlier, Mr. Salah had received another call from a Jewish-American business partner who was so concerned about the demonstrations that he canceled a $100 million manufacturing venture he and Mr. Salah had agreed to start over the summer.
The company, Vishay Intertechnology Inc. of Malvern, Pa., an electronics manufacturer, had conceived of the plant as a complement to its fast-growing Israeli subsidiary, which is managed by the company president's son.
"We would no longer feel exactly safe there," Felix Zandman, Vishay's president, said in a telephone interview.
Until a few weeks ago, Mr. Salah felt that he was in the vanguard of a movement that would ultimately transform the tense relationship between Israel and its Arab neighbors -- and create thousands of jobs and millions in profits in the process. The leaders of Israel, Jordan and the Palestinian territories were all working toward a negotiated regional peace. All three economies were enjoying strong, sustained growth in per capita income for the first time in years, and Jordan's exports to Israel had jumped by 50 percent.
This summer, in his most audacious Israeli business move yet, Mr. Salah purchased a bankrupt sweater company in Ofakim, an Israeli town that had become a national symbol of the disappearance of blue-collar factory jobs. "It's the Allentown of Israel," said Mr. Salah, who said his familiarity with middle American industrial geography owed more to Billy Joel than to his five years studying at Purdue University in Indiana.
The $1.8 million he paid to the Israeli bank receivers was one of his best investments ever, Mr. Salah said. The reopened factory secured new contracts to supply the Gap, J. C. Penney and other American retail chains, and its unlikely new Jordanian owner become a hero to the 70 newly re-employed workers there.
In Jordan, conditions seemed favorable for a further expansion of the American-endorsed "qualifying industrial zones" that allow Jordanian manufacturers to piggyback on Israel's duty-free access to the United States market.
To qualify for zero-customs status, the Jordanian export must be at least 7 percent Israeli -- a condition resented by many Jordanian entrepreneurs. But Mr. Salah, who helped negotiate the agreement with the American and Israeli governments, enticed Motorola, Sara Lee, Jordache and other brand-name American manufacturers into lucrative joint ventures in the new industrial zones, and made Century Investment one of Jordan's biggest employers.
But now, he said, it may be time for Jordan to look beyond its next-door neighbor and concentrate instead on selling to the American market without Israeli partners or intermediaries. The free trade agreement Jordan signed with the United States this month, though it is still subject to Congressional approval, will make it possible for Jordanian businesses to avoid further dependence on Israel, he said.
"It was like a marriage between the Montagues and the Capulets," Mr. Salah mused. "Now that the marriage is suddenly off, yes, you can still be friends, but you also realize that the friendship was predicated on an event that is no longer going to take place."
