HEADLINE: REVIEW;
Web Sites With Civil War Lore Are as Popular as the Battlefields

BYLINE: By DAVID M. OSHINSKY 

 BODY:

THE CIVIL WAR ON THE WEB: A GUIDE TO THE VERY BEST SITES
By William G. Thomas and Alice E. Carter
(Scholarly Resources, $18.95 paperback.)
 
VALLEY OF THE SHADOW: TWO COMMUNITIES IN THE AMERICAN CIVIL WAR
By Edward L. Ayers and Anne S. Rubin
(CD-ROM for Windows and Mactinosh; W. W. Norton & Company; $49.95.)
NO event in the history of the United States attracts more public interest than the Civil War. Visitors flock to its battlefields, where re-enactments are the rage. Truckers and accountants boldly storm Gettysburg's Little Round Top or Chickamauga's Horseshoe Ridge in the tailored uniforms of "Billy Yank" and "Johnny Reb." The Civil War shelves in bookstores are crammed with best-selling novels and histories like Michael Shaara's "Killer Angels" and James McPherson's "Battle Cry of Freedom." More than 40 million people watched some or all of Ken Burns's 1990 documentary, "The Civil War." 
 The interest is understandable. The Civil War pitted brother against brother in the bloodiest conflict in American history. The North put 2.2 million men in uniform, half of its entire draft age population; the South mustered 800,000 men, an astounding 75 percent of its white draft-age population. More soldiers died -- about 625,000 -- than in all of America's 20th-century wars.
Some states took decades to recover. A third of Mississippi's 78,000 soldiers were killed in battle or died from disease. And more than half of the survivors brought home a lasting disability of war. Mississippi resembled a giant hospital ward, a land of missing arms and legs. In 1866, one-fifth of the state budget went for the purchase of artificial limbs.
The sheer carnage led each side to stress the virtues of the cause. The winner thanked Providence for a victory that had preserved the union and cleansed it of slavery. The loser viewed its ghastly sacrifice as proof of the gallantry of the "Southern way of life." In myth and in history, the Civil War became synonymous with freedom, courage, regional pride and national reconciliation.
No outlet better reflects the war's enduring popularity than the World Wide Web. The reach of the Internet has opened a vast archive of Civil War material to the public. Anyone bold enough to check a search engine for, say, Robert E. Lee will find several hundred thousand matches. There are sites for every political and military figure of the era, every battle and skirmish, every regiment and artillery piece.
How does one maneuver through this information logjam? A new book, "The Civil War on the Web," offers much needed help. After exhaustive investigation, the authors -- Dr. William G. Thomas, director of the Virginia Center for Digital History at the University of Virginia, and Alice E. Carter, project manager for education at New York Times Digital -- recommend 95 sites based on the richness of sources, ease of navigation and visual appeal. These criteria are flexible, they say, because most sites were not made by professional Web designers but by "librarians and archivists, re-enactors and preservationists, students and educators -- people more interested in the Civil War than in slick appearances or sophisticated menus." Put simply, most sites are stronger on content than on aesthetics.
Dr. Thomas and Ms. Carter take a broad approach to their subject. Their survey gives equal time to both the battlefield and the home front, where important social, cultural and racial changes occurred. One chapter reviews the best Web sites on women in the Civil War, and another examines sites on slavery and emancipation.
But even the chapters on Web sites concerned with military matters go beyond battles and armaments to the experiences of common soldiers. Want to learn about the treatment of wounded troops? The University of Toledo has a good Web site (www.cl .utoledo.edu/canaday/quackery/quack8 .html). Need some material about Jews in the Civil War? Click on www.jewish-history.com/civilwar.htm. Curious about the layout of the Civil War prison at Andersonville, Ga.? A National Park Service Web site, www.nps.gov/ande, has details.
Among the most prominent Civil War Web sites is the Valley of the Shadow, (valley.vcdh.virginia.edu) a remarkably ambitious project that began at the University of Virginia in 1992. (Both Dr. Thomas and Ms. Carter have also worked on this project.) The Web site examines two Shenandoah Valley counties -- Franklin in Pennsylvania and Augusta in Virginia -- in the late 1850's and 1860's.
Created by Dr. Edward L. Ayers, a history professor at the University of Virginia, the Valley Web site contains primary information, including maps, photographs, letters, diaries, newspapers, census data, church documents and military records. The objective is to make the raw materials of history available to the widest audience, allowing users to ask their own questions and draw their own conclusions about the Civil War by studying one Northern county and one Southern county in detail.
The Web site averages about 7,000 page-views per day. Although the site attracts scholars and history buffs, it also appeals to students. A survey published in 1999 showed that a typical week included requests from Harvard and Stanford, a community college in New Mexico and high schools in California, Wyoming and Indiana. An eager fourth grader recently asked the project: "Fax me everything you have on the Civil War."
That would take awhile. The sheer size of the Valley Web site archive can be daunting. A well-directed student should have no problem navigating through the mammoth collections, but others may be confused.
That is not the case with the Valley of the Shadow's new CD-ROM, a user-friendly guide that spotlights Augusta and Franklin Counties in the critical years between 1858 and the spring of 1861. Titled The Eve of War: Valley of the Shadow, it comes with an excellent book by Dr. Ayers and Dr. Anne S. Rubin describing both the history of the region and the roots of the conflict. Even better, the CD contains reference tools that allow a novice to find material.
Navigating the CD is a snap. Each collection is carefully introduced and indexed by name, subject and date. On one level, the user can search the census data to find an individual's occupation, race, religious affiliation and level of wealth, then follow that person through letters, newspaper accounts and enlistment reports. On another level, the user can peruse larger subjects, under headings like Race Relations and Arts/Entertainment/Leisure, to get a feeling for the pulse of daily life in the Shenandoah Valley.
The CD contains wonderful photographs, a foot-tapping music score and a time line linking Augusta and Franklin Counties to national events, like the Dred Scott decision and John Brown's raid on the federal arsenal in nearby Harper's Ferry, W. Va.
What comes through clearly in The Valley of the Shadow are the similarities of these two counties, only 200 miles apart, and the reluctance of their residents to go to war. Both were prosperous farming communities, known for their grain and livestock; both were settled by people from Germany and the British Isles; both were deeply racist places, with whites viewing blacks as inferior. The defining difference, quite simply, was that Augusta County had slavery, and Franklin County did not.
One can sift through the documents to see how slaves lived and worked in Augusta County, and how valuable they were to the local economy. Or the searcher can explore the mixed emotions of Franklin County's whites concerning the evils of slavery and its further expansion. Some viewed slavery as the proper station for those with dark skin, while others accepted its presence in the South but opposed its spread into new territory. A few demanded its abolition on moral grounds.
It is painful to read the diaries and newspapers from the Shenandoah Valley as the events of this era, like Lincoln's election and South Carolina's secession, tear the nation apart. In once-cautious Augusta County, a newspaper headline calls: "Men of Virginia, to the Rescue!" In once optimistic Franklin County, a newspaper headline retorts: "Ready, Aim, Fire." Few could imagine the horrors that lay ahead.
Although this saga ends with the coming of the Civil War, Dr. Ayers and Dr. Rubin intend to carry it forward in two future CD-ROM's. The death of Stonewall Jackson, the thunder at Gettysburg, the Confederate surrender at Appomattox, the abolition of slavery, the promise of Reconstruction -- all are part of the the Great Valley's amazing next chapter, and the young nation's as well.

HEADLINE: THE POP LIFE

BYLINE: By Neil Strauss 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:

Give No Awards On Broadway
This is how it used to work: The Grammy Awards would simply alternate between Manhattan and Los Angeles. Since the late 80's the prestigious music awards show had spent two years in one city, then two years in the other.
But in a news conference on Tuesday at the Staples Center here, the Los Angeles mayor, Richard J. Riordan, and Michael Greene, the president of the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences (which presents the Grammys), said that the awards would stay in Los Angeles for a third consecutive year. 
 The 43rd annual Grammy Awards, Mr. Greene said, have been scheduled for Feb. 21 at the Staples Center. They are to be broadcast at 8 p.m. on CBS. The nominees are to be announced in early January.
But what about Manhattan? Will the Grammys ever return? It seems that "forgive and forget" is not in the vocabulary of Mr. Greene or Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. In the news conference in January 1998 to announce that year's Grammy nominees, Mr. Greene and Mayor Giuliani butted heads after the mayor's role in the conference was cut and City Hall said that Mr. Greene treated a mayoral aide uncivilly. Afterward Mayor Giuliani wished the Grammys back to Los Angeles, never to return during his administration, and vowed to "replace the prestige of the Grammys."
Mr. Greene said there were several reasons why the Grammys remained in Los Angeles. "There are probably three things I would say to keep me out of trouble," he began. "Because we were involved in the design of the Staples Center, we created an easy and economical place to do the show. And because we did the Latin Grammys there just a few months ago, the crew and the unions there are getting very good at setting up."
"Also," he said, "it's important to us that people at all levels of government are very supportive of the educational and cultural programs leading up to the Grammys, and that nothing distracts from the artists. If you look at which city has the greater likelihood for there not to be any political intrigue to get in the way, it is L.A. at this moment."
As for whether the Grammys will return to Manhattan in 2002 when a new mayor is in office, Mr. Greene said, "We will be back in New York very soon."
 
Icelandic Picks
Responding to Tuesday's article in The New York Times on the thriving and eclectic rock scene in Reykjavik, the teeny capital of Iceland, several readers wanted to know what Icelandic albums to buy beyond Bjork.
Despite its small population, Reykjavik's musical output is prodigious. Each of the four record stores on the pedestrian street Austurstraeti has a section for local music that dwarfs the equivalent in cities 10 times its size. "Two or three years ago, there wasn't anything like this," said Karl Henry Hakonarson, the singer in the slow-rock band Utopia. "But now the music is changing so quickly, and there is so much new stuff going on."
Here, then, are five albums to serve as a map for a journey through two decades of innovative Icelandic rock, from its late-blooming punk movement to its early-rising post-rock scene. Some of these are available at Other Music in Manhattan, at Amazon.com and directly from the source: Smekkleysa Records (the name means Bad Taste), P.O. Box 1263, 121 Reykjavik, Iceland; e-mail: badtase@saga.is.
*Various Artists, "Rokk i Reykjavik" (Smekkleysa): Documenting the punk explosion of the early 80's, this two-CD companion to the movie of the same name features live three-chord stompers from Tappi Tikarrass (Bjork's early band); Theyr and Purkur Pillnikk (both featuring future Sugarcubes members); and Q4U, Ego and more than a dozen other lost legends. Picture the Sex Pistols, the Clash, Killing Joke, and X-Ray Spex singing in Icelandic.
*Sugarcubes, "Illur Arfur" (One Little Indian): In the late 80's, seemingly out of nowhere, the Sugarcubes (Sykurmolarnir in Icelandic) burst out of Reykjavik and helped alternative rock reach its creative crest with the woman-child vocals of Bjork and a careening mix of drums, guitar, trumpet, and electronic effects. This album is the Icelandic-language version of the band's second album, "Here Today, Tomorrow, Next Week," though the band's first album, "Life's Too Good" (Elektra), is the superior English-language album.
*Various Artists, "Popp i Reykjavik" (Elf/Dennis): A soundtrack to a 1998 documentary of "the world's most desperate night life" (to quote from the film), this CD features 17 of Iceland's best new artists, including popular exports like Gus Gus, experimental electronic groove riders like Surefni and Aria; and high-quality original rock bands like Maus, Slow blow and Ensimi, whose Steve Albini-produced "BMX" is one of Iceland's best collisions of modern rock guitars and techno keyboards.
*Sigur Ros, "Agaetis Byrjun" (Smekkleysa): A masterpiece not just of contemporary Icelandic rock but of the entire international genre of post-rock, this entrancing CD-length journey is Radiohead's "Kid A" pushed one step further into beautiful abstraction.
*Mum, "Yesterday Was Today -- Today Is Okay" (TMT): The compilation "Tilraunaeldhusith 1999" (Kitchen Motors) may provide a more complete glimpse into the Reykjavik equivalent of the Knitting Factory scene, featuring live experiments from the guitarist Hilmar Jensson; a collaboration between Mum and the electronic-instrument collector Musikvatur; and a 13-guitar orchestra featuring members of Sigur Ros. But this innovative electro-acoustic album by Mum is infinitely more listenable, standing out as an Icelandic equivalent of the Aphex Twin's ambient works.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

SECTION: Section A; Page 31; Column 2; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 1281 words

HEADLINE: Bill Clinton in the Eye of History

BYLINE: By David M. Kennedy; David M. Kennedy, professor of history at Stanford University, won a Pulitzer Prize this year for "Freedom From Fear: The American People in Depression and War, 1929-1945."

DATELINE: STANFORD, Calif.

 BODY:
It's a time of transition, a time to look to the judgment of history. The case before us is the first Democratic president in six decades to be elected to two terms. Voters understood at the outset that he came before them trailing conspicuous liabilities: His party had been deeply discredited by its questionable role in a divisive war just a generation earlier. He himself had avoided military service in that war. His presidential campaign was marred by salacious rumors of sexual misconduct, to which, in effect, he publicly confessed -- a confession that the public, somewhat surprisingly, appeared to understand and accept. And thanks to a splinter populist movement that siphoned off some of the strength of the incumbent Republican president, he was elected.
In office, he favored more restrictive spending policies but more expansive trade policies. He fancied himself a reformer, a legatee of a liberalizing tradition handed down from his party's glory days a generation or two earlier, but a reformer chastened by past policy and political failures. He called himself a new Democrat. But neither the country nor the Congress was in a mood for much reform. He announced grand schemes but accomplished little. His situation was made especially difficult by the inability of his party to pull together sufficiently to control the Congress. Democrats were the majority party in both chambers for just two of his eight years in office. No wonder he was frustrated. 
 The president in question, of course, was Grover Cleveland. It was the Civil War that had discredited the Democrats of his day, because they were thought to be the party of disunion. As the draft law of the era allowed him to, Cleveland had hired a substitute to serve for him in the Civil War. His sexual scandal was an accusation of having fathered an illegitimate child. The third-party candidate who helped him win was James B. Weaver of the Populists. And his big reform issue was lower tariffs, an important step in the direction of what our era has come to call globalization.
I've taken this exercise of assimilating Bill Clinton to Grover Cleveland about as far as it will go: not only were Cleveland's two terms not sequential, but, more fundamentally, his second term was swamped by an economic crisis the likes of which the country had never seen. The notorious Depression of the 1890's shut down the Democrats' bid in those years to become a long-term majority party. As historians never tire of saying, each historical moment is unique and must be understood on its own terms. And yet it is worth lingering in these apparently remote historical precincts just a bit longer.
When Cleveland left office for good in 1897, he ended the presidency of the only Democrat elected to the office since James Buchanan 36 years earlier. When William McKinley followed Cleveland in 1897, he ushered in a period of precisely 36 years when Republicans dominated the national political scene. They held the White House consecutively until 1933, except for the brief interlude of Woodrow Wilson's presidency, itself made possible only by the major split in Republican ranks in 1912, when Theodore Roosevelt bolted to form the most successful third party in American history. That pair of 36-year intervals is intriguing. They form part of a pattern that has by now become something of a chestnut among students of American political history.
The pattern is the remarkable periodicity of something called American party systems: sequential historical eras characterized by distinctive relationships between the contending political parties and constellations of electoral majorities. In this accounting, there have been five clearly defined party systems since the nation's founding: the first from 1789 to 1828, the second stretching from Andrew Jackson's election to Abraham Lincoln's, the third spanning the era from Lincoln's presidency to McKinley's, the fourth running from 1897 to 1933, and the fifth dominated by the Democrats and Franklin Roosevelt's New Deal coalition.
The idea that some deep, mysterious mechanism has shaped those three-and-a-half-decade cycles of political realignment raised the possibility that in about 1968 we would see the wheel of history turn again with the emergence of a sixth political system. Precisely that prediction formed the premise of Kevin Phillips's provocative political tract of 1969, "The Emerging Republican Majority."
Yet if there has been a sixth system, it has been a much messier proposition than the earlier ones. So messy, in fact, that the theory of a built-in periodicity in American political history has been rather discredited in recent years. But it may be that in time we will come to see the years from 1968 to 2000, or perhaps 2004, as constituting a coherent unit of analysis. Our own era bears some arresting resemblances to Grover Cleveland's late 19th century. As then, we live in a time of precarious political balance between the two parties (divided government, it's sometimes called), of checkmate and stasis in the political system, swelling energy in the private economic sphere, and an inchoate but building sense that the capacity of our formal political institutions is growing dangerously incommensurate with the scale and power of the forces at work in the economy at large.
A similar sense a hundred years ago gave birth to the progressive movement, a broad-based effort at reform whose principal historical project was to devise the theory and the institutions of activist government -- to substitute drift for mastery, as Walter Lippmann once described it. That reform ferment yielded meaningful results at last in the New Deal, which defined both the political universe in which we have lived ever since and the terms in which the very legitimacy of our government is still argued.
The challenge of the future is to devise -- and to legitimate -- a set of new institutions that will allow for a measure of politically accountable control over our own economic and social environment. Those institutions are not likely to look like the ones the New Dealers created. They will not be national institutions, but international ones. They will be scaled to deal with the array of issues generated by globalization: the vast increases in the flow of capital, technology, information, goods, culture and even peoples that have been the signature creation of the post-World War II era.
Bill Clinton has, in fact, taken the measure of globalization and has foreseen the necessity of reforms both domestic and international to navigate into that future, indeed to survive in it. Yet he has been unable to do much about that vision, and for reasons that have little to do with Monica Lewinsky or the threat of impeachment. That scandal and its political fallout were but the last and redundant nails in the coffin of the Clinton presidency. He has been effectively a crippled duck almost from the outset, and for reasons that Grover Cleveland would have understood: political paralysis and the inability of either party to build a stable electoral majority.
Yet the party and the political leaders who can take on the question of the commensurability of political institutions with the economic and social realities of our time, and who can make a plausible case both to the American people and to peoples elsewhere about the necessity of political change that will match the phenomenally rapid changes that the new millennium is bringing in the circumstances of our lives, will be in power for a long time to come. They will preside over their own durable party system, whatever ordinal number history will assign it.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Shares Pull Back as Investors Cash In and Volatility Ebbs

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Blue chip stocks and technology issues closed lower yesterday as investors cashed in some of their winnings from the big rally earlier this week.
A last-minute round of buying late in the day offset some of the damage. Analysts attributed the sell-off to profit taking rather than a return of investor anxiety about stocks. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 71.67 points, or 0.7 percent, at 10,899.47. Broader stock indicators also fell. The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index slipped 36.24 points, or 1.1 percent, to 3,333.39 after rising 178 points on Tuesday. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was off 8.18 points, at 1,421.22.
"Bargain hunting does come to mind here," said Arthur Hogan, chief market analyst at Jefferies & Company. "We've been selling off stocks for about eight weeks now, and the indices are starting to look pretty good."
Early in the day, investors seemed to take a step back after Tuesday's frenzied session, when the Dow and the Nasdaq rallied well over 100 points each. Telecommunications and financial issues, which had shot up on Tuesday, were among the biggest decliners.
But about 45 minutes before the market closed, investors appeared to have a change of heart. Money poured into stocks that had spent much of the day lower, limiting losses in many cases.
In the Dow, J. P. Morgan fell 38 cents, to $165.13, after dropping about $2 earlier in the day. Johnson & Johnson closed down $1, at $91, recovering from an earlier loss of $2.88.
JDS Uniphase lost $2.88, to $78.56, after rising more than 14 percent on Tuesday. Nortel Networks slipped $1.56, to $43.94.
Future earnings also remained a focus. WorldCom plummeted $4.81, to $18.94, a 20 percent drop, after the telecommunications company warned of disappointing revenues next year and announced it was creating a separate stock to track its long-distance business.
But the online auctioneer eBay rose $2.52, to $54.02, and the Web portal Yahoo was up $5.73, at $64.36.
Also yesterday, the market got conflicting signals about the health of the economy. The National Association of Purchasing Management reported that United States manufacturing activity slowed in October, while the Commerce Department said construction spending jumped 2.4 percent in September, the biggest gain in 10 months.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasuries Advance
By Bloomberg News
Treasury bond prices rose yesterday after a manufacturing report suggested six interest-rate increases by the Federal Reserve had slowed economic growth, fueling speculation the Fed may cut rates next year.
Declines in the three major stock measures also helped demand for government debt.
"The economy has shifted to a pace of slower growth, and that's good for Treasuries," said Dana Johnson, head of research at Banc One Capital Markets in Chicago. "Yet the dominant story in fixed income has been the turmoil in stocks for several weeks" in driving bond prices higher or lower, he said.
The 10-year Treasury note rose 3/32 , to a price of 100 3/32 . The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.74 percent from 5.75 percent on Tuesday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 1/32 , to 106 20/32 . The bond's yield was unchanged at 5.78 percent.
The National Association of Purchasing Management reported its index fell to 48.3 from 49.9 in September, below the forecast of 49.5 expected by analysts in a survey by Bloomberg News. The decrease follows a larger-than-expected decline in the regional survey by the National Association of Purchasing Management-Chicago.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE UNIONS;
Labor Tailors Its Vote-for-Gore Message, State by State

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: KENOSHA, Wis., Oct. 31

 BODY:
At the giant DaimlerChrysler engine plant here, 75 volunteers from the United Automobile Workers distributed a leaflet today seeking to reassure the factory's employees, many of whom hunt on weekends, that Vice President Al Gore's gun control proposals would in no way hurt sportsmen.
In Florida, labor is deluging union retirees with mailings saying that Gov. George W. Bush's privatization proposal could endanger their Social Security benefits and that Mr. Gore would do more to cushion the cost of prescription drugs. 
 In California, where many union members are low-wage, newly naturalized immigrants, labor's campaign literature is often in Spanish or Chinese and frequently emphasizes bread-and-butter messages like Mr. Gore's call to raise the minimum wage and extend health insurance to millions more children.
And in New York State, with its giant teacher and government employee unions, labor's leaflets often dwell on Governor Bush's reducing contributions to Texas' teacher pension funds and his seeking to privatize state government jobs.
Organized labor, making its biggest political push ever, is relying increasingly this fall on such customized, state-by-state messages. This more sophisticated strategy, by a movement once considered a monolith that took a one-size-fits-all approach, is intended to appeal specifically but simultaneously to engineers and janitors, to teachers and garment workers. Labor leaders hope it will excite union members and help put Mr. Gore over the top.
"We tailor our message to different regions and to different types of workers," said Steven Rosenthal, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s political director. "But the message is basically the same: that there is a stark contrast between Bush, who's antilabor and antiworker, and Al Gore, who has long been a good friend of workers."
Last weekend unions in this blue-collar city distributed to 7,600 union households customized leaflets saying that Kenosha could hold the key to what happens in Wisconsin and that Wisconsin could hold the key to whether Mr. Gore wins the election.
Overseeing a phone bank at a U.A.W. hall, Curt Wilson, president of the Kenosha Central Labor Council, said a town-specific, get-out-the-vote leaflet made sense because when cities here in southeastern Wisconsin rolled up a large Democratic majority, the Democratic candidate usually won the state despite Republican majorities in northern Wisconsin.
These leaflets are part of a last-minute blitz in which John J. Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s president, has asked every union in the 13-million-member federation to distribute one piece of pro-Gore literature to every union member today, another piece on Thursday and another next Monday. And from this Friday through next Tuesday, Election Day, thousands of staff members are being released by unions to work full time on the campaign. As for volunteers, the painters' union alone said 17,000 of its members would do campaign work for Mr. Gore this week.
Of labor's all-out effort, John Drew, president of the U.A.W. local that represents 1,850 engine plant workers here, said, "If Bush wins, we could wake up Wednesday morning with a Republican president, Senate and House, which would mean it would be very difficult to stop an agenda that would seek to weaken unions."
Many experts say that if Mr. Gore wins battlegrounds like Wisconsin, Michigan and Pennsylvania, it will be unions that are responsible.
"If the unions weren't active, Gore wouldn't have a chance in these states," said David W. Rohde, a professor of political science at Michigan State University. "And without those states, he doesn't have a chance nationwide."
Unions' enthusiastic support for Mr. Gore follows anger expressed by large numbers of them over his backing for the legislation that liberalized trade with China. Union leaders now say it makes sense to support him because his opponent is, if anything, worse on the trade issue and because his positions are so close to labor's on other matters, including health care, Social Security and the minimum wage.
In fact, for the union movement the stakes in this election are huge. In his five years heading the A.F.L.-C.I.O., Mr. Sweeney has worked hard to reverse labor's decades-long slide and increase its political influence. A Gore loss would be a stinging setback to those efforts, made all the worse if the Democrats fail to gain control of the House, a goal for which labor has deployed 1,100 staff members to work full time in 71 Congressional districts.
Labor leaders hope Mr. Gore will attract at least as large a share of union votes, 59 percent, as President Clinton got in 1996. That may not be easy, given workers like Terry Plant, a Bush supporter who belongs to the machinists' union.
"I think the Democratic Party is morally bankrupt," said Mr. Plant, who works at a General Electric medical equipment factory in Milwaukee, although "it's hard being a union guy and not following the Democratic Party. I feel some regret that I voted for President Reagan 20 years ago, because the first thing he did was go after the unions."
Bob Hopkins, a spokesman for the Bush campaign, said the governor was holding his own with the union rank and file. Pointing to Wisconsin, Michigan, Minnesota and Missouri, Mr. Hopkins said: "In state after state that has a strong labor presence, Governor Bush is neck and neck with Al Gore, or leading. He would not be able to do this unless his message was reaching independent voters, swing voters and rank-and-file union members."
Mr. Hopkins said Mr. Bush's promises in particular to cut taxes and improve education had resonated with working families.
When Mr. Gore barnstormed through Wisconsin on Monday, he tailored many of his remarks to union members. In one speech after another, he promised to raise the minimum wage and push for laws making it easier for unions to organize. He has made similar labor-friendly remarks in Michigan and Pennsylvania, where, as in Wisconsin, voters from union households accounted for more than 30 percent of all voters in 1998.
One leading example of labor's customizing its message was what happened in early October when union leaders in the hunting-popular Midwest concluded that it was crucial to distribute a flier defending Mr. Gore on the gun issue. The vice president had called for a variety of new gun controls, and in mailings and television spots the National Rifle Association was trying to peel Midwestern union members away from him. "Al Gore Wants to Ban Guns in America," one N.R.A. brochure proclaimed.
The A.F.L.-C.I.O. responded with a brochure, distributed in Wisconsin, Michigan, Minnesota, Pennsylvania and West Virginia, that said: "Al Gore doesn't want to take away your gun. But George W. Bush wants to take away your union."
And the Wisconsin State A.F.L.-C.I.O. recently printed tens of thousands of fliers warning union members that the N.R.A. was trying to distract them from fundamental economic issues.
"How do you stay on target?" the flier said. "Don't be tricked by issues that don't affect your family's bottom line. Realize every candidate opposes crime and supports sportsmen and hunters."
Unions are customizing in numerous other ways as well. In Chicago, they are distributing fliers in Polish. In Florida, Haitian-American workers have received leaflets in Creole. When building trades unions distribute campaign literature, it usually mentions that Mr. Gore wants to preserve a federal law guaranteeing union-level wages on government construction projects and that Mr. Bush has called for watering down the law.
The A.F.L.-C.I.O. has created a Web site where presidents of union locals can order federation-designed campaign fliers on which the locals can include their own community-specific message. Locals have ordered more than three million customized fliers this way, labor officials said.
With Mr. Gore so far ahead in New York and Massachusetts, unions in those state have sent hundreds of campaign workers to other states. New York City's largest health care union, 1199/S.E.I.U., has dispatched 40 full-time campaign workers to Pennsylvania and Michigan for four weeks.
"This resembles the Second World War," said Dennis Rivera, president of 1199, "when the United States was sending arms to the British so they can fight the Germans."

LENGTH: 442 words

HEADLINE: Fed Report Seen Offering Little Reason To Lift Rates

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
The economy grew moderately last month, but many parts of the country reported evidence of slowing activity in critical sectors like retail sales and housing, the Federal Reserve said today.
The Fed said its latest survey of business conditions around the country, compiled by its 12 regional banks, indicated "additional signs of slowing growth in some areas." 
 It reported that business activity had slowed in five regions -- Atlanta, Cleveland, Dallas, Philadelphia and Richmond, Va. -- while other areas indicated that growth was continuing at about the same moderate pace.
The Fed said that retail spending had softened in some parts of the country and that the outlook was "a little less positive" for the tourism industry. A slowdown was also indicated in home sales and construction activity generally.
The central bank survey found little evidence that rising energy prices or continued tight labor markets were causing overall inflation pressures to accelerate.
The latest survey of economic activity, compiled from information gathered before Oct. 23, will be used by Fed policy makers when they meet on Nov. 15 to decide whether interest rates should be changed.
The views expressed in the report, known as the beige book for the color of its cover, will probably reinforce the view of most economists that the Fed will leave rates alone, convinced that six rate increases from June 1999 to May of this year have achieved the desired aim of slowing economic growth to keep inflation under control.
In another report today, the National Association of Purchasing Management said activity in manufacturing contracted in October for a third consecutive month, with its index dropping to 48.3. A reading above 50 on the index indicates growth in manufacturing, while a reading below that level indicates a slowdown.
Not all reports released today showed weaker activity. The Commerce Department said construction spending increased 2.4 percent in September, the biggest gain in 10 months, reflecting strength in home remodeling, office building and government projects. The gains pushed spending to an annual rate of $819.3 billion, the second-highest level on record. The rise in construction spending was the biggest since a 2.6 percent gain in November 1999.
The September increase reflected a 2.1 percent rise in private construction, led by a 3.4 percent surge in nonresidential activity. Office building soared 6.2 percent, and gains were also registered in the construction of factories, hotels and hospitals.
Residential activity rose 1.1 percent, with all the gain coming from a 6.4 percent rise in home remodeling.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
Economics as the Path to Foreign Policy

BYLINE: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR 

 BODY:
DAVE H. WILLIAMS, the new chairman of the Foreign Policy Association, grins when asked if he can name the political leaders of Taiwan, India, Pakistan or Chechnya.
"No," Mr. Williams, an investment banker, answers without batting an eye, "I cannot." 
 (You may recall the incident a year ago, which seems like light-years in campaign time, when Gov. George W. Bush flubbed a similar pop quiz.)
It's not that Mr. Williams finds foreign policy or unfamiliar leaders dull. On the contrary, he wants to know how well various countries are run. What about the names? "I can always look it up; I don't need to clutter my brain with that."
His interest in the subject dawned after he graduated from the University of Texas in 1956 with a degree in chemical engineering and joined the Navy. He spent three years aboard the U.S.S. Maury, mapping the bottom of the Atlantic. The mapping aided the placement of listening devices that eavesdropped on prowling Soviet submarines, and monitored the plop of test rockets fired from Cape Canaveral.
If you are thinking his interest in foreign affairs grew out of steamy port calls, you're wrong.
"Some of the islands in the south Atlantic were not the most exotic liberty ports," he says.
But the Navy fertilized his awareness of a wider world that multiplied in tandem with his four decades as an investment banker in New York City. (There was an intermittent stop at Harvard Business School for an M.B.A. in 1961.) The importance of things foreign in his field intensified from 1977 to 1999, his years as the chairman and chief executive of Alliance Capital Management, a money-management firm.
"There is probably less interest in foreign affairs from the standpoint of whether we are going to have a nuclear war," he says, "but probably more interest from the standpoint of business and commerce."
Groups like the Foreign Policy Association have found the appeal of what they do (and hence donations) fading along with the cold war and fear of Communist domination. Conversely, businessmen have needed to learn more about foreign countries leaping into competing markets.
"Whether we like it or not, that is where a lot of opportunity for American business has come from and looks to be in the future," Mr. Williams says.
His desk doesn't exactly radiate power banker, or perhaps not the Hollywood version. It is too messy, for one, the note pads and reports jumbled with stuff like a little red doll from a granddaughter and a chunk of the flight deck from the U.S.S. Intrepid, a souvenir of helping underwrite New York City's Military Salute Week last June.
The office walls are hung with prints by W.P.A. artists from the 1930's, part of a collection of 6,000 amassed by Mr. Williams and his wife, Reba White Williams. The couple gave several hundred such works by African-American artists to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, on whose board Mr. Williams sits.
HE retains something of a trim, military bearing, speaking and dressing in a quiet, understated way. Now 68, though he looks younger and says he tries to run 20 to 30 minutes a day no matter where in the world he is, he stepped aside last year from making the day-to-day decisions at Alliance, but he remains chairman. Alliance is is now a subsidiary of a French insurance giant, Axa Group; there is a miniature French tricolor amid the clutter.
Which leads us back to the Foreign Policy Association. He has been on its board for 10 years, first drawn there when Alliance wanted to open an office in India to arrange such things as mutual fund transactions in rupees. Mr. Williams found attending association meetings on policy changes emerging from New Delhi's tangled bureaucracy easier than trekking to the subcontinent.
The association is frankly not the most high-profile foreign-policy group going. It was started after World War I to help familiarize Americans with all sides of international problems. It is best known for its Great Decisions Program, in which small groups scattered around the country, especially students, debate policy papers the association produces with names like "The Euro's Challenge to the Dollar: King Kong versus Godzilla?"
Mr. Williams's main goal during his tenure is to extend the association's reach through the Internet, specifically by pumping up its $3.5 million annual budget. He may not know the names of foreign leaders quite like he knows fund-raising.
He was chairman of a corporate fund-raising event at the Met in 1994 that raised nearly $1 million in one night. During the current election cycle, Mr. Williams says, he raised up to $250,000 for the Republican Party, most of it for George W. Bush, but some for Rick Lazio as well. (He and his wife were major supporters of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani until 1998, when Mrs. Williams famously resigned as president of the city's Art Commission after repeated skirmishing with the parks commissioner, Henry J. Stern, over the design of public stuff like yardarms on flagpoles.)
Mr. Williams finds the current emphasis on foreign policy in the New York Senate campaign dubious.
"They get more simplified in a campaign; there is polarization that wouldn't be there but for courting voters," he says. "Silly season really applies to the discussion of foreign policy in a campaign."

HEADLINE: Why West's Billions Failed to Give Russia a Robust Economy

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
Western powers gave tens of billions of dollars in aid to Russia with no comprehensive strategy, and, at least partly as a result, the programs failed to bring about the desired capitalist transition there, a Congressional study has concluded.
The study, by the nonpartisan General Accounting Office, raises questions about what has arguably been the highest foreign policy priority of the United States: making sure Russia did not become hostile after the collapse of Communism in 1991. Many Clinton administration officials supported a huge amount of international aid and a "big bang" approach to change in which Russia was encouraged to sell state companies rapidly and overhaul banks as a way of making the nation both capitalist and democratic -- and of ensuring that Communists could never regain control of the economy. 
 A cumulative $66 billion in aid from the United States, Europe and the leading international lending agencies did prevent Communists from returning to power and kept the nation from descending into anarchy. But the aid programs failed to build robust capitalist institutions or produce sustained economic growth in Russia, which produces roughly one-third less now than it did a decade ago, the report says.
The accounting office review said donors did not coordinate programs sufficiently and tended to distribute money hurriedly.
"While the worst fears of the early transition period, such as anarchy or return to Communist rule, have not been realized, Russia's economic decline has been more severe and its recovery slower than anticipated," the report says.
The report seems likely to offer support for both sides in the continuing battle over Russia policy. It gives ammunition to Republican critics who say the Clinton administration and the leading aid agencies squandered billions in Russia while tolerating widespread corruption. But it suggests that the goal of stabilizing a former foe still seems valid and places much of the blame for the failure of aid on Russia itself.
Russia has been plagued by corruption, a rebellious Parliament, heavy turnover among government ministers and limited grass-roots support for capitalist changes. Moreover, a new economic elite prevented many changes from taking hold. Local support for change is a prerequisite, the report says.
The report notes that the Group of 7 wealthy nations tried to coordinate Western aid strategy in the early 1990's, but adds that the collective effort soon dissolved. That left the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and individual nations to pursue aid programs largely independently, with varying aims and mixed results.
An even bigger failure may have been Western support for a major privatization scheme in the mid-1990's, the report notes. The "loans for shares" program put many of the nation's most productive enterprises in the hands of a small elite. But analysts say that state assets were effectively stolen during that process, and that privatization brought few benefits to the overall economy.
James A. Leach, an Iowa Republican who is chairman of the House Banking Committee and first asked for the study of Russian aid, said it shows that aid was "worse than wasted."
The Clinton administration, which responded to the Congressional report in a letter, said the main conclusions were balanced, agreeing that a central problem was Russia's own failure to embrace change.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC SCENE;
The U.S. tax system is discouraging married women from working.

BYLINE: By Virginia Postrel; This column appears here every Thursday. Virginia Postrel is the editor at large of Reason magazine and the author of "The Future and Its Enemies: The Growing Conflict Over Creativity, Enterprise, and Progress." Four economic analysts -- Ms. Postrel, Jeff Madrick, Alan B. Krueger and Hal R. Varian -- rotate as contributors.

 BODY:
THE single women of "Sex and the City" read the New York Times wedding announcements and mock a bride who was "until recently" employed as an account executive. Now that she's found an investment banker to marry, they scoff, she doesn't have to pretend to be interested in her career. These independent women are contemptuous of such behavior. They're looking for love, not a meal ticket.
But maybe the new Mrs. Investment Banker doesn't deserve their scorn. Maybe she's just a rational "economic woman," responding to incentives. 
 Marriage has kicked her into the highest bracket. With federal, state and Social Security taxes, she's now losing about half of every dollar she earns -- starting with the very first one. You've got to really love your work to do it for half price.
The Census Bureau recently said that both spouses now work in 51 percent of married couples with wives of childbearing age -- the first time that number has surpassed 50 percent since the bureau started tracking it. More wives would work if our progressive income tax structure didn't sock second earners with high marginal rates.
"There is a relationship between taxes and labor-force participation," said Nada Eissa, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley and the National Bureau for Economic Research. "We think it's fairly strong. In fact, we think it's strongest for married women," who are usually the family's secondary earners and are more likely to consider not working outside the home.
Far more than men or single women, married women act like supply siders. Cut their marginal tax rates, and they get jobs. Raise their taxes, and they stay home.
By disproportionately punishing married women's work, the tax system distorts women's personal choices. And by discouraging valuable work, it lowers our overall standard of living.
This is a tax story you won't hear from politicians. The "marriage penalty" debate tends to frame the issue as one of family formation: how does the tax code affect a couple's decision to marry? But marriage isn't primarily an economic decision.
The more pertinent question is how does the tax code affect a married woman's decision to work? There are obvious political reasons not to ask that. Democrats don't want to admit that soak-the-rich taxation wallops working wives, lest they split feminists and redistributionists. And Republicans don't want to admit that cutting taxes will lead more married women to get jobs, lest they split economic libertarians and social conservatives. So everyone stays mum.
But the empirical evidence is pretty clear. Tax rates are a feminist issue.
Professor Eissa has studied how the tax bite affects behavior at both ends of the income distribution. In a 1995 paper for the National Bureau of Economic Research, she looked at how married women responded to the Tax Reform Act of 1986. That law created a natural experiment. It chopped the top marginal tax rate to 28 percent, from 50 percent, but had only a minor impact on middle-income taxpayers. That gave her an opportunity to compare the responses of different groups of wives before and after the change.
Before it, the women in the 99th percentile of family income (the top 1 percent) on average paid about 52 cents in taxes on the first dollar they earned. In some states, a wife who earned less than $30,000 a year could have paid in taxes as much as 70 cents of the first dollar she earned.
The 1986 law flattened federal rates and, as a result, slashed the average marginal rate faced by such wives to 38 percent. The percentage of these married women who worked jumped from 46 percent to 55 percent -- a 19 percent increase -- and those who had jobs increased their hours 13 percent.
To make sure this increase was caused by the tax change rather than other trends, Professor Eissa compared it with the behavior of women in the 75th percentile, who got a much smaller tax cut. Their labor force participation and hours worked also rose, but by significantly less -- a 7 percent jump in those working and a 9 percent increase in hours worked.
Since 1986, rates have become steeper, as Washington pursued increased revenue and lost interest in supply-side incentives. "There's been less discussion of the behavioral effects of taxation," Professor Eissa said.
Policy makers have, however, tried to reform the incentives faced by poor women. And here, too, Professor Eissa finds they've managed to prejudice married women against work. The 1993 tax bill expanded the Earned-Income Tax Credit, a subsidy that goes to the working poor and is administered through the tax-filing system. The credit is intended partly to counteract the discouraging effects of Social Security payroll taxes, which hit wage earners at their first dollar.
Like the rest of the tax system, the credit's sliding scale applies to households rather than individuals. One spouse's income is enough to qualify for the subsidy, and the credit is phased out as total family income increases. So if a husband earned $11,650 in 1997, his family of four got $3,656 from the earned-income credit, assuming his wife did not work. For every dollar she earned, the credit was reduced 21 cents -- in effect, a marginal tax rate of 21 percent on top of Social Security and state taxes.
In a 1998 paper, Professor Eissa and her colleague Hillary Williamson Hoynes found that the expanded tax credit did increase married men's labor force participation. But married women were 5 percent less likely to work if their family incomes were high enough that anything they earned would cancel out some of the credit. And if they did work, the tax credit led them to reduce their hours 20 percent.
By paying one spouse to work and reducing the payments as household income rises, Professors Eissa and Hoynes wrote, the tax credit "is effectively subsidizing married mothers to stay at home." It's possible that's what policy makers intended. But it's more likely that they didn't fully consider how married women would react to what amounted to high marginal tax rates.
That's a pervasive problem throughout the tax system. Once a woman is married, it seems, the tax laws don't really want her to work.

HEADLINE: U.S. Auto Sales Sag, Another Slowdown Sign

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 1

 BODY:
Not even aggressive discounting by automakers could lift sales of new cars and light trucks last month, and bloated inventories of unsold models have led to the closing for a week of 8 of the nation's 55 auto assembly plants.
Auto sales are the first important economic indicator to come out at the beginning of each month, and today's results were another sign that growth in the American economy has been slowing somewhat recently. Although sales have leveled off at a high level by historical standards, they are increasingly being sustained by ever more generous rebates and low-rate loans, rather than by strong consumer demand. 
 In early October, General Motors began offering zero-interest loans for up to five years to help customers buy its minivans, midsize sport utility vehicles and some midsize cars. It was the only large automaker to report a rise in sales last month, with an increase of 6.5 percent. DaimlerChrysler, Ford Motor and foreign automakers have been helping their buyers with low-rate loans to a lesser extent -- such programs are costly after the Federal Reserve's six increases in short-term interest rates since June 1999.
The pace of sales slowed sharply from September, even after adjusting for seasonal differences, and was little changed from October of last year, even though that had been one of the industry's less strong months in 1999. Estimating sales for three small automakers that did not report sales today, Mark Cornelius, an auto consultant in West Olive, Mich., said that the overall industry's sales appeared to have fallen roughly 0.8 percent from the year-earlier period.
Automakers are having trouble selling models not covered by various discount programs. This week, G.M. has closed 3 of its 25 assembly plants in North America: two factories in Lansing, Mich., that make small cars and a factory in Orion, Mich., that makes full-size cars. DaimlerChrysler has quietly closed this week 7 of its 16 factories in North America, including two plants that make sport utility vehicles, two that make pickup trucks, and one each that makes small cars, large cars and full-size vans.
Jamie Jameson, DaimlerChrysler's vice president for North American sales and marketing, said that other automakers might also need to close their factories briefly because of rising inventories. "You may see more of those before it's over," he said.
G.M. and DaimlerChrysler each said that the closings were only scheduled to last one week. Many of the factories are in Midwestern states that are expected to be crucial in next Tuesday's election: in addition to the three G.M. factories in Michigan, one of the DaimlerChrysler factories is in Michigan, another is in Ohio, a third is in Missouri and a fourth is in Illinois. Two more are in Canada, and the last in Delaware.
Under the automakers' contracts with the United Automobile Workers union, workers continue to receive 90 percent of their base pay when temporarily laid off. But because many workers have nearly doubled their pay with extensive overtime for the last seven years, this could still represent a small financial setback for many families, as well as a warning that the economy might not be as strong as it once seemed. Under a new provision negotiated last year, the automakers' employees will be given a holiday on Election Day for the first time this year, and the U.A.W. has begun an elaborate effort to make sure that workers do go to the polls and vote Democratic on their day off.
Jim Betty, the president of the union local at a DaimlerChrysler pickup truck factory that is closed this week in Warren, Mich., said that he doubted the factory closings would affect his workers' votes. "They're not blaming anyone -- we've been on a run for 10 years and things are getting slow, we've been telling them that for months," he said.
Mr. Jameson said that DaimlerChrysler had chosen this week to close the factories without considering any possible political implications.
Ford will close two Canadian factories for a week beginning next Monday, but the company said this decision did not reflect weak sales. The company said it was shutting the factories to free up side air bag modules for minivans and large cars, which the company is replacing in large numbers at dealerships after three recent incidents in which the air bags deployed while vehicles were being assembled.
Della DiPietro, a company spokeswoman, said that Ford had begun using a new kind of air bag module that caused the problem. Only 1,600 were sold before the problem was detected; these have been recalled, and Ford is not aware of incidents involving accidental air bag inflation on the road, she said.
Some of the auto industry's most profitable models, notably full-size pickup trucks, did not sell well last month. General Motors announced today that it would reduce further its already discounted interest rates on loans for full-size pickups, while Ford said that it was studying what to do about an 11 percent drop last month in its sales of big F-series pickups. Separately, DaimlerChrysler said that it would begin discounting leases on its new minivans -- a sign of difficulty for a freshly redesigned vehicle.
Ford said that sales dropped 16 percent for Ford Explorer sport utility vehicles. But overall sales of Ford sport utility vehicles nonetheless rose 11 percent, as some customers appeared to have switched to other Ford models. Ford attributed the decline in Explorer sales to bad publicity from the deaths in Explorers equipped with Firestone tires; the decision of some customers to wait for the introduction of a completely redesigned Explorer early next year; a shortage of Explorers in some markets because Ford stopped production at a factory for three weeks to make replacement tires available; and the introduction of the slightly smaller Ford Escape sport utility vehicle, which competes to some extent with the Explorer.
Ford's overall sales were down 6.2 percent, excluding its purchase of Land Rover. Nissan Motor's sales were down 3.6 percent; Honda Motor's, down 5.6 percent; and Toyota Motor's, down 5.7 percent. DaimlerChrysler's sales fell 8.4 percent excluding Mercedes, and dropped 7.4 percent including Mercedes.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: OUTSIDERS;
Observing, Yet Shunning, Political System

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: TULSA, Okla., Nov. 1

 BODY:
Outside the Shady Rest tourist cabins, a relic of the 1930's flaking away on old Route 66, Charles W. Murphy and his low-rent neighbors along this margin of the American dream broke the seal on a half pint of Kentucky Deluxe whiskey.
"We are the people, you know," said Mr. Murphy, taking the lead in an animated, garrulous midday gathering that amounted to an antidote to all the ponderous focus-group preenings of this campaign season. 
 "But on Election Day, I'll be sitting in that room," Mr. Murphy announced, pointing at his small gray tourist cabin standing atilt near a chained-up dog.
"I'll be watching the TV votes, but I will not vote and for a very good reason," said Mr. Murphy, a grizzled, amiable man waxing fierce as his opening nip of "Ky-Dee" at the motor court picnic table. "I never saw a politician come anywhere near all of us living here in what is just Bum's Rush, Okla., the cheapest place in town. Never heard one knock on my door like they do and say, 'Can I have your vote?' "
Mr. Murphy nodded firmly at his sense of being politically unnecessary. It is his justification for not partaking in a campaign in which manifold slices and slivers of the focus-grouped public have been targeted for the candidates' finely honed slogans.
The dozen tenants of Shady Rest amount to a nonfocus group, but a talkative one that registers a dire frustration with politics driven by their subsistence here in $80-a-week shelter. On one level, they are just another part of the nonvoting American majority. But on another, they marshal the added excuse for not voting of being down and out, not up and coming.
"The only change in my life across eight years of Clinton was the taxes kept rising on the cigarettes that give me comfort," summarized Janet McFarland, the night clerk at the Gateway Motor Inn. She emerged from cabin No. 11 in her morning kimono, passing up the whiskey but not the political discussion.
One by one, other residents appeared over three hours of disorganized but heartfelt socializing. Like the ordinary humans dramatized by Eugene O'Neill, the group conceded life's seediness even as they toasted their common wit and fate.
"We're like a family here," Mrs. McFarland said.
"And I'm the Pa," exulted Mr. Murphy, a 62-year retiree who described a roustabout career from the Korean War to silver mining to pool shark. He sounded like O'Neill's Hickey easing the underclass wait for life's betterment by suddenly brandishing a book of his poetry writings. "Here's one: 'Freedom is just another word you often hear/ From people in plastic houses they hold so dear.' "
Mrs. McFarland's husband, Jim, emerged on a bicycle from the trailer-truck racket of Route 66, after a job hunt in the booming economy he hears about. "The position at McDonald's was already filled," he announced. "But I've got friends in other places."
The gathering was as up to speed as other Americans on the investment proposal for Social Security and on Al Gore's kissing his wife for votes. As much as they clearly knew about the candidates' basic differences, they insisted that politicians could never convincingly get past the burned-out "welcome" sign by the roadside weeds.
"I used to listen to the politicians a lot on the radio," said Louise Hopkins, who showed up fresh from a court hearing in a drunken driving case and plopped a six-pack of beer on the discussion table.
"The politics now seems like the rich are getting richer, like they say, and the poor poorer," said Ms. Hopkins, concocting a boilermaker of beer and the Ky-Dee. "I'm entitled to a little fun, right?" she defensively told her friends concerned at the drink.
As they talked, Ms. Hopkins, Mr. Murphy and others spoke to one of the campaign's big issues, the inability to afford all the medication they need for their mounting ills. But they insisted the candidates' talk of this problem was just that. "Clinton had eight years and didn't solve it," Mr. Murphy said.
Mr. McFarland gently observed, "The last time a politician really excited me was John F. Kennedy asking what we can do for the country."
His wife interrupted with a question: If Jesse Ventura can be governor of Minnesota "why can't Hulk Hogan be president?" There were smiles but no outright dismissal of the notion.
The youngest tenant, 18-year-old William Cooley, arrived back from his job as a dishwasher at Ollie's Restaurant to await his father, who was newly released from jail after a domestic dispute. "It's very important to vote," Mr. Cooley declared, bucking the group consensus. "I have my goal -- a diploma and a trade," the young man said in an aside. "It's not a bad little shindig here, but there are better places."
At the common table, tenants pursued politics as the American majority does: as a provocative topic but an uninviting endeavor. The poetic relief from Mr. Murphy deepened with the level of the Ky-Dee bottle. "I'd rather knock at the door of heaven," he darkly intoned to his neighbors, "than live in this pit of hell."
Not really, he quickly amended, brightening as he offered a nonfocus group conclusion worthy of Shady Rest: "Bush blows smoke, Gore rides Clinton's shirttails, and the race is going to be close."

HEADLINE: U.S. Proposes Changes in Electricity Marketing in California

BYLINE: By NEELA BANERJEE 

 BODY:
Citing the "seriously flawed" nature of the California electricity market, which was plagued with price spikes and brownouts this summer, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission proposed changes yesterday in the sale and pricing of electricity intended to overhaul deregulation in the state.
The commission's review was set off by widespread outrage after consumers in San Diego saw their electricity bills triple this summer. 
 Once viewed as a pioneer in developing an efficient electricity market, California is now thought to embody the many problems that can arise from deregulation. States that are taking a go-slow approach to deregulation are sure to follow closely the changes proposed for California.
Commission and industry analysts warned that the proposed measures, which would affect 85 percent to 90 percent of the California market, were but a first step to undoing the complicated knot of factors that led to high prices. They said the measures were not a guarantee that prices would be lower next summer.
"Some people want, to use a psychobabble word, closure on all this," said Robert Michaels, a deregulation expert and professor of economics at California State University at Fullerton. "But the California institutions are so complex that no one measure by F.E.R.C. will resolve it. The process will go on for a long time."
The commission oversees the progress of deregulation across the country although states determine the specific conditions. The commission will accept commentary on the proposals and issue a binding order in December, a spokeswoman said.
California electricity prices rocketed last summer largely because consumer demand for power outstripped supply. As a result, the commission warned, California officials will have to find ways to build more power plants and transmission lines.
The commission's recommendations center on the sale of power through institutions set up as part of California's deregulation process. Many investor-owned utilities no longer generate power, but buy it on the wholesale market. Currently, utilities can buy and sell power only through the California Power Exchange, a state-run electricity marketplace. The commission has proposed eliminating that requirement so utilities can shop around for long-term electricity contracts, a move most analysts welcomed.
"This gives us more flexibility to obtain affordable power for customers," said Shawn Cooper, a spokesman for the PG&E Corporation, the major utility in Northern California. "Right now, we're limited on the energy product we can buy."
Turning to the exchange, Mr. Cooper said, "is like going to a car lot and being able to buy only one or two models."
But experts said the other proposals might be easily thwarted by power-generating companies seeking top dollar. The commission proposed, for example, to lower the price cap for a megawatt hour to $150 from $250. Power suppliers that bid over $150 would be paid their price but would be required to explain the reasons for their bid. Such a system, some experts say, would prove a sizable loophole.
James Bushnell, a research associate with the Energy Institute of the University of California, said, "I think a clever engineer at any power company could come up with a whole bunch of reasons for whatever they want their costs to be."

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
Concern for the Economy Upstate

BYLINE: By Randal C. Archibold 

 BODY:
This is a new 30-second commercial that Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign began broadcasting yesterday.
 
PRODUCER -- Callahan Creative 

ON THE SCREEN -- A series of street interviews, intercut twice with text reading "Who is the right choice for New York?" and "Hillary has a plan to create 200,000 jobs."
 
THE SCRIPT -- FIRST WOMAN: "My husband and I have five children, and three out of five moved away to get jobs. We're still hurting here, and I don't think Mr. Lazio has helped." FIRST MAN: "He's really out of touch." SECOND MAN: "More concerned about downstate than upstate." SECOND WOMAN: "It's important to have a very detailed, economic growth plan for upstate." THIRD MAN: " Hillary has shown a definite interest in the upstate New York area." THIRD WOMAN: "She's about helping people who need help." FOURTH MAN: "I'm a registered Republican, and I think Hillary is what we need in this area."
 
ACCURACY -- Mrs. Clinton, the Democratic nominee, unveiled an economic plan in February to address the needs of upstate New York, where jobs have been increasing but not at the same pace as in New York City and its suburbs. Mrs. Clinton's opponent, Representative Rick A. Lazio, does not have a plan aimed at upstate New York. But he has an overall economic plan of tax cuts that he contends will spur economic growth statewide. Both candidates also promote the idea of cultivating high-tech businesses in areas that have lost manufacturing and other industrial jobs. Mr. Lazio has drawn some criticism for being more optimistic about the upstate economy..
 
SCORECARD -- The man-in-the-street format gives the ad a grass-roots feel, of hearing real people's concerns. And Mrs. Clinton strikes a chord -- the loss of the upstate region's young people -- that is likely to resonate. But the fact that the upstate economy generally is improving by most measures is overlooked, and, though he has not released a plan specifically aimed at the region, the ad wrongfully leaves the impression Mr. Lazio has not addressed economic concerns at all. Randal C. Archibold

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Revlon to Close 3 Plants As Loss Beats Forecasts
After posting its eighth consecutive quarterly loss, Revlon, the cosmetics giant controlled by Ronald O. Perelman, announced yet another round of cutbacks. The moves include the closing of three plants, which will result in the layoffs of 1,115 employees.
 Excluding a charge for reorganization, the company lost $12.6 million, or 25 cents a share, which was slightly better than Wall Street forecasts of a loss of 32 cents a share but still far short of the kind of turnaround numbers that spur investor interest. Page C6. 

Newell Rubbermaid Chief Resigns
Rattled by disheartening earnings and faced with ebbing investor confidence, Newell Rubbermaid, the maker of Levelor blinds and Rolodex office supplies, announced that John J. McDonough, the chief executive esteemed for his vision but criticized for failing to carry it out smoothly, had resigned. C8.
 
Stocks Fall in Bout of Profit-Taking
Blue-chip stocks and technology issues fell as investors took profits. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 71.67 points, or 0.7 percent, to 10,899.47. The Nasdaq composite index slipped 36.24 points, or 1.1 percent, to 3,333.39, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 8.18 points, to 1,421.22. C10.
 
Complication in Seagram Unit Sale
Seagram faces potential hurdles in the sale of its wine and spirits business, people close to the talks said. Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, the buyout firm that owns the G. H. Mumm and Perrier-Jouet champagne brands, for which Seagram holds distribution rights, is expected to object to the transfer of those rights to any company that owns champagne labels. C6.
 
Chief of Covad Is Stepping Down
The chief executive of Covad Communications, Robert E. Knowling Jr., quit. Charles McMinn, a board member and one of the company's founders, will serve on an interim basis while Covad searches for a new chief. C6.
 
Fed Sees Evidence of Slowdown
The economy grew moderately in October, but many parts of the country reported evidence of slowing activity in critical sectors like retail sales and housing, the Federal Reserve said in its latest survey of business conditions. In another report, the National Association of Purchasing Management said activity in manufacturing contracted in October for a third consecutive month, but the Commerce Department said construction spending increased 2.4 percent in September. C6.
 
AOL-Time Warner Deal Still Backed
Despite a drop in the stock price of America Online, many Time Warner shareholders and analysts still see a merger of the companies as strategically sound. Market Place. C8.
 
Changes Urged for California Power
Citing the "seriously flawed" nature of California's electricity market, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission proposed changes in the sale and pricing of electricity intended to revamp deregulation in the state. A21.
 
Some Women Taxed Out of Jobs
Far more than men or single women, married women act like supply siders. Cut their marginal tax rates, and they get jobs. Raise their taxes, and they stay home. By disproportionately punishing married women's work, the tax system distorts women's personal choices. Virginia Postrel: Economic Scene. C2.

HEADLINE: Chief Who Put Newell Rubbermaid Together Quits

BYLINE: By GREG WINTER 

 BODY:
A troubled merger and an inability to raise prices have combined to topple the chief executive of Newell Rubbermaid Inc., the maker of Levelor blinds and Rolodex office supplies.
Rattled by a year of disheartening earnings and faced with ebbing investor confidence, Newell Rubbermaid announced yesterday that John J. McDonough, the chief executive esteemed for his vision but criticized for failing to carry it out smoothly, had resigned. 
 The announcement came one week after Mr. McDonough warned analysts to scale back their forecasts for the third time this year, a move that helped drive Newell's stock to its lowest level since 1994.
Once regarded as a stalwart engine of predictable growth, Newell long benefited from an expansive line of relatively inconspicuous products that weathered the ups and downs in consumer spending through much of the 1990's. But the company is staggering under the weight of its $5.8 billion purchase last year of Rubbermaid Inc., a problem-plagued company that has proved exceedingly difficult to turn around. The deal demonstrates just how costly some mergers can be.
Newell has also been grappling with its dwindling influence over what large retailers like Wal-Mart charge for its products, an increasingly common difficulty for consumer products companies that rely on routine price increases for growth.
The problem has been particularly pronounced for Newell because many of its plastic products, from dish trays to wheelbarrows, use resin, a raw material whose price rises with the cost of oil. Without the ability to dictate store prices, the company has been unable to pass these higher costs onto consumers.
During his three-year tenure as chief executive, Mr. McDonough tried to bolster Newell's bargaining strength with stores by shifting the company's tight focus on the United States to overseas markets, where many retailers have expanded in recent years. Since 1998, Newell has made sweeping purchases of picture frame, window dressing, office products and hardware manufacturers in Europe, continuing the acquisitive strategy the company has pursued at home for decades.
With its widely recognized name, Rubbermaid offered Newell a chance to enhance its overseas presence significantly. But unlike the small companies swallowed in Europe, most of which had annual revenues of $100 million to $300 million, Rubbermaid was nearly three-fourths the size of Newell at the time, boasting $2.4 billion in sales, compared with $3.3 billion for its suitor.
Many analysts derided the $5.8 billion sales price as too high, warning that Rubbermaid's sagging profit margins would take too long to reverse. But Mr. McDonough hailed the acquisition as "a terrific strategic fit" and set about repairing Rubbermaid's blemished image as an unreliable manufacturer, prone to disappoint retailers with late or incomplete deliveries.
The rehabilitation proved more difficult than anticipated. After replacing many Rubbermaid officials with Newell executives, leaving a new corps of executives to run Newell's own divisions, analysts say, the company became distracted, losing sight of some of its more established brands. In the quarter that ended Sept. 30, Rubbermaid sales fell 1 percent, while Newell's home decor division was flat, and its cookware unit, which includes Calphalon and Mirro, grew a mere 2 percent.
When the company announced in a conference call last week that its fourth-quarter earnings would be 43 to 48 cents a share, instead of the 55 cents that many analysts had expected, the mounting frustration with the company was palpable.
