HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
Gore and Bush Trade Jabs On Pensions and Spending

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 1

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore warned elderly and middle-age voters today in a campaign sweep across central Florida that Gov. George W. Bush's Social Security proposals would threaten their retirement and the country's economic well-being.
"Join with me," Mr. Gore told his audience at a civic center this morning in Kissimmee, near Orlando, "and we won't make promises just to break them. We'll keep our promises to the seniors who gave us everything that we have today." 
 Mr. Gore, who spent the day traversing the crucial Interstate 4 corridor, devoted most of an address in Kissimmee to attacking Mr. Bush's plan, which would let individuals invest part of their Social Security payroll taxes in stocks and bonds. Mr. Gore restated his position that the Bush plan would remove $1 trillion from the Social Security system, a sum that he said would be needed to make payments to current and future recipients.
"Instead of a system where everyone's in it together, the Bush plan would turn Social Security into a grab bag where everyone is out for himself," he said. "You might call it social insecurity. And that's wrong for our values."
Mr. Gore emphasized that today's Social Security decisions should matter not only to elderly Americans but also to middle-age workers. That reflects the sense of Gore strategists that Mr. Bush's Social Security proposals can be used to sow broad doubt about his competency.
"It cuts a couple of different ways," said Carter Eskew, a top Gore adviser. "It's both a pocketbook issue and a readiness issue."
With six days to go before Election Day, campaign activity in Florida is as intense as officials in either party can remember. Mr. Gore and his running mate, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, campaigned separately across the state today, hitting four media markets between them. Mr. Lieberman, who visited two retirement communities, a mall, a fire station, and a sheriff's station, and held rallies in Boca Raton and Daytona Beach, emphasized the importance of Florida to the Democrats' hopes on Tuesday.
The vice president's central message focused on Social Security. Besides attacking the Bush plan, Mr. Gore promoted his own, which would dedicate nearly all the Social Security surplus to paying the $3.4 trillion national debt within a dozen years.
That, theoretically, would free general tax revenues equal to the amount of interest saved from debt reduction -- $250 billion a year by 2016 -- that could be used to extend Social Security's solvency to 2054, from the current projection of 2037.
"For 45-year-olds today," Mr. Gore said, "Social Security would be secure, without any cuts or changes, until their 100th birthdays."
Mr. Gore's campaign is convinced that the argument -- along with his stands on Medicare and the environment -- is crucial to winning Florida's 25 electoral votes, and that those votes may determine the election.
He returned here today with recent polls contradictory. One tracking poll conducted for Reuters and MSNBC shows Mr. Gore with a lead of 12 percentage points in the state. A Los Angeles Times poll taken from Oct. 27 through 29, meanwhile, gave Mr. Bush a four-point advantage. Gore aides and state Democratic Party officials said they believed Mr. Gore had a lead of two to four points.
Mr. Bush, who took a bus tour across the state last week, is tentatively scheduled to return this weekend, and his running mate, Dick Cheney, traveled to four Florida cities today. Mr. Bush's parents -- former President George Bush and his wife, Barbara -- joined their son Jeb, the state's governor, at a rally in Orlando on Tuesday night.
Mr. Gore's aides do not preclude the possibility that the vice president will return for one last visit in the final two days of campaigning.
Both parties also have huge ground operations under way, involving millions of phone calls and mailings, and TV broadcasts are punctuated morning and night by streams of political commercials, many of them focusing on Social Security.
"In many ways," Mr. Gore said today, "Florida is the key to this race."
Mr. Lieberman made the same point to a crowd of 4,000 people at Florida Atlantic University in Boca Raton. He paraphrased the song "New York, New York," by singing, "If we can win it here, we'll win it everywhere, it's up to you, Florida."
But plenty of Floridians remain undecided. One of them, Jim Tuten, a 46-year-old systems engineer, came to hear Mr. Gore at an afternoon rally in a downtown park in Tampa. A true swing voter who supported both Ronald Reagan and Bill Clinton, Mr. Tuten said he was tempted to vote Democratic because he wanted the country to stay its economic course.
But he said he still did not have much of a feel for Mr. Gore. "I'm not sure about Gore because he's really been behind the scenes," Mr. Tuten said. "Other than the screwups he's had, like with the Internet, you didn't hear that much about him."
Mr. Tuten also said he was concerned that both parties were too eager to squander the federal surplus. "Each party has 50 different ways to spend it," he said.
Here in Tampa, where the singer Jimmy Buffett warmed up a substantial crowd for Mr. Gore, the vice president focused on environmental issues. "Everyone in Tampa Bay knows that Florida depends on clean beaches and clean air," he said. "While my opponent refuses to take a clear stand on this, I will. So let me pledge to you again, I will ban all new oil and gas drilling off the coast of Florida and California."
And Mr. Gore again used his economic policies -- in this case his Social Security plan -- to suggest that he would have the backbone to stand up to special interests while Mr. Bush would not.
"Sometimes," he said, "a president has to stand up and say no so that our families can have a better life. I'm not running for president to go along and get along at any price. The presidency is really not just a popularity contest. If you want someone who smiles and looks the other way while special interests have their way, then I'm not your guy."
 
In His Own Words
AL GORE
 
Remarks yesterday in Kissimmee, Fla.:
 
"Instead of a system where everyone is in it together, the Bush plan would turn Social Security into a grab bag where everyone is out for himself. You might call it social insecurity. And that's wrong for our values. It's also wrong for our economy. Even though he has promised it to two different groups of people, we still don't know where the trillion dollars comes from in the first place. The money is nowhere to be found in his budget.
 One of the authors of Governor Bush's proposal wrote that Social Security would start borrowing heavily to make the program solvent under their approach. The borrowing would actually come to $3 trillion. In other words, under the other side's plan, according to one of its authors, Social Security would go bankrupt fairly soon and then go into massive deficits, competing for investment capital that is needed elsewhere in the economy, all while many of today's seniors are still counting on Social Security and a strong economy, both of which would be jeopardized under his plan.
Under our plan, Social Security will remain financially sound for more than 50 years . . . Join with me and we won't make new promises just to break them. We'll keep our promises to the seniors who gave us everything that we have today.
Seniors are not the only people who are counting on a secure retirement. And if you'll forgive me if I have a special place in my heart for middle-aged workers. They're working for two or three decades and have every intention of working some more. . . .
Today's middle-aged workers are the heart of our work force and the heart of family life in America. They're the ones who are often forced to choose between the needs of their children and the needs of their aging parents. They're the ones who bear the burdens, pay the taxes and live the American dream. And they should not have to worry whether Social Security will be there for them when they retire.
Under our plan, we therefore make the responsible choices by balancing the budget, paying down the debt and using the interest savings to strengthen Social Security."

HEADLINE: Yes to Transportation Bonds

 BODY:
New Yorkers will be doing more than electing hundreds of officeholders throughout the state on Tuesday. They will also have an opportunity to approve a $3.8 billion bond issue that, if enacted, would speed improvements in New York City's mass transit system and upgrade highways and rail links crucial to the upstate economy. Incurring new borrowing is not something to be done lightly by a state already heavily burdened by $37 billion in debt. But the projects to be financed by this issue are so crucial that a "yes" vote is merited.
Residents of New York City would reap an especially important advantage from the bond issue. The city's Independent Budget Office estimates that 44 percent of the proceeds would finance improvements in the city. Since the city represents about 40 percent of the state's population and provides about the same portion of its tax revenues, that proportion is a modest bargain. 
 The bond issue would help finance part of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's $17 billion capital plan over the next five years, which is primarily aimed at completing the Long Island Rail Road access to Grand Central Terminal and a new Second Avenue subway from 125th Street to 63rd Street. Both projects are vital to relieving transit congestion in the city. The bond issue would also help finance the State Transportation Department's plans to improve rail lines and highways upstate and to speed development along the Erie Canal. The anemic upstate economy would benefit.
All these schemes have flaws. The M.T.A.'s $17 billion capital plan, for instance, would increase debt service payments and thus put more pressure on the transit fare. To meet transportation needs beyond the reach of this bond issue, the state should do more to tap its budget surpluses, especially now that another $1 billion surplus is expected in the budget for the year under way.
In addressing New York City's needs, the M.T.A. is also spending money to plan for several possibilities, including extension of the Second Avenue subway to lower Manhattan, a rail link from Midtown to La Guardia Airport and extension of the No. 7 subway line from Times Square down to 34th Street and over to the Hudson River, where it would connect with a possible stadium and an expanded Javits Convention Center. As this page has suggested in the past, the No. 7 line may well prove to be a higher priority than the La Guardia link or perhaps even the Second Avenue subway extension, especially if it can be seen to help develop the whole underused area on the West Side south of 42nd Street.
The transportation priorities outlined by Gov. George Pataki, the leaders of the Legislature and the M.T.A. are, in the end, well drawn up and sensitive to the region's needs. We conclude that the bond issue, if enacted, would address needs that are essential to the future economic health of the state.

HEADLINE: Offer of Free Computers for Schools Is Withdrawn

BYLINE: By JOHN SCHWARTZ 

 BODY:
Earlier this year, Plainfield High School in Central Village, Conn., signed up for a free computer lab from the ZapMe Corporation. The highflying company was promising to connect the nation's schools to the Internet, asking only to deliver advertising to the students' computer screens to pay the freight.
Last week, the Plainfield school superintendent got the bill. 
 An e-mail message from a company employee explained that times were tough for ZapMe, which had come under attack as a tool of commercialization in the schools and had experienced a drop in its stock to just over $2 from a high of $13.75. As a result, the superintendent was told, the company was quitting the free-computer business.
Starting in February, the message explained, "there will be a fee charged for the service and equipment." It said the school could go ahead and install the computers, wait until a price list arrived in November before making a decision or make arrangements for ZapMe to pick up the equipment.
"It was quite a shock," said the superintendent, Mary Conway. Her school had spent $4,000 to prepare a room for the computers -- a lot of money for Plainfield, which ranks 161st out of the state's 169 school districts in spending.
ZapMe says it has given millions of students access to the Internet in 2,000 schools nationwide; a total of 15,000 had signed up for the service. At its height last fall, ZapMe's stock was worth half a billion dollars; the company was emblematic of the new economy, a place where good deeds, vision and commerce form a single elegant braid.
Now it has all unraveled: ZapMe says it is refocusing on selling its technologies for high-speed Internet access and services via satellite to business. It says, meanwhile, that it is trying to find ways to keep the school network alive without forcing the schools to pay.
"We are exploring many opportunities," said the company's founder and chief executive, Lance Mortensen, "including -- but not limited to -- partnerships, the outright sale of the network, joint ventures and alternative options to schools that would allow them to keep the labs, which means, obviously, for pay."
The story of ZapMe and schools like Plainfield shows the ripple effects of the dot-com downturn that extend far beyond Silicon Valley and Alley. To its founders, ZapMe had a noble vision defeated by a handful of naysaying activists opposed to any commercialism in schools and ready to jump to conclusions about the company's use of data about the students' computer use. While schools were still eager to sign up, Mr. Mortensen said, the bad publicity worried potential advertisers "about having an association of their brand with our brand."
To its critics, ZapMe represented a bad idea that collapsed under its own weight. Gary Ruskin, director of Commercial Alert, a group affiliated with Ralph Nader that opposes "excessive commercialism" in society, was involved in a public relations war that Mr. Mortensen cites as the key factor in his company's decline. Mr. Ruskin counters that "their business model of violating the privacy of children and forcing them to watch ads was a total flop."
Mr. Mortensen insists that he hopes to keep the service free to the schools through subsidies from business, foundations and government. "We're looking for people to adopt these schools," he said, but noted that ZapMe still had bills to pay. He said the company was spending about $3,000 a month on each of the smaller schools it served to pay off the equipment costs -- typically 5 to 15 computers -- and supply high-speed Internet connections.
"We personally anticipate, through a number of efforts, to get that cost discounted down," he said.
At first, ZapMe, based in San Ramon, Calif., made an offer that thousands of schools found too tempting to pass up: a complete computer lab with PC's, teacher training and access over high-speed satellite connections to a collection of 13,000 child-safe Web sites.
The company insists that while it reserved the contractual right to track students' surfing habits individually, it never gathered anything more than their age, sex and ZIP code -- information it then shared in aggregate form with advertisers. When the company announced a program called ZapPoints, which would have given students points toward prizes while gathering personally identifiable information about them, the outcry was so swift and loud that ZapMe quickly discontinued the idea.
Nancy Willard, a consultant at the University of Oregon's Center for Advanced Technology in Education, said the ZapPoints program was the company's fundamental flaw. "The ZapMe model was going to fail because of the level of commercial intrusion into the schools" required by the ZapPoints program, which was an essential part of reaching profitability, she said.
Mr. Mortensen said the e-mail message that Plainfield received was a mistake. "That's an action by one employee and not the corporation," he said. He did not deny that the company might ask for money to keep the program running but said "there would be no forced issue," since the company could simply pick up the PC's.
"We never gave the computers to the schools" outright, Mr. Mortensen said. And William R. Connon, a Hartford lawyer who represents the Plainfield Township schools, said the ZapMe contract gives the company the right to charge for its services or to take them back.
A half-dozen schools with existing labs contacted by a reporter said they had not heard from ZapMe about the future of their programs. Schools that have not yet received computers are also waiting to hear what ZapMe has in store. William G. Smojver, director of technology and information services for the school district of Waukesha, Wis., near Milwaukee, said he called the company recently to ask about the pending delivery of machines and was told that a letter would be going out soon describing the company's new policy. "We are fairly pessimistic about receiving anything," he said.
George Smith, director of technology for the Green Bay School District in Wisconsin, said he had not yet heard from ZapMe about the 45 computers the company had provided. He did say, however, that technical problems had limited the usefulness of the computer labs. "They can come pick 'em up and take 'em back," Mr. Smith said. "Nobody will shed a tear."

HEADLINE: Ralph Nader's High-Wire Politics

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Nader Sees a Bright Side to a Bush Victory" (news article, Nov. 1): 
 A vote for Ralph Nader is a vote for George W. Bush, and as your article makes clear, Mr. Nader likes it that way.
It is false for Mr. Nader to say that Al Gore and George W. Bush are indistinguishable. They operate at opposite sides of the American mainstream. It is fantasy to think that a Bush administration would, by its conservative excesses, pave the way for a liberal comeback.
To speculate that by promoting political reaction now, one would reap political benefits later is a strategy for disaster. If Mr. Nader thinks people will forget that he has been willing to bring grave harm to this country, he is in for a big surprise.
 
DAVID S. LANDES
Cambridge, Mass., Nov. 1, 2000
 
The writer is professor emeritus of history and economics, Harvard University.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE TEXAS GOVERNOR;
Republican Declares Rival a Throwback on Fiscal Policy

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 1

 BODY:
Gov. George W. Bush sharply attacked Vice President Al Gore today as a Democratic throwback to an old era who would bring the nation "spending without discipline, spending without priorities and spending without an end." 
 With just six days left before Election Day, Mr. Bush stepped up his assault on Mr. Gore, seeking to sever him from the fiscal policies of the Clinton years and the nation's record economic expansion.
"Al Gore's massive spending would mean slower growth and higher taxes," Mr. Bush told thousands of people gathered here in an airport hangar on a foggy, drizzly day. "And it could mean an end to this nation's prosperity."
"These aren't the policies of the 1990's," he shouted hoarsely into a microphone, speaking under a banner proclaiming. "Bringing America Together." "These are the same policies that threatened our economy in the 70's. When Ronald Reagan changed those policies in the 80's, my opponent was there opposing him all the way."
Mr. Bush's decision to campaign in Minnesota, which is usually a reliable Democratic state in presidential elections, underscored the volatile nature of this race. Across the nation, polls show this to be potentially the tightest presidential contest in four decades, and those numbers have sent the candidates scrambling to states that have normally decided on a candidate by this time.
Mr. Bush, whose own record in Texas has come under relentless attack from Mr. Gore, reached back almost two decades to showcase votes that Mr. Gore cast as a member of Congress from Tennessee.
"In 1981, the vice president voted in favor of a 70 percent top income tax rate," Mr. Bush said, adding, "I want you to hear the facts."
He said that if Mr. Gore's "views had prevailed, a family of four, making $50,000 would pay three times more in federal income taxes than they pay today." And he said the National Taxpayers Union, a conservative research group, had rated Mr. Gore as a "big spender" 12 times while he was in Congress.
"Three of those times, he earned the worst rating of any member of Congress," Mr. Bush said to cheers, "and considering the competition, that's quite an achievement."
Playing off President Clinton's pledge when he was re-elected to find the "vital center" of American politics, Mr. Bush said of Mr. Gore, "Just when progress on important issues seems within reach, he's left the vital center of American politics."
Mr. Bush accused Mr. Gore of proposing $2 trillion in new spending over 10 years but gave no clue as to how he had reached those figures. Aides later said he was relying on estimates by the Republican staff of the Senate Budget Committee and by the National Taxpayers Union and another private group, Citizens Against Government Waste.
The Gore camp dismissed the National Taxpayers Union as a "right-wing group." And Kym Spell, a spokeswoman for Mr. Gore, said: "Governor Bush continues to practice fuzzy math and displays fuzzy priorities. Bush's proposals would bankrupt the Social Security system, squander the surplus and risk our prosperity. That's not what a real leader does for America."
The Gore campaign says it has proposed $700 billion in new spending over 10 years.
Mr. Bush did not concentrate only on Mr. Gore's spending plans. He ridiculed the vice president's proposal for a tax cut of nearly $500 billion as full of "fine print," and he tried to tap into resentment of the Internal Revenue Service.
"Fine print creates more rules and regulations and bigger bureaucracies," he said. "It looks as if some in Washington are already preparing for the Gore tax plan: the I.R.S. just announced they are going to hire an additional 2,079 bureaucrats."
He then sought to wield Mr. Gore's own campaign mantra against him.
"My opponent talks about fighting for the people against the powerful," Mr. Bush said. "But it works out a little differently. In this case more audits for people, more power for the I.R.S."
Mr. Bush's presence here so close to Election Day was savored by local Republicans. Minnesota has supported the Democrat candidate in every presidential race since backing Richard M. Nixon in 1972. But it displayed a maverick streak with the election of a former professional wrestler, Jesse Ventura, as its governor and recent polls have shown the Green Party candidate, Ralph Nader, eating into Mr. Gore's liberal base.
A survey released by St. Cloud University last week portrayed the race in Minnesota as a tossup, with Mr. Gore at 39 percent, Mr. Bush at 38 percent and Mr. Nader at 10 percent.
Mr. Gore campaigned here last Saturday night, calling the state the "heart and soul of the Democratic Party." Senator Paul Wellstone, Democrat of Minnesota, one of the Senate's most liberal members, took the stage before Mr. Gore did and urged the thousands not to vote for Mr. Nader.
Yet even as Mr. Bush proclaimed he would win Minnesota, he had to fend off questions today about whether he was faltering in Florida, where his brother Jeb is the governor.
Asked about one recent poll that showed him substantially trailing Mr. Gore in Florida, Mr. Bush said, "I don't believe it."
Mark McKinnon, his media strategist, said the poll, by John Zogby, was flawed because it sampled people only in the daytime, a method he said could lead to skewed results by sampling too many retirees who were at home during the day.
While Mr. Bush emphasized spending and cutting taxes, the two tickets also kept up a battle over Social Security.
In advertisements and on the stump, Mr. Gore has homed in on the issue, saying Mr. Bush's plan to divert some Social Security taxes to individual investment accounts promises the same $1 trillion over 10 years to younger workers and to current retirees. Because the Social Security system essentially uses the payroll taxes of current workers to pay the benefits of retirees, any transition to private accounts has a temporary large financing gap, worth hundreds of billions of dollars.
The Bush campaign, which has fired back with its own advertisement challenging Mr. Gore's credibility, argues that $2.4 trillion in surplus Social Security revenue will provide enough money over the next decade to permit about two percentage points of the payroll taxes to be used for younger workers to create private accounts.
Mr. Bush criticized his opponent over the issue, saying Mr. Gore offered "an old and tired approach" to the looming financial troubles of Social Security.
And his running mate, Dick Cheney, today enlisted his Persian Gulf war colleague, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, to try to convince elderly voters that the Republican proposal to privatize part of the Social Security system would not endanger their benefits.
General Schwarzkopf, who, at 66, was introduced as a "senior American," described the debate over the pension system in militant terms.
"I enlist all of you in the battle that we're about to wage," he said at a rally in Punta Gorda, Fla. "We're going to replace a campaign of fear with a counterattack of the truth."
 
In His Own Words
GEORGE W. BUSH
 
Remarks yesterday in Minneapolis:
 
"Vice President Gore offers an old and tired approach. He offers a new federal spending program to nearly every voting bloc. He expands entitlements, without reforms to sustain them.
 And when others, Republican or Democrat, propose needed reform in Social Security, Medicare or education, he opposes and attacks and demonizes them. Just when progress on important issues seems within reach, he's left the vital center of American politics.
Until recently, I didn't even have to point all this out. He was out there claiming credit for all this new spending. But lately he's been backpedaling. Even with these 285 new or expanded programs, he says he is committed to cutting government. He says he won't hire even one new government employee.
Think about that. Two hundred and eighty-five new or expanded programs, and $2 trillion more in new spending - and not one new bureaucrat to file the forms or answer the phones. Let me tell you what I think: I think he might be exaggerating.
And it's not the first time. He says his efforts at 'reinventing' government have substantially reduced the federal work force. But this week, Newsweek magazine calls that claim 'misleading.' The magazine concludes that the vast majority of reductions came from 'military downsizing.'
You might call that short-sighted. You might call that unwise. But you can't call it 'reinventing government."'

HEADLINE: Entertainment Web Venture Expects Layoffs

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
Urban Box Office Network, one of the largest Internet companies specializing in hip-hop and Latino entertainment, appears headed for the expanding dot-com graveyard.
The company plans to lay off between 70 percent and all of its 300 employees by tomorrow, said Adam Kidron, the chief executive of the network. He said an anticipated investment from a Texas venture capital company had fallen through. 
 "We might be out of business by Friday," Mr. Kidron said.
The venture capital company, Interfase Capital of Austin, said it was willing to provide interim financing but could not support a business that was losing nearly $1 million a week. Mr. Kidron did not deny the company's "burn rate" was that high but said it was immaterial to the financing agreement. Mr. Kidron said a total of $34 million had been invested in the company so far.
Aside from the loss of jobs, the collapse of Urban Box Office would be a setback for economic development efforts in Harlem. The company had put together a separate package of public and private financing for a $12 million renovation of a building at Amsterdam Avenue and 126th Street and was planning to move there next year from its offices at 31st Street and Seventh Avenue.
Mr. Kidron said the company had counted on a total of $35 million to $50 million from Interfase and other investors. He accused Interfase of reneging on its commitment to provide $20 million of the total.
Interfase officials, however, said they withdrew their financing offer in part because Urban Box Office had failed to meet a requirement that it establish strategic partnerships with other, larger companies. Urban Box Office officials said they had forged a couple of alliances with such companies but were not able to identify them publicly at this point.
In some ways, Urban Box Office has been fighting an uphill battle since February.
Mr. Kidron came up with the idea for a Web portal linking several sites for urban music, entertainment and information. But during its first year of development, the company was more closely associated with George Jackson, the former Hollywood producer and record company executive who helped found the company with Mr. Kidron, a longtime British music industry producer, and Frank Cooper, former vice president for business affairs at Def Jam Recordings.
But on Feb. 10, just as the company was about to start its first major Web site, Mr. Jackson, 42, died of a stroke.
In recent months, Mr. Kidron said, Urban Box Office had come into its own. The number of visits to its Web sites had quadrupled since July, and the company was about to sign an advertising agreement with Pepsi-Cola. But 25 employees were laid off after IndiePlanet.com, one of the Web sites, failed to catch on, he said.
People drawn to so-called urban entertainment have plenty to choose from on the Internet, including such sites as Hookt.com, Volume.com, Bet.com and 360hiphop.com. But Urban Box Office Network planned a wide array of original content, including situation comedies, dramatic series, talk shows and animation.

HEADLINE: Metro Business Briefing;
NEW YORK CITY ECONOMY GROWING

BYLINE: By Leslie Eaton 

 BODY:
Although the national economy appears to be slowing, business conditions in New York continue to improve, according to several economic reports released yesterday. A periodic survey of economic conditions by the Federal Reserve Bank, informally known as the beige book, reported that inflationary pressures in New York were waning and that the "economy has shown few, if any, signs of slowing." And the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported that New York City had added far more new jobs -- 101,000 -- than any other metropolitan area in the country during the last 12 months. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

HEADLINE: Ring Lardner Jr., Wry Screenwriter and Last of the Hollywood 10, Dies at 85

BYLINE: By RICHARD SEVERO 

 BODY:
Ring Lardner Jr., whose satirical screenplays twice won the Academy Award but whose career collapsed in 1947 after he refused to tell Congress if he had ever been a Communist, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 85.
Mr. Lardner was the last surviving son of Ring Lardner, the baseball writer, humorist and short-story author. He was also the last surviving member of the Hollywood 10, the blacklisted group of writers, directors and producers who were sent to Federal prison in 1950 for terms ranging from five months to a year because they all refused to tell the House Un-American Activities Committee if they were or ever had been members of the Communist Party or if they knew of any Hollywood colleagues who were. 
 Ring Lardner Jr. shared an Academy Award for best original screenplay with Michael Kanin in 1942 for "Woman of the Year," a comedy that marked the first teaming of Katharine Hepburn and Spencer Tracy. In 1970 he forcefully re-established himself with an Oscar for best screenplay for "M*A*S*H," which was based on Richard Hooker's novel about an irreverent Army medical unit during the Korean war. These two movies were at either end of a lengthy period between 1947 and the early 1960's when Mr. Lardner found it difficult to get work in Hollywood under his own name.
In 1947 Mr. Lardner was an unrepentant and fiercely outspoken witness when he was interrogated by the committee's chairman, the famously aggressive J. Parnell Thomas, Republican of New Jersey. Mr. Lardner was, in fact, a Communist, but he refused to answer Thomas because he felt that his political leanings were none of the government's business.
 
'I'd Hate Myself In the Morning'
At one point Thomas demanded to know if Mr. Lardner was or ever had been a Communist. Mr. Lardner started to reply, then hesitated.
"It is a very simple question," the congressman said sharply. "Anybody would be proud to answer it -- any real American would be proud to answer the question, 'Are you or have you ever been a member of the Communist Party?' "
"I could answer the question exactly the way you want," Mr. Lardner replied, "but if I did, I would hate myself in the morning." An angry Thomas had him removed from the witness stand.
In late 1947, 20th Century-Fox, which had been paying Mr. Lardner $2,000 a week, announced that "his employment with the company has been terminated." Two weeks after that, Mr. Lardner and the nine others who refused to answer were indicted and subsequently convicted of contempt of Congress.
Lawyers for the Hollywood 10 succeeded in getting the court to agree to procedural delays, but all their ploys were unsuccessful in protecting their clients, who, in addition to Mr. Lardner, were Albert Maltz, Dalton Trumbo, Samuel Ornitz, John Howard Lawson, Herbert Biberman, Adrian Scott, Lester Cole, Alvah Bessie and Edward Dmytryk. There were many others in Hollywood who also ran afoul of the committee, and they were blacklisted, too. Of the Hollywood 10, only Mr. Dmytryk, after serving his jail term, named names. Mr. Dmytryk, deciding he was making a martyr of himself for an ideology in which he no longer believed, went on to cooperate with the committee, salvaging his directing career.
Mr. Lardner was sentenced to a year in the federal prison at Danbury, Conn. As the time approached when he had to turn himself in, he put his house in Santa Monica, Calif., up for sale and attracted buyers with an advertisement that carried the caption "Owner Going to Jail." He said he took a $9,000 loss on the house, which was purchased by a physician.
But by the time he began to serve what turned out to be a little more than nine months in 1950, he learned that Congressman Thomas was also imprisoned in Danbury after his conviction on defrauding the Government by putting fictitious workers on his Congressional payroll. They "became reacquainted," he wrote later.
After Mr. Lardner left prison, he accepted his forced unemployment with laconic wit. As a nonworking writer, he said, "My tennis game improved, my wife conceived and bore another child, making five for whose rearing and education I was financially responsible." Some of his less fortunate former colleagues, he said, went into carpentry, selling women's clothes, bartending, driving a school bus and waiting on tables. He did none of these things, searched for writing assignments and thought the whole thing "would blow over like other periodic tempests in the movie business."
But it did not blow over and Mr. Lardner found himself working briefly in Mexico, in New York and in London, writing television series in the late 1950's and early 60's, the best known of which was "The Adventures of Robin Hood," starring Richard Greene. The show was produced in London and sold to American networks.
During this period, Mr. Lardner used several pen names to conceal his identity, including that of Oliver Skene. On one occasion, in 1958, he used the name Philip Rush as the credit on a movie he wrote for Sidney Poitier called "Virgin Island," and was quite chagrined when a British historian of the same name turned up and sent a tart letter to The Times of London, saying that he had absolutely nothing to do with the movie.
Some people in Hollywood tried to help Mr. Lardner. In the early 1960's, the producer and director Otto Preminger was criticized by the American Legion and other groups after he hired Mr. Lardner to adapt "Genius," a novel by Patrick Dennis, for the screen. The project was ultimately shelved.
During the same time period Mr. Lardner collaborated with Ian Hunter on several projects, including "Foxy," a Bert Lahr musical that failed on Broadway. Mr. Lardner did have some success, however, as the author, with Terry Southern, of the 1965 movie "The Cincinnati Kid," which starred Steve McQueen and Edward G. Robinson.
Among Mr. Lardner's other screen projects, either as author or co-author, were "Meet Dr. Christian" (1939); "Courageous Dr. Christian" (1940); "The Cross of Lorraine" (1943); "Tomorrow the World" (1944); "Cloak and Dagger" (1946) and "Forever Amber" (1947). Among the screenplays he either wrote or contributed to under pseudonyms were "The Forbidden Street" (1949) and "Four Days Leave" (1950). One of the other screenplays he wrote after the blacklist was "The Greatest" (1977), starring Muhammad Ali.
Ringgold Wilmer Lardner Jr. was born in Chicago on Aug. 15, 1915, one of four sons born to Ring Lardner and the former Ellis Abbott. The other three sons, James, David and John, also became writers but died relatively young. James, 24, fought and died in the Spanish Civil War as a volunteer with the Lincoln Brigade. David, 25, was killed by a land mine in Germany while covering the World War II battleground for The New Yorker. John, 47, a critic and journalist, died of a heart attack in 1960.
Mr. Lardner's first byline appeared in 1919, when he was just 4 years old. It was a travel story called "The Young Immigrunts" but it was really written by his father and described the family angst of a cross-country trip by automobile.
 
Introduced To David O. Selznick
When Mr. Lardner was about 6, his family moved to Greenwich, Conn., and then to Great Neck, on Long Island, where neighbors or regular visitors included the journalists Herbert Bayard Swope, Grantland Rice and Heywood Broun, the authors H. L. Mencken, Dorothy Parker and Alexander Woolcott and the composer and critic Deems Taylor. Mr. Lardner was naturally a left-handed person, but his parents instructed him to write and eat with his right hand. He thought this probably caused him to develop a stutter as a child.
He graduated from Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., and went to Princeton, where he joined the Socialist Club. After his sophomore year, he sailed to Hamburg, where he caught a train to the Soviet Union and enrolled at the Anglo-American Institute of the University of Moscow, a center established to encourage young Americans to support the Soviet system. Young Lardner was won over. He returned to New York and in 1935 got a job working for Stanley Walker, then editor of The Daily Mirror. He did not remain there long. His roommate at Princeton had been Herbert Bayard Swope Jr., whose father, a former executive editor of The New York World, introduced him to David O. Selznick, who was then in the process of starting his own movie company.
At first, Mr. Lardner was assigned to work with Mr. Selznick's publicity director. But after a year or so passed, Mr. Selznick asked Mr. Lardner and a co-worker, Budd Schulberg, a reader in the story department, to rewrite some scenes for a new movie featuring Fredric March and Janet Gaynor. It was called "A Star Is Born" and it already had four writers assigned to it full-time. The pair is credited with the famous line at the end of the film, "This is Mrs. Norman Maine speaking." Mr. Selznick liked their work and said that the two should consider themselves scriptwriters.
Not all Mr. Lardner's judgments were wise ones, however. Mr. Selznick asked his secretary, Sylvia Schulman, and Mr. Lardner, who was dating Miss Schulman (and later married her ) if they would read Margaret Mitchell 's novel "Gone With the Wind.' and tell him if they thought it was good enough to be made into a movie. Miss Schulman gave it an enthusiastic "yes," but Mr. Lardner thought that "Gone With the Wind" had no future as a movie.
By 1937 Mr. Lardner, he would later recall, had been recruited by the Communist Party in Hollywood and was attending a Marxist study group and similar meetings four nights a week. In time he became a member of such groups as the Hollywood Anti-Nazi League, the Citizens Committee for the Defense of Mexican-American Youth, the Hollywood Writers Mobilization Against the War. He also served on the board of the Screen Writers Guild.
In 1941 he got an important boost to his career when the writer Garson Kanin gave Miss Hepburn a story called "Woman of the Year," which Mr. Kanin's brother, Michael, had written with Mr. Lardner. Miss Hepburn liked it so much that she went to Louis B. Mayer at MGM, and said she wanted to play the title role, a world famous political commentator who gets such a comeuppance from a sportswriter (played by Spencer Tracy) that she marries him. Miss Hepburn demanded $200,000 for the story, took $100,000 for herself, and gave the rest to Mr. Kanin and Mr. Lardner. Their script received an Academy Award in 1942; since then "Woman of the Year" has been turned into a successful Broadway musical and another film in 1976.
During World War II, Mr. Lardner served in the Army Signal Corps and was sent not into battle but to Astoria, Queens, where he spent most of his military career writing the script for a training film.
 
Credit, of Course, For M*A*S*H
Mr. Lardner felt that for him, if not for all the other members of the Hollywood 10, the blacklist ended at some point in the 1960's and there was no question about his receiving credit for the work he did on "M*A*S*H." After "M*A*S*H" proved to be a big moneymaker, he was asked if he thought it could be adapted for television. He said that "M*A*S*H" had no future as a television show. (It became one of television's most successful series, from 1972-83.)
In 1981 Mr. Lardner turned from screenwriting to concentrate on books. In addition to "The Lardners: My Family Remembered," he was the author of two novels, "The Ecstasy of Owen Muir" and "All For Love." His final book, "I'd Hate Myself in the Morning" (Nation Books), a memoir, is scheduled for publication in January.
Mr. Lardner's marriage to Miss Schulman ended in divorce. He is survived by his wife, Frances Chaney, his brother David's widow, whom he married in 1946. Also surviving are three sons, Peter, of St. Augustine, Fla., James, of New York, and Joseph, of Los Angeles; two daughters, Ann Waswo of Oxford, England, and Katharine, of New York; seven grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Joseph and Katharine were Ms. Chaney's children from her marriage to David Lardner.
Although Mr. Lardner allowed his Communist Party membership to lapse in the 1950's, he returned to Moscow in 1987 and told Philip Taubman of The New York Times, "I've never regretted my association with Communism. I still think that some form of socialism is a more rational way to organize a society, but I recognize it hasn't worked anywhere yet." Mr. Lardner wrote in his final book that he never wanted the United States to be remodeled along Soviet lines and always believed in the democratic process.
The House inquiry into suspected disloyalty in Hollywood left some of its victims bitter and angry that some of their colleagues, like the writer Budd Schulberg, co-operated with the committee.
One day, Mr. Lardner, accompanied by his wife, Miss Chaney, encountered Mr. Schulberg in a restaurant. Mrs. Lardner looked the other way because she did not want to talk to an informer. But Mr. Lardner took the hand of his old friend and co-worker and shook it. "I shake hands with anybody," he said. "I don't believe in blacklisting."
 
Blacklisted in Hollywood for Contempt of Congress
Besides Ring Lardner Jr., these are the members of the Hollywood 10 who were jailed and fined in 1950 for contempt of Congress:
 
JOHN HOWARD LAWSON -- A co-founder and the first president of the Screen Writers Guild. Among the movies for which he was not credited was the script for "Cry the Beloved Country," which described the oppression of blacks in South Africa. He died in 1977.
 
ALVAH BESSIE -- Wrote or contributed to the screenplays for "Hotel Berlin," "Objective Burma," "The Very Thought of You" and "Northern Pursuit." He died in 1985.
 
DALTON TRUMBO -- Won an Oscar for the script of "The Brave One," which he received in 1975, some 18 years after it was given to "Robert Rich," his pseudonym. He died in 1976.
 
SAMUEL ORNITZ -- Wrote 25 movies, most of them not well known, between 1929 and 1949, when he was blacklisted. He died in 1985.
 
LESTER COLE -- Wrote or contributed to the films "Objective Burma," "The Romance of Rosy Ridge," "High Wall" and "The House of the Seven Gables." He published a memoir called "Hollywood Red" and became a stage actor and playwright, changing his name to Lester Copley. He died in 1985 at age 81.
 
ALBERT MALTZ -- Went to Mexico and wrote for the movies under pseudonyms. after his blacklisting. He returned to Hollywood in the 1970's and wrote "Two Mules for Sister Sara" and "The Beguiled." His earlier films included "Broken Arrow" and the Technicolor epic about the first years of Christianity, "The Robe." He died in 1985.
 
HERBERT BIBERMAN -- Helped found the Screen Directors Guild. Before his blacklisting, he directed "One Way Ticket," "Meet Nero Wolfe" and "The Master Race." He died in 1971.
 
ADRIAN SCOTT -- Produced "Murder My Sweet" and "So Well Remembered" but was blacklisted after being named as a communist by Edward Dmytryk. He died in 1973.
 
EDWARD DMYTRYK -- Directed "The Caine Mutiny," "Cornered," "Raintree County," "A Walk on the Wild Side" and "The Young Lions." He died in 1999.

HEADLINE: Clinton Now Running on Husband's Record

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: HAUPPAUGE, N.Y., Nov. 2

 BODY:
Moving into the final leg of her campaign for Senate, Hillary Rodham Clinton sprinted from Buffalo to Manhattan to Long Island today, trying to do in New York State what Al Gore has studiously avoided doing across the nation: run on the record of the Clinton administration.
Looking fatigued and swigging bottled water to fight a dry cough, Mrs. Clinton disparaged Representative Rick A. Lazio at every opportunity, describing her opponent's campaign as "a charade" intended to hide what she called his conservative and caustic ideology. But even as she attacked Mr. Lazio today for running a "campaign of insults," she released the latest in a parade of notably negative advertisements, this one featuring a clip of Mr. Lazio confronting her in their first debate, demanding that she sign an agreement on campaign financing. 
 At a moment in campaigns that politicians typically use to sum up the case for their candidacy, Mrs. Clinton repeatedly returned today to the record of her husband's years as president. While she was sparing in mentioning the president himself, her eagerness to affix her fortunes to his administration during the most-watched stretch of a campaign contrasted sharply with Mr. Gore, the other Democrat who has been seeking to emerge from Mr. Clinton's shadow and has not wanted the president to campaign with him.
"We've had eight good years: people are working, people are employed, people are buying homes, unemployment is down, and I think the Clinton-Gore administration has done a darn good job on the economy," the first lady shouted, her voice hoarse, at a raucous labor rally at a hall in the Manhattan Center on West 34th Street. "My opponent is saying eight years is enough. I don't know what planet he's on, but I think that eight years has not been enough."
"I remember what it was like in 1992 -- it has taken eight years to get this country going in the right direction," Mrs. Clinton said. She got so wrapped up that she even invoked the signature theme of her husband's 1992 campaign, telling an audience of students to "put people first."
Mrs. Clinton's aides said today that the president would come to New York to attend three get-out-the-vote rallies Saturday, in Brooklyn, the Bronx and Harlem. Mrs. Clinton will not be with him at those rallies, though an aide said they might well make several joint appearances before Tuesday. Mr. Clinton also plans to be in New York on Tuesday to listen to the election returns with his wife.
Mrs. Clinton's remarks came on a day when both candidates moved into a high gear of campaigning, each setting a frenetic pace -- in their travels, the release of new advertisements, and a seemingly endless parade of e-mail attacks -- that aides to both said would continue through Monday. And once again, much of the battle was engaged upstate.
Mrs. Clinton also moved to take advantage of what her aides argued was a mistake by Mr. Lazio, whose campaign released and then pulled back a radio advertisement that attacked her support of the Kyoto treaty on global warming. The advertisement, which was broadcast only upstate, described the pact as "radical" and suggested that it would cost jobs in a part of the state where the economy has had some difficulty.
Mr. Lazio dropped the advertisement under pressure from environmental groups, and amid concern by some Republicans that the episode could undercut his effort to present himself as a moderate Republican. Mrs. Clinton mentioned the incident today as she said Mr. Lazio was running a negative campaign and had "no plan" to address economic problems upstate.
"My opponent has no plan to bring and attract and keep good jobs here in upstate New York," she said. "And in the absence of a plan, which he has been promising for a week, he put up a misleading and inaccurate radio ad as a smoke screen to try to cover up the fact that he has no plan for the upstate economy."
Even as she attacked Mr. Lazio for attacking her, her campaign released one of the toughest advertisements of the contest, including a clip of the moment in which Mr. Lazio walked from his lectern over to hers during their debate in Buffalo and demanded that she sign a written agreement restricting use of soft money in the campaign. "Right here, right here, sign it," Mr. Lazio is shown saying to Mrs. Clinton.
The confrontational scene was repeatedly played on television at the time, and aides to both candidates believe that it hurt him, particularly among women.
Mrs. Clinton learned of a bombing in Jerusalem while touring a supermarket warehouse in Buffalo. She retired to a private office and spoke on the telephone before coming out and condemning the attack and calling on Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, to put back in jail the terrorists he had freed in recent weeks.
Mrs. Clinton acknowledged that she had no idea whether any of those people were involved in the bombing but said, "It just makes common sense that if you are committed to ending violence and terrorism, you would not let out of prison people who are known to be terrorists."
Mrs. Clinton's repeated efforts today to run on the Clinton administration's record came after 16 months in which she has often seemed unsure about how closely to associate herself with a politician who remains one of the most popular Democrats with New York voters. Mr. Clinton has been only an occasional visitor to New York since she started her campaign.
But today, speaking to union members, the most solid kind of Democratic audiences, the first lady shed any ambivalence about the association. "I'm proud of the fact that I am committed to continuing the policies of the past eight years," she said.

HEADLINE: MARATHON 2000;
Distance Runners No Longer Lonely

BYLINE: By SELENA ROBERTS 

 BODY:
Just after his daily 6 a.m. bargaining session with the snooze button, and before his desk job would begin hours later, Josh Cox would start a 10-mile training run by quickly summoning his matador instincts.
As he trotted along the shoulder of San Diego's Highway 54 during part of his route, he was faced with the snorting tractor-trailers and charging cars that wind-whipped his body. Sometimes, he could sidestep peril. Other times, he would find himself ensnared on a hood ornament. 
 "It happened a few times; and once I ended up on top of a hood, looking at a lady through her windshield," Cox said. "She was turning right, and I thought we had made eye contact. Obviously, we didn't. Luckily, I was all right."
There was no one to warn Cox, no training partners to shout, "Watch out," and no safer place for him to run. In many ways, Cox was the typical American marathoner: a solo act, running at his own risk.
But in a new effort to regenerate this fading class of athlete in the United States, and restore American prominence in a sport in which Americans have experienced a free-fall since the 80's, Gabriele Rosa has set up the same kind of program he has used to turn unknown Kenyans into marathon icons. In August, Rosa selected Cox as one of six men and three women to move to a training site financed by the apparel company Fila in Mount Laguna, Calif., where they are free to focus only on running.
If the program succeeds, the crowds that watch the New York City Marathon will soon have an American to cheer on to victory. For now, Sunday's field will still belong to the Kenyans, the Mexicans and the Ethiopians.
"What I'm trying to do is begin a new strategy in America," said Rosa, a medical doctor and Italian coach who has trained several elite runners who will compete in Sunday's marathon, including Kenya's Japhet Kosgei. "It's not easy for Americans. The athletes like to enjoy outside things and want to have girlfriends and stay out, too. So it's a difficult situation.
"In Kenya, it's a different social and economic atmosphere. At first, I wasn't sure if this idea would work in America. But now, I think it can. There's only one way to reproduce the mentality and philosophy and the mission of running. This program is the way."
Rosa's approach is simple in design: create the perfect setting to succeed. The Fila training facility is about 50 miles east of San Diego, at an elevation of 6,000 feet, which mirrors the terrain of Kenya. There are cabins that house two runners each, chefs from the Job Corps who cook up the 6,000 calorie-a-day diets for the athletes, and a high-mileage regimen that has already produced results.
The 25-year-old Cox finished 10th in the Chicago Marathon last month, beating his personal-best time by more than five minutes, finishing in 2 hours 13 minutes 55 seconds.
"Before I came to the camp, my high mileage building up to the Olympic trials was 135 in a week, and I probably averaged 110," Cox said. "Now, 135, that's a normal week at camp."
If he hadn't run in Chicago -- an event that annually depletes the New York field -- Cox would probably be the first American to cross the finish line on Sunday. So there is hope for the future -- particularly with other training facilities like Rosa's starting to pop up in other parts of the country -- and there is also motivation for American marathoners like Cox.
On one wall of his cabin, next to the calendars and posters, Cox has taped an article as an inspirational reminder of his purpose.
"In a magazine on the West Coast, they put out an article about why we were so terrible," Cox said. "It was about American distance running. Personally, I'm tired of hearing how we're behind, how we're slow. Yeah, we are behind right now. But I can't worry about what everyone else is doing. I can only worry about myself. I know there are critics out there saying Americans don't work hard enough. I'm doing everything I know how to do. I would put Dr. Rosa's program up against what anyone else in the world is doing. If they say we're not working hard, they can come up to camp and follow us around for two weeks.
"I have that article on the wall to remind me to stay motivated. When it's all said and done, I want to know that whatever God gave me when I was born, I want to be able to multiply that gift by as much as I can."
Now, he has a support system to do it. When the alarm jars his senses at 6 a.m., he hustles out the door, knowing there are five other runners waiting on him. When he doesn't feel he can squeeze another mile out of his body, he has training partners to push him. When he runs the trails that wind around Mount Laguna, he can focus on the path, not the perils of Highway 54.
"On Mount Laguna, the biggest thing we have to wait for is the cows to go by in the pasture," Cox said. "You get a stampede of those once in a while. Other than that, it's smooth sailing."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
IN STRATEGY SHIFT, GORE ADS QUESTION BUSH'S CAPABILITY

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Nov. 2

 BODY:
In a late shift in his advertising strategy, Vice President Al Gore sought to heighten anxieties about Gov. George W. Bush today by broadcasting a tough new advertisement that bluntly questions whether Mr. Bush is "ready to lead America."
The new commercial, which criticizes Mr. Bush's Texas record on the environment, health care and the minimum wage, and attacks his proposals on Social Security, is scheduled to run often in all 17 battleground states where Mr. Gore is advertising. In most of those states, it will constitute half of the campaign's advertising in the final five days of what remains an intensely competitive race. 
 The end-game maneuver came on a day when the vice president drew the largest crowd of his campaign at a center city rally in Chicago, a Democratic stronghold in a state that had been leaning to Mr. Gore but where the race now seems to have tightened.
Speaking to a crowd that filled Daley Plaza and flowed over into surrounding streets, Mr. Gore used his remarks to paint Mr. Bush as a captive of special interests and portrayed himself as a fighter with the backbone to stand up for working families.
"I believe the presidency is not just a popularity contest," Mr. Gore said as the cheers of the crowd echoed off the surrounding skyscrapers. "I believe it is a day-by-day fight for real people who face real challenges. And you know what, I can say no to special interests with a smile."
Mr. Gore said that millions of dollars had been invested in the 2000 race "to try to put the special interests in charge." But on one day every four years, "you have the power," he said. "That day is dignity day."
Mr. Gore roared through a break-neck schedule spanning 18 1/2 hours and 4 states, including Illinois, which was once considered a safe bet for him but where tracking polls now show a very close race. Police officials estimated the crowd in Chicago at 51,000 people. Buying hours by crossing time zones, Mr. Gore also spoke today in Scranton, Pa., and Las Cruces, N.M., and planned to end his day at 1:30 a.m. Friday in Kansas City, Mo.
At each stop, Mr. Gore repeatedly drew contrasts between himself and Mr. Bush. But his most powerful message was delivered in the advertisement, the timing of which was debated for days within the Gore headquarters in Nashville.
Only Wednesday, the campaign released another Gore advertisement that focused on admirable chapters of the vice president's biography, like his service in Vietnam, and promoted his "experience, vision, values." But with the race still quite close, his strategists concluded that they had to put some advertising might behind their efforts to raise doubts about Mr. Bush.
In the last two weeks, that case has been made with escalating force by Gore surrogates, initially by members of Congress and then by his running mate, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, in television interviews on Sunday.
But Mr. Gore, who has pledged not to make personal attacks, had avoided directly questioning Mr. Bush's capacity to lead in either his speeches or his advertising.
Mr. Gore's Chicago rally was held at the downtown square named for former Mayor Richard J. Daley, the father of the current mayor, Richard M. Daley, and of Mr. Gore's campaign chairman, William M. Daley.
The Gore campaign built the crowd with the organizing skills of the Daley brothers and with significant help from trade unions in this traditionally Democratic city with its reliable Democratic power structure. It did not hurt that Stevie Wonder and Hootie and the Blowfish performed as opening acts, continuing the Gore campaign's practice of summoning crowds with heavily amplified popular music .
Waving the Gore-Lieberman campaign's distinctive blue placards, as well as inflatable red hands, the throng packed in against police barricades and flowed over into surrounding streets as office workers peered down through the windows of surrounding buildings.
The crowd estimate was provided by Deputy Chief Dennis Lesniak of the Chicago police, which is controlled by Mayor Daley.
In Scranton this morning, Mr. Gore summarized his policy agenda and his distinctions from Mr. Bush in an address at an auditorium at Lackawanna Junior College. Normally at such an event, Mr. Gore would enter the stage from the wings, but today he chose to walk down an aisle as heroic music swelled and the crowd chanted "We want Al." The campaign placed people wearing veterans' caps, doctors' lab coats and hard hats on risers to his side.
Mr. Gore, who has been urged by some Democrats to make a stronger case for the achievements of the administration of which he was such a crucial part for eight years, began by detailing what he called the economic successes of the Clinton team.
"Now the question before us is where do we go from here," he said, his tone confident and firm. "What will we do with our prosperity? Well, I want to put it to work for you, the hard-working families of this country and make sure you get your fair share of the pie."
Mr. Bush, he said, "has a very different view. He wants to change the very best things about the economic course we're on. He wants to go back."
Mr. Gore added: "I have a simple message. We have worked too hard on this economy to put it all at risk."
Mr. Gore then went on to question Mr. Bush's proposals on tax cuts, education, health care, Social Security and the environment.
After outlining each policy distinction, Mr. Gore announced: "The choice is yours and it's on the ballot on Tuesday."
The script of Mr. Gore's new advertisement makes a similar point. As the screen shows images of a sheepish Mr. Bush along with pictures of oil wells, a smoggy city and a woman caring for a sick child, a narrator says:
"As governor, George W. Bush gave big oil a tax break while opposing health care for 220,000 kids. Texas now ranks 50th in family health care. He's left the minimum wage at $3.35 an hour, Let polluters police themselves. Today Texas ranks last in air quality. Now Bush promises the same $1 trillion from Social Security to two different groups. He squanders the surplus on a tax cut for those making over $300,000. Is he ready to lead America?"
"It's clearly obvious the worse Al Gore does in the polls, the more negative he gets," said Dan Bartlett, a Bush spokesman.
The advertisement began running in what campaign aides called "a very substantial buy." In most places, it will run in rotation with the new advertisement about Mr. Gore's experience and a third advertisement criticizing Mr. Bush's Social Security plans. The Gore campaign plans to spend $7 million on television advertising until the election Tuesday. The Democratic National Committee is spending $9 million on advertising this week, with much of that sum also devoted to attacking Mr. Bush on Social Security.
Mark D. Fabiani, Mr. Gore's deputy campaign manager for communications, said there was never much internal debate over whether to run the new advertisement, but that there was significant discussion about timing. The advertisement became viable, he said, after Mr. Bush acknowledged in the last debate that his proposal to partly privatize Social Security would draw $1 trillion from the current system; after he suggested 10 days ago that NATO forces be withdrawn from the Balkans; and after the Bush campaign began broadcasting an advertisement this week that harshly questioned Mr. Gore's truthfulness.
"I think people, not just in the Gore campaign but in the country, have known for a while," he said, "that Bush's readiness to lead has been the elephant in the room for this entire election."

HEADLINE: City to Charge Truck Drivers For Parking

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
Saying that traffic has brought many Midtown streets to a near standstill, the city has decided for the first time to charge delivery trucks for parking when they are loading and unloading around Times Square.
The plan is a first strike in a new battle to impose order on the city's most chaotic streets, ones that have confounded city planners for years. To drivers, the streets are an all-too-familiar trial: trucks parked and double-parked, many following no discernible rules and others that are not making deliveries at all. 
 Truckers like Robert Arias agree that traffic is a nightmare, but say that it will take nothing short of a revolution to improve it. "I don't see anything working," Mr. Arias said yesterday, sitting in his private mail delivery truck. "All I want to know," he asked, "is who's going to pay me for paying to park?"
But the plan, which will go into effect on Nov. 13, is intended to accomplish much more than extracting quarters from commercial drivers in loading zones. It will be the city's first attempt -- and the first of its kind in the country, experts say -- to use an economic idea called congestion pricing to control commercial parking by varying the rates depending on the time of day.
The carrot-and-stick approach is now used on the New Jersey Turnpike, and on toll roads in California and other states to discourage driving during rush hours: higher tolls are charged for cars during peak hours. Variable parking rates, depending on the time of day and the duration of the parking, have also been used in Europe, but not in the United States, experts said.
The city's pilot plan, which will last for a year and half, will use computerized parking meters recently installed in Midtown that print receipts after coins or debit cards are inserted. The receipts are placed on the dashboards of cars or trucks, showing ticket agents how much parking time has been bought.
Between 7 a.m. and 6 p.m., the busiest hours of the day, truckers making deliveries between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas, from West 43rd to West 48th Street, excluding 47th Street (where, generally, "no standing" rules apply), will have to feed these meters. And they will have to pay for spaces that they have long been able to grab for free, if they could find them.
Parking prices in the loading zones will escalate -- $1 for one hour, $3 for two hours and $6 for three hours -- to encourage shorter use of the spaces, city officials said. The spaces will remain free all other hours, to encourage deliveries at night or in the early morning.
Iris Weinshall, the city's new transportation commissioner, said the loading zones, where trucks have generally been allowed to park for up to three hours, had become de facto long-term truck parking on many streets. Because police enforcement has often been lax, some spots are occupied all day by cars and vans that have commercial license plates, but do not make deliveries.
This sometimes forces truckers making deliveries to circle blocks again and again, adding to the congestion. Many truckers give up and double-park, which clogs the streets even more and spreads congestion outside the Times Square area.
"The economy is changing," Ms. Weinshall said. "More people are buying things on the Web; more things have to be delivered. And I can't expand the streets. So instead, we're trying to move the spots over more and more by making a financial incentive to the trucks to make their deliveries and leave faster."
Ms. Weinshall emphasized that the parking plan was only an experiment. The Police Department has agreed to strictly enforce the new rules and to help the transportation department collect information on whether it is actually changing parking patterns in the areas.
"This is not cast in stone, and we will change it if we need to," Ms. Weinshall said. "Every place I go now, people talk to me about this concept of congestion pricing, and we just don't have any empirical data in New York to know whether it will work or not."
The idea, which has been discussed seriously by city officials, civic groups and the business community since at least 1995, was applauded yesterday by longtime critics of the city's transportation policies.
"This is a really important step forward for transportation planning in New York City," said John Kaehny, executive director of Transportation Alternatives, a cyclist and pedestrian rights group. "It's an extremely rational use of a scarce resource -- curb space -- and I would expect it to work extremely well."
Others were not as enthusiastic.
Douglas Durst, a major commercial landlord in the area, said he appreciated the effort. But, he said, "I don't think this is really going to alleviate the traffic problems in Times Square. The major culprit is not the trucks. The major problem is private cars, and the city must at some point look into regulating private cars in this part of the city."
Earnest Rice, the community relations manager for Manhattan for the United Parcel Service, said he thought the new system might help the company avoid some of the approximately $2 million in ticketing and towing charges that it pays every year in the city. But he said a $6 charge for three hours was not steep enough to encourage truckers to move sooner.
In addition, he said, some delivery trucks, including many U.P.S. trucks, have legitimate reasons for staying in spots longer than three hours.
"I think it's a great idea to try," Mr. Rice said. "I would agree with trying anything because it's so bad out there right now."
Others also pointed out that unless the police department monitors the plan closely, it will be possible for drivers to skirt it, just as they do other parking regulations. For example, drivers could return to their trucks every hour to replace one-hour receipts with new ones; in that way they could park for three hours, but pay $3 instead of $6. Or they could stay longer than three hours by replacing a three-hour receipt with a new one.
"It will happen, you know?" Mr. Arias said yesterday. "It's a big game out here and everybody's hustling one way or another."

HEADLINE: Metro Business Briefing;
LOW UNEMPLOYMENT IN STAMFORD

BYLINE: By Leslie Eaton 

 BODY:
With unemployment rates of just over 1 percent in September, Stamford and Danbury, Conn., are among the cities with the lowest levels of joblessness in the nation, the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics announced yesterday. The Stamford-Norwalk area's unemployment rate was 1.1 percent, a rate matched by Bloomington, Ind. Danbury and Sioux Falls, S.D., had rates of 1.2 percent. Columbia, Mo., had the lowest rate: 1 percent. The average unemployment rate for the nation is 3.9 percent. Leslie Eaton (NYT)
