HEADLINE: ART GUIDE

 BODY:
A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.
 
Museums
 
"AMAZONS OF THE AVANT-GARDE," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Jan. 7). A concise exercise, monographically arranged, this show focuses on six Russian women who painted around the time of the revolution. Several continued to work much later and do more than paint, but this is a tendentious affair, plausibly so. If only a couple of the women, Natalia Goncharova and Liubov Popova, were truly great painters, the exhibition still isn't a case of special pleading. The Russian avant-garde wouldn't have been what it was without them collectively. The story as it unfolds here seems, if anything, more remarkable, not less, for having as little to do with sex as it does and almost everything to do with painting. Many of the works have a surprising fortitude. Revolution. A brave new art world. The dream persists even though the form it takes keeps changing. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $12; $8 for students and the elderly (Michael Kimmelman). 

 "GIORGIO ARMANI," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Jan. 17). The Guggenheim has served up another plateau of urban history: a retrospective of the Milanese fashion designer Giorgio Armani. What it lacks in depth it makes up for with sparkle, and Robert Wilson's architectural transformation of the museum's rotunda may be the best yet. In an inverted version of a life class, instead of the undraped body, the show offers just the drapes. The mannequins have been pared down to the edges of the costumes, and they cluster in groups in the building's structural bays, spatial modules with the proportions of shop windows. Hours and admission: See above (Herbert Muschamp).
 
 * "THE EMBODIED IMAGE: CHINESE CALLIGRAPHY FROM THE JOHN B. ELLIOTT COLLECTION," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Jan. 7). In China the written word has traditionally been the highest art form and a source of political and emotional power. To see that power in action, check out this grandly scaled exhibition, which brings together two superb calligraphy collections -- from Princeton University and the Met -- in the most comprehensive survey yet seen in these parts. The dozens of scrolls covered with hand-written words collectively radiate a kind of conversational buzz and suggest a richly varied cast of personalities: fastidious court functionaries, impulsive social agitators, unworldly monks, visionary poets. Together they offer an ice-breaking introduction to an art that to anyone who doesn't know Chinese can seem unapproachable. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $5 for students 12 and older and the elderly (Holland Cotter).
 
 "AN ENGAGEMENT WITH FOLK ART: CYRIL I. NELSON'S GIFTS TO THE MUSEUM OF AMERICAN FOLK ART," 2 Lincoln Square, at West 66th Street, (212) 595-9533 (through Jan. 7). This show celebrates the largess of Mr. Nelson, a book editor and folk art collector who has given 113 objects to the museum with the promise of more. The works, from the late-18th to the mid-20th centuries, cover the traditional areas of folk art -- portraits, landscapes, sculptures, painted and decorated furniture -- but the focus is on American needlework: quilts, coverlets, blankets and the like. Among the quilt spectaculars is the "Samuel Steinberger Log Cabin Quilt, Courthouse Steps Variation," by a 19th-century immigrant. Painted furniture, too, shines in this show. The painting and sculpture pieces make a more modest impression, but over all, what's on view represents a refined, solid ensemble that is very visitable. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11:30 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. Free (Grace Glueck).
 
 "HIP-HOP NATION: ROOTS, RHYMES AND RAGE," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Dec. 31). The complex cultural amalgam of music, poetry, break-dancing, art and fashion that is hip-hop poses a serious challenge to any art museum, but with the proper resources and curatorial expertise, it could have been done. Instead this show offers a partial outline of hip-hop history, conveyed by photographs, posters, magazine and album covers, memorabilia and monotonous expanses of clothes that make the show nearly indistinguishable from the gift shop. Garnished with graffiti art, it bypasses many other equally interesting connections to contemporary art. Because the show omits music videos, it manages to be virtually devoid of the sounds, words and moving bodies that are the essence of hip-hop. The results are a cross between a mall and a mausoleum. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (until 11 p.m. on the first Saturday of each month); Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $4; $2 for students and the elderly (Roberta Smith).
 
 "IN THE PRESENCE OF SPIRITS: AFRICAN ART FROM THE NATIONAL MUSEUM OF ETHNOLOGY IN LISBON," Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, near Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 966-1313 (through Dec. 31). The more than 140 objects on view relate to the secular and the supernatural in African culture: masks, power figures, dolls, decorated stools and chairs, pipes, posts and other artifacts. Outstanding is a group of initiation masks made from wood and more fragile materials like feathers, fabrics and barkcloth fibers. Ranging from fierce to benign in expression, they are giddily imaginative. Impressive, too, is a selection of dolls, important in the socialization of girls, from the Ambo people of southwestern Angola. The objects in the show were chosen for their high aesthetic value, and it doesn't disappoint. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50 for children, students and the elderly; free on Sundays (Glueck).
 
 LEE KRASNER, Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Jan. 7). Despite its restless energy and moments of formal power and elegance, Lee Krasner's career in this economical retrospective looks more like one of tantalizing frustration than real fulfillment. In the 1950's and early 60's, Krasner painted splattery, ambitious Abstract Expressionist works, but they look indebted to other artists, Pollock and de Kooning mainly. Where she looks most herself is in collage; a set of large collages on canvas from the early 50's have raw density or explosive buoyancy. Collages made in the 1970's using 40-year-old charcoal drawings have a beautiful Cubistic elegance; they are the best works of her career. Hours and admission: See above (Ken Johnson).
 
 "MOROCCO: JEWS AND ART IN A MUSLIM LAND," Jewish Museum, Fifth Avenue at 92nd Street, (212) 423-3200 (through Feb. 11). When Arab Muslims arrived in Morocco, Jews had already been living there for centuries, and the two cultures formed a cooperative and uneasy bond. Their relationship is explored in this exhibition, which offers a little bit of many things, mostly dating from the 19th and 20th centuries. In elaborate jewelry, shimmery textiles, liturgical objects and folk amulets, Jewish and Islamic ingredients often form a distinctive hybrid blend. A selection of European Orientalist paintings, by Delacroix among others, provide a firsthand outsider view of a once-vibrant interaction. Hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 11 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Tuesdays to 8 p.m. Admission: $8; $5.50 for students over 11 and the elderly (Cotter)
 
 "OPEN ENDS," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, (212) 708-9400 (through Jan. 2). The third and final cycle of "MOMA 2000," the millennium-marking rethinking of the Modern's permanent collection, is off and running, with the first of three staggered floor-through sections in place. The dates covered are 1960 to the present, so there's some sense of how a bastion of modernism is dealing with a postmodern world. Pretty well, judging from recent acquisitions of work by Pipilotti Rist, Matthew Barney and Cai Guo-Qiang. The real interest is in smart theme shows that play with such contemporary fixations as childhood innocence and adult experience, and the blend of art, abjection and design. (The third-floor galleries open on Sunday.) Hours: Saturdays through Tuesdays and Thursdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 8:15 p.m. Admission: $10; $6.50, students and the elderly (Cotter).
 
 "PIERRE ET GILLES," New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through Jan. 7). No history of postmodern photography, fashion photography, celebrity portraiture, record album covers or the highbrow beefcake tradition would be complete without the work of the French photo team known as Pierre et Gilles, who have collaborated on over-the-top, tightly styled, hand-finished photographs since 1976 and become wildly famous in Europe in the process. In their first American museum retrospective, their work feels more than a little embalmed, existing behind a not-so-invisible shield of artistic conservatism. Certain images come to life as art objects -- most notably, one of a beautiful young sailor up to his chest in water with an iridescent night sky behind him -- but those are few. Hours: Wednesdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays through Saturdays, until 8 p.m. Admission: $6; $3 for students, artists and the elderly (Smith).
 
 "POWER AND DESIRE: SOUTH ASIAN PAINTINGS FROM THE SAN DIEGO MUSEUM OF ART, EDWIN BINNEY 3RD COLLECTION," Asia Society at Midtown, 502 Park Avenue, at 59th Street, (212) 517-2742 (through Jan. 7.) The album-size paintings known as Indian miniatures, produced for an elite clientele who demanded the finest workmanship, are rightly renowned for their suave forms and brilliant colors. They also embody the moral values, political ambitions and personal aspirations of the culture that produced them. All of these ingredients come into play in this show of 67 top-of-the-line examples from the 16th to 19th centuries. They add up to a kind of grand but intimate theater, equal parts farce, melodrama and mystery play, where men strut like gods, gods have the failings of men, and nature is a gorgeous curtain behind which infinity lies. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $4; $2 for students and the elderly (Cotter).
 
 * BRIDGET RILEY, "Reconnaissance," Dia Center for the Arts, 548 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 989-5566 (through June 17). Once overly identified with Op Art, this British abstract painter never got her due in anti-Op New York, but a beautifully installed show of 40 paintings from 1961 to 1984 should change things. Concentrating on the early black-and-white paintings that made Ms. Riley famous, it presents stringently pure yet accessible works that have, at their best, extended the optical potential implicit in the work of Mondrian, Josef Albers and Ad Reinhardt. At their weakest, their meticulously calibrated patterns can be so aggressive that they virtually kidnap the eye, take it on a joy ride and leave it in a crumpled heap. Either way, the overall effect is of an artist of unusual dedication who has remained loyal to the original premises of her art and yet steadfastly refused to repeat herself. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, students and the elderly (Smith).
 
 * SCYTHIAN GOLD. "The Golden Deer of Eurasia: Scythian and Sarmatian Treasures From the Russian Steppes," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Feb. 4). "Gold of the Nomads: Scythian Treasures From Ancient Ukraine," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Jan. 21). Certain kinds of art are box-office gold. Art made of gold is one of them, and there's a Fort Knox-size supply of the precious stuff in these two opulent exhibitions. The Brooklyn show is a survey-style glimpse at some exquisitely wrought 14-carat objects drawn from museums in Ukraine, where the Scythians put down roots in the first millennium B.C. The Met has drop-dead museological rarities from the State Hermitage Museum, but the focus here, which gives the proceedings a kind of treasure-hunt thrill, is on a cache of objects excavated fairly recently from tombs belonging to non-Scythian people whose identity is something of a mystery. Ideally, the two shows should be seen together: they offer a really substantial archaeological update on the last big Scythian showcase in these parts, the Met's smash-hot "In the Land of the Scythians" of 25 years ago. Hours and admission: See above ( Cotter).
 
 * EDWARD STEICHEN, Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through Feb. 4). A big, thorough exhibition, maybe a little too big and glossy, of one of the great photographers in American history, a restless, benign, flawed genius. Steichen also painted, made films, designed textiles, organized aerial reconnaissance photography in two world wars and put together the most popular photography exhibition ever, "The Family of Man." We'll see how people respond to someone whose eclectic work can look, if anything, almost too elegant and self-regarding. Steichen ultimately seemed to reduce everything and everyone to props to demonstrate his own refined and stage-savvy sensibility. But what refinement. His best work has a finesse that borders on the erotic. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays and Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $8 for students and the elderly (Kimmelman).
 
 * "UNTITLED PASSAGES BY HENRI MICHAUX," Drawing Center, 35 Wooster Street, SoHo, (212) 219-2166 (through Dec. 20). The books of the great Belgian-born French poet and writer Henri Michaux are not exactly unknown on these shores, but his considerable achievement as a visual artist -- a self-taught one -- has yet to gain a solid foothold. This exhibition of more than 100 works on paper should change things. Spanning the late 1920's to the late 1970's, it includes examples of his finely textured "mescaline" drawings, his raucous ink-scapes and his animated, often preening calligraphies. It reveals an artist profoundly influenced by Asian art who assiduously mined the fault line between language and sign, text and drawing, image and abstraction, manifesting the flow of human thought and energy in different, often hypnotic ways. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Free. A related show, "Henri Michaux: Works on Paper," is at Michael Werner, 4 East 77th Street, 212 988-1623, through Nov. 25 (Smith).
 
Galleries: Uptown
 
"REMBRANDT AND THE VENETIAN INFLUENCE," Salander-O'Reilly Galleries, 20 East 79th Street, (212) 879-6606 (through Nov. 18). The Venetian influence in Rembrandt's later paintings has long been noted; this show is an attempt to demonstrate by specific examples. But the topic is more suited to a museum presentation; this one mounts only a dozen paintings, three by Rembrandt and one labeled "Studio of Rembrandt," along with oils by Titian, Tintoretto and Veronese. It is too small and catch-as-catch-can to make the case. The most salient example here of Venice in Rembrandt is his great painting "Flora" (circa 1654). Next to it, the other works in this show pale (Glueck).
 
Galleries: 57th Street
 
 JOHN MASON AND PETER VOULKOS, Franklin Parrasch, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 246-5360 (through Nov. 11). During the 1950's, Mr. Voulkos and Mr. Mason shared studios and an ambition to give ceramic sculpture an unprecedented physical expressiveness. Though the lesser known of the two, it is Mr. Mason who steals this show. His tower of mooshed-together clay chunks glazed green and his rumpled orange slab imprinted with the letter A make Voulkos's plates, pots, stacked vessels and totem-like sculptures look conservative (Johnson).
 
 TABITHA VEVERS, "Flying Dreams," Kraushaar, 724 Fifth Avenue, (212) 307-5730 (through Nov. 11). Updating medieval manuscript illumination, Ms. Vevers combines handwritten texts and deftly painted narrative imagery to document dreams of flight, her own and those of friends. One of these small, mysterious works illustrates the artist's dream of running a seaside flying school for babies, who are equipped with little golden parachutes (Johnson).
 
Galleries: SoHo
 
FRANCES BARTH, Donahue/Sosinski, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 226-1111 (through Nov. 11). Ms. Barth's medium large, semi-abstract pictures are an odd combination of muted Color Field painting and geological diagramming. Sketchy topographical signs, patterns and textures scatter across broad, stained areas of canvas, and are set off against narrower bands representing stratified cross-sections. The paintings have a curiously dry yet somehow romantic eccentricity (Johnson).
 
 JAMES ESBER AND KATIA SANTIBANEZ, P.P.O.W., 476 Broome Street, (212) 941-8642 (through Nov. 11). Mr. Esber's paintings of distorted and fragmented cartoon characters look like collaborations between Peter Saul, Philip Guston and R. Crumb, but have their own creepy-comical sensibility. The best, made of colored modeling clay applied directly to the wall, have a weirdly vivid palpability. In Ms. Santibanez's neat, easel-size abstractions, color-coordinated grass made of strokes of gouache seems to grow from the seams of smooth, cool-white stripe, grid or nested square compositions, to quietly eye-buzzing effect (Johnson).
 
 GUDRUN MERTES-FRADY, Rosenberg + Kaufman, 115 Wooster Street, (212) 431-4838 (through Nov. 18). The works of this veteran abstract painter, who moved from Germany to New York two decades ago, are academic but sumptuous. She drags, squeegees and scrapes paint this way and that, creating layered, blurred, checkered surfaces that are richly material yet vaguely illusory, like paintings by a less adventurous Gerhard Richter (Johnson).
 
 RAPHAEL MONTANEZ ORTIZ, Mitchell Algus, 25 Thompson Street, (212) 966-1758 (through Nov. 11). A sculptor, performance artist, film and video maker and self-styled modern shaman, Mr. Ortiz became famous in the 1960's for destroying pianos. Here he shows recent large psychedelic digital prints that mix Aztec, Cabalistic and Christian iconography. More persuasive are mesmerizing Cubistic videos made in the 1980's from clips of Marx Brothers movies and "King Kong" (Johnson).
 
 DAVID RABINOWITCH, Peter Blum, 99 Wooster Street, (212) 343-0441 (through Nov. 18). Restricting his vocabulary to circles, ovals and straight lines, and his means to pencil, ink or colored pencil, this Constructivist-Minimalist sculptor produced this series of extremely spare drawings during the early 1970's. Called "Construction of Vision," they are resolutely abstract and quasi scientific. But the ellipses and angled lines, cleanly drawn with mechanical drafting tools, have a subtly playful animation (Johnson).
 
 JASON RHOADES, David Zwirner, 43 Greene Street, (212) 966-9074 (through Nov. 18). In one room of Mr. Rhoades's latest essay in sculptural extravagance stands a sort of giant Tinkertoy sawmill -- Sutter's Mill, birthplace of the California gold rush -- made of polished aluminum pipes and clamps. In another room is an identical but incomplete version. During the exhibition, an assistant will always be building or dismantling one or the other mill, acting out a Sisyphean loop of construction and deconstruction (Johnson).
 
 CHRIS VERENE, American Fine Arts, 22 Wooster Street, (212) 941-0401 (through Nov. 11). With often piercing intimacy, this 31-year-old photographer chronicles the lives of friends and relatives in his hometown of Galesburg, Ill. Each of 60 richly colored, squarish images in this two-gallery show has a brief handwritten text added by the artist. Under the picture of a cousin, Steve, and his young daughter at a McDonald's, the text says, "His wife had just left them to go to a battered women's shelter" (Johnson).
 
Galleries: Chelsea
 
ISA GENZKEN, AC Project Room, 453 West 17th Street, (212) 645-4970 (through Nov. 18). Ms. Genzken, a German sculptor who has been exhibiting since the mid-70's, presents an Arte Povera-style homage to New York City in the form of slapdash skyscraper models made of colored tape, sheets of colored plastic or Plexiglas and found things like a pizza box, a fan propeller or oyster shells. A set of photographs of sleek office buildings offers a sharp contrast to the funky sculptural aesthetic (Johnson).
 
 JENNY HANKWITZ, Catherine Moore, 140 West 30th Street, (212) 279-8977 (through Nov. 11). Contemplating Ms. Hankwitz's abstract paintings is like looking through the window of a churning washing machine. Working from drawings made on a computer, the artist layers flat, crisply painted swirls, blobs and bubbly shapes into radiating, spiraling compositions, producing a sudsy mix of formalist flux and Pop buoyancy (Johnson).
 
 DAMIEN HIRST, Gagosian Gallery, 555 West 24th Street, (212) 741-1111 (through Dec. 16). Welcome to the Damien Hirst Universe. It's a big shiny place with mathematical grid paper printed on the walls, pale pristine dot paintings and many large vitrine sculptures, including two outfitted as gynecological examining rooms and filled with water and fish. It shows the artist moving beyond the dead animals and putrefying flesh that catapulted him to fame while clarifying and enriching the grandiose themes of his art: life and death and their complex, sometimes oppressive relationship to science and commerce. It contains some undeniable duds, but if it doesn't win over those who have resisted the work of this notorious young British artist, it won't be for lack of trying (Smith).
 
 SCOTT RICHTER AND BILL SMART, Elizabeth Harris, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 463-9666 (through Nov. 11). In opposite but equally engaging ways these two artists address basic elements of painting. Mr. Richter piles up paint into great heaping stacks of viscous color, exaggerating its sumptuous materiality to the point of absurdity. Mr. Smart reduces paint to almost pure primary colors in a series of square monochromes that have rounded corners and white circles like punch holes, giving Minimalism a subtle Pop spin (Johnson).
 
 ALEXIS ROCKMAN, Gorney Bravin + Lee, 534 West 26th Street, (212) 352-8372 (through Nov. 11). Inspired by a trip into South American jungles, Mr. Rockman's Pop-realist paintings depict a Northerner's lurid fantasies of tropical adventure and danger. One shows the artist himself gripped in the tentacles of a man-eating plant; another portrays him surrounded by parasites and dangerous fish. Something political about tourism is implied, but the satire is less biting than it should be, and the painting looks like overblown magazine illustration (Johnson).
 
 RANDY WRAY, Derek Eller, 526-30 West 25th Street, (212) 206-6411 (through Nov. 11). To make his oddly confounding paintings, Mr. Wray first creates a funky, coffee table-scale abstract sculpture that he then photographs; the photograph is in turn digitally transformed into a kind of paint-by-numbers diagram that the artist copies in paint using brushes and various sorts of extruders, adding three-dimensional canvas elements as well. The final products are ambiguously suggestive and slightly creepy, hovering between pixilated abstraction and surrealism (Johnson).
 
Other Galleries
 
"PASTORAL POP!," Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris, 120 Park Avenue, at 42nd Street, (917) 663-2453 (through Dec. 15). Nature-inspired kitsch is the theme of this delirious seven-artist show. It includes Rob de Mar's comical landscape in the form of a spindly tree, Lisa Ruyter's psychedelic update of Seurat's "Grande Jatte," Alyson Shotz's grove of weird plant machines, Peter Gould's transformation of the guard station into a bucolic cartoon, Jason Middlebrook's Styrofoam stonewall planter, Katrin Asbury's miniature diorama in a planter and Rachel Feinstein's suspended Rococo-style pitcher exploding flowers like a pinata (Johnson).
 
Last Chance
 
ROE ETHRIDGE, Andrew Kreps, 516-A West 20th Street, Chelsea, (212) 741-8849 (through tomorrow). Mr. Ethridge's clever orchestration of his own almost hallucinogenically clear photographs includes portraits of UPS delivery men in their trucks, head shots of two pretty young female models, close-up studies of young pine trees and a big picture of an ambulance that had just crashed. Believe it or not, these disparate images are persuasively connected by the theme of perfection and its tragic impossibility (Johnson).
 
 DAN FLAVIN, Zwirner & Wirth, 32 East 69th Street, (212) 517-8677 (through tomorrow). Flavin's simple fluorescent-light works from the 60's illuminate this posh new gallery to simultaneously matter-of-fact and mystically radiant effect. The white ones have classic Minimalist rigor; examples consisting of just two or three colors are almost hedonistically sumptuous (Johnson).
 
 JOHAN GRIMONPREZ, "Inflight!," Deitch Projects, 76 Grand Street, SoHo, (212) 343-7300 (through tomorrow). Mr. Grimonprez's 1997 film "Dial H-I-S-T-O-R-Y" documented the history of skyjackings through vintage film and video footage to riveting effect. This time he offers a parody of an inflight magazine -- free to all visitors -- filled with excerpts from books and magazine articles about skyjackings. A mock airline waiting room provides a theatrical context. One gets the point about how the media turns history into infotainment, but this project is not as compelling as the film (Johnson).
 
 LAWREN STEWART HARRIS, Americas Society, 680 Park Avenue, at 68th Street, (212) 249-8950 (through Sunday). A co-founder of the famous Group of Seven, a collective dedicated to the advancement of a truly Canadian vision in painting, Harris (1885-1970) produced his best work in the 1920's and 30's. In this engaging retrospective, his wilderness scenes of icy mountains, remote lakes and lonesome houses rendered in a simplifying style like Georgia O'Keeffe's have a poignant romanticism and visionary radiance (Johnson).
 
 * JACQUES HENRI LARTIGUE, Edwynn Houk, 745 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street, (212) 750-7070 (through tomorrow). This magical exhibition of more than 60 vintage prints was drawn from the private collection of the French photographer's widow, who died in May. Concentrating mostly on small, wonderfully lively pictures made when he was a teenager, it vividly conveys his boyish enthusiasm for childhood games and horseplay, his fascination with flying, racing cars and fashionable women, and his excitement about the miracle of photography itself (Johnson).
 
 JANE AND LOUISE WILSON, 303 Gallery, 525 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 255-1121 (through tomorrow). The British twin-sister video makers here direct their haunting ultraformalist vision to sites of post-cold war resonance: two centers of research, training and development for the Russian space program. Focusing mostly on architecture and high-tech equipment, their four projections take you on a mesmerizing Cubistic journey through places that seem at once futuristic and dilapidated, a mix of "2001: A Space Odyssey" and "Blade Runner" (Johnson).
 
 CINDY WORKMAN, Lennon, Weinberg, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 941-0012 (through tomorrow). Laminated to the reverse side of Plexiglas panels that are attached to the wall by heavy bolts, Ms. Workman's layered, digitalized montages of found imagery -- little girls, scientific or technical diagrams, girly cartoons and old smut photographs -- meditate on innocence, experience, consumerism and modernity (Johnson).

PUB-DATE: November 3, 2000

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 1; Automobiles 

LENGTH: 1274 words

HEADLINE: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Technology;
Hybrid Cars Show Up In M.I.T.'s Crystal Ball

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE Massachusetts Institute of Technology and DaimlerChrysler have given their assessments on the future of the automobile, and have both come out in favor of hybrid gasoline-electric cars. But scientists at M.I.T.'s Energy Laboratory, working with computer models, had an easier time predicting costs and benefits of the cars than DaimlerChrysler, working in steel and glass, is likely to have selling them.
M.I.T. completed a two-year study last month comparing a gasoline-powered 1996-model sedan with some cars that might be feasible by 2020, including advanced gasoline models; hybrids that combine a gasoline or diesel engine with an electric motor and batteries; cars running on fuel cells with a raw fuel of either natural gas, gasoline or methanol; and electrics running on batteries. The study was a "well to wheels" comparison that took into account the energy use and greenhouse-gas emissions at every stage, from making the gasoline or other fuel to burning it in the vehicle. It also looked at the costs to consumers of the various technologies. 
 The engineers found that the best car would use an electric drivetrain and get its energy from a small internal-combustion engine running on gasoline, diesel fuel or compressed natural gas. More exotic technologies like fuel cells or pure battery-electric cars would be more expensive and, taking into account the energy required to make their hydrogen or electricity, did not compare favorably on energy use or greenhouse emissions. But a hybrid car could cut greenhouse emissions, perhaps by half, though it would cost about 20 percent more than a conventional gasoline automobile.
DaimlerChrysler said the extra charge would be $3,000 for a hybrid version of the Dodge Durango, a hefty four-wheel-drive sport utility vehicle. The engineers would substitute a V-6 engine for the Durango's
V-8 and disconnect it from the front wheels, which would be powered instead by a 100-horsepower electric motor. The motor would draw on a battery, and the battery would be recharged by letting the front wheels drag a little -- using the motor as a generator, converting torque to electricity instead of vice-versa. It would do that during braking, thus recapturing some of the energy lost at each stop sign.
The hybrid's acceleration would be equal to, or better than, a gasoline Durango. Short-distance performance off road would be equal, but for long off-road drives, the electric side would have trouble recharging, engineers said.
One expected result is an increase in fuel economy, to 18 m.p.g. from 15. But the actual cost to the company is not clear; for one thing, the plan is to use lithium-ion batteries, the kind now in high-end laptop computers, and those have not yet been built on the scale the Dodge would require.
Adding three miles a gallon for $3,000 means, with gas at $1.60 a gallon, that 1,875 gallons would have to be saved to break even. If the vehicle went 12,000 miles a year, the ordinary version would use 800 gallons, and the hybrid version, 667. With savings of 133 gallons a year, the added cost of the hybrid would take 14 years to pay for itself, or 168,000 miles -- a challenge for a Dodge truck. An economist would calculate that the savings would have to be even larger to break even, to take account of the interest payments that the $3,000 could have earned if left in the bank -- or if not borrowed from the bank as part of a car loan.
Consumers who weigh the energy efficiency of appliances they are buying usually look for a three-year payback. The Durango could do that if gas was $7.50 a gallon (133 gallons a year for 3 years is about 400 gallons, divided into $3,000).
DaimlerChrysler executives had said they would not build the car unless Congress approved a tax credit. But now, perhaps goaded by Ford and G.M., DaimlerChrysler plans to go ahead regardless. Also in 2003, Ford plans to sell a hybrid version of its Escape, an S.U.V. slightly smaller than an Explorer, and G.M. is working on hybrid pickup trucks and buses. Toyota and Honda are already selling small hybrid-powered cars, and G.M. has been working with Toyota on a small hybrid S.U.V.
Bernard Robertson, senior vice president for engineering technologies at DaimlerChrysler, said in announcing the 2003 production date for the hybrid Durango that his company hoped eventually to sell 100,000 hybrid vehicles a year of various models, perhaps 30,000 of them Durangos (or 15 percent of Durango production).
But the purpose seems more to break the ice than to save gasoline. At $3,000 a vehicle, and 100,000 vehicles a year, the added cost would come to $300 million a year. Asked if that much money would save more gasoline if it were invested in marginal shifts like better engines and lighter bodies, he said it was possible, though he had not done the calculation.
The Durango came out better on cost, though, than another car shown off by Chrysler in October, a Jeep Commander concept car powered by fuel cells. DaimlerChrysler says it wants to sell fuel-cell buses in 2003 and fuel-cell cars in 2004, but Mr. Robertson acknowledged, "There are a lot of challenges left."
The biggest is to cut the cost of fuel cells to $50 per kilowatt of capacity -- about what that much power costs from an internal-combustion engine; engineers will not be specific, but at the moment the figure is perhaps 100 times that. The car carries 50 kilowatts of fuel cells. Moshen D. Shabana, chief fuel cell engineer on the project, acknowledged with a smile that this was "the most expensive vehicle I ever touched."
M.I.T. seems confident that the costs of fuel cells will fall, along with the costs of batteries and other components of advanced vehicles. But plain old gasoline is likely to be the cheapest power source.
Malcolm Weiss, a researcher who was the lead author of the M.I.T. study, said in an e-mail message that if payload, performance and range stayed constant, the new, more fuel-efficient vehicles would always cost more. They "cannot pay for themselves in fuel savings based on any personal rational economic analysis," he said; there would have to be other reasons to buy them.
He wrote, "Perhaps customers will come to value fuel efficiency as a social good they're willing to pay for -- or perhaps taxes will go way up (politically absurd), increasing the value of fuel savings, but don't hold your breath." He calculated that the owner of a hybrid Durango would lose $387 a year, at current gasoline prices, compared with the owner of a conventional Durango.
His study, which tried to predict the state of technology by 2020, listed a margin of error on its estimates of 10 to 30 percent, which made its conclusions less than authoritative. And the authors acknowledged looking at the feasibility of technology, not the actual process of inducing change in a multibillion-dollar industry.
The M.I.T. study mostly looked at energy consumption and gases that play a role in global warming. It assumed that all vehicles would meet the current federal "Tier 2" standards for smog pollutants and did not concern itself further with such conventional pollution, although a proponent of fuel cells could argue that they are cleaner.
The study compared a 1996-model Toyota Camry, the "reference" vehicle, to an advanced internal-combustion car, a hybrid using gasoline, diesel or compressed natural gas, a fuel cell car using gasoline, methanol or hydrogen, and a battery electric car.
The battery car, which was the car of the future a decade ago, is too expensive and is not the best on energy consumption and greenhouse gases, the study concluded.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
A Market in Search of Direction Settles for Mixed Results

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Buyers moved selectively back into the stock market yesterday, snapping up financial and technology issues after the market's decline on Wednesday. Selling in basic material and retailing stocks left the overall market mixed.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 18.96 points at 10,880.51. Broader stock indicators fared better. The Nasdaq composite index rose 95.63 points, or 2.9 percent, to 3,429.02, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was up 7.10 points, or half a percent, at 1,428.32. 
 The market seemed in search of a direction a day after the Dow and Nasdaq fell on a mix of profit taking and a profit warning by WorldCom.
Technology issues led the gainers, with Intel up $1.81, to $46.69, and Sun Microsystems rising $3.19, to $109.06.
Shares of Oracle fell, however, after rumors rippled through the markets early in the session that its chief executive, Lawrence J. Ellison, and chief financial officer, Jeffrey O. Henley, planned to resign. The software company's stock plunged as much as 13 percent before public denials from Mr. Ellison and Mr. Henley convinced investors the rumors were false. Still, Oracle shares fell $1.81, to $29.56.
Financial issues were higher across the board. Merrill Lynch rose $1.31, to $69.81, after dropping Wednesday.
But weakness in issues of materials companies like the aluminum manufacturer Alcoa, which fell $1.31 cents, to $27.75, and in energy companies, like Exxon Mobil, down $3.88, to $88.19, kept the Dow treading water.
"There has been a pop-up in retail and material company stocks over the last couple of days, but it didn't seem to have fundamental support. Rather it was more of a rotation toward stocks that hadn't moved up yet," said Ronald Hill, investment strategist at Brown Brothers Harriman. "I think now we're seeing that gain was short-lived."
Retailers received a mixed response. Many retailing issues have been trading down for months on worries that moderating economic growth will hurt their bottom lines.
J. C. Penney was up 75 cents, to $12, after initially falling on weak October sales. Wal-Mart Stores was up $1.25, to $48, after reporting strong monthly sales but warning of a weak fourth quarter.
The warehouse retailer Costco rose 44 cents, to $36.19, recovering from earlier losses after Banc of America Securities downgraded its stock. But Home Depot, a Dow component, slipped $1.13, to $42.88.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasury Prices Mixed
 (By Reuters) -- Treasury bond prices were mixed yesterday after a report showing a jump in unit labor costs dampened expectations that the Federal Reserve might soon shift to a neutral stance on interest rates.
The 10-year Treasury note rose 1/32, to a price of 100 4/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.73 percent from 5.74 percent on Wednesday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 1/32, to 106 19/32. The bond's yield was unchanged at 5.78 percent.
Recent data have fueled optimism that the Fed may soon drop its bias toward tighter credit in favor of a neutral stance. But an unexpected jump in worker compensation kept bonds close to Wednesday's levels.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
'Green' Tower at Battery Park City

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
While it will be the 22nd residential tower in Manhattan's Battery Park City, the 266-unit rental scheduled to rise there next will be the first designed as a so-called green building: one that is energy efficient, environmentally sensitive and healthier for tenants.
The Albanese Development Corporation of Garden City, N.Y., is developing the 27-story structure, estimated to cost $110 million, to meet environmental and design guidelines set by the Battery Park City Authority. The building, billed as the nation's first green residential high-rise, will be at Terrace and Murray Streets, overlooking the Hudson River. 
 It will feature such advanced engineering technologies as a central heating and cooling system fueled by natural gas to increase energy efficiency. The system also includes a fresh-air heating, cooling, filtering and humidifying system that will serve all apartments. And to conserve water, it will have a water recycling plant in the basement to treat waste water from showers, sinks and washing machines and reuse it for irrigating plants and flushing toilets.
Each of the one- to three-bedroom units, averaging 750 to 1,500 square feet, will have its own temperature controls. Each will also be equipped with energy-efficient appliances, including washers and dryers. And the developer will limit the project's impact on the environment by using materials that, among other things, have recycled contents and reduced toxicity.
Outside, Cesar Pelli & Associates has designed the building's glass and masonry facade with photovoltaic panels that convert sunlight into electricity. The panels will be arranged mainly in a vertical pattern -- and in some places used instead of brick -- over the main entrance to the building to supply 5 percent of the building's electrical load. The roof will also be covered with lightweight soil and plantings, creating a parklike setting that will provide added insulation value to the roof.
In addition to the project's environmental features, planned amenities include a health club, children's playroom and garage parking. All of the apartments, designed by Schuman Lichtenstein Claman Efron, will have floor-to-ceiling windows in the living rooms to maximize light and views. A third of them will be three-bedroom units, which are in short supply and high demand in the downtown rental market, said Russell C. Albanese, president of the development company. He said construction would start in the first quarter of 2001, with completion 18 months later.
The Battery Park City Authority recently issued requests for proposals to develop two more green buildings on North End Avenue between Murray and Warren Streets, near the Albanese development in what the authority calls the north neighborhood.
Those buildings, which could hold 250 apartments each, will continue development in that neighborhood, which began in 1995 and has since filled with five residential buildings, totaling some 1,440 rental units, more than 200 of them for the elderly.
Four more residential and two commercial buildings that will complete the development of Battery Park City will also be green, said James F. Gill, chairman of the authority. "With this project," Mr. Gill said, referring to the Albanese rental, "we are trying to demonstrate that developers can build buildings that are advanced environmentally and from a health point of view and still turn a profit."
The Albanese building will be the first to be built under New York State's $25 million environmental tax credit program, which is intended to encourage the construction and rehabilitation of environmentally friendly buildings. Under the program, which was signed into law in May and will become effective in January, property owners can apply for tax credits to offset the cost of designing buildings with higher energy efficiency and lower impact on the environment.
Mr. Albanese said his company got involved with the project "because it was a great opportunity and the economics make sense." He estimated that adding the environmental features to the building would account for 12 to 15 percent of the $110 million construction cost. But, he added, his company is confident it will recoup much of the cost in the long term through lower operating costs.
And though monthly rents have not been set, Mr. Albanese said that given the building's riverside location, larger units and amenities, it not only "will achieve top rental rates, but push the market upward."
Douglas Wagner, president of Benjamin James Associates, a residential brokerage company in Manhattan, said average annual rents at buildings in and around Battery Park City were $44.35 a square foot. That means monthly rents would be $4,435 for a 1,200-square-foot two-bedroom apartment and $5,543 for a three-bedroom unit with 1,500 square feet.

HEADLINE: Private Buildings Sought for Public Schools

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Trying to address a shortage of sites on which to build new schools, Chancellor Harold O. Levy said yesterday that he wanted to ask private real estate developers to construct mixed-use buildings that would put commercial offices or apartments on top of new schools.
The idea, which has been used infrequently over the last three decades, has gained reinvigorated currency recently as the Board of Education has developed a growing backlog of new school proposals. 
 At least 12 new schools, meant to serve more than 5,000 students, have languished on the School Construction Authority's drawing board for more than a year because the Board of Education cannot find sites for them. Rising prices for property, opposition in some communities and environmental problems on many of the available parcels of open space in the city have hampered the search for sites.
Under Mr. Levy's proposal, which is still in the early stages, developers could gain tax advantages or expanded building rights if they agreed to include schools on the bottom floors of buildings they plan to construct on their own property.
Theoretically, that could open a host of new, privately owned sites to potential use by the Board of Education. Another option would have the school system sell the air rights above current school buildings to private developers, and those buildings could then be expanded as part of larger mixed-use complexes constructed over the existing schools.
Education officials said Mr. Levy's staff had already discussed the idea with several developers. Mr. Levy said he had directed David Klasfeld, the Board of Education's deputy chancellor for operations, to explore "how we might be able to work with real estate developers to multiply the number of classrooms we have."
"The New York City school system is probably the largest real estate owner in the city," Mr. Levy said. "This could be another vehicle to get new schools and classrooms, potentially faster than we could otherwise build them."
Some or all of the construction costs could be financed using the bonding authority of the Educational Construction Fund, a city agency that has sold bonds for similar uses in the past but which has been been inactive in recent years. The fund is separate from the School Construction Authority, which operates on a budget allocated by the City Council.
One large New York City developer applauded the idea of public-private partnerships yesterday. Henry Elghanayan, chief executive of Rockrose Development Corporation, said he believed that many real estate companies would be interested in a plan to put up mixed-use buildings on Board of Education property or their own building sites.
At least two such sites already exist in New York City. In Battery Park City, Public School-Intermediate School 89 occupies the bottom few floors of the Tribeca Bridge Tower, a 25-story, 151-unit rental building at the corner of West and Chambers Streets. The building was developed by the Battery Park City Authority, a state agency.
The type of public-private partnership envisioned by Mr. Levy is more likely typified by Norman Thomas High School, which occupies space in a commercial building on Park Avenue between 33rd and 34th Streets.
That building was developed in 1974 by Cohen Brothers Realty and Construction Corporation on the site that once held the 71st Regiment Armory. The property had been owned by the state and was conveyed to the Board of Education for school use. The board leased the air rights to Cohen Brothers and issued bonds that would be paid off through future lease payments to finance school construction. The school's entrance is on 33rd Street, around the corner from the building's Park Avenue commercial entrance.
Mr. Levy disclosed his interest in the development plan yesterday at a meeting of the School Construction Authority in response to a question about the possibility of housing schools in mixed-use buildings from Howard Wilson, chairman of the construction authority's trustees.
Mr. Wilson was appointed to the construction authority board by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who along with Mr. Levy, also a construction authority trustee, has advocated varying forms of public-private partnerships throughout the city's school system.
Anthony P. Coles, deputy mayor for planning, education and cultural affairs, said that while City Hall had not seen the specifics of Mr. Levy's proposal, it was an idea that the city had successfully implemented in the past and was worth considering again. Certainly money is not the main obstacle to solving the problem of overcrowded schools, which affects every borough in the city, said Adam L. Barsky, director of the city's Office of Management and Budget.
In addition to the $7 billion included in the five-year capital plan, which would pay for construction through 2004 by the School Construction Authority, the mayor's office last year set aside $150 million, to be administered by the Economic Development Corporation, for use by private developers that want to build new schools.
Nevertheless, school overcrowding is rampant, particularly in Queens, where each of the seven community school districts operates above capacity and some schools have 60 percent more students than they were intended to hold.
Six new schools that were planned for construction in Queens beginning last year have still not been started because of trouble finding sites for them, according to the School Construction Authority. Last spring, dozens of residents of Maspeth, Queens, attended a City Council hearing to protest plans for a new elementary school, saying they wanted the site to be used for a Staples office supply store instead.
Even finding a potential site is no guarantee that a school will be built. For one proposed school in District 6 in Upper Manhattan, the School Construction Authority has conducted 13 feasibility studies of how and where to place the school on various sites.

HEADLINE: Bill Gates Turns Skeptical On Digital Solution's Scope

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: REDMOND, Wash., Nov. 1

 BODY:
As the "Creating Digital Dividends" conference drew to a close in Seattle recently, the final speaker arrived and started asking skeptical questions. The premise was that "market drivers" could be used "to bring the benefits of connectivity and participation in the e-economy to all of the world's six billion people," according to conference materials, but the speaker would have little of it.
"I mean, do people have a clear view of what it means to live on $1 a day?" the speaker, William H. Gates, asked. "There's no electricity in that house. None." 
 When a moderator brought up solar power, Mr. Gates shot back, "No! You can't afford a solar power system for less than $1 a day." And, "You're just buying food, you're trying to stay alive."
It is a theme to which Mr. Gates, the world's richest man, returns in an interview at his office here at the Microsoft Corporation, the giant software maker he founded. Pacing the room, waving his hands, he conjures up an image of an African village that receives a computer.
"The mothers are going to walk right up to that computer and say, My children are dying, what can you do?" Mr. Gates says. "They're not going to sit there and like, browse eBay or something. What they want is for their children to live. They don't want their children's growth to be stunted. Do you really have to put in computers to figure that out?"
For a man often thought of as the world's chief evangelist for technology, Mr. Gates is assuming a surprising role these days, in which he seems to be taking his own industry to task for having far too much faith in digital solutions to the planet's worst ills. He openly dismisses the notion that the world's poorest people constitute a significant market for high-tech products anytime soon. Such thoughts, he says, may undercut the case for urgent aid to the most impoverished people.
But in a way, the man who has also become the world's biggest philanthropist seems to be taking himself to task, offering the confession that he himself was "naive -- very naive" when he began his charitable endeavors six years ago.
When he did so, he said in the interview, he expected that projects involving computers and information technology would make up the bulk of his giving. But now his priorities are otherwise, with health care, especially development and distribution of vaccines, soon expected to account for at least two-thirds of the grants offered by the $21 billion Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.
Or, as he put it at the Seattle conference, the world's poorest two billion people desperately need health care right now, not laptops.
Mr. Gates said he had certainly not lost his faith in the long-term promise of technology to deliver a better world. But he has lost much of the faith he once had that global capitalism would prove capable of solving the most immediate catastrophes facing the world's poorest people, especially the 40,000 deaths a day from preventable diseases. More philanthropy and more government aid -- especially a greater contribution to foreign health programs by American taxpayers -- are needed for that, he says.
And it also explains, he said, why he has taken on the unaccustomed role of self-described "troublemaker" about the promises of technology. It is a role he assumed at the Seattle conference, which created a stir in his industry and irritation among at least some of the organizers, but one that he seems to have played at other recent appearances.
"Whenever the computer industry has a panel about the digital divide and I'm on the panel, I always think, 'O.K., you want to send computers to Africa, what about food and electricity -- those computers aren't going to be that valuable,' " he explained in a speech last month before the Global Foundation in Melbourne, Australia.
"They want to sit on the panel and talk about how the computers will solve all the world's problems," Mr. Gates continued. "They're amazing in what they can do, but they have to be put into the perspective of human values. And certainly as a father of two children, thinking about the medicines I take for granted that are not available elsewhere, that sort of rises to the top of the list."
Some people in Mr. Gates's industry have commended him for his recent comments, while others have accused him of setting up a straw man. Nothing in the quest for a more wired world, they say, is at odds with the notion that food and health care remain a more immediate concern.
And still others, including some of Microsoft's principal competitors, argue that Mr. Gates is downright wrong. They say there are all kinds of tangible, profitable products that their industry is developing that will help improve people's lives, including the world's poorest people. Some directly involved in the conference here, sponsored by the nonprofit World Resources Institute, seemed annoyed by Mr. Gates's comments.
"After listening to three days of serious analysis and work, and then to have Gates rather flippantly say, 'You've got to have clean water and food,' to hear that simple repetition of Maslow's hierarchy, that wasn't exactly furthering the point of the entire meeting," said John Gage, the chief research officer for Sun Microsystems and the founder of Netday, a global volunteer effort to connect schools to the Internet.
Mr. Gage's reference was to Abraham H. Maslow, the psychologist who suggested that human beings reach fulfillment through satisfying a series of needs, which begins with basic physiological needs like food and water and rises to others that include love, self-esteem and personal expression. Where Mr. Gates has it wrong, Mr. Gage argued, is that technology is rapidly being used to satisfy even the most basic needs on the hierarchy.
Mr. Gage, known as a periodic critic of Mr. Gates, said that the declining cost of cell phones and other hand-held mobile technology would soon make them immensely useful for even the poorest people. They might use the devices to share important information about health care and food conditions, he said.
Others in the industry were more measured in their response to Mr. Gates's recent comments. "I think he's right and he's wrong," said James F. Moore, chairman of GeoPartners Research Inc., which specializes in technology and economic-development issues. "He's right, and I'd emphatically support him on this, that other divides are more important than the digital divide: the divide on health care, the human-rights divide, the education divide."
But in the view of Mr. Moore, a policy adviser to Hewlett-Packard, which recently announced a $1 billion program to focus on new markets in the third world, "what's going on here is that people are really trying to think about the essence of high technology and what it can do. And I would say I think he's missing something by being so dismissive of these markets."
Mr. Gates, however, seems adamant on the point. "Anybody who says, 'Oh sure, we'll sell to the people who live on a dollar a day,' they just don't get it," he said.

HEADLINE: Public Interests;
Now, the College Bowl

BYLINE: By GAIL COLLINS 

DATELINE: SCRANTON, Pa.

 BODY:
These days, the Gore campaign really cannot say enough good things about the Electoral College.
"The Founding Fathers were men of vision," Mr. Gore's press secretary, Chris Lehane, said sunnily. 
 If this were a normal country, where getting the most votes equals winning the election, the Gore people would be in the classic sullen campaign-on-the-skids mode by now. But they're actually pretty chipper, in a manic, sleep-deprived sort of way. (You have never seen so many eyes with huge pupils outside of a detox center.) The national polls are not really going their way, but Mr. Gore seems to be either slightly ahead or tied in the big up-for-grabs states like Michigan and Florida and Pennsylvania. If he wins there, he could rack up enough Electoral College votes to take the presidency.
Reasons it might be fun to have an election where one candidate wins the popular vote but loses the White House:
* Makes up for our having missed the last one in 1888.
* Sudden demand for documentaries on the Electoral College provides job opportunities for people who have been unemployed since the millennium roundups ended.
* Chance to see how spontaneous combustion really works when Trent Lott gets the news.
Best of all, the whole situation makes every voter feel important. (This of course does not include people who live in non-swing states like New York or Massachusetts, where there are so few signs an election is going on that the citizenry must think it's been postponed.) The whole game could hinge on a very small number of votes in a few very key places -- a precinct or two in central Florida, the level of turnout in Flint or Detroit. The vice president has been driven into an absolute frenzy of activity by the possibility that one more speech, or one more minute at the right table at the right senior citizens breakfast, could make all the difference.
"I need your help! I need your help!" he cried at a late-evening rally in Scranton. Mr. Gore was working on two hours' sleep and he had just come from a long day of campaigning in Florida. ("Listen," said an aide proudly, as the vice president delivered an address on Social Security at one stop. "He just said the name of the town. He definitely knows what state he's in.")
In Scranton, you would have thought he was fresh as a daisy, except for the fact that his words tended to come in bursts, as if his brain were in danger of short-circuiting. Searching for a non-abortion-related Supreme Court issue that might interest Catholic union members, he finally blurted out "those anti-working people provisions they're trying to come up with."
But the crowd was not so much listening to his points as waiting for opportunities to jump in and lend a hand by cheering wildly. Mr. Gore took off his coat to demonstrate his determination to fight hard. Then he rolled up his shirt sleeves, delighting the people even more. If the temperature at the outdoor rally had not been in the mid-30's, he might have gone one step short of the full monty.
This is called energizing your base, a political task that requires a great deal of stamina and a willingness not to dwell too long on the exact point behind all your effort. It's the job Mr. Gore has been training for all his life. At last we have an explanation for why his father the senator forced young Al to spend an entire summer clearing 20 acres of underbrush with a hand ax.
Who knows what will make the difference? Tipper Gore has put in hours and hours giving interviews while balancing delicately on the arm of her husband's chair, in case there's somebody left who doesn't know they're happily married. True, anyone out there now who's truly undecided is probably either too dim to find the polling place or too sensitive to live outdoors. But still, maybe the next hand you shake will belong to the aunt of that one swing voter who will turn the precinct that turns the county that turns the state that provides the last critical electoral vote.
"It may come down to you," Mr. Gore told members of the Tampa football team this week, on the outside chance that any of them actually lived in Florida.
Finally, a single vote does matter. And it belongs to a Tampa Bay Buccaneer.

HEADLINE: Productivity of Workers Increases, as Do Labor Costs

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2

 BODY:
The productivity of workers, which has underpinned the nation's record economic expansion, grew more strongly than expected in the third quarter even as some inflation pressures increased, the Labor Department reported today.
The report said that productivity in nonagricultural occupations -- the hourly output for each worker -- increased 3.8 percent compared with the previous three months, below the 6.1 percent rise recorded in the second quarter and above market forecasts of a 3.1 percent increase. 
 Unit labor costs, closely watched for signs of inflation as the largest part of total production costs, increased 2.5 percent after falling 0.2 percent in the second quarter, exceeding expectations of a 1.5 percent rise.
The strong unit labor cost reading was not enough to change investor expectations that the Federal Reserve will hold interest rates steady when its policy-making panel meets on Nov. 15. "The economy is cooling, but productivity is holding up and containing unit labor costs," said Gary Thayer, chief economist at A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis.
Compared with figures in the period a year earlier, unit labor costs were up only 0.1 percent, the report said. It also said the second-quarter productivity gain had been revised upward from an originally reported 5.7 percent increase.
The productivity report came on the heels of other data showing that the economy had lost some of its vigor. Economic growth slowed to 2.7 percent in the third quarter from a breakneck pace of 5.6 percent in the second quarter, perhaps reassuring Fed policy makers that six interest rate increases between June 1999 and May 2000 had succeeded in cooling the economy.
And the Conference Board, a private research group, said today that its Index of Leading Economic Indicators, a key measure of economic activity, was unchanged in September at 105.7, in line with expectations.
Productivity growth was again strongest in manufacturing, where it increased 6.4 percent from the previous quarter. Year over year, manufacturing productivity was up 7.5 percent, its biggest increase on record, the Labor Department said.
Overall productivity in the nonfarm sector was up 5 percent compared with figures in the period a year earlier, the report said.
"It's suggesting this structural change playing out in the U.S. economy seems to still be continuing," said Paul Ferley, assistant chief economist at the Bank of Montreal/ Harris Bank.
The report also said that hourly compensation rose by a strong 6.4 percent, its highest rate of increase since an 8.8 percent gain recorded in the first quarter of 1992.
In a separate report, the government said the number of Americans seeking first-time unemployment benefits remained unchanged last week at 308,000, pointing to a continued tight labor market -- another potential inflation risk that has been prominent on the list of Fed worries.

HEADLINE: Retail Sales in October Up a Disappointing 2.9%

BYLINE: By LESLIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
At the Lord & Taylor flagship store on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, decorators are hard at work on the circus-themed holiday windows to be revealed in two weeks. Sony Play-Station 2, the season's hottest gift item, is already almost impossible to find. But even as the season's rituals unfurl with predictable flourish, many retailers are preparing to deal with a rising tide of consumer malaise.
Retail sales for October in stores open at least a year, a crucial industry measurement, rose just 2.9 percent, according to the Goldman, Sachs retail composite index. That was one of the smallest increases this year and well below last year's October gain of 4.9 percent. 
 Those lackluster numbers came after the Conference Board reported on Wednesday a sharp monthly decline in consumer confidence, and they seemed to offer further proof that shopper enthusiasm, while strong by historical standards, was declining going into the all-important holiday season.
Merchants typically generate some 40 percent of their business around Christmas. And two consumer surveys released this week held out hopes that Americans might yet open their wallets wide for the holidays and bail out retailers. But most investors and economists remain unconvinced.
"Don't count on the consumers," warned Jeffrey Feiner, a retail analyst at Lehman Brothers, summing up the darkening industry mood.
Facing high gas prices, stock market volatility and increased interest rates, many large merchants have been lowering their sales estimates during the year. The trend continued yesterday.
After the stock market closed on Wednesday, Gap Inc., which has been struggling to get its fashion mix and back-up delivery systems right this year, announced that its third-quarter profits would be slightly lower than analysts had expected. In October, the ubiquitous chain reported that sales declined 2 percent over October 1999, a performance actually better than the 4 to 6 percent decline the company had originally predicted.
Even Wal-Mart Stores Inc., by far the nation's largest merchant, announced that sales growth for the fourth quarter would be a solid but unspectacular 3 to 5 percent. That is down sharply from last December, when Wal-Mart had 9.1 percent year-over-year sales growth. Stock analysts had been expecting growth more in the neighborhood of 4 to 6 percent a month.
Slowing economic conditions contributed to the mediocre sales, but fashion missteps by some retailers may be making the problem worse. The merchants that had the right fashion mix had strong gains, most notably the Limited Inc., whose high-flying Express division reported a stellar 22 percent sales growth over the previous October. Its stores were loaded to the hilt with the hippest items -- gold-tone jeans, leather and rabbit trim everything.
"Fashion is getting a lot flashier," said Irma Zandl, president of the Zandl Group in New York, which tracks teenage buying habits. "To succeed, you want to have that pimped-out look, which is so much harder to get right than your basic khaki."
A fortunate note is that many retailers had anticipated the clouding sales picture and had taken steps to protect their bottom line. "The managements have accepted that we are in a slower economy," said George Strachan, a retail analyst with Goldman, Sachs, "There has been a lot more conservative planning for the second half. Even companies that are putting out bad numbers have their inventories controlled."
There were also reasons to hope the holiday season might yet still shine. The 15th annual Consumer and Retailer Mood Survey: Retail Holiday Outlook, conducted by Deloitte & Touche in affiliation with the National Retail Federation and released Wednesday, predicted that consumer spending on general merchandise, apparel and home furnishings would rise by a strong 5.5 to 6.5 percent in November and December.
The survey based its positive assumptions partly on sound consumer fundamentals like low unemployment and partly on a September poll of 1,000 consumers, 82 percent of whom said they planned to spend at least as much as they did last year. "Look, it's not going to be a barn-burner, but it is not going to be a disaster either," Irwin Cohen, global managing director of the consumer business practice at Deloitte & Touche, said of the holidays.
The American Express retail index, released yesterday, had similarly optimistic findings. Polling 800 consumers, American Express concluded that holiday spending would rise 8 percent over 1999. The survey also found that consumer budgets across every category of holiday spending were at their highest levels since the survey began in 1995, and that spending could exceed these estimates, because 44 percent of all respondents said they usually spent more than they budgeted.
In keeping with previous seasons, clothing is expected to top holiday shopping lists, according to American Express, followed by gift certificates and money, music, compact discs and movies, toys and games.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY;
Less Venture Backing for Start-Ups Is Seen

BYLINE: By MATT RICHTEL 

 BODY:
The nation's venture capital firms, while continuing to invest at a steady pace, are bolstering companies in which they already have stakes at the expense of financing new ventures, according to an industrywide report to be released today.
The numbers suggest that venture capital financing has leveled off as investors fundamentally reassess where they place tens of billions of seed money, shifting it away from Internet start-ups. 
 The report was compiled by the National Venture Capital Association, a trade group, and Venture Economics, a research division of Thomson Financial Securities Data.
Over all, the venture firms -- typically high-risk, high-reward investors that seed companies in their early stages -- invested $25.9 billion in 1,774 companies in the third quarter. That is a slight drop from the $27.8 billion and 1,830 companies they invested in in the quarter before, and an indication that the level of venture capital financing has leveled off after exploding in the previous two years, researchers said.
"The faucet has been turned down a bit," said Jesse Reyes, vice president for global product management for Venture Economics. "We'll continue to see some slowing down over the next couple of quarters."
The figures gel with a report issued earlier this week by the Venture-One Corporation, a market research firm that measures a less broad universe of venture investors. The VentureOne report found that in the third quarter, venture capitalists invested $16 billion in 879 deals, 6 percent fewer dollars and 16 percent fewer deals than in the previous quarter.
But researchers who compiled both studies said that more remarkable than the overall investments is their composition, in particular the emphasis on investments in companies already in the venture capital portfolios.
According to the report released today, venture capitalists invested $5.2 billion in 623 start-ups during the third quarter, compared with $7.1 billion in 695 start-ups in the second quarter. By contrast, in the third quarter, venture capitalists put $18.32 billion in follow-up rounds of financing into 1,010 companies.
Sasha Talebi, director of research for VentureOne, said his firm's own research reflected in part an overly zealous atttitude toward investments during the dot-com boom. "Many of them have been burned this year, and many of them have been burned by markets that have not matured," he said. "They are putting more time and energy into making their existing portfolio companies successful."
And, by their own admission, they are putting time and energy into closing some investments that will never have a chance at success. With the public-market investors no longer favoring consumer and retail-oriented Internet companies, venture capitalists say they have begun to shed those companies from their portfolios, assuming they no longer have a place to resell their investment.
The phenomenon has resulted in a spate of layoffs and closings of Internet companies, which should continue, said Jim Breyer, a partner in Accel Partners, a venture firm.
"We expect to see a dramatic increase in the number of bankruptcies and mergers," Mr. Breyer said. "A lot of private companies are actively targeting the holiday season as a do-or-die time."
Still, the recent spate of failures far from fully dampens a historic period for venture capital firms. Investment leapt from $14.3 billion in the third quarter of 1999 to $25.9 billion in the fourth quarter, the figure around which it has hovered since, according to the report from Venture Economics and the National Venture Capital Association.
The organizations said that investment in the third quarter of this year -- $25.9 billion -- would probably wind up being a higher figure as the researchers get additional information on deals in the weeks after the report is filed.
Still, the venture capitalists have for several months been reworking the balance of their portfolios away from consumer-based Internet companies. According to the VentureOne study, the beneficiaries are biotechnology companies, in which investment rose 140 percent in the third quarter over the previous quarter and medical and health companies, which had a 70 percent jump.
Investment in Internet companies over all accounted for 70 percent of the venture capital allotment, a drop from 80 percent in the quarter before, according to the report.
Mr. Talebi, from VentureOne, said his firm's research found that the percentage of investment in Internet-related ventures fell in the third quarter and the second quarter.
 
http://www.nytimes.com
