SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 3186 words

HEADLINE: Uneasy Pieces in an Era of Mergers;
The Chaos At the Core Of Prosperity

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT

 BODY:
THIS is not what a victory party is supposed to look like.
The American economy is enjoying its longest expansion on record, and an unusually large share of the gains has gone to corporate profits. It has been years since people questioned whether the United States was falling behind Europe or Japan. Instead, other countries are scrapping regulations to try to make their economies and corporations more like America's. Those United States companies are selling the world not just diet sodas, chicken sandwiches and blue jeans, but also movie tickets, Internet access and word-processing software. 
 Yet one could hardly describe the last few months in corporate America as a celebration. One after another, pillars of the vaunted American economy have been shaken.
AT&T, once the world's largest company, is splitting itself into four pieces, reversing its multibillion-dollar strategy of the last three years. The chief executives of Coca-Cola, Gillette, Procter & Gamble and Xerox -- all prototypes of the global corporation -- have resigned unexpectedly or been fired in the last year. J. P. Morgan, the nation's most prestigious commercial bank only 10 years ago, decided that it could no longer survive on its own.
No organization seems safe. Dot-com businesses are filing for bankruptcy, and Wal-Mart has yet to figure out how to build a good Web site. Medium-size companies are putting themselves up for sale, saying they cannot compete with global behemoths, while the behemoths are suffering from currency fluctuations. Stalwarts of both the new economy and the old, from Intel to Home Depot, have watched their stocks drop as much as 50 percent in a day because of mildly bad news.
"This is the best economy I've ever seen," said Charles Pradilla, 60, chief investment strategist for SG Cowen Securities, "and here we have some of these icons in deep trouble."
All of this offers perhaps the best evidence yet that corporate America has entered a new stage of instability, one in which seemingly ascendant companies can quickly lose their way. Many causes of this instability -- like deregulation, globalization and changes in technology and on Wall Street -- may not be new, but they are coming together in particularly explosive ways. A result, analysts say, is a reminder that the very companies that have pushed for such tectonic shifts must also often pay a price for them.
"People are dealing with more variables at one time than they ever did in the past, and a lot of the changes are of a fundamental nature," said William Esrey, chief executive of Sprint and the recently elected chairman of the Business Council, a group of more than 100 top chief executives. "The pace of change is clearly at an unprecedented level."
 
Against the Economic Grain
The turmoil of recent months, however, seems inconsistent with what life should resemble in the world's richest nation a decade after it last went through a recession or had a serious strategic rival on the world stage.
"It's a wonderfully counterintuitive situation," said Adrian J. Slywotzky, a management consultant who writes often about large companies.
An unprecedented bull market has left investors accustomed to 15 or 20 percent annual returns -- and willing to punish harshly any companies that show signs of falling short of earnings targets. Those targets, meanwhile, have become harder to reach as economic growth has begun to slow.
Nowadays, companies also have to compete with all sorts of new rivals, as the Clinton administration has continued a two-decade American push toward deregulation and freer trade. Investment houses suddenly face threats from banks, and onetime phone monopolies are doing battle with telecommunications companies based on other continents. Perhaps even more important are the technological shifts that have forced companies to make enormous bets that can turn sour within years, or even months.
This notion of rapid economic change has been popular for at least five years, roughly since Netscape Communications went public amid great acclaim and the Internet became recognized as a mass medium. Management books soon appeared with titles like "Blur" and "Blown to Bits." For even longer, economists have recognized that globalization and technological change can exact a heavy price on workers, in the form of layoffs or depressed wages.
But there is more than anecdotal evidence that the shifts are taking a new toll on American companies. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is on pace to change by an average of more than 1 percent a day this year, which would be the first time it did so since 1987, the year of the crash. Change the yardstick to the number of days in which the index moves by at least 3 percent, and this is the most volatile year since 1946, according to Leuthold Weeden Research in Minneapolis.
Those gyrations are one reason for the record number of chief-executive departures -- voluntary, supposedly voluntary or otherwise. Even throughout the 1990's, when corporate governance reforms and the Internet were said to be endangering executives, annual turnover in the corner offices of America's 200 biggest companies hovered at about 10 percent. In the first 10 months of this year, it has already reached 19 percent, according to Pearl Meyer & Partners.
In October alone, 129 chief executives -- at companies of all sizes -- left their jobs, more than twice as many as in the same month a year ago, according to Challenger Gray & Christmas, a job placement firm in Chicago.
Mr. Esrey said members of the Business Council now discuss whether they should wait to invite new chief executives to join the group, in case their tenure is brief. "That concept never even came up in the past," he said.
The big question now, analysts say, is whether this instability is a harbinger of yet more turmoil when the economy truly does slow down or moves into recession. In one outlook, expectations for profit and stock growth will wane, causing share prices to become more stable and giving executives greater room for error.
On the other hand, the battle for profits is almost certain to intensify during a slowdown. Prices will become even more difficult to raise than they are now, and American consumers -- the world's most reliable revenue generators for a decade -- will cut back their purchases. As companies struggle, and investors demand action, the mergers, spinoffs and resignations may become all the more common.
"We really are in new and uncharted territory," said David Hale, chief global economist for Zurich Financial Services. "The general profit slowdown has really just begun in the last few months. And the consequences of that we don't understand."
 
A Cannibalistic Vision
"Creative destruction" has become the most fashionable phrase for describing the change. Coined by Joseph A. Schumpeter, an early 20th-century economist, it suggests that capitalist economies grow by creating new businesses that then destroy the old ones. It is a cannibalistic vision that seems perfectly tailored for the recent turbulence.
But the theory behind the phrase also offers insight into the turmoil of the last few months. Dr. Schumpeter, an Austrian who spent much of his career at Harvard arguing against many conclusions of Karl Marx and John Maynard Keynes, asserted that profit comes only from innovation. When all companies are making the same goods the same way, he said, none can make a profit, because they eventually cut prices to the level of their costs.
Then along comes an entrepreneur -- a word also popularized by Dr. Schumpeter -- with a new product or process. That person's company can cut prices, lift sales and still earn a healthy amount -- until rivals figure out how to mimic the innovation. Earnings then decline until another wave of creative destruction sweeps aside the old.
In real life, though, there were many ways to earn profits without a recent innovation. Some companies -- selling, say, electricity, financial services or telecommunications -- had exclusive access to a market because of trade barriers or internal regulations. Other companies prospered for years from a single innovation that competitors struggled to copy or surpass.
In recent years, however, a phalanx of political and economic forces have come together to turn creative destruction into a reality for a much wider range of industries. "The theoretical competitive model has been around forever," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at Deutsche Bank Securities Alex. Brown. "Only in the past few years has it become relevant to how markets are actually operating."
 
Of AT&T, and Beyond
 If Dr. Schumpeter were alive today, his students would almost certainly be hearing a lot about AT&T.
In 1996, the Clinton administration and a Republican-led Congress agreed on a new law intended to open vast swaths of the nation's communications network to competition. AT&T would again be allowed to sell local phone service, while the regional Bell companies it shed under court order in 1984 could offer long-distance plans.
That part of the story has been a familiar one over the last decade. The repeal of the Glass-Steagall Act last year freed banks and investment firms to tread on one another's turf. Utility deregulation has permitted stodgy monopolies to reshape themselves. Trade agreements have enabled companies to move factories to Mexico and to sell more goods in Europe and Asia.
In virtually every case, businesses have pushed for the dismantling of regulation and trade barriers, and many Republicans and Democrats in Washington have reached a consensus in support of most of the measures. Businesses' vigorous support has contributed enormously to the notion that globalization helps companies -- particularly big, lean American ones -- at the expense of workers. Critics of the policies point out that economic data supports that notion, at least over the short term. Largely lost in the debate, however, is the instability that deregulation causes at the very companies that are its champions.
Without deregulation, J. P. Morgan, PaineWebber and First Boston might all still exist as free-standing firms. Old-line energy companies would not be looking enviously at the market capitalizations of Enron and AES, two companies that did not exist in 1980. AT&T almost certainly would not be ripping itself apart for the second time in 16 years.
"As regulation fades away, you have a lot more opportunities, but you also have a much more intensely competitive environment," said Daniel Yergin, the chairman of Cambridge Energy Research Associates, a consulting firm, and the co-author of "The Commanding Heights," a book about markets triumphing over government. AT&T, for example, found itself competing not only with Sprint and WorldCom but also with the regional Bells, an entirely new set of upstarts and foreign carriers like Vodafone.
Even when an act of deregulation took place decades ago, some effects are being felt only now. President Jimmy Carter took the government out of the business of designing airline schedules in 1978, but only in the last few years has lasting low-fare competition seemingly arrived in the Northeast, in the form of Southwest Airlines. This suggests that the broader turmoil across the economy is unlikely to abate soon.
In most industries, it isn't simply that the players are changing; the game is, too. The explosion of computing power in recent years has allowed companies to greatly shorten the time needed to develop a new product or to copy a competitor's innovation. In other words, they have moved much closer to Dr. Schumpeter's theoretical vision.
Consider the personal computer industry itself. Dell Computer recently introduced a menu on its Web site to let customers to design their own computers. The customers would choose how much memory and how large a monitor they wanted, then provide a credit-card number. It was a far less cumbersome process than Dell's rivals put their customers through, said Mr. Slywotzky, the consultant -- and within months, those rivals had mimicked virtually every aspect of the menu. Now many manufacturers have similar sites.
"It's a shocker when you look at it," said Mr. Slywotzky, a vice president at Mercer Management Consulting, but "that's a microcosm of what's going on in industry."
Clothing, perfume and furniture designers -- even toymakers -- all copy successful rival products much faster than they once did. "Time lines which used to be measured in 5- to 10-year periods are now down to 2 years," said C. K. Prahalad, a professor at the University of Michigan's business school who is on leave to work as chairman of Praja, an Internet software company.
Perhaps more significant, executives say they do not even know what products they will be selling in a few years. As a result, many are taking enormous gambles on unproven technology, hoping that they will reap similar-sized profits down the road.
For C. Michael Armstrong, AT&T's chief executive, that meant buying cable and high-speed Internet access companies at a total cost of $100 billion. He thought that many consumers would eventually log on to the Internet through the fat cables that were connected to their televisions and could carry huge amounts of data. In the three years since his shopping spree began, however, financial markets have begun to wonder whether wireless technology will beat cable to the punch. Within months, investors had changed their minds about the strategy's wisdom, and Mr. Armstrong decided last month that he had no choice but to abandon the grand plan. A week later, fickle investors prompted Worldcom to reverse course, too.
"When technology is changing so fast," Mr. Yergin said, "it's possible to make brilliant decisions, but it's also possible to make brilliant mistakes."
 
Prices Under Siege
The pricing pressure that has become a part of nearly every large industry has complicated the task. For AT&T, the squeeze came in long distance, where competition was driving down the price of a phone call more quickly than management had expected, Mr. Armstrong said. So even as the company tried to strike out in a bold new direction, its core business was withering.
This is a common story. Gillette tried to lift profit margins in its Duracell division by introducing an expensive long-lasting battery, and the new product was a hit. But the company's revenue suffered because its competitors were able to grab sales by cutting prices in the lower end of the market. Last month, Warren E. Buffett, the billionaire investor and a member of Gillette's board, forced the resignation of its chief executive.
The causes of the pricing squeeze may vary by industry, but at the heart of each is an accelerated race to find profits. Packaged-goods companies, like Procter & Gamble, have suffered as consolidating retailers have introduced many private-label brands.
In the past, those less-expensive products gained market share only during recessions, said Burt P. Flickinger III, managing director of Reach Marketing, a consulting firm in Westport, Conn. Now, even after 10 years of an economic expansion, the most popular brand of vitamins is Wal-Mart's OneSource, Mr. Flickinger said, and the most popular dog food is its Ol'Roy line (named for Sam Walton's hunting dog).
AT&T can blame its troubles on deregulation and new technology. Car companies are suffering from a global glut of their products. A vast array of businesses must fend off more imports, and the price of those imports has fallen steadily in recent years, according to the government.
Those are the reasons, economists say, that Dr. Schumpeter has become so in vogue. "The only way to be very profitable is to innovate," Dr. Yardeni said.
Of course, innovation requires talented people to come up with new ideas and then turn the ideas into profits or cost savings. But executives at dozens of companies say their biggest problem is a shortage of good employees. They can blame themselves for part of the problem: throughout this expansion, layoffs have continued to be a core part of many strategies, leaving companies with lower costs but fewer experienced people. AT&T famously fired 30,000 workers in 1996, landing Robert Allen, then its chief executive, on the cover of Newsweek, alongside the headline "Corporate Killers."
The tight labor market has also played a role, giving many people new alternatives. And the bull market has permitted some senior managers to retire early. "There's been a general weakening of management in American business," Mr. Flickinger said.
If these trends -- layoffs, price pressures, technological advances and deregulation -- have been percolating for some time, it is Wall Street that has caused them to boil over, analysts say.
Driven by the strong performance of American business, and by what people now consider a speculative boom, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index more than tripled between the start of 1995 and the spring of this year. That is an annual growth rate of about 25 percent, well above the growth pace of corporate profits. Given that stock prices are a bet on future earnings, the imbalance may not continue for long, said Mr. Esrey at Sprint.
"It's irrational," he said. "We have not reinvented the laws of finance." On Friday, Sprint itself said that its 2001 profits could be 21 percent less than Wall Street's expectations.
But investors have become accustomed to fat returns, and they continue to look for stocks that will provide them. That is not easy, because the market has given many companies high share prices based on the assumption that they will take advantage of technology to earn huge profits. When a company announces that it will fall short of a goal, investors head for the exits. "It's like you're a tightrope walker," said Robert E. Litan, director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution. "One slip, and you're in the net."
Even a partial list of companies that have found that net in recent weeks is impressive: Apple Computer, Eastman Kodak, Home Depot, Intel, Nortel -- and AT&T. With the rise of day trading and, more significantly, the pressure on mutual fund managers to post better returns than their peers, a stock often falls harder and faster than in the past, sometimes pulling down the rest of its sector, too.
All the while, the $100 billion venture capital industry is scouring small companies, looking for the next winner. In the past, almost all entrepreneurs had to go begging for financing. Now, Dr. Yardeni noted, the money goes looking for them.
"The V.C.'s find the latest innovations, and they come to market," he said. "And then the V.C.'s find the wannabe challengers."
The picture is keenly reminiscent of Dr. Schumpeter's theory: companies that do not innovate will wither. For people wary of the dry language of economics, Ken Goldstein, an economist at the Conference Board, suggests a Bob Dylan lyric to describe the current reality: "He not busy being born is busy dying."

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Gloom Over Ad Shares, but Why?

BYLINE: By BERNARD STAMLER

 BODY:
THEIR earnings this year have been good -- great, in fact, according to many people who study the industry. Consolidation has increased their global reach, simultaneously reducing their vulnerability to problems in any particular market. And on Wall Street, there is enormous optimism about their earnings and growth.
So why are investors so bearish about advertising companies and their stocks? 
 The torrent of Olympics-related ads is past, election campaign commercials are about to end and dot-com advertising is a shadow of its former self, explained Lauren Rich Fine, a Merrill Lynch analyst. Then there is the possibility of a cooling economy. "People are concerned that this has been a peak year in advertising, and that this is as good as it gets," she said.
And so, despite stellar results for the first three quarters of this year, advertising shares have performed rather poorly.
That is especially true for the big three, which were created over the last several years through a frenzy of mergers and acquisitions: the WPP Group, based in London, whose J. Walter Thomson, Ogilvy & Mather and newly acquired Young & Rubicam units make it the world's new No. 1 advertising and marketing company in revenue and billings; the Omnicom Group, based in New York and now second, with agencies like BBDO Worldwide, DDB Worldwide and TBWA Worldwide; and the Interpublic Group of Companies, also in New York, whose agencies include Draft Worldwide, the McCann-Erickson World Group and the Lowe Group.
Within the last month or so, before their favorable third-quarter earnings reports and the Dow's rebound, they languished at or near their 12-month lows. Despite solid prospects, their shares are still trading far below their peaks of about a year ago.
Ms. Fine concedes that it may be difficult for those agencies to replicate the sharp revenue increases -- 16 percent at Omnicom and WPP, 15 percent at Interpublic, even before the impact of acquisitions -- that they enjoyed last year.
"But so what?" Ms. Fine declared. Despite the likelihood that, as corporate profitability cools, the current rate of expansion in ad sales will slow, she is predicting double-digit growth in revenue for the big agencies in 2001. And her view is shared by other analysts, who are concentrating on the revenue figures because of the possibility of an economic slowdown.
But investors also remain wary of the agencies, says Alexia S. Quadrani, an analyst at Bear, Stearns, because they confuse what they do with what media companies do. "These are not just ad companies, but marketing services companies, too," she said. "And they are at least a couple of steps removed from the weakness now seen in broadcast companies."
They are global and diversified, she said, with less than half their revenues derived from ad sales. And their manner of compensation has mostly changed. Once, commissions -- or pay based on a percentage of billings, usually 15 percent -- predominated. Now many clients pay fees to agencies for actual work done or to compensate them on the basis of performance, rewarding them for increasing sales or stimulating interest in a product.
James D. Dougherty, an analyst at Prudential Securities, said a very small percentage of these companies' revenues come from buying advertising in the United States, "even though people seem intuitively to think otherwise." Less than 10 percent of their revenue comes from commissions on advertising sales, he said.
Because Interpublic, for example, has grown so large and diversified, said Sean F. Orr, the company's chief financial officer, "half of our business consists of things like direct marketing, sales promotions, public relations, event marketing and market research -- businesses that are not media-related.
Susan Watson, Interpublic's senior vice president for investor relations, said fee-based compensation for creating advertisements resulted in the company's being "paid the same thing," whether an ad "is seen in one magazine or 50, or on one television station or on more."
In some ways, however, a downturn in advertising spending can catch the agencies unaware. Internet advertising is not turning out to be as reliable a source of growth as some agencies had hoped. For instance, Zentropy Partners, an interactive consulting business that Interpublic had hoped would compete with publicly traded firms like Razorfish, has now become part of another Interpublic agency rather than remaining autonomous. Plans to take Zentropy public were foiled late last month by market resistance to new, Internet-related initial public offerings, and by the slowdown in dot-com advertising.
Ms. Fine said Zentropy would do better as an integrated part of a larger agency than as a separate business.
But not all large agencies are doing as well as the big three. True North Communications, based in Chicago and ninth in global revenue, has snared new business in the last year from marketers like Taco Bell and Kraft. But its growth, at just under 12 percent for the third quarter, has been less than that of its larger competitors.
And its biggest client, the Chrysler Group of DaimlerChrysler, is considering consolidating all the work handled by True North and Omnicom at one of those agency companies; a decision is expected soon. Revenue from the Chrysler Group is about $140 million, or 9 percent of the True North total. Even if True North emerges as the winner of the review, it will likely be earning less profit from handling the Chrysler assignment, because the primary reason for the consolidation is to save the company money. As a result, Mr. Dougherty, for one, will not recommend True North's stock to Prudential's customers.
BUT even the DaimlerChrysler cloud has its silver lining, according to Ms. Quadrani of Bear, Stearns. She contends that the impact of losing the account has already been absorbed by True North's stock, which fell significantly when the review was announced.
Besides, if DaimlerChrysler left, it would eliminate potential conflicts if True North combined with any other agency company, like Interpublic, that had big automotive clients.
"It would make True North a very attractive takeover candidate," she said, and that much more attractive to investors.

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES;
A Quiet Sign of Better Days Ahead

BYLINE: By MARK HULBERT; Mark Hulbert is editor of The Hulbert Financial Digest, a newsletter based in Annandale, Va. His column on investment strategies appears every other week. E-mail: strategy@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
THERE were no headlines last week announcing it, so most stock-market bulls are unaware of the good news. But a market timing model with a good long-term record has flashed the all-clear signal to re-enter the market.
The model is based on a statistic reported each week in the Value Line Investment Survey. It is the median projection from Value Line's analysts of how much the 1,700 stocks they monitor will appreciate over the next three to five years. After being cautious about the stock market for some time, the model based on this statistic is now forecasting healthy gains. 
 Most investors are probably unaware of the statistic, or of many others that Value Line publishes. Value Line is much better known for its stock ranking system, which over 35 years has outperformed the market by a large margin.
As best as I can determine, two people developed this market-timing model in the late 1980's, independent of Value Line and of each other: Daniel A. Seiver, an economics professor at Miami University of Ohio and editor of the PAD System Report, an investment newsletter, and Peter Bernstein, founding editor of The Journal of Portfolio Management. Each concluded that this measure of Value Line analysts' optimism could be valuable in timing the markets. Also deserving credit are William Reichenstein and Steven Rich, finance professors at Baylor University who conducted a study on a variant of the model in the early 1990's.
This model is helpful for two major reasons. First, Value Line's analysts are willing to make much longer-term forecasts than others -- projecting stocks' returns over three to five years rather than just the next several quarters. Second, they have proved themselves relatively immune to Wall Street hysteria. As the stock market rises and bullish sentiment heats up, they usually resist the tendency to raise their long-term earnings forecasts accordingly.
To be sure, Value Line's analysts are like their colleagues in at least one respect: they tend to be too optimistic. So both Mr. Seiver and Mr. Bernstein determined the Value Line median needed to be chopped by 50 to 60 percentage points to say where the market would be in four years.
In Mr. Seiver's codification, an all-clear signal occurs only when the Value Line's indicator approaches 100 percent, which, after adjustment, translates into an annualized return of about 11 percent over four years.
The median projection finally approached 100 percent in late October, as the market pulled back and as analysts' price targets remained largely unchanged. As recently as the summer of 1999, that figure had been as low as 55 percent.
I concede that some skeptics may dismiss this model, arguing that it largely missed the bull market of the late 1990's. Four years ago, the indicator stood at 50 percent, implying, after adjustment, that the market today would be no higher than it was in late 1996. Why pay attention to this model now after it was so wrong?
Because it was not wrong. The average American stock has produced only mediocre returns in the last four years, the picture painted by the popular market averages notwithstanding. Indexes like the Standard & Poor's 500, which weights stocks according to total market value, are dominated by a few stocks that happen to have done extraordinarily well, at least until recently.
But over the last four years, the Value Line Geometric Composite index, which gives equal weight to each of the 1,700 widely held stocks that Value Line monitors, has gained just 2.7 percent a year. That is not only well below the market's historical return of about 11 percent annually, but is also below that of simple money market funds. For investors who weren't lucky enough to be holding stocks like Cisco Systems or General Electric, the Value Line indicator has accurately reflected their experience.
So it is truly good news that this indicator is now signaling a buy.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
Going to Work to Sell Business Casual

BYLINE: By ABBY ELLIN

 BODY:
ONE evening in September, employees at Scient, an Internet business consulting firm in Manhattan, gathered for a party. They sipped green-apple martinis delivered to their desks and snacked on hors d'oeuvres served on fancy platters. A D.J. spun records. People danced and mingled. An hour or so later, they watched a fashion show.
But this was no ordinary company morale booster. It was the kickoff event for Banana Republic@yourservice, a marketing effort in which the retailer creates makeshift stores within companies to spread the word about its business casual clothing. The first to take part were New York offices of Scient, HBO and Credit Suisse First Boston. 
 Banana Republic, a unit of Gap Inc., is among the many clothing chains that view workers -- in their workplace -- as an important new market. Prompted by the trend toward casual dress on the job as well as the weak sales growth in many of their own stores, the retailers, like modern-day Willy Lomans, have decided to pitch their products on the road. But they are knocking on doors at the office, not at home.
Retailing executives do not expect an immediate windfall from such an effort. But they see it as a smart way to help define fashion trends and prompt repeat buying in an affluent part of the market at little cost.
"There is a lot of confusion in the workplace as business casual becomes more common in different types of work environments," said Christina Gabriel, director of Banana Republic@yourservice. "Plus, people don't always have the time to go out shopping, and to spend 10 minutes within their own workplace with someone who is completely skilled makes it really easy and painless."
But, she added, the objective is also to build loyalty with existing customers and to "register Banana Republic as a destination for business casual."
The on-site boutique at Scient was open all day and offered employees a 20 percent discount, complimentary tailoring, appointments with fashion consultants, free shipping and a two-week extension of the 20 percent discount for online purchases. At Credit Suisse First Boston, a similar effort lasted three days.
"It was great," said Yan Perepletchikov, a technician at Scient. Mr. Perepletchikov, 26, bought a shirt and two pairs of pants. "I usually shop five or six times a year, but this made it easier because everything was right there. I didn't have to waste time in stores."
Many corporations are embracing the trend toward less traditional work attire. The Society for Human Resource Management, a research concern in Alexandria, Va., found in a recent survey that 87 percent of office workers now had the freedom of "casual day" every day.
That said, many employees are confused as to whether "casual" means a less formal shirt and tie or bluejeans and a T-shirt. For that reason alone, retail analysts said, the in-office store is a good idea.
"If Banana Republic can provide the answer appropriately and confidently, especially on the male side, then they're making a friend for life," said Richard Jaffe, an analyst who follows the retailing industry at PaineWebber.
Corporate customers are being courted with elaborate perks from retailers like Brooks Brothers, J. Crew, Eddie Bauer and Ralph Lauren and department stores like Saks Fifth Avenue. Employees at various corporations receive discounts of 20 percent to 30 percent on their purchases, with the option to order online or at the store. Sometimes, the discounts even extend to the employees' family members. The chains also sponsor promotional nights in their stores just for corporate customers.
"Retail clothing companies are flexing to meet the ever-changing demands of society," said Angela Georgallis, a spokeswoman at the Society of Human Resource Management, adding that the apparel companies view workplace customers as very influential. "Why not partner up with huge, national companies to get their products and name out there, while making tons of money in the process? They're trying to strike winning deals between themselves and their customers -- enticing customers while growing their customer base."
Gap at Work, a program of the Gap chain, now has relationships with more than 50 companies including Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, Arthur Andersen, America Online and American Express. Employees receive a 20 percent discount on work clothes; they can download discount vouchers from their workplace computers for use in Gap stores, or they can shop online.
J. Crew has introduced an "In-between Weekends" catalog of sportswear and casual work clothes. The Corporate Alliance Program at Saks, which began last year, is aimed at corporate employees who may have thought that the store sold only much more formal attire. Corporate shoppers in New York and Boston receive discounts of 15 percent to 20 percent at Saks stores.
BESIDES their stated desire to relieve dress-code confusion, of course, the retailers have another motive -- selling more clothes. That is especially true this year, as apparel sales growth has slowed considerably.
The Credit Suisse First Boston total retail same-store sales index, a barometer of industry trends, increased 5.1 percent over the last 12 months, compared with 6.9 percent in the previous 12 months. It rose 4.4 percent for the third quarter, compared with 7 percent in the period a year earlier.
"It's been a choppy year for apparel and retailers relative to the last three years, and for some companies more so than others," said Barbara Miller, a specialty retail analyst at Goldman, Sachs. "Yet I'm not convinced they're doing it because growth is slowing elsewhere, but in a way to expand their franchise in a nontraditional way at a time when people are dressing in a nontraditional way and need a little guidance. It's an effort to capture customers at a time when customers are trying to figure out exactly what they should be wearing."
Other said the push into workplace clothing partly reflects retailers' anxiety about their fourth quarter, their most important sales period of the year. Last Wednesday, the Gap reported a 2 percent drop in October sales and warned that third-quarter sales would not meet Wall Street estimates. Other big retailers also reported disappointing October sales last week.
There is anecdotal evidence that the workplace clothing effort is producing sales gains.
In the Banana Republic program, Ms. Gabriel said, 625 employees of HBO, Credit Suisse First Boston and Scient had bought 2,360 items during the on-site promotions.
The promotions are aimed at workers who earn in the high five or six figures annually, raising the question of why they are even offered discounts.
"Price is an easy and effective way of getting potential customers' attention," said Richard Baum, a retailing analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston, who did not buy anything during the promotion. "The cost of getting a new customer, with advertising and catalog expenses, is more expensive than the 20 to 30 percent discount. It's a very effective way to do target marketing. You can go right into a C.S.F.B. and advertise to 1,000 employees."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Will Nasdaq's Fall Haunt the Democrats?

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON

 BODY:
MAYBE it's time to replace the famed campaign slogan "It's the economy, stupid" with "It's the Nasdaq, numskulls."
The amazingly close presidential race has puzzled investors accustomed to believing that as long as the nation's economy is strong, the incumbent party will be returned to power. Al Gore himself, locked in a down-to-the-wire battle, can only wonder why this year may be different. "We've had such prosperity for so long and Greenspan gets more credit for it and technology gets more credit for it," explained Tom Gallagher, a political economist in Washington for International Strategy and Investment. 
 Declining stock prices are also working against Mr. Gore. While economic news remains relatively rosy -- unemployment is low, and so are mortgage rates -- share prices have gone sour.
Although the broad market averages are basically flat this year, the Nasdaq composite, where individual investors have placed many of their bets, has been hammered. It is down 33 percent from its March high.
Individual stocks are faring badly, too, according to Salomon Smith Barney. As of Oct. 31, Nasdaq stocks were down 47.8 percent, on average, from their 52-week highs. Stocks in the Standard & Poor's 500 index were off 24.4 percent, on average.
Although the Nasdaq numbers have gotten a bit better in recent weeks, they are ugly when viewed historically. Today's average decline exceeds the 44.5 percent of November 1987, immediately after the market crash. The current decline is also much larger than the 42.2 percent drop seen in October 1990 after Iraq invaded Kuwait.
If Mr. Gore triumphs on Tuesday, the market should continue to move sideways. A Gore administration would probably continue attacking tobacco companies and would squeeze profits at health maintenance organizations and drug companies. Indeed, Mr. Gallagher said few industries or companies were likely to benefit from a Gore presidency. His short list included environmental cleanup companies and those developing alternative fuels.
If George W. Bush is elected, investors can expect more. The cloud over drug and tobacco stocks would lift. A Bush victory would also help Microsoft, Mr. Gallagher said, as a government-ordered breakup of the company would be less likely.
Christine A. Callies, chief United States investment strategist at Merrill Lynch, said airlines, whose stocks have fallen as oil prices have risen, could benefit from a Bush presidency. While Mr. Bush might consider modernizing the Federal Aviation Administration and relieving the staffing crunch in air traffic control that has caused an enraging increase in flight delays, Mr. Gore would probably not, she said.
Another favored area in a Bush administration, Ms. Callies said, would be stocks of electric utilities. The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, which sets price ceilings for utilities, is dominated by Democrats. Under Republicans, price caps could be raised, increasing profitability for power companies.
The only investors who might not celebrate a Bush victory would be the nattering nabobs of negativism in the bond market. Gemma Wright, director of market strategy at Barclays Capital in New York, expects bond prices to fall -- and interest rates rise -- if Mr. Bush wins.
"His proposal will give more of a quick stimulus to the consumer in the form of tax cuts," she said. "The bond market will be concerned that this will keep the Fed more inclined to leave interest rates higher than lower."
But the bond market would also be uneasy with a Gore victory. What it really wants is a continued stalemate between the White House and Capitol Hill. "When fiscal policy is a battle," Ms. Wright said, "the bond market is relieved."

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Splash of Cold Water for Bond Market

BYLINE: By DANNY HAKIM

 BODY:
IN March, Stephen J. Zaslaw invested $3,000 in a high-yield municipal bond fund. Mr. Zaslaw, 55, a software engineer who lives in Cream Ridge, N.J., near Trenton, expected some volatility. After all, high-yield -- a k a junk -- bonds pay higher yields for a reason. In the case of high-yield munis, they represent loans to finance municipalities or municipal projects that have low credit ratings or no credit ratings at all.
Still, a bond fund is a bond fund and not, say, an Internet stock fund. At least, that is what Mr. Zaslaw and most investors assume. But when Mr. Zaslaw checked his portfolio on Friday, Oct. 13, and found that his $3,000 had largely evaporated, he was left bewildered. 
 "What was three thousand and something was now less than $1,000," he recalled last week. "It scared the heck out of me."
Unfortunately for Mr. Zaslaw, this was no glitch by his brokerage firm. It was an October surprise that has left the mutual fund industry wondering about the reliability of municipal bond pricing and about what role, if any, high-yield muni bond funds should play in an investor's portfolio. Some in the business, however, say the episode raises more questions about one firm than about this investment category.
Mr. Zaslaw's investment manager was Heartland Advisors, a Milwaukee company with $2.3 billion under management. On Oct. 13, the firm announced that its Heartland High-Yield Municipal Bond fund had fallen more than 70 percent that day, after a change in the method used to assign values to its bonds. The collapse left it as the year's worst-performing mutual fund in any category, according to Morningstar Inc. -- trailing even the worst of the Internet funds. A second fund, Heartland Short Duration High-Yield Municipal, fell 44 percent that day. At the end of the day, the two funds' total assets amounted to $58 million, down from $120 million.
The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating, Heartland said, and shareholders have filed two suits against Heartland and one of the fund's managers, Thomas J. Conlin, who departed the firm for what were described as personal reasons a few weeks before the revaluation. In a statement, Mr. Conlin said, "My resignation from Heartland was neither a cause nor effect of the funds' declines."
An executive at a prominent bond investment management firm, Pimco Advisors, said the Heartland matter reinforced doubts about whether the risks of high-yield municipal funds were worth the potential rewards. "I just don't believe that a fund comprised strictly of high-yield munis makes sense for most investors," said Mark McCray, who manages $2.1 billion, including all six of Pimco's municipal bond funds.
Pimco, a unit of Germany's Allianz, does not offer a high-yield muni fund. "I believe it simply isn't worth the incremental risk for the extra percent or two of yield," Mr. McCray said. "Sure, it would be much easier to advertise and market a nice juicy yield, but I don't believe our municipal investors would be well served."
A top official at the Vanguard Group, the nation's second-largest manager of bond funds, disagreed. "I think that's hogwash, to say that a high-yield muni fund has no place in a portfolio," said Ian MacKinnon, chief of Vanguard's bond operation. Mr. MacKinnon called the Heartland revaluation "appalling" but said it should not sully high-yield muni bond funds as a category.
In fact, Vanguard's high-yield muni fund bears little resemblance to Heartland's. The Vanguard High-Yield Tax Exempt fund is not even considered a high-yield fund by Lipper Inc., the fund tracker The fund itself has only 10 percent of its $3 billion in assets invested in unrated debt.
By contrast, Heartland High-Yield Municipal, as of midyear, was nearly 97 percent invested in unrated debt. Such bonds, traded infrequently, are the most difficult to value. "A more normal allocation to nonrated debt would be 50 percent," said Christopher J. Kelsch, a Morningstar analyst. "They were way out there in terms of risk."
Most larger firms estimate the value of such bonds by using pricing services and their own analysts. It is part art and part science.
Until October, Heartland relied largely on a pricing service. Both Mr. MacKinnon of Vanguard and a Merrill Lynch executive questioned whether Heartland could effectively check its pricing service's work. "Obviously, they didn't have people out there in the field doing what we do," said Hugh T. Hurley III, a vice president in Merrill Lynch's bond department. "It was negligence, either by accident or on purpose."
Doug Lucas, a Heartland spokesman, said the firm is best known for stock funds. "It is important to keep in mind that we have more than 98 percent of the assets of this firm in the equity side," he said. Bond funds, he said, are "relatively new assets."
In 1997 and 1998, the Heartland High-Yield Municipal fund was a top performer, but now investors wonder if the fund's past net asset values were a mirage. "People who bought these funds feel like they've had their pockets picked," said Samuel H. Rudman of Milberg Weiss Bershad Hynes & Lerach, a New York firm representing the plaintiffs in one of the suits.
William J. Nasgovitz, Heartland's president and founder, said the risks were clearly described in prospectuses. He placed much of the blame for the two funds' troubles on the markets, saying that buyers for illiquid high-yield munis like those in the Heartland funds had grown scarce. "We changed the pricing to match the reality of the marketplace during the week of Oct. 9," he said, citing the Owens Corning bankruptcy filing and a general falloff in high-yield trading.
HEARTLAND itself has revised its method of valuing these bonds to reflect, Mr. Nasgovitz said, "credit quality concerns, lack of market makers, lack of bids" and trading in similar bonds.
Mr. McCray of Pimco said investors might want to be cautious about any high-yield muni bond fund. "As the economy slows, lesser credits will suffer," he said. "Investors in high-yield munis may find that the incremental 1 percent or 2 percent of yield doesn't pay for the risks."
Mr. Zaslaw had expected the $3,000 investment to pay a regular income without substantial risk. "Certainly I expected the principal to be preserved," he said.
So would just about any other investor who bought a bond fund. Now such conservative investors might want to think twice.
"Investors should rightly consider their investments in high-yield municipal bond funds as risk capital," Mr. McCray said. That does not mean one should expect to end up with a fund that drops 70 percent in a day. Unless it's Friday the 13th.

HEADLINE: The World: Middle East Maneuvering;
Palestinians Fight, but Iraq and Iran May Be the Winners

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AS Israelis and Palestinians battle for the same small piece of land, Iraq and Iran are using the conflict to portray themselves as the true champions of the Palestinian cause, and hence as the leaders of the entire region.
Iraq, in particular, has already benefited so much that it looks as if the Palestinians, believing that they're liberating Palestine, may be liberating Saddam Hussein instead. 
 The current crisis has accelerated the erosion of international sanctions against Iraq, allowing Mr. Hussein to argue that doing business with him is, by implication, striking a blow against America, which is excoriated regionally as the protector of Israel.
Since Saddam International Airport in Baghdad opened in August, more than 40 planes have landed from abroad, carrying aid as well as businessmen and government officials. Jordan announced last month that it would no longer let Lloyd's of London agents inspect shipments bound for Iraq arriving at the Jordanian port of Aqaba. Syria and Iraq plan to reopen their cross-border oil pipeline this month, in defiance of sanctions, and Turkey has recently become the first NATO country to upgrade relations with Baghdad to ambassadorial level. Even Iraq's Kurds have established a relationship of coexistence with the regime, denying Iraqi opposition leaders access to Kurdish territory.
The end of Iraq's isolation is especially worrisome, given that even before the outbreak of violence more than a month ago, Mr. Hussein had made a series of startlingly belligerent speeches, as he did before the invasion of Kuwait in 1990.
Last August, for example, he criticized "those rulers and kings who have sold out their souls" by allowing what he called the occupying foreigner to rule over them. He has called on the Arab masses to overthrow their rulers and told his people never to trust outsiders. At the recent emergency Arab summit in Cairo (the first such meeting Iraq had been invited to in a decade), Iraqi officials criticized their Arab brothers for not waging holy war against Israel. Iraq also mobilized several divisions on its western border, offering to step in if Syria needed military help. (The United States, aided by a number of Arab states, including Syria, ordered him to pull them back. He did.)
"We're seeing the old Saddam," said Judith Yaphe, a senior research professor at National Defense University. "He's trying to prove to his own population and to the Arab street that he's the only Arab standing up to the West. He's trying to send a message that, 'I'm in charge. I can do whatever I want. Watch me.' "
No one yet knows what, exactly, to watch for. Mr. Hussein "will use the pressure that he hopes the street could bring to demolish sanctions and to remind his neighbors that they will have to deal with him again as a legitimate Arab leader," Ms. Yaphe said, adding that even the next American president will have to wait for "what his next move will be in testing the resolve of the new administration."
Iran's role in the Palestinian-Israeli crisis is more complicated, because the Islamic Republic is trying to do two things at once.
ON the one hand, its reformist president, Mohammad Khatami, has worked for three years to position Iran as a responsible regional power and a reliable economic partner, forging alliances with key Arab and European governments. Last week Mr. Khatami was in Japan, the first Iranian leader to visit since the 1979 revolution, promoting his campaign for a "dialogue among civilizations" and granting Japanese firms negotiating rights for the development of Azadegan, the world's biggest undeveloped oil field.
On the other hand, one of the pillars of the Islamic Republic's foreign policy (and domestic legitimacy) has always been enmity toward Israel and support for the Palestinians. Iran continues to provide the Lebanese Shiite militia Hezbollah with weapons and money. It also gives money and possibly weapons to Hamas and the Palestinian Islamic Jihad. Half a dozen of Iran's Revolutionary Guards, the remnants of a far larger force deployed years ago, still train "Islamic warriors" near Baalbek in Lebanon.
Should the Palestinians and Israel make a comprehensive peace, however, the Iranian people may begin to question the point of their country's remaining a militant theocracy. For that reason, the current crisis hurts Iran's democratic reform movement and strengthens the hand of Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran's spiritual leader (who wields more power than the elected president) and the conservative clerics behind him.
Mr. Khamenei has called Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, "a traitor and an idiot" for making concessions to Israel. And in a sermon to more than 100,000 military volunteers two weeks ago, he said the only solution to the Middle East crisis was to destroy "the Zionist regime."
THE crowd responded with chants of "Ready, leader, we are ready," and some current and former military commanders said the volunteers were ready to fight and die to liberate Palestine.
It is unlikely their government will give them the chance. Iran cannot afford another war. Indeed, it cannot do anything terribly provocative and still continue to repair its international reputation. But if the violence between Israelis and Palestinians continues, Iran may find it more difficult to maintain its balance between re-entering the community of nations and calling for the destruction of one of its members.
Even Ayatollah Khamenei seems to recognize this. Instead of pledging arms shipments, troops or massive aid in his sermon, he called for Palestinians to stage a referendum to decide what kind of government they want.
Ultimately, the greatest fear of leaders in the region and Washington policymakers is that the two battle-tested powers of the Persian Gulf might forge an alliance against Israel, however temporary. But Iran and Iraq have never even signed a peace treaty ending their eight-year border war. Each still holds some of the other's prisoners, and Iraq allows an armed Iranian opposition group to operate from its territory, while Iran gives refuge to an Iraqi Shiite opposition group.
Instead, Iran and Iraq will probably continue to use this moment for their separate purposes. One thing neither is likely to do is offer much more support to the Palestinians.

SECTION: Section 8; Page 13; Column 1; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 1041 words

HEADLINE: BACKTALK;
Pushing Beyond the Physical Limits for Benefits That Outlast the Pain

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE

 BODY:
Toni Baum, a 39-year-old mother of two, runs her first marathon in 10 years today. She has been training even as sciatic pain burns down both legs, upping her dosage of the painkiller Celebrex to keep going. She loves that sense of well-being she feels, the smug righteousness as she hobbles back into the driveway after a long run.
Her psychiatrist, Dr. Antonia Baum, a 39-year-old in private practice and on the clinical faculty of the George Washington University Medical Center in Washington, wonders briefly if there is something masochistic in Toni's pleasure. She sees obsessive-compulsion in Toni's training regime. But then, because of their oneness, she backs off. 
 "There is a tendency to overpathologize this," she said last week after a seven-mile tapering run. "I don't think I'm doing any lasting physical damage, and psychologically I think there is something healthy about not succumbing to pain, to standing up to it. People just don't push themselves hard enough, long enough."
Despite the approximately 30,000 people who will be pushing themselves hard enough and long enough to finish today's New York City Marathon (Baum is running one in Virginia), the conventional wisdom is that most Americans prefer quick athletic fixes or long hours on the couch watching others. Since I won't be running any marathons today (I prefer my sustained voluntary pain from a bicycle seat), I have time to consider some of the paradoxes and complications of all this.
The country is growing fatter and less fit, even while it takes more steroids so it can train harder and/or look better. With the same yearning for a larger and more rigorous context that has brought many to new spirituality and orthodox religions, men and women have found ways to test and stretch themselves in long-distance running, swimming, biking, and in boxing and other martial arts. Meanwhile, the most celebrated athletes are the ones who follow the slam-dunk/home-run/knockout-punch yellow-brick road.
"Since the 70's, it's become unnatural for elite athletes to push themselves without a constant and terrific narcissistic boost to make the pain worthwhile," said Michael Miletec, a Detroit-area psychiatrist and psychoanalyst whose patients include pro athletes. "Maybe it's our lottery mentality, too many comforts, too much excitement, earn a million and feel great by 30. That ethos is entrenched in the culture in and out of sports. Can you imagine Keyshawn Johnson rowing?"
Think of what the Tampa Bay widemouth receiver is missing.
"Rowing is having sex with the earth," said Louis Mackall, one of five middle-aged men who pulled 100 miles from South Street Seaport to the tip of Long Island last June to, well, just do it. "The longer the better, to a point, and no need to rush. To row, say, eight miles out to a point of land is to stretch my body and lay it down over that whole length of water, just as my eye does in anticipation. Among other things this helps me recover from living too much in a box."
One attempt to escape the box is eloquently described in the forthcoming "Long Distance: A Year of Living Strenuously." The writer Bill McKibben dedicates himself to becoming a credible cross-country ski racer and learns, among other lessons, that "skiing up a hill, right at this particular moment, doesn't fit our culture quite as well as skiing down it."
The quick-fix ethos has even taken hold in boxing, traditionally a pit of arduous, even sacrificial, training. A strong economy, too many accredited championships and fewer fights for more money have meant fewer hours of roadwork, jumping rope, calisthenics and sophisticated weight-training, according to Dr. Ronald L. Kamm of Oakhurst, N.J., an internationally known sports psychiatrist and vice president of the board of Fighters' Initiative for Support and Training (FIST), a nonprofit aid group headed by the former heavyweight Gerry Cooney.
"The pros and top amateurs are in poorer shape than they used to be, except for the women," Kamm said. "But these recreational boxers, men and women, are very dedicated, and may be the fittest of all."
The first great athletes of America, the Indian runners, were marvels of endurance and dedication. When the Pueblos rose up against the Spanish in 1680, teams of runners delivered the messages that successfully bound the tribes. Some famous early marathon runners were Indian, and the first American to win the Olympic 10,000-meter championship was Billy Mills, a Sioux.
The third world runners who dominate modern marathons come from similar cultures of hardship where deprivation and suffering are givens, and a 26-mile-385-yard run for prize and endorsement money sounds like a good deal. Perhaps because of the leading runners' often touching back stories, we tend to overlook the commercialization of the marathon itself; television sponsors and sneaker pushers have become as entrenched here as in the National Basketball Association.
The real marathon competition is often between the so-called serious runners and the self-described penguins, many of them women, who start merely to finish. The faster runners who have trained hard to lower a personal best are frequently contemptuous of the sloggers who get in their way en route to their own slower life-enhancing experiences.
More jock than penguin, Toni Baum, the psychiatrist, will be wearing her 1990 Newport Marathon T-shirt today in the Montgomery County, Va., parks department race. She says she will be happy to break four hours after 10 years off to bear and raise her daughters. But she yearns for more.
"I've always thought there is something admirable about pushing beyond your physical limits," said Baum, who played varsity field hockey at Brown. "And if you don't do it, don't at least try, you'll be missing something very important in life."
Miletec, a former weight lifter, is specific about what's missing.
"You'll lose discipline, the dealing with frustrations, the working through mundane hard tasks, that enhances self-esteem," he said. "You need to know you don't have to run for cover when things get tough because you've handled tough, hard things before, that you have a sense of your own destiny, that you can't be beaten."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 16; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1082 words

HEADLINE: The World;
The Strange World of North Korea

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
REPORTERS accompanying Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright on her recent trip to North Korea had no chance to see the rusted steelworks, the flooded mines or factories at a standstill. Nor were they able to see the small livestock markets that have sprung up in some parts of the country, testimony, apparently of farmers' abandoning their collectives and taking matters into their own hands as a matter of sheer survival.
But they were able to see that a major hospital had no lights except in the foyer and to hear about operations without anesthesia. 
 They learned of the motto "Children are king," and indeed, Dr. Albright saw -- and danced along with -- 5-and 6-year-olds who literally sang the praises of the North Korean leader, Kim Jung Il. Some 15 miles out of the capital, however, children labor on a road-building project, breaking stones by hand, a sight that recently reduced some toughened Western aid workers to tears.
Even on a hasty two-day trip, it was clear there are only a few paradoxes in North Korea. The country is overwhelmingly poor, and its people are indoctrinated with a mixture of homegrown ideology focused on self-reliance and Communist beliefs from the 1920's and 30's.
In contrast to the United States' engagement with the Soviet Union and China, the Clinton administration has made clear that its objectives with North Korea do not include a makeover of the totalitarian regime into a democratic government with a market economy. The major goal is simply to coax Mr. Kim to get rid of his missiles and reduce the threat of war.
Mr. Kim's goals seem equally limited. His country desperately needs help, and if North Korea takes the necessary steps to get off the State Department's list of countries that support terrorism -- which essentially revolves around what to do with three members of a terrorist group, the Japanese Red Army, who are wanted by Japan -- the regime will qualify for support from the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.
But even given the modesty of each side's aspirations, if engagement continues, North Korea's people will inevitably come into more contact with the outside world. And that raises questions about how a nation as closed as North Korea will react.
Certainly, contacts with the West will come as a shock. But for the moment, the North Korean regime most fears contact between its people and South Koreans, who enjoy a vastly more prosperous life and who in large numbers feel great emotional bonds to their Northern brethren. In the days before Dr. Albright arrived, North Korean officials forbade American officials who drove over the demilitarized zone from South Korea to bring their South Korean drivers with them. All signs in English and emblems of South Korea affixed to the American officials' cars had to be covered.
But there is not the slightest hint that reunification along the model of East and West Germany is possible anytime soon. East Germany was far more porous than North Korea, where Mr. Kim has achieved an Orwellian thoroughness in keeping his people insulated -- all televisions and radios, which broadcast only government material, must be registered. What passes for broadcast news, largely the latest doings of the "Dear Leader," is delivered in a harsh martial voice, and often over street loudspeakers, making it hard to ignore.
Because self-sufficiency has been elevated by the state as the ultimate virtue and contrasts with modern prosperity have been shut out, there is little likelihood of immediate demand for the political and social change that brought revolution in the former Soviet Union.
Any kind of change is likely to come slowly. A few small ruptures in the seal around North Korea's people illustrate how glacial the pace of change may be.
FIVE years ago, the State Department's desk officer for North Korea, Ken Quinones, accompanied by three other officials, landed in the country for an extremely delicate job: overseeing the removal of fuel rods from the Yongbyon reactor that contained enough plutonium for four or five nuclear bombs. The mission was to start the process of closing down the reactor under the terms agreed to between North Korea and the United States in 1994.
The Americans, who were bunked at the top secret facility, were made to feel just what they were, Mr. Quinones said: enemies on enemy territory.
They fought to get the tiniest freedom of movement. Only after agonizing negotiation did they win the right to go for a morning and evening walk to a tree, a quarter-mile outside the gate. (It helped that the tree happened to commemorate the founding leader of North Korea, Kim Il Sung, the current leader's father.)
"Everything was gradual and incremental, with profuse explanations every step of the way," said Mr. Quinones, who is now the head of Northeast Asia projects for Mercy Corps, a nongovernmental organization specializing in medical help for poor countries, including North Korea.
One of the most interesting examples of interaction between North Koreans and outsiders is a joint effort between the government and the Nautilus Institute, a group based in Berkeley, Calif.
Two years ago, on a farm west of Pyongyang, Nautilus installed windmills to generate energy for household lighting, a village water pump and a refrigerator in the village kindergarten. To Peter Hayes, the director of Nautilus, the project illustrates how stereotypes can, over time, be broken down.
At first, he said, it was hard for the villagers to believe that the American technicians would return after the installation of the windmills, turbines and other equipment -- all of it imported, together with tools for assembling. When the Americans lived up to their promise and did return, some trust was established. Even so, Mr. Hayes said, it was hard to get villagers to allow the Americans to inspect their homes to see that the light bulbs initially installed were still working. But this suspicion broke down too.
Mr. Hayes says he was not surprised when one of the North Koreans on the project told him, "My mother thinks that all Americans are wolves, and we are the prey." But one North Korean showed great gratitude that his family was rescued from the darkness -- due to lack of oil and other energy sources -- that now blankets most of North Korea at night. The most rewarding words Mr. Hayes said he heard were from the man who said: "Thank you, please come back and build more."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE ECONOMY;
From Social Security to Environment, the Candidates' Positions

BYLINE: By Richard W. Stevenson

 BODY:
Voters have many questions about issues,and Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas have many answers. Here aresummaries of the Bush and Gore positions onpolicy issues that have recieved considerable attention in the presidential campaign, with a comparison to show how the candidates differand agree, and assesments of their position fromexperts and political analysts-some partisan, some not.
"Prosperity itself is on the ballot," Mr. Gore has been telling voters in the campaign's final weeks. And while both candidates flatter themselves by suggesting that they have the right prescription for an economy as large, complex and ever-changing as this country's, there are stark differences in their approaches. 
 The main battleground has been fiscal policy. Assuming that the federal budget surplus materializes as projected over the next 10 years -- by no means a given -- the next president will have an opportunity to apportion trillions of dollars, something none of his recent predecessors has enjoyed.
Mr. Bush would use much of the surplus for a $1.3 trillion, across-the-board tax cut, much of which would go to upper income households, and the creation of personal investment accounts within Social Security.
Mr. Gore's emphasis would be on eliminating the $3.4 trillion national debt and increasing spending on education, health and the environment.
Mr. Bush's approach embraces the conservative orthodoxy that reducing tax rates creates incentives for economic growth that benefit everyone. And it is rooted in the ideological belief that people are better equipped to make economic decisions than are governments.
Mr. Gore emphasizes that eliminating the government's borrowing puts downward pressure on interest rates -- the equivalent of a tax cut for most people -- and frees capital for use in more productive ways, for example building a factory or founding the next Microsoft.
Although each campaign has sought to label the other's proposals as reckless budget-busters, both approaches, in general, are well within the mainstream of economic thought.
In terms of bang for the buck, debt reduction trumps tax cuts in the view of Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, especially when the Fed is trying to keep the economy from overheating. But as Mr. Bush points out, tax money that flows into Washington is often spent before it can be used for debt reduction.
The expansion has now been under way for 116 months, 10 months longer than any previous business cycle. There is no indication that the good times will end soon; still, with each passing month the chances increase that the next president will have to deal with a downturn.
Mr. Gore has said that in a recession his instinct would be to keep the budget balanced and trust the Fed. Mr. Bush's aides say a weakening economy would only bolster the case for a big tax cut.
 Richard W. Stevenson
 
CHECKLIST
 
Would give a tax cut to everyone who pays income tax
Bush -- Yes
Gore -- No
 
Would pay off the $3.4 trillion national debt by 2012
Bush -- No
Gore -- Yes
 
Supports repeal of federal inheritance tax
Bush -- Yes
Gore -- No
 
Has pledged not to interfere with the Federal Reserve
Bush -- Yes
Gore -- Yes
 
TWO ASSESSMENTS
 
"There are two big issues: keeping the expansion going, and the neglect of social investment over the last decade and more. Bush's big tax cut puts the economy in a much more vulnerable position on the first point, and pretty much precludes us from getting back to a more balanced set of investments. We have this huge and vibrant private sector, yet fundamental human needs are not being met. We have the most inefficient health system in the world. For all the talk of the information age, we're investing insufficiently in education. Head Start, there's a program everyone loves, and it's still not fully funded."
 
Jeff Faux, president, Economic Policy Institute
 
"The contrast is one of philosophy. Bush would give individual citizens more power over their money. Gore would empower the collective community through government. The contrast is between Bush and returning the money to taxpayers and Gore's ambitious new spending agenda. The question is whether politicians will spend the money before either candidate gets a chance to do what they want with it. That's the $64,000 question: whether these surpluses will materialize. Everything else is commentary."
 
Marshall Wittmann, senior fellow, Hudson Institute

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Who Needs The Next Four Years?

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
THE moment should strike sometime around midday on Wednesday. It will dawn on someone -- perhaps the president-elect himself -- that despite all that rosy campaign-trail optimism about how this is America's moment of glory, the next four years could get really, really nasty.
While America remains strong and prosperous, there's a palpable nervousness that a lot of problems are ready to become uncorked. The next war in the Middle East may have already started. The same goes for the next economic slowdown at home. Who knows what use India or Pakistan will make of their nuclear toys? Or whether North Korea is really ready to auction off its missiles? Southeast Asia's giant, Indonesia, appears to be fracturing, and scientists are pretty worried that Al Gore wasn't crazy to think that global warming is already under way. And those are just the specters everybody already knows about. 
 Maybe, just maybe, America is on the kind of roll that both presidential candidates have taken for granted. Maybe its military competitors are so far behind, its global businesses so far ahead, its friends in Europe and Asia so secure that, no matter who gives the victory speech on Tuesday night, his biggest challenge will be to manage good times.
But maybe not.
"Times have been so good for so long that you have to think the next four years are going to be comparatively ugly," one of President Clinton's top advisers said recently. "Just look at all the bullets we ducked" -- a near-nuclear exchange in South Asia, near blowups in Korea and the Taiwan Strait, financial near-disasters. Even the optimist-in-chief, Bill Clinton, has remarked to his staff about the huge gulf between what the candidates have been talking about (prescription drugs, tax cuts, secure retirement) and the kind of issues consuming him in his last days in office (terror attacks, a Middle East blowup, Balkan hatreds).
So what could make Tuesday's victor wish, in a few months or a few years, that the other guy had won?
Start with the perennial problem-in-waiting: an economy that's been running on eight cylinders for longer than any in history. It could begin running on, say, just four. Or, as one of President Clinton's former top economic officials puts it: "Not a recession. Just something that, after all this prosperity, feels like a recession."
The signs are already there. The stock market's fall to Earth has made free-spending consumers feel a little less wealthy. Out here on the frontier of the new economy, a lot of E-entrepreneurs are suddenly sending resumes to old-line companies that compensate their employees with a regular salary, not stock options. Detroit is sitting on car inventories so big that eight of the country's 55 auto plants are taking a weeklong holiday.
NONE of that spells doom; it may just be a much-needed pause. Still, those surpluses Mr. Gore and George W. Bush argued about all year could dissolve overnight if Congress comes under pressure to spur the economy.
And that's just the start. Once the American economy slows, international investors are likely to think about putting their money elsewhere. That money is financing a record trade deficit that few care about as long as jobs are plentiful.
What if unemployment rises? (Where else can it go?) That benign trade deficit will look like it's stealing jobs. Just ask the other George Bush, who was ushered out of the Oval Office partly because of a national perception that such economic issues bored him.
Then there is a long list of less familiar frights. Mr. Clinton's former national security adviser, Anthony Lake, has just published a guidebook to future calamities -- "Six Nightmares" (Little, Brown & Co.) -- in which he describes wandering through Washington's MCI Center, just blocks from the White House, to see how vulnerable the indoor stadium might be to biological attack. Big surprise: no one challenged him.
Similarly, the Pentagon quietly ran an experiment a few years ago to see how much damage some medium-skilled hackers could inflict on the country's infrastructure. Plenty, it found.
While there has been lots of talk in the campaign of keeping America strong, perhaps the most complex set of new threats involve the weakness, rather than strength, of other countries. That was the lesson of the Soviet breakup, the Mexican and Asian economic crises, the fracturing of Yugoslavia.
It may be the lesson of the Middle East, where the economic disparity between Israel and the Palestinians only fuels the ethnic and territorial tensions. The Arab states have failed to build strong democracies, legal institutions and economies, the combination usually associated with stability and security. Along with its peace brokering, the Clinton administration has made some modest efforts to close the economic gap, figuring that once young Arabs have an economic stake in peace and stability, they are less likely to lob rocks or worse. It's a nice theory, but so far it hasn't taken hold.
Weakness and fear are clearly at the heart of the India-Pakistan dispute; why else would two nations battling so much poverty, corruption and population growth divert their scarce cash into building nuclear weapons? The Bomb, indeed, has become the poor nation's equalizer, the way to make the world deal with them.
"Half the foreign and defense policy establishment fears, legitimately, that the Big Terrible Thing is coming, whether in India-Pakistan, or in Asia or in lower Manhattan," Peggy Noonan, the Ronald Reagan loyalist who is supporting Mr. Bush, wrote last week. Yet the Bush campaign has said lots about national defense, and far less about preventing the spread of nuclear weapons.
Mr. Gore talks about preventive diplomacy but can be equally vague. Indonesia has been fracturing since the ouster of its strongman, President Suharto, more than two years ago, threatening a crackup of the world's fourth most populous nation. Yet when asked in a recent interview how he would approach Indonesia's problems, the vice president allowed that maybe it was near time to assemble some experts on the subject.
WHO can blame these guys? Promising to strengthen America is one thing, but it's a rare politician who dares to run on a platform of using America's money or military to prop up weak nations.
It's no way to get elected president. It probably never will be. Whether it's a way to secure America's place in the world is a different question -- one the next president can start thinking about on Wednesday.
