HEADLINE: Liberties;
I Feel Pretty

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
I feel stunning
And entrancing,
Feel like running and dancing for joy . . . 
 O.K., enough gloating. Behave, Albert. Just look in the mirror now and put on your serious I only-care-about-the-issues face.
If I rub in a tad more of this mahogany-colored industrial mousse, the Spot will disappear under my Reagan pompadour.
Whew! Now that W. has slipped on a mud pie at the finish line, I can admit I was scared, just like all the other Democrats. Things were stickier than a barrel of goo-goo clusters.
It would be awful to blow it just because no one can stand the sight of me. Or to win the Electoral College but not the popular vote. Ouch!
How could I lose to a guy who promises to fix Social Security without knowing it's a federal program? He probably thought it was a dating service.
But my inner teleprompter tells me I've got a much better shot now. Goody-goody for the goody-goody!
Only 48 more hours and I am Martin Sheen. I can upgrade to Air Force One. Only 76 days, 8 hours and 15 minutes and I will never, ever have to lay eyes on that megalomaniac Bill Clinton again! Ding dong!
I know I haven't been the best candidate. But you try running with Clinton Past while Clinton Present is hanging on for dear life, trying to polish Clinton Future. It's like climbing Mount Rainier with ankle weights and sandbags on your back.
I couldn't believe how everyone in my camp was doubting me, from the president (even though we tried to confine him to Black Entertainment Television and keep him off CNN) to my overpaid Washington hacks to all those Democrats who wanted me to brag on our economy and campaign with Bill, because people like him.
It seemed as if the only people who still believed in me were Tipper, Karenna and my pal Marty Peretz. Which was fortunate, since they were the only three I ever talked to.
Even Tipper was getting fed up with me kissing and hugging her a hundred times a day. She actually pushed me away at one point when I was going in for a big one. That hurt.
But no matter how dark things got, I reckoned that in the end, Boy Scout would trump Frat Boy, especially if somebody could find something better to pin on him than the Case of the Purloined Debate Prep Video.
For some reason, voters never get excited about me. That's why I had to hook up with Clinton in the first place. But now people have no other choice -- unless they want President Adam Sandler.
No way will Americans go for toga state dinners and a leader who might steal the White House Christmas wreath as a hazing prank. Once the Maine Democrats ratted out Bush on that embarrassing little incident up in Kennebunkport (it was great that the news broke on conservative Fox!) everyone realized that W. had even less controlling legal authority than I did. Buddhists vs. Budweisers.
That's what W. gets for hanging out at the family estate, chugging beers with Australian tennis players, while I worked like a dog campaigning for my first Congressional seat, so I could spend 12 hours a day grinding away on the House Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations of the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act.
W. should never have run against me in the first place. The only rationale for his campaign was avenging his father's loss. And revenge is not a healthy reason to seek the highest office in the land. A president must not be filled with bile. A president must bring everyone together.
Where's my Palm Pilot? I need to do a couple e-mails to kick off the Gore era starting Tuesday night.
Note to self: Clinton said I would be "the next best thing" to having him for another four years. He can Next Best this: The new site for our radioactive dump is on the Arkansas River, next to the Clinton Library.
Note to Congressional liaison: Whenever we announce highway money for New York, give Chuck Schumer 48 hours' notice so he can get full credit (and Senator Hillary can get lost).
Note to Karenna: Anything those Maine Democrats in the wacky hats want from us -- yea-a-a-ah! -- give it to them.

HEADLINE: WINE UNDER $20;
A Mere $2.88 per Chapter

BYLINE: By HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

 BODY:
In a city where tidal charts could reflect sommeliers' arrivals and departures, Joseph DeLissio's career as the River Cafe's wine director rests on the same bedrock as the Brooklyn Bridge overhead. For 22 years, his wine program has illuminated the restaurant's American cuisine as brightly as Lower Manhattan lights that sparkle across the East River.
 Whether stocking the cellar or working the floor, he has influenced the tastes and judgments of thousands. His own were partly shaped by Italian grandparents who, digging into the New World, built a wine cellar, stored their wine in wooden milk crates and reused corks. 
 Reared in Brooklyn and a longtime Staten Island resident, Mr. DeLissio, who knows the value of a buck, conveys in "The River Cafe Wine Primer" (Little Brown, $25.95) his tugboat-like ease in steering novices. Nine chapters, each the equivalent of a $2.88 glass of wine, brim with sensible information that can save budget-conscious holiday shoppers cash at a moment of economic ebbing.
 "Ordering wine in a restaurant should be easy, not intimidating," he writes. "Selecting wine in a local wine shop should be enjoyable, not anxiety provoking."
 Since wine is organic, buying is always somewhat risky. Mr. DeLissio's list of "good value wineries" -- I agree with them -- offsets risk. For example, in California: Beringer Founder's Estate line, Domaine Carneros sparkling wines, Estancia, Fetzer, Franciscan, Louis Martini and Ravenswood; in Washington, Chateau Ste. Michelle, Columbia Crest, Hogue Cellars; in Oregon, Oak Knoll and Sokol Blosser.
 From Spain: Torres, Conde de Valdemar and Marques de Murrieta; Italy, Alois Lageder, Chiarlo; Germany, Robert Weil; Chile, Los Vascos and Santa Rita; France, Burgundies of Joseph Drouhin, Rhones of Jaboulet and such Bordeaux chateaus as d'Angludet and Meyney.
 His restaurant tips are smart: Sniff empty glasses before wine is poured, because they might impart off odors. And refuse a wine if "the server has not informed you of a vintage or producer change." HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

HEADLINE: DATABANK: OCTOBER 30 - NOVEMBER 3;
Bulls, Bears, Donkeys and Elephants

BYLINE: By JOAN M. O'NEILL

 BODY:
After weeks of sloshing higher and lower, the stock market, like the rest of the country, may settle down to watch the finish of the presidential race this week.
Traders will not only be looking for the winner of the White House, but also for the new balance of power between the incoming administration and the legislative branch. "What the market likes is gridlock in Washington," said Tim Woolston, portfolio manager at Boston Advisors, part of the Advest Group. 
"It likes nothing better than to have a divided White House and Congress," he said. "It means that very little in terms of significant legislation is likely to get through."
 As a backdrop, both the Dow Jones and Nasdaq indexes managed to move higher last week. With most corporate earnings out of the way, and seasonal selling for tax purposes also mostly over, Mr. Woolston said the market might be forming a bottom.
 The Producer Price Index, the most significant piece of economic information due this week, is likely to soothe, showing prices nearly flat for October.
 The Nasdaq composite index rallied 5.3 percent last week, to 3,451.58. The Dow Jones industrials rose 2.1 percent, to 10,817.95. JOAN M. O'NEILL

HEADLINE: Far More Single Mothers Are Taking Jobs

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4

 BODY:
For the first time in more than a decade, single mothers are more likely than married mothers to be employed, new government statistics show.
The figures also show a large increase in the proportion of single mothers who are working, with explosive growth in work by low-skilled women with children born out of wedlock. 
 Even more remarkable, economists say, is the increase in work among single mothers who have never been married. In 1993, 44 percent of them were employed. The figure shot up to 65 percent last year.
The new numbers, from the Labor Department and the Census Bureau, have caught the attention of liberals and conservatives alike.
Wendell E. Primus, a liberal Democrat who resigned from the government in protest over President Clinton's decision to sign the 1996 welfare law, said: "The growth in the proportion of never-married mothers who are working is phenomenal. I find it astonishing."
Ronald T. Haskins, a conservative Republican who works for the House Ways and Means Committee, said: "Never-married mothers are the ones who have the least education and have historically worked the least. They were also the most likely to be on welfare and to stay on welfare for long periods. So the fact that the proportion of never-married mothers who work exploded after 1993 is extremely important."
Jared Bernstein, a labor economist at the Economic Policy Institute, a liberal research center here, said, "The increases in work among single mothers, their magnitude and the speed at which they occurred are truly remarkable."
Economists gave several reasons for the increase in work among single mothers:
*The strong economy has created millions of jobs and improved the quality of low-wage jobs.
*Welfare recipients are now required to work under federal and state welfare laws, and states have sharply increased spending on child care.
*The federal government and the states have adopted policies to "make work pay," in a phrase used by proponents of such policies. As a result, many single mothers find they are financially better off if they take jobs outside the home.
*Work has become more attractive because of increases in the minimum wage and the earned income tax credit, which can add several thousand dollars a year to the income of a low-wage worker with children.
Representative Nancy L. Johnson, the Connecticut Republican who is chairwoman of a House subcommittee responsible for welfare policy, said the strong economy alone could not explain all the increase in work by single mothers.
Although 17 million jobs were created from 1981 to 1989, Mrs. Johnson said, "that did not help women in poverty." The proportion of single mothers with jobs did not rise.
The new statistics on working mothers were extracted from government data by Gary Burtless, an economist at the Brookings Institution here. The trend is clear.
The proportion of married mothers with jobs grew slowly and steadily from 1986 to 1997 and leveled off at 68 percent in the next two years.
By contrast, the proportion of single mothers with jobs showed hardly any change from 1986 to 1993, remaining around 58 percent. But then it began a sharp rise, as states revamped their welfare programs to emphasize work.
Last year the proportion of single mothers with jobs reached 71.5 percent, exceeding the 68 percent for married mothers. The figure for single mothers also exceeded that for married mothers in the late 1970's and early 80's, but in those years, married women were less likely to work outside the home.
"No previous decline in the overall jobless rate has ever produced such a large increase in employment of never-married mothers," Mr. Burtless said. "President Clinton, Congress and state legislatures have provided more generous benefits to indigent working mothers with dependent children. But they have made it more difficult for nonworking mothers to collect public assistance."
Census Bureau figures on the employment of welfare recipients show a similar trend. In 1995, as in 1979, about 40 percent of welfare recipients worked at some time during the year. This proportion leaped to 58 percent by 1999.
The number of families on welfare has dropped by more than half since 1994, to 2.4 million from a peak of 5.1 million. Welfare officials often say that the first people to leave the rolls are those with the most skills. Officials assumed that people who remained on the rolls would have more difficulty finding jobs.
But David Card, a professor of economics at the University of California at Berkeley, said, "The employment rate has increased even after the best-trained, best-prepared people have left the welfare rolls."
Economists have detected an increase in wages among never-married single mothers, even as the supply of such low-wage workers has increased.
"Prior to 1996, wages in low-wage jobs were not keeping pace with inflation," said Mr. Bernstein of the Economic Policy Institute. "But then, as the unemployment rate moved toward a 30-year low, the real wages of low-paid workers began to rise for the first time in a couple of decades. That creates incentives to join the labor force and to try to cash in on those wage gains."
Still, said Mr. Primus, the former Clinton administration official, the poorest fifth of the nation's female-headed families had less disposable income, on the average, in 1999 than in 1995. Higher pay was often offset by the loss of income from welfare, food stamps and other government programs, Mr. Primus said.
"Many families have had spectacular increases in earnings," Mr. Primus said, "but those gains do not always show up on the bottom line."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: FOREIGN POLICY;
From Social Security to Environment, the Candidates' Positions

BYLINE: By David E. Sanger

 BODY:
Voters have many questions about issues,and Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas have many answers. Here aresummaries of the Bush and Gore positions onpolicy issues that have recieved considerable attention in the presidential campaign, with a comparison to show how the candidates differand agree, and assesments of their position fromexperts and political analysts-some partisan, some not.
Foreign policy has not figured prominently in the campaign, even though outside this country's borders -- in the Middle East, the Korean peninsula, the tense border between India and Pakistan -- Washington finds itself dealing with questions of life, death and potential war. 
 Mr. Bush has little foreign policy experience: At 54, he has left the United States (apart from trips to Mexico) three times in his adult life. Mr. Gore, in contrast, has broad experience in foreign affairs, but he has some vulnerabilities. Talk of Asia brings up memories of campaign contributions in 1996 from a Taiwan-connected Buddhist temple; talk of Russia reminds voters of Mr. Gore's secret deal to stop Russian arms exports to Iran, a deal the Russians appear to be violating.
But there are big differences. Mr. Gore is an interventionist, and over the years has repeatedly pressed for more vigorous United States involvement in hot spots around the world, including Bosnia and Kosovo. Mr. Bush denies he is an isolationist, but says United States troops should not be used for nation-building abroad. He would start by bringing home the 11,400 troops in the Balkans, once this country's NATO allies had agreed. That statement caused an uproar in Europe.
Not surprisingly, both men insist they are free traders. But Mr. Gore's use of that title is dubious: he has often jumped to help his protectionist labor constituency, and was known in the White House as the most unforgiving of Japanese protectionist trade practices. Mr. Bush seems cut from more traditional free-trade cloth, but to appeal to voters in West Virginia and Pennsylvania, he talks about enforcing American antidumping laws, which many read as a backhanded way of saying he would protect workers in those states from intense foreign competition.
Both men have steered clear of specifics in the toughest new territory in American foreign affairs: How to deal with the forces of economic globalization and resentments engendered by America's economic, military and cultural might around the world. They say they would act with humility. They do not say how. David E. Sanger

HEADLINE: Tens of Thousands In Manila Demand Leader Step Down

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MANILA, the Philippines, Nov. 4

 BODY:
Tens of thousands of Filipinos crowded streets and highway overpasses in Manila today demanding that President Joseph Estrada resign over allegations he received huge payoffs from illegal gambling.
"Mr. President, you are the cause of our hardships, you are the problem," said former President Corazon Aquino. "History may treat you more favorably if you resign." 
 Pressure on Mr. Estrada to step down has grown rapidly as prominent lawmakers have deserted his party in recent days. More than 50 of them have said they will support an impeachment motion in the House of Representatives, virtually assuring enough votes to send it to the Senate for a trial.
The resignations submitted on Friday included the leaders of both houses of Congress: the Senate president, Franklin Drilon, and the House speaker, Manuel Villar.
Today's rally, organized by Manila's influential archbishop, Jaime Cardinal Sin, was held at a shrine commemorating the peaceful "people's power" revolt that ousted the dictator Ferdinand Marcos in 1986. Participants crowded three highway overpasses overlooking the shrine and threw confetti from nearby buildings.
While the color yellow symbolized the 1986 revolt, many at the rally wore white, representing their call for corruption-free government.
"He is mismanaging the economy and the government is ridden with scandal," said Sister Rufisanti, a nun who said she also took part in the "people's power" revolt. "He should resign."
The crisis surrounding Mr. Estrada began early in October when a provincial governor, Luis Singson, testified that the president had asked him to coordinate the collection of payoffs from an illegal numbers game called jueteng.
Mr. Estrada has denied taking any illegal gambling money but has provided little evidence. On his weekly television program today, he suggested he would stay on to face impeachment.

HEADLINE: Teacher Caliber Is Lowest in Cities, New York Study Finds

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT

 BODY:
The caliber of public-school teachers in large urban areas in New York State is much worse than in the state's small cities and suburban and rural areas, according to a new study that examines 30 years' worth of state teaching data.
Teachers in New York City and the state's four other major urban areas -- Buffalo, Rochester, Syracuse and Yonkers -- are more likely to lack certification, to have failed their certification exams or to have attended less-competitive colleges, according to the study, which was conducted for the State Education Department by researchers at the State University of New York at Albany. 
 The study, whose results will be released Wednesday in Albany, also found that teachers who begin their careers in New York City are far more likely to leave the public schools than are teachers whose first job is in another region of New York.
All those trends, the study concluded, have a disproportionate effect on poor students and on black and Latino children, although it did not say why that was so. In New York City particularly, poor or black and Latino students are far more likely than white or middle-class students to have low-quality, inexperienced teachers.
"The lowest-quality teachers are the ones teaching the children who come from environments with the greatest educational needs," said Hamilton Lankford, an associate professor of economics at the university and an author of the study. "I find that very troubling."
James Wyckoff, an associate professor of public administration at the university and the other author, said the pattern was found even among newly hired teachers, not just among veterans who are more likely because of union work rules to be able to choose their school assignments.
The study was conducted for the Educational Finance Research Consortium, a group of researchers from colleges and universities across the state. The findings will be discussed Wednesday at a policy conference in Albany that is co-sponsored by the State Board of Regents.
Dr. Wyckoff said the study was the first to examine information for every teacher and administrator employed in a state public school from 1969 through 1999. That database, which includes statistics on 600,000 teachers, is maintained by the State Education Department.
Some findings appear to confirm widely held beliefs about public school teachers -- that teachers in New York City earn less than those in suburbs, for example, and that schools in poor neighborhoods have more inexperienced teachers. But other findings run counter to the conventional wisdom.
For example, while it has long been known that the salary for starting teachers in New York City -- roughly $30,000 -- is about 25 percent less than for those in the surrounding suburbs, the study found that that is not the case in the state's other major metropolitan areas. There, salaries paid to urban teachers are equal to or exceed those paid to teachers in nearby suburbs.
The study found that two of every five teachers who began their careers in New York City in 1991 had left the city school system within six years. Nearly all of them also stopped teaching in any public school in the state. Only 3 percent moved to suburban schools in New York.
It is not clear how many of those teachers quit the profession and how many continue to teach in another state or in a private school in New York, the researchers said. But the fact that, on average, nearly one in three teachers across the state left the New York public school system within six years indicates that a fair number probably quit teaching for other fields, they said.
Dr. Wyckoff and Dr. Lankford said that they did not know the reasons behind some of their findings, but that they were continuing to research the explanations.
The state education commissioner, Richard P. Mills, said the question of why so many teachers are leaving was at the top of the list of concerns being addressed by the Board of Regents.
"It's difficult and costly to find teachers,' Mr. Mills said. "So when we find them we can't let them get away." Among the measures that the Regents have approved in an effort to retain teachers are more thorough career-development programs.
Mr. Mills said that the Education Department commissioned the study because "we need the people who make decisions about these matters, in the Legislature and elsewhere, to know that these conclusions are based on good research."
Randi Weingarten, president of the United Federation of Teachers, the New York City teachers' union, said that higher salaries were the best way to attract and keep more qualified teachers.
Additional incentives are needed to attract teachers to low-performing schools, Ms. Weingarten said. "If you let a school system starve and don't pay attention to the human resources -- namely, teacher salaries and other human infrastructure -- then what you see in this report will happen," she said. "You'll get bad consequences for kids and worse consequences for the poorest children."
Anthony P. Coles, deputy mayor for planning, education and cultural affairs, disagreed, saying salaries did not directly affect teacher quality. "If you look at the private and parochial schools in the city, they offer salaries that are significantly less, yet they don't have the same problems," he said.
"They do an effective job of teaching students and provide a better work environment for teachers," in large part because they lack the "inefficiency, bureaucracy, and red tape" of the city's public schools, Mr. Coles said.

HEADLINE: Clinton and Lazio Differ on School Aid, Social Security and Tax Cuts

 BODY:

Education
With New Yorkers citing education as a major concern, Representative Rick A. Lazio and Hillary Rodham Clinton have both embraced the issue as a top priority in the Senate race.
But Mrs. Clinton's education proposals are similar to those of the powerful teacher unions that support her, while Mr. Lazio is more focused on wooing the suburban residents whose votes he needs. He has joined other Republicans in stressing the importance of local control over education spending and policy. 
 Mr. Lazio has called for $98 billion in new federal spending on education over the next decade, compared with the roughly $125 billion in education spending that Mrs. Clinton has proposed. Both have proposed competency tests for teachers and alternative certification programs to ease the state's severe teacher shortage.
But Mrs. Clinton has proposed testing prospective teachers on their subject of expertise as a condition of letting them teach -- a plan the unions have endorsed.Mr. Lazio's plan would give districts the option of testing teachers every five years.
Mr. Lazio's most costly proposal would provide $60 billion -- the bulk of his $98 billion education package -- in grants to the states to cover the cost of special education programs over 10 years. Federal law requires such programs, but pays only about 12 percent of their cost. Aware that the issue resonates with suburban voters, Mrs. Clinton has a similar proposal, although hers would provide $20 billion over 10 years.
Mr. Lazio also wants to invest $10 billion on a "Hometown Choice" grant program that would let local schools and parents decide how to spend the federal dollars. On vouchers, Mrs. Clinton has sided with the teachers' unions in vehemently opposing vouchers, saying they would strip the public schools of precious resources. Mr. Lazio has quietly endorsed vouchers, a position that appeals to more conservative voters. In Congress, he voted several times for experimental voucher programs. But in the Senate race, where he has been careful to paint himself as a moderate, he has referred to vouchers as "opportunity scholarships." Under his plan, the federal government would provide $5 billion to families who have children in failing schools that could be put toward tuition at a private school.
 
Abortion
Mrs. Clinton supports abortion rights, including government financing of abortions, and backs the approval by the Food and Drug Administration of the abortion-inducing drug RU-486. But she has said she could support a ban on a form of late-term abortion that its critics call "partial birth," as long as the provision includes an exemption to allow the procedure if a mother's health or life needs protection. She has also said that she would not vote for a Supreme Court nominee opposed to abortion rights.
Mr. Lazio generally supports abortion rights, but he opposes government financing of abortions. He also supports government approval of RU-486, but he is against allowing the government to pay for it. He also supports a ban on the so-called partial-birth abortions. Mr. Lazio has said he would not reject Supreme Court nominees opposed to abortion rights, but has also said he would consider their abortion views in deciding whether to confirm them.
 
Campaign Finance
Both Mr. Lazio and Mrs. Clinton support legislation in Washington that would overhaul the campaign finance system by banning so-called soft money, the largely unregulated contributions to political committees. Mr. Lazio voted for the legislation in the House, breaking with many leaders of his party.
 
Gun Control
Mr. Lazio and Mrs. Clinton both support the Brady Law, which imposes a waiting period on prospective gun purchases and bans many types of assault weapons. Mrs. Clinton supports licensing new guns and registering new gun owners. Mr. Lazio opposes those measures, arguing that the nation should first enforce existing gun laws before considering national registration.
 
Social Security
Mrs. Clinton says that her plan would set aside part of the national budget surplus to preserve Social Security in its current form. Her campaign says that the tax-cut proposal offered by Mr. Lazio would squander the surplus in the same way she says the Republican presidential candidate's plan would, and, in the process, undermine Social Security. But Mr. Lazio counters that his tax-cut plan would cost less than the one proposed by George W. Bush, and that there is enough of a budget surplus to ensure the stability of Social Security.
 
Prescription Drugs and Medicare
Mrs. Clinton has also proposed putting more money into Medicare, the federal insurance program for the elderly and the disabled, to offer prescription drug coverage to all beneficiaries. Her plan would cost $253 billion over 10 years and would offer drug benefits under the existing Medicare program. The benefit would be available to the elderly for an additional monthly premium that would start at $25 a month in 2002 and nearly double over the next decade. Mr. Lazio also proposes to provide prescription drug coverage for the elderly, but to do so in a way that is strikingly different from the approach supported by Mrs. Clinton. His plan would set aside about $40 billion over five years to help individuals buy prescription drug coverage from private insurers. It would apply only to elderly people who are eligible for Medicare but who lack their own private prescription drug coverage. Mr. Lazio wants to use private insurers and health maintenance organizations to deliver prescription drug benefits to the elderly. But the government would still pay most of the costs and would have the authority to approve or disapprove drug plans offered by insurers.
 
Health Care
Mrs. Clinton's health care policy is very similar to the proposals that the Clinton administration has been championing in Washington since the failure in 1994 of her proposal to provide health insurance for every American. Mrs. Clinton, generally speaking, wants to expand existing government programs and, in the process, provide more generous benefits than Mr. Lazio would. But his advisers say she is simply trying to achieve her 1994 goals in an incremental fashion.
In general, Mr. Lazio favors providing more access to health care coverage through the private sector, primarily by helping people cover the costs of prescription drugs and health insurance with some government subsidies and tax breaks. Another chief difference between the two candidates centers on what is called a patients' bill of rights to protect those who belong to health maintenance organizations. Mrs. Clinton's proposal would, among other things, give people the right to sue if an insurer denies coverage for a medical procedure.
Mr. Lazio opposes that approach, saying that it would lead to needless litigation and force up the price of health insurance. His plan would offer an alternative appeals process if insurers deny coverage, providing people with the right to sue only after all internal and external appeals had been exhausted.
 
New York City Sports Stadium
In her debate with Mr. Lazio on Oct. 8, Mrs. Clinton said she was opposed to using taxpayer money to build a domed stadium on the West Side of Manhattan, a favorite project of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who wants to use the stadium to lure the New York Jets and the 2012 Olympics to New York City. But later, Mrs. Clinton said she would keep "an open mind," adding that no stadium should be built without major public transportation improvements, including completion of the Second Avenue subway and bringing the Long Island Rail Road to the East Side.
Mr. Lazio supports using taxpayer money to build the stadium, although he has said that private money should be used as well. Mr. Lazio has also praised the stadium plan as an opportunity to expand the nearby Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.
 
Missile Defense
Mrs. Clinton supports financing research for a missile defense system, but stops short of endorsing its deployment. Mr. Lazio, who voted against a bill last year that called on President Clinton to deploy the missile shield as soon as possible, now supports deployment of the missile shield.
 
Middle East
Mrs. Clinton has shifted away from the position she took two years ago, before entering the race, supporting an independent Palestinian state. She now says she does not support a unilateral declaration of independence by the Palestinians and would support a Palestinian state only as part of a comprehensive peace agreement between Israel and the Palestinians.
Mr. Lazio has voted consistently in favor of maintaining sanctions against Israel's enemies and in favor of foreign aid to Israel. He said recently that he would remain personally opposed to an independent Palestinian state, even if both sides agreed to its creation, because he believes such a state would be unsustainable.
 
Worldview
Mrs. Clinton sees the United States as an active international player, using its role as the sole superpower to right wrongs and exert moral authority. While saying she would not support intervention abroad without strong justification, she offers an expansive definition of the national interest that includes struggles against environmental degradation, poverty and disease.
Mr. Lazio says he supports global engagement, but to a more limited degree that squares more ideologically with the views of Mr. Bush. But unlike Mr. Bush, Mr. Lazio said he does not support the withdrawal of American forces from Bosnia and Kosovo.
 
Tax Cuts
The candidates have both proposed cutting taxes, but their approaches could hardly be more different. Mr. Lazio has proposed several significant changes to the tax code, most notably making Social Security tax payments deductible for those in the two lowest tax brackets (which cover married couples who have taxable income of up to $106,000 a year). He backs eliminating both the estate tax and the so-called marriage penalty, and has proposed a cut in the capital gains tax. Mrs. Clinton's tax-cut proposals tend to be narrower. She favors tax credits for businesses that create jobs and for families with disabled relatives and children in college or in day care. She favors changing, rather than eliminating, the marriage penalty and estate taxes, to benefit lower-income people.
When it comes to retirement plans, Mrs. Clinton backs a scaled-down version of Vice President Al Gore's proposed retirement savings accounts. Mr. Lazio favors an even less expensive plan, simply increasing the cap on contributions into Individual Retirement Accounts.
 
Upstate Economy
In upstate New York, it's still the economy. While economic conditions north of Westchester are no longer in free fall, as they were a couple of years ago, upstate cities have not prospered the way New York City and its suburbs have.
Mrs. Clinton has made a major campaign issue out of upstate's lagging fortunes, and has accused Mr. Lazio of being an "ostrich" who refuses to acknowledge that the region has serious problems. She has proposed a variety of programs to help upstate, including tax credits for businesses, training programs for workers, and measures to improve tourism, transportation and technology.
Like his ally, Governor Pataki, Mr. Lazio has focused on upstate's improving job growth, and has criticized Mrs. Clinton for portraying the region as "a vast economic wasteland." He has stressed a general tax cut as a way to return money to residents' pockets, which he says will prompt investment and job creation.
 
Housing
The short supply and high price of housing is a major problem across the New York metropolitan region. As chairman of the House subcommittee on housing, Mr. Lazio claims housing measures, including a revamping of public housing and more funds for the elderly, disabled, homeless and others, as his main legislative achievement.
Mrs. Clinton and her allies accuse him of reducing subsidized housing for the poor, taking credit for the ideas of others and standing by while the Republican-controlled Congress slashed housing funds. Her proposals include tax credits to promote construction, new public housing and more rental aid vouchers for the poor.

HEADLINE: Yugoslavia Now Wrestles With Forming A Government

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER

DATELINE: PRAGUE, Nov. 4

 BODY:
More than a month after elections that led to the overthrow of Slobodan Milosevic, the Yugoslav Parliament today confirmed a new federal government dominated by the coalition that backed the new president, Vojislav Kostunica.
The new government will move quickly, its leaders promise, to restore diplomatic relations with the United States and other major NATO countries and to bring Yugoslavia back into international organizations like the International Monetary Fund and the Council of Europe. 
 The confirmation was another important step in the consolidation of power by Mr. Kostunica and his supporters after the 13-year rule of Mr. Milosevic. But the more powerful Serbian government remains transitional, with elections for a new Serbian Parliament due on Dec. 23.
The new federal Parliament was elected on Sept. 24, the same day as Mr. Kostunica. But Mr. Kostunica could not take office until a popular uprising forced Mr. Milosevic to resign on Oct. 6.
And negotiating the shape of the new government was onerous, largely because the Western-supported president of Montenegro, Milo Djukanovic, boycotted the September elections in protest against Mr. Milosevic. Montenegro is Serbia's sole partner in the Yugoslav federation.
Although fewer than 30 percent of Montenegrins voted, the boycott by Mr. Djukanovic left all of Montenegro's seats to allies of Mr. Milosevic.
Mr. Kostunica, a constitutional lawyer, insisted he would have to form a federal government from the parties elected to the Parliament. By constitutional tradition, he would have to have a Montenegrin prime minister from the largest Montenegrin party in the Parliament -- the Socialist People's Party, which had backed Mr. Milosevic.
Mr. Djukanovic was offered some posts in the new government anyway, but declined. In private, however, he has told Mr. Kostunica that they can work together to discuss a new relationship between Serbia and Montenegro.
The prime minister-designate, Zoran Zizic, in a speech to the Parliament today, said the government would move quickly to restore relations with the rest of Europe and press for the "firm implementation of Security Council Resolution 1244, which guarantees the territorial integrity and sovereignty of the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia," including Kosovo.
His new foreign minister, Goran Svilanovic, a Kostunica supporter and leader of the Civic Alliance, traveled on Thursday to the United Nations, where Yugoslavia was readmitted as a full member. Mr. Svilanovic, 37 years old and born in Kosovo, is a shrewd, liberal-minded politician who was Mr. Kostunica's own choice for foreign minister.
Mr. Svilanovic is one of the nine new ministers from the Kostunica coalition, still known -- now somewhat incongruously -- as the Democratic Opposition of Serbia. Montenegrin parties have seven ministries, including finance and defense. The old government, by contrast, had 30 ministers.
The most crucial position is held by Miroljub Labus, an economist who is deputy prime minister and in charge of international financial relations. Mr. Labus is chairman of a group of opposition economists and policy experts known as G-17 Plus, which was instrumental in drawing up the government's program.
After a decade of mismanagement, price controls, a state-supported mafia and crony privatization, Yugoslavia needs help to restructure its economy without creating excessive popular anger at the new authorities.
The new interior minister is Zoran Zivkovic, the mayor of Nis, the third-largest city in Serbia. Mr. Zivkovic promised that the police would serve citizens, work openly "and not be a shadowy force."
As important as the federal government is, the more powerful Serbian government has presented further complications. In September, there were no elections for Serbian posts, so the new powers in the land forced through the resignation of the existing Serbian government of Milosevic supporters.
Mr. Kostunica's allies, led by Zoran Djindjic, the Democratic Party leader, cobbled together a temporary government with some of Mr. Milosevic's less loyal Socialists until early Serbian parliamentary elections are held. The workings of the temporary government have been stalled over opposition demands for the firing of Rade Markovic, the head of the Serbian secret police.

HEADLINE: Searching for the Relevant;
For Many, Races Reflect the Worst of Political Times

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY and ANDREW JACOBS

 BODY:
For nearly two years, residents of New York and New Jersey have been exposed to United States Senate campaigns that will not be remembered for their crystallizing moments of political distinction. No William Jennings Bryan speech, no Lincoln-Douglas debate, no photograph of Adlai Stevenson, his feet up to reveal well-worn soles and therefore a piece of his soul.
The New York race, between Hillary Rodham Clinton and Representative Rick A. Lazio (and before him, Rudolph W. Giuliani), will be recalled as the most expensive Senate race ever, one more often defined by personalities than by positions. 
 The New Jersey campaign pits a career politician, Representative Bob Franks, against a former Wall Street executive, Jon S. Corzine, who has brought distinction to that race by spending more of his own money, an estimated $60 million, than any other Senate candidate in history.
In two days, both races will end. And not a moment too soon, according to a survey, decidedly impressionistic rather than scientific in design, of more than 50 people, from Rochester to Riverhead in New York, and in several communities throughout New Jersey.
Many of those questioned said they felt more than just weariness about the two protracted campaigns, something deeper, more disturbing.
At times, they said, the races seemed to reflect the worst in electoral politics.
They spoke of profligate spending that reinforced the sense that elections are bought, not won; of squabbles over tangential issues that were unimportant to them; of often subjective news coverage; and of continual mudslinging in the guise of slick advertising.
Many clung to memories of, and hopes for, a purer kind of politics, one that has not existed for a long time, if ever. It is the sentiment in the movie Mr. Franks says is his favorite, "Mr. Smith Goes to Washington." On screen, an idealist beats back corrupt powers to win an election, but that Frank Capra film also suggests that corruption and dishonesty are the political norm. It was released in 1939.
Kathleen McNeile, a social studies teacher at Rye High School in New York, said she had been using this year's campaigns to teach her students about the political process. They debated the issues and saw "Gore Vidal's 'The Best Man,' " a Broadway play about electoral politics. Through it all, she said, she has decided that she is "an optimist, but not an idealist."
"I realize the issues for many candidates are not nearly as important as simply trying to get elected," Ms. McNeile said, "doing whatever it takes to get elected."
It was a familiar sentiment, but nonetheless profound. Few people said they had experienced any epiphanies about the issues of the day, including economic development and health care. None said they had arrived at a greater appreciation for those striving to win public office.
Instead, these people from New York and New Jersey, where voter turnout has hovered around 50 percent in recent presidential election years, spoke of trying to wade through muck to find data that would help them choose between what several described as the lesser of two evils.
"Don't get me started," said Warren A. Brandenstein, a retired sales executive, as he waited for a haircut at Image Haircutters in Riverhead. "The whole system stinks. This battling back and forth, what this guy did, what that guy did, you don't know what to believe."
In New York, most people said they did not care about the debate over campaign financing, which seemed to preoccupy the Clinton and Lazio campaigns for weeks on end.
Many said they did not care that Mrs. Clinton accepted and later returned $50,000 in contributions from members of an American Muslim organization that Mr. Lazio tried to portray as tacitly supportive of terrorist acts. And they shrugged off the news that the Lazio campaign had previously solicited contributions from the same Muslim group.
"They are bringing up a lot of things that are just not relevant to the office," said Michael P. Reichel, the superintendent of the Town of Riverhead Sewer Department, as he paused near a roiling treatment tank.
"There is too much about the character of the person," he said, "the character of the family. I just don't think it's appropriate. All the negative stuff doesn't help when you're trying to make up your mind."
In New Jersey, where the Senate campaign has been under way for more than a year, most people said the most familiar issue seemed to be Mr. Corzine's willingness to spend a chunk of his personal fortune in pursuit of elective office.
That level of spending has made his voice and image so ubiquitous on television that Patricia Hollingsworth, 32, a lawyer from Millburn, has developed a Pavlovian response. "As soon as I see them I flip the channel," she said.
Several New Jersey voters said the matter was overblown, given that the spending of one's own wealth on political office has a history that dates to well before Nelson Rockefeller and John F. Kennedy. A few repeated Mr. Corzine's argument that it is preferable to have an elected official free from the favoritism that can come from accepting campaign contributions from corporations and special-interest groups.
"He didn't take it from me or anyone else," said Alex Garden, 68, who works part time in his wife's clothing store in Summit. "He can spend it any way he wants. This is a democratic country."
But what Mr. Garden saw as a reflection of democracy was the same detail that Michael Savage saw as evidence that "we have a great democracy but it's been screwed up."
"It's sickening," Mr. Savage, 42, a sales manager from New Providence, said of the Corzine campaign's spending. "The guy is just buying himself a seat in the Senate." Mr. Savage said that while he was leaning toward voting for Mr. Franks, the financial underdog, "I'll just be glad when this whole waste of money is over."
For all the criticism of the candidates and their campaigns, several people pointed to the news media as equally responsible for what was wrong with the political process. They railed against what they called slanted coverage and the preponderance of talk shows in which journalists, political scientists and so-called focus groups begin deconstructing televised debates before the candidates have even left the stage.
"I wish somebody would sit down and really analyze what the candidates are saying," said James C. Andrews, a retired civil engineer, as he stood on Main Street in the historic whaling village of Sag Harbor on Long Island's South Fork. "But instead of getting into the facts, they are getting into who made a mistake. It's the politics of who looks better and who is the nicest."
What results, he concluded, is a distortion of the campaigns "by a national media that are a bunch of empty heads and pretty faces."
Rob Harper, a banker spending a day off in City Hall Park in Lower Manhattan, agreed. One of his complaints was the news media's reliance on polls that often seem both contradictory and intended to sway a voter's thinking before Election Day.
"This poll's numbers show Lazio ahead, the next day another shows Hillary ahead," he said. "You're left wondering which one is right, and do I even have to vote?"
A few of the people interviewed said disillusionment, as well as the sense of being disconnected from those matters that are the focus of campaigns, had led them to decide against participating. In other words, they will not vote on Tuesday.
"I'm just not excited about anyone," said Susan Lockwood, 57, a touch of apology in her voice. She said she had always voted in the past, often supporting Republican candidates for president.
But after decades of leading what she described as a solid middle-class life, Ms. Lockwood is divorced, and was on her way up Passaic Avenue in Passaic, N.J., to clean other people's houses.
"Me, I'm just scraping by," she said, turning away, "and the politicians really don't care."
Such apathy was also found among more affluent people in Summit, the comfortable suburb where Mr. Corzine lives and where Mr. Franks grew up. Brad Mell, 34, a bond trader walking along Springfield Avenue, Summit's well-tended commercial spine, had only a vague idea what the presidential and Senate candidates were for or against.
Politics, he said, is a childish game of promise-making and name-calling, an annoying burble that only clogs up prime-time television each fall. "Who wants to hear all that bashing?" he said.
It is not that Colleen O'Halloran and her boyfriend, Nicholas McCarthy, want to hear the bashing, or anything else unrelated to the issues in New York's Senate campaign. Ms. O'Halloran said she thought that Mr. Lazio "has acted like a child." Mr. McCarthy said that if the only open Senate seat were in Michigan, Mrs. Clinton "would have gone to Michigan."
Ms. Halloran and Mr. McCarthy, two 21-year-old college students from Brooklyn, paused from their lunches in City Hall Park to say they saw the elections as a process in which candidates would say anything, no matter how vicious or pandering, for the sole purpose of getting elected. They suggested that while that was unpleasant and not particularly edifying, it remained important to them.
When asked whether they planned to vote on Tuesday, the cynicism of the moment melted away as both vigorously nodded their heads yes.

HEADLINE: As High-Tech Companies Retrench, Financial Firms Stock Up on Office Space

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI

 BODY:
Financial services companies have reasserted their importance to New York City's real estate market and the economy with a vengeance as the dot-com companies have retreated from the stage in recent months.
Uptown and downtown, investment banks, commercial banks and insurance companies are building new office towers and gobbling up space with the same kind of abandon that characterized the technology companies at the beginning of the year. Financial services now account for almost 40 percent of the 400 million square feet of office space in Manhattan, four times more than any other industry, according to Cushman & Wakefield, the commercial real estate brokerage firm. 
 The Goldman Sachs Group, for one, is finishing up negotiations for a total of 1 million square feet of space in two downtown buildings that will bring its combined holdings to an estimated 4.4 million square feet, the equivalent of one 110-story tower at the World Trade Center. Over time, Goldman may shed some old space, but it has also started work on a 2 million-square-foot hotel and conference center in Jersey City that will include the tallest skyscraper in New Jersey at its opening, set for 2004. Three years ago, the investment bank had 1.5 million square feet of space and less than half the 11,000 employees it has today.
"Financial services is still driving the bus in this city," said Richard Clark, president of Brookfield Financial Properties, whose 10 million square feet of office space in Manhattan is filled with companies like Merrill Lynch. "Everybody's doing well, but Goldman is amazing."
Technology companies seemed to have eclipsed the financial industry in the first half of the year, when the dot-coms chased after space in every quarter of the city, driving rents up and accounting for a quarter of all the leasing deals in Manhattan. But those companies never accounted for more than 5 percent of the city's employment and income, while Wall Street generated 20 percent of the city's income. As the technology industry slowed in the third quarter, financial services surged.
"High tech was a blip," said Janice Stanton, managing director of investment research at Cushman & Wakefield. "Financial services is just huge in New York. Banking and finance have accounted for a third of all the leases year to date. And if you include all the rumored deals, it jumps to 50 percent."
Ms. Stanton said that financial services accounted for 31 percent of the office space in Manhattan, and that if insurance companies were added to the mix, the number would jump to 37 percent. Law firms make up the next largest concentration, 10 percent of the total.
While Goldman Sachs will soon have 4.4 million square feet of space in Manhattan, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter has 4.5 million and Merrill Lynch has more than 3.4 million, according to RealtyIQ, a real estate data company.
More than 170,000 people in New York City work for Wall Street companies, according to the State Department of Labor, up 30 percent since the recession of the early 1990's. Financial services jobs make up 5 percent of the city's private employment, but almost 18 percent of the wages with an average salary of more than $200,000.
An additional 180,000 people work at commercial banks and insurance companies, although the number of jobs in both sectors has declined every year since 1987, in part because of mergers and consolidations.
But the relative dominance of the financial industry could also create a problem if the economy slows down and jobs and tax revenues decline, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall said two years ago. He said it was critical that the city cultivate other industries so that the local economy was not as dependent on the fortunes of Wall Street.
"There has been an overreliance on the financial sector," Mr. McCall said recently. "If there's a downturn, it'll have a big impact. But I've seen more diversity. The new-media and Internet companies have really taken root here, and that's good. At the same time, you've got to expect a shakeout among the technology companies."
To be sure, there is still life among many high-technology and dot-com companies. Some are still growing, and their emergence downtown has helped diversify the traditionally finance-bound character of the area, noted Carl Weisbrod, president of the Alliance for Downtown New York.
The fast-growing networking giant Cisco Systems is exploring a deal for the proposed 1 million-square-foot tower over the Port Authority Bus Terminal at the southwest corner of Eighth Avenue and 42nd Street, according to real estate brokers.
But it is the financial sector that is exerting its muscle in Midtown and downtown.
Morgan Stanley is building a 1 million-square-foot skyscraper on Seventh Avenue at 50th Street, its third tower in the Times Square area. Having already outgrown its 1.2 million-square-foot headquarters under construction at Madison Avenue and 47th Street, Bear Stearns Companies has decided to keep a large block of space in its current home at 245 Park Avenue.
Demolition has begun for a new 1.1 million-square-foot headquarters for the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce at Madison Avenue and 42nd Street. Two blocks west, Deutsche Bank is in talks with Douglas Durst, the developer, about a 1.5 million-square-foot headquarters at the northwest corner of 42nd Street and the Avenue of the Americas.
Brown Brothers Harriman is negotiating with state and city officials about moving to new quarters at Battery Park City, and Lehman Brothers is looking for 500,000 square feet downtown.
Chase Manhattan Bank, which is acquiring the J. P. Morgan investment bank, recently rented 556,000 square feet at 1166 Avenue of the Americas, one of the largest leasing deals of the year. The two companies combined have 12.5 million square feet of office space in Manhattan and 2 million square feet in Brooklyn. Chase, however, recently signed a deal to move out of 55 Water Street downtown and into 1.1 million square feet in Jersey City.
Stretching beyond its headquarters on Madison Avenue, Credit Suisse First Boston recently took 264,708 square feet at 315 Park Avenue South.
"High-tech tenants are not out of the market," said Ms. Stanton of Cushman & Wakefield. "But they're no longer dominating."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Hampton Decides to Seek Better Offers as Free Agent

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

DATELINE: AMELIA ISLAND, Fla., Nov. 4

 BODY:
Mike Hampton's relationship with the Mets grew tenuous today when the pitcher's agent notified the club that Hampton had chosen to become a free agent.
After giving the Mets a chance to sign Hampton with no competition from other teams, Mark Rodgers, his agent, said they made the decision because "we were informed that the Mets had no current intention of improving on the offer the club made to Mike in February." 
 Mets General Manager Steve Phillips said he was neither surprised nor discouraged by the development. "I'd still like to see if we can work out a deal to have him fit here," said Phillips, who is here for the general managers' annual meetings. "It's just a matter of determining where the deal should go. I had to let the market tell me what the appropriate range is."
The two sides have not disclosed details of the proposal the Mets made in February, but a wide gap, philosophically and economically, apparently separated them. The free-agent market is expected to enable Hampton to sign for about $15 million a year, the amount Kevin Brown gained from Los Angeles two years ago.
Asked if he was prepared to meet the market, wherever it went, Phillips said: "It's not a decision to be made in a vacuum. It depends on all of the other considerations we have. It's all part of the combined plan."
That plan begins with Alex Rodriguez, the free-agent shortstop whom the Mets covet and who is expected to command $20 million or more a year on a very long-term contract. The Mets cannot ignore free-agent pitchers like Hampton and Mike Mussina because Rick Reed and Bobby J. Jones are also free agents.
Nevertheless, Rodgers said he was prepared to continue to listen seriously to what Phillips said. "If he is serious about it, Mike Hampton and I will never close the door on the New York Mets," Rodgers said in a telephone interview.
Speaking of free agency, Rodgers, in a statement he released earlier in the day, said, "It simply closes one window of opportunity, i.e., the opportunity the Mets possessed to negotiate exclusively with Mike outside the four walls of the free-agent market."
Any interest the Mets have, the agent added, "will be balanced now against the interests of other clubs."
Rodgers said he would begin talking to other clubs "in earnest" on Sunday when he arrived here. The agent can speak to other clubs about Hampton, but he cannot negotiate with any team but the Mets until Nov. 11, after the 15-day filing period ends.
Hampton said in a statement: "I have filed for free agency because I am curious about the possibilities that may be available for me around the major leagues. I did not file for free agency because I am angry with the Mets."
He added that he enjoyed playing in New York. Hampton said he intended to keep an open mind, which included the possibility of remaining with the Mets. The Mets, however, may find a more economically feasible solution in trying to sign Denny Neagle as a free agent.
When Neagle first joined the Yankees in July, he talked of signing with them, and they echoed the interest. However, his performance for the Yankees deteriorated after his first two starts and the team's interest waned. Their late-season offer to Neagle nevertheless remains on the table.
The Mets apparently are considering Neagle because he will not cost nearly as much as Hampton to sign.
"Denny wants to play with a winner, and obviously the Mets are that," Barry Meister, Neagle's agent, said. "Denny's had a tremendous amount of success in the National League and he wouldn't be averse to playing in New York. Also, since the early 80's, I've had a lot of pitchers play for Bobby Valentine. I'm a big Bobby Valentine fan. I think he's terrific with a pitching staff, and he can be an inspirational guy. Personality-wise, I think he and Denny would be a great fit."

HEADLINE: Remote Yemen May Be Key to Terrorist's Past and Future

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS

DATELINE: WADI DOAN, Yemen, Nov. 2

 BODY:
By legend, this remote valley nestled between the Arabian Sea and the black, crumpled mountains that form a shield against the vast deserts of Arabia is the land of the Queen of Sheba and the place fabled for the gold and frankincense and myrrh that the Wise Men carried to the manger where Jesus was born.
Even today, nearly 3,000 years after a civilization first flourished here, ancient mudbrick skyscrapers, amber-eyed men with short-tailed turbans and elusive, fast-walking women clothed head-to-toe in black shrouds and tall, conical straw hats lend the landscape a pervasive air of mystery. 
 It was into this world, ancient and in essential ways unchanging, that agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation stepped two weeks ago. What drew them was not a way of life that has fascinated generations of Arabists, anthropologists and explorers. Rather, they were investigating the links between this fastness of low-lying mountains and Osama bin Laden, the self-proclaimed leader of an Islamic "holy war" against the United States, who is considered a prime suspect in organizing or at least inspiring the bombing of the destroyer Cole on Oct. 12, which killed 17 American sailors.
The two men who spent four months staking out American warships entering Aden harbor -- thought to be the same two who loaded a skiff with high explosives and blew a gaping hole in one of the world's most sophisticated warships -- spoke with Arabic accents that identified them as natives of Hadhramaut, this province in eastern Yemen that is home to bin Laden's ancestral village, Al-Rubat.
It was from that hilltop village that Muhammad bin Laden, Osama's father, migrated in the 1950's to Saudi Arabia, where he formed close ties with the ruling Saud dynasty and accumulated a billion-dollar fortune building roads and palaces and trading real estate.
Though the 43-year-old Osama bin Laden, the 17th of more than 50 children born to his father, never lived in Wadi Doan and now makes his headquarters in the isolated mountain caves and desert hideouts of Afghanistan, he absorbed his fundamentalist views on Islam from the strict Wahhabi form of Muslim beliefs that is prevalent in this region. And it is here, in Wadi Doan, that some of the clues to his character -- as well as to the bombing of the Cole -- may lie.
F.B.I. officials have said they have only suppositional evidence linking Mr. bin Laden to the Cole attack, but the agency believes from investigations into at least a half-dozen major terrorist strikes on American targets in the past decade that Wadi Doan and similarly remote places in Yemen's hinterland have served as strongholds for a variety of Islamic terrorist groups with links to Mr. bin Laden.
One way and another, the F.B.I. has established links between these Yemeni redoubts and several of the worst Islamic terrorist attacks on American targets, including the bombing of two American embassies in East Africa that killed 242 people and wounded about 5,000 in August 1998 and the World Trade Center bombing in New York in 1993 that killed 6 people and injured 1,000. Altogether, more than a dozen major attacks on American targets in the Middle East, Europe and elsewhere over the past decade -- including an attack on an Aden hotel in 1992 that was aimed at American soldiers, but missed them, killing two Yemenis -- have been linked to groups with ties to Mr. bin Laden.
Now, the F.B.I.'s investigation into the Cole bombing has led them back to Wadi Doan. Beyond the accents of the two men suspected in the attack, the F.B.I. also believes that Mr. bin Laden, under pressure from the Taliban rulers of Afghanistan, who have been subjected to United Nations trade sanctions for harboring him, gave a number of hints shortly before the Cole attack that he was renewing links to his family's ancestral home, possibly as a prelude to seeking a new sanctuary in Yemen.
For one thing, the 6-foot-3-inch Mr. bin Laden, in a videotape secretly delivered to a television station in the Persian Gulf state of Qatar and broadcast from there throughout the Middle East on Sept. 22, wore traditional Hadhrami dress, with a curved dagger at his belt, as he delivered a fresh tirade against the United States and new threats to attack American targets in the Arabian peninsula.
For another, Al-Quds, a London-based Arab-language newspaper with a history of solid reporting on Mr. bin Laden's activities, reported recently that, following strict Islamic tradition, Mr. bin Laden had held a lavish wedding feast in the Afghan city of Kandahar and married, as his fourth wife, a 17-year-old girl from a prominent Hadhramaut family.
Mr. bin Laden's ancestral village, Al-Rubat, lies about 1,350 miles from the deserts and mountains of eastern and southern Afghanistan where he now hides, after quitting his previous base in Sudan under growing F.B.I. pressure in the early 1990's. But the remote Wadi Doan is redolent of many things that appear to have fed into Mr. bin Laden's character and his battle against America -- including a profound Islamic faith that has evolved little in a millennium, a deeply frugal lifestyle, and a passion for secrecy and conspiracy in the face of all things alien or unfamiliar.
Though Mr. bin Laden grew up in the Saudi Arabian city of Jiddah, about 700 miles away across the Arabian peninsula beyond the arid, burning reach of low shale mountains and deserts known as the Empty Quarter, and though he has traveled far even from there, those who know him say he remains every bit a Hadhrami -- as the people of this remote region of eastern Yemen are known: among other things intensely clannish, and just as intensely conservative in their adherence to strict forms of Islam.
"He is a very good man, a very honest man, a very devout man," said Jafr Ahmed, a man in his 70's with cracked spectacles who sat on a stoop in the hilltop fastness of Al Hajrayn, smoking a hookah pipe fashioned from an old oil can and a length of rubber hose. Mr. Ahmed, who worked as a jackhammer operator for the bin Laden company in Saudi Arabia for 35 years, added, "Father and son both, they were kind, they were true to Islam."
Those around here who knew his father say the key to Osama bin Laden's character -- his shrewdness and singularity of purpose, his deeply conservative religious and political views, his profound distaste for non-Islamic influences that have penetrated some of the most remote corners of old Arabia, even the cunning tradecraft he has used in his meticulously planned attacks -- lies in the unrelenting traditions of the Hadhrami.
One of the investigative breaks that brought the F.B.I. to Hadhramaut within days of the Cole bombing was the discovery that one of the presumed bombers, who called himself Abdullah Ahmed Khaled al-Musawah and wore the thick, bushy beard favored among the devout in Islam, carried a driver's license and other documents identifying him as a Hadhramaut native.
The other man, slight and goateed, rarely spoke to those who met him in the steep, cloistering alleyways above Aden harbor, before the two men disappeared for the last time at dawn on the day of bombing. But neighbors said that the second man also spoke with a thick Hadhrami accent, in his case spiced with the linguistic influences of Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf.
As Hadhramis, the suspected bombers came from a world that could scarcely be more different from the one inhabited by the Americans who sent the Cole into Aden for the 25th in a series of refueling stops that began in 1999, disregarding years of C.I.A. and State Department warnings that Yemen offered a haven for Islamic terrorists. Those American officers and diplomats came from a world of stunning technical sophistication and global reach barely imaginable amid the unchanging rhythms and beliefs of life in Hadhramaut.
In these broad valleys, where the rivers dried up in times immemorial, becoming shallow streams only during the August rains, the distant world has not been wholly shut out. For one thing, the poverty that set in centuries ago -- when the collapse of the Roman Empire caused a decline in the frankincense trade and newer civilizations turned increasingly to other, cheaper fragrances available closer at hand -- has made wanderers of the Hadhrami people.
With little to sustain them here, and the maritime traditions born of living on the Arabian Sea, Hadhramis began dispersing to places as distant as Java, the Malaccas and the great port cities of India. During the first big Middle Eastern oil boom in the 1950's, the migration shifted to Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf.
It was this migration that carried Osama bin Laden's father, Muhammad, and several brothers to Saudi Arabia, where they parlayed their Hadhrami frugality and shrewdness into a vast fortune that left Osama bin Laden, after his father died when he was still in his teens, with a personal wealth Saudi acquaintances of the bin Ladens have estimated at $300 million, perhaps even more.
On their travels, Hadhramis took with them special skills, especially in construction techniques developed over the millennia in building the distinctive mud skyscrapers in which most Hadhramis live. When they returned, as many did once they had made enough money to sustain their families, they brought back vestiges of foreign influence.
In recent years, for example, virtually every home in their mud skyscrapers has satellite television that has made Hadhramis enthusiastic watchers of Egyptian movies and Lebanese game shows, and of other light entertainment originating still farther afield, in Europe and the United States.
But the basic Hadhrami qualities -- Islamic devoutness, grinding thrift and, above all, an abiding wariness of foreigners and anything alien to Islam -- have endured. So, too, has an even narrower exclusiveness toward Arabs and Muslims from much closer at hand, a trait sociologists have said is particularly marked in Wadi Doan, the stoney valley that runs down toward the Arabian sea from a point south of the Empty Quarter.
For most Hadhramis, this means never discussing with a stranger anything of political or religious importance, and certainly nothing to do with the bombing of the Cole. "I have no right to ask you anything, and you have no right to ask me -- this way, we both can be happy," said Jamal Ahmed, a 40-year-old seller of stationery, backing away from a visitor to his shop in Al Hajrayn to engage in a self-conscious dusting of his array of pencils, notebooks and erasers.
It was this culture that the bin Ladens carried with them on their travels -- and that made Hadhramaut, for Osama bin Laden, an ideal base when he began in the early 1990's, from his headquarters in Afghanistan, to develop the terrorist diaspora he has used in his self-proclaimed "holy war" against the United States and the ruling dynasties in the Persian Gulf that are its allies.
As Yemen's government discovered after it united the country in a bitter civil war in 1994, the writ of any law but the Koran's, and the local landlords' and tribal leaders', does not run deep.
In the distinctive citadels they have built on the rocky hills that flank the valley, Hadhramis tolerate the groups of intrepid tourists, mostly from France and Germany, who wander the narrow streets. As long as questions relate to matters of tradition and lifestyle, of the skills used in the bee-keeping, goat-herding and subsistence farming that provide much of what little there is in local employment -- and as long as no outsider, particularly a Western man, tries to speak to the shrouded women who scurry past along narrow alleyways -- Hadhramis are friendly, if not exactly exuberant in their attitude toward outsiders.
But once the talk shifts to topics even vaguely related to politics, much more anything as potentially explosive as the use of Hadhramaut as an Islamic terrorist bastion, shutters go up quickly. Ali Omar Bahareish, a trader selling honeycombs opposite the mosque in the hilltop citadel of Al Hajrayn, about 20 miles north of the bin Laden family's native village at Al-Rubat, chatted easily for an hour about his 35 years as a construction worker in Saudi Arabia, some of it working for the bin Laden family company that now has projects throughout the Middle East.
Like many Yemenis, and even most of the people approached in the ancient citadels that crowd every hilltop in Wadi Doan, Mr. Bahareish said he was sorry for the sailors who died aboard the Cole, and sorry, too, for the people of Hadhramaut, since the bombing would further discourage the tourism that also adds to what little local economy there is. But he had scarcely had a chance to say even that before a Yemeni government "minder" assigned to accompany this reporter and a crew from ABC television's "Prime Time" program leapt to his feet from the alcove where he had been dozing and ordered the honey-seller to shut up.
"Don't talk about that, nothing, not a word, nothing about bin Laden," said the minder, in an angry whisper, glowering through his dark glasses, before moving from the alcove to a position a half-dozen paces away where he could monitor the conversation even more carefully.

HEADLINE: Crowds Shower President With the Star Treatment

BYLINE: By MARC LACEY

 BODY:
President Clinton acted as a stand-in yesterday as he stumped across the Bronx, Harlem and Brooklyn urging New York Democrats to turn out en masse for his vice president and his wife. But at times, this retiring politician whose name will appear on no ballot on Election Day sure seemed like the main attraction.
Before he made his well-practiced pitch, Mr. Clinton had to quiet the crowd, which surged forward for a glimpse of him at rally after rally and roared whenever he tried to open his mouth. 
 "You're the man, Bill!" one giddy onlooker shouted, teetering atop a chair for a peek at the president at the Marina Del Ray, a restaurant in the Bronx packed with 1,000 Democrats.
"Thank you, Bill! Thank you, Bill!" came another thunderous chant.
Later, in Harlem, Mr. Clinton was the featured speaker at a get-out-the-vote rally in African Square Plaza that drew more than 5,000 excited onlookers.
"We want Bill! We want Bill!" the crowd was shouting when his motorcade pulled up -- and continued shouting long after he took the stage.
Mr. Clinton may well be a detested figure in some parts of the country. And he may well turn off swing voters and energize the Republican base, as the Gore campaign has calculated. But none of that was on display yesterday as Mr. Clinton stuck to solidly Democratic turf -- "I'm preaching to the saved," he noted at one point -- while trying to boost the fortunes of Al Gore's presidential campaign and Hillary Rodham Clinton's Senate bid.
"Why are New Yorkers so fanatically loyal to President Clinton?" Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president and likely mayoral candidate, asked in introducing the president. "The answer is simple: For the first time in my lifetime, there has been someone in the White House who has felt comfortable with people like us."
Others seemed to agree. The focus was supposed to be on Mr. Gore and Mrs. Clinton, both of whom are locked in tight races, but the Democrats who turned out yesterday could not help repeatedly invoking the name of Mr. Clinton.
"You can't help but love the guy," said Tecala T. Hall, a social worker and Democratic activist. "He gets down with the people. Gore isn't quite there yet, but I want him in the White House. He'll get there."
Fred Judd, a union advocate from Brooklyn and a fervent backer of Mrs. Clinton, said her connection to the president is one of her pluses. "Hillary's going to be good for New York because of all the insider connections she has from the president," Mr. Judd said. "She'll have a pipeline between Washington and New York. She'll get things done."
Mrs. Clinton did not campaign with the president yesterday, but she too was clearly concentrating on her get-out-of-the vote effort in the suburbs and the boroughs. Joined by Representative Nita Lowey, Mrs. Clinton addressed an abortion rights rally at Manhattanville College in Purchase, knocked on doors of homes in New Rochelle and, earlier in the day, strolled through a retail district in Scarsdale.
With President Clinton working to get traditional Democratic voters excited about Tuesday's election, Mrs. Clinton set her sights on women who might otherwise not support her. She talked mostly about abortion rights and the importance of future appointees to the Supreme Court, but she also stressed her opposition to school vouchers and her support for gun safety measures.
Mrs. Clinton got a rousing response from the largely partisan audience at Manhattanville, but she also seemed to make some headway among the handful of Republicans and independents she met throughout the day, including in Scarsdale.
Christine Conklin, 35, a Republican from Eastchester, said she would vote for Mrs. Clinton, in large part because she likes the idea of a woman representing New York. Leslie Hansen-Sturm, 56, a real estate agent and independent, said she had recently decided to vote for Mrs. Clinton as well.
"She's got backbone, whether you like it or not," said Ms. Hansen-Sturm, who was among several dozen people who greeted Mrs. Clinton outside the Coffee Tree shop near the train station in Scarsdale. "I think she will really do something for us."
In Rochdale Village in Queens last night, about 400 residents turned out at a Democratic rally as Mrs. Clinton beseeched members of the predominantly black audience to vote. "My race is tight," Mrs. Clinton told them. "It is volatile. I never know what they are going to do next. "
The president, too, remarked on his own about the surprises Mrs. Clinton has experienced along her 16-month campaign journey, which he said he knew from the start would be a slugfest.
"She has been subject to a campaign that has been amazing to me, and I've been through a lot," Mr. Clinton remarked. "But hey, you know, that's part of the deal. She's met every test. She's worked her heart out for 16 months."
Mr. Clinton clearly relishes all the embraces in these waning days of his presidency, but he also clearly agrees with another line from Mr. Ferrer, who cheered Bronx Democrats by saying, "The legacy of the Clinton-Gore administration hangs in the balance over the next four days."
Mr. Clinton said yesterday that he had never seen a presidential election as close as this one. As he does to audiences everywhere, Mr. Clinton touted the current economic prosperity and argued that Republican policies would squander the surplus and endanger all that his administration has struggled to build.
"If you want to keep the prosperity going, you've got one choice," he said in the Bronx, surprising no one with his answer. "Al Gore. Joe Lieberman. And Hillary."
