SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 2; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 2865 words

HEADLINE: Where Is Russia's New Music? Iowa, That's Where

BYLINE: By RICHARD TARUSKIN

DATELINE: IOWA CITY

 BODY:
RUSSIANS of a certain age are apt to regard the state of Iowa with slightly mordant nostalgia. Nikita S. Khrushchev passed through during his 1959 official visit to America. He took home some Iowa corn, ordered his collective farmers to grow it, produced a historic crop failure and . . . well, you know the rest.
But that was not the reason 14 Russian composers and musicologists gathered recently for a long weekend at the University of Iowa here. Khrushchev's corn mania was nurtured at Iowa State, which has a famous agricultural college. The Iowa City institution (best known, perhaps, for its Writers' Workshop) has long been distinguished in contemporary-music circles. In 1966, with Rockefeller Foundation money, it set up a Center for New Music, one of the earliest campus performance outlets of its kind. 
 Now led by David Gompper, an energetic 46-year-old composer, conductor and pianist with an admirably ecumenical world view, the center has undertaken a series of display events to acquaint its audience with the work of composers from foreign countries. In 1998 the favored nation was Greece; in 1999, Austria. The Russian Contemporary Music Festival, with three full-length concerts and a slew of meaty conference sessions, was by far the biggest. Though underbudgeted and virtually unpublicized (hence sadly underattended), it was a fascinating and important event.
Information on what has been happening musically in post-Soviet Russia has been hard to come by. In the late Soviet period, when listening to contemporary music carried a mild cachet of dissidence, it had a popular following at home and an appeal to journalists abroad that the Western avant-garde could never command. As long as the Big Troika of Moscow modernists -- Alfred Schnittke, Sofia Gubaidulina and Edison Denisov (along with the fellow-traveling Estonian, Arvo Part) -- could be seen as living dangerously, their exploits were widely reported and their every premiere was news. When they began living (or, in the case of Denisov, sojourning) abroad, their proximity further magnified them and virtually hid their contemporaries from view.
Since the Soviet collapse, there has not been an official propaganda machine to bring Russian music to the world's attention, and deteriorating economic conditions have vastly inhibited publication and recording. Unsurprisingly, then, Iowa's Russian festival was a showcase of unknowns. Here is the roster of 16 composers, aged 29 to 70, whose music was performed at the concerts: Vladislav Agafonnikov, Yuri Butsko, Irina Dubkova, Andrei Golovin, Faradzh Karayev, Leonid Karev, Mikhail Kollontay, Nikolai Korndorf, Roman Ledenyov, Vladimir Nikolayev, Olga Rayeva, Dmitri Ryabtsev, Albina Stefanou, Vladimir Tarnopolski, Aleksandr Vustin, Sergei Zagny. How many names did you know? This onlooker, thought to be a specialist in Russian music, knew six. If you knew more, kindly keep it to yourself.
Their work covered a stylistic and ideological range at least as broad as any Western country's, showing that beneath the enforced unanimity of Soviet public life, a rich and varied culture always seethed. Svetlana Savenko, the senior musicologist present, noted with a twinkle that "as in a good supermarket, you can find virtually anything you wish" in Russian music today.
Nor did anybody abruptly change styles on Dec. 25, 1991, the day Mikhail S. Gorbachev called it quits. Ms. Savenko, her twinkle now a bit mischievous, reported that foreign visitors had sometimes expressed surprise at this. But if you laughed at the Fidel Castro surrogate in Woody Allen's "Bananas," who on the day after the revolution announced that his little republic's official language would henceforth be Swedish, you know better. All the collapse of totalitarianism did was level the playing field. A hundred flowers now bloom undisturbed, and also unassisted. It's not better for everyone.
Elena Dubinets, a Russian-trained musicologist now living in Seattle and the festival's co-organizer, emphasized in her opening remarks that the event was "unprecedented in plan and scope." The words had a faint ring of irony; for with plurality come factions, rivalries and mutual antagonisms. One had a strong sense that the Iowa participants could never have been induced to inhabit the same room, let alone share a rostrum, at home.
At first glance, one saw the same factions as everywhere, though in the slightly fossilized variants you might expect to find where a status quo had long been embalmed in amber. There was the senior academic faction that in the West would of course comprise serialists but that here consisted of impressionists, folklorists and neo-classicists: what you would have found in an American music department in the 1950's. There were elite modernists, mostly former pupils and grandpupils of Denisov, whose attitudes somewhat resemble those of the European avant-garde of the 1960's (say, Berio or Ligeti).
They describe themselves as today's Russian avant-garde, but they are in no sense rebels: they have inherited their seniors' commitment to old-fashioned academic training and despise composers who lack "technique." To find rebels one had to look to a third group, not necessarily younger than the others, who take what might hereabout seem a somewhat faded inspiration from Dada and Cage but also go in for the kind of border-crossings (serious-pop, high-low, art-commerce) associated in the West, if a little jadedly by now, with postmodernism.
Each group has its own niche festival at home. The seniors get played at the Moscow Autumn, which tourists attend and where big-name artists and ensembles perform. The modernists hold forth at the Moscow Forum, which functions as a branch of the International Society for Contemporary Music and maintains contacts with elite modernists abroad. Its performing ensembles, highly professional and specialized, are the ones most comparable to the new-music groups on American campuses. And the rebels have their Alternativa festival, where just about anything goes except Autumn and Forum fare, and where the main performing groups have names like Ad Hoc and 4:33 (after Cage's immortal bout of nothing). Mixed grills like the one savored in Iowa are served, as yet, only in Iowa.
But if you looked a bit below the surface, especially if you did so with some knowledge of Russian music and its checkered history, much more interesting configurations turned up. There were many at the festival who did not want to be looked at this way, especially the Alternativa crowd for whom nationalities were just another border to be crossed. Mr. Zagny, for example, who at 40 still enjoys (in every sense) the reputation of an enfant terrible, was especially vehement in asserting his right to be considered as a human being, not a Russian. Dmitri Ukhov, the Alternativa organizer, sneeringly consigned the "national question" to the museum, his face suggesting that he had a less dignified destination in mind.
No wonder. Nobody likes to be categorized, especially when the category in question is as fraught with stereotypes as that of "Russian composer." Nor was anybody forgetting that displays of national character had been promoted, and at times insisted on, by the Soviet state. Attitudes toward it opened up a yawning generation gap.
Professor Ledenyov, of the Moscow Conservatory, the oldest composer present, serenely maintained the old Soviet line, asserting that "there exists a Russian school of composers" characterized by "a conglomerate of certain features peculiar to this national culture and its folk music." He even claimed that Moscow and St. Petersburg schools could still be defined just the way they had been in the 19th century (St. Petersburg being "theatrical" and Moscow having "profound psychologism").
The piece he presented to demonstrate his relationship to the living national traditions he described, "Metamorphoses" for viola and chamber orchestra, was attractively lyrical and moody, and did incline more toward the psychological than to the showy. But it was based on a theme by Bach ("Erbarme dich," from the "St. Matthew Passion") and made side references to Schumann, Chopin, Mozart, "The Umbrellas of Cherbourg" and bossa nova. Go figure.
The headiest moment at the festival came when Marina Frolova-Walker, a musicologist less than half Professor Ledenyov's age, trained at his conservatory but now teaching at Cambridge University in England, got up to inveigh against everything he had said. She denied that there ever was any such thing as Russian music, only music from Russia, and hinted that to maintain a nationalistic view of culture was to espouse a reactionary view of society. There were overtones here not only of Russia's eternal identity crisis but also of the mutual suspicions that have always colored relations, in the 20th century, between Russians at home and Russians abroad.
Yet even advocates of the avant-garde occasionally cited nationality as a determinant of style. Ms. Dubinets distinguished Russian minimalism from its Western counterpart. "Minimalism can be oriented not only to commercial accessibility," she said. "It can be very lyrical, sensitive, suffering and compassionate. It can touch the soul and disturb the subconscious." Ms. Frolova-Walker would no doubt call this a salad of cliches. (And not only she: the Russian artist Serge Soudeikine once exclaimed that his mission in life was "to show the world that the Russian can also be gay.") But if a cliche, however disprovable, is accepted by artists and embodied in their art, then it has indeed become a stylistic determinant. And the art it determines is in no way necessarily condemned to banality.
A CASE in point is Mr. Korndorf's "Hymn II," one of the few works presented at the festival that is available on CD (from Sony Classical, with the BBC Orchestra directed by Aleksandr Lazarev). This gleaming piece is recognizably minimalist in its radically reduced material, but the composer said that he had modeled it on the solemn doxologies of the Russian Orthodox Church. And its liturgical character derives not only from actual liturgical sources but also, and at least as much, from the familiar Russian glory-music of the concert and opera stages. (Imagine Gorecki arranged by Rimsky-Korsakov, or a diatonic "Poem of Ecstasy.") One can believe that such a synthesis would have occurred only to a Russian composer without buying into the biology-is-destiny mystique of nationalism.
Resonances of more ancient Orthodox music could be found in other festival offerings, providing an avenue, for those desiring it, toward a genuinely national modernism or modern nationalism. In its pious archaism it proclaims its freedom from the constraints of a more recent past, and it crosscuts generations, uniting Mr. Butsko, one of the oldest composers represented at the festival, and Mr. Karev, one of the youngest. Much of their music (and not only theirs) is based on an imaginative extension of a scale peculiar to medieval Russian chant, credited to Mr. Butsko.
The scale contains both B natural in its low tessitura and B flat in its higher one. The extension incorporates all the notes of the chromatic scale into an evolving tonal structure that picks up flats as it ascends and sharps as it descends. The piquant, very original harmonic idiom that emerges from it can be sampled on CD's in Schnittke's Fourth Symphony, a work inspired by Mr. Butsko's "Polyphonic Concerto" for organ, piano, harpsichord and celesta, from which Mr. Karev, a Russian organist (rare breed!) who lives and works in Paris, performed some excerpts with Mr. Ryabtsev joining in at the piano. It is one of the exasperating vagaries of fame that Schnittke is usually given credit for inventing the mode.
Another area in which today's Russian avant-garde works in high consciousness of national traditions, perhaps unexpectedly, is that of electro-acoustical music. As Mr. Ukhov was at pains to point out, the genre has a longer history in Russia than almost anywhere else. It was 80 years ago that Lev Sergeyevich Termen (known in the West as Leon Theremin) invented the dual-antennaed sound-emitter that bears his name, the only musical instrument one plays without touching.
Composers who heard the theremin in the 1920's were often struck by its possibilities. The sounds it produced "between the fixed pitches and tone colors" of conventional concert music revealed to Ernst Toch "a true new vista that Theremin lays open to the composer of music, still incalculable in its consquences." But that promise long went unfulfilled. Theremin himself, scientifically gifted but musically unimaginative, thought of his instrument as a sort of modernized violin or cello, on which he played salon gems like Saint-Saens's "Swan." His protegee Clara Rockmore mastered Bloch's "Schelomo." By the 1930's, John Cage could write in disgust that "thereministes act as censors, giving the public those sounds they think the public will like; we are shielded from new sound experiences."
It was exciting, then, when Mr. Ukhov produced a tape of Vladimir Nikolayev's "19 Piques" for theremin and string quartet, performed by Lydia Kavina, the inventor's grandniece, at "ALT-2K," this year's Alternativa festival. A thing of feral glissandos and haunting microtones, it finally kept the broken promise of long ago and made the dowdy old theremin (long since consigned to sci-fi soundtracks and rock backups in the West) seem again an instrument of real -- indeed, inspiring -- possibilities.
But the biggest impression of all (and on all) came from Vladimir Tarnopolski, a world-class talent by any standard. Now 45, Mr. Tarnopolski is an emblematic figure, having been appointed to the Moscow Conservatory's composition faculty in 1992, the first post-Soviet year. Widely acknowledged at home (along with Aleksandr Knaifel of St. Petersburg) as the standard-bearer for Russia's elite modernists, he was given pride of place at the festival. Two of his major works were presented. An opera, "When Time Overflows Its Banks," was shown on videotape in a performance given last year in German at the Munich Biennale, which commissioned it. "Cassandra," a 20-minute composition for a large chamber ensemble (or small orchestra) of 19 players, was put over brilliantly by a valiant band of students and faculty members from the University's School of Music under Mr. Gompper's expert baton.
BOTH were scorching, moving experiences. In "Cassandra," the titular tone of dire prophecy is conveyed by a mounting sonic wave that comes up against cacophonous obstacles in the form of stridently repeated chords and clusters. The work would have had a powerful effect under any circumstances, but knowing that it was written in the spring and summer of 1991, during the time of foreboding that led up to the aborted August putsch, lent it the kind of special poignancy that Shostakovich's works often possess when they are apprehended in their historical context. (It is recorded, along with three other Tarnopolski scores, on a Belgian CD, Megadisc MDC 7838, which is hard to find in America but may be ordered online through amazon.co.uk, the British Amazon Web site.)
The opera has a similarly obsessive and intensifying shape. Its three scenes are parallel constructions. The first, an abstraction from Chekhov's "Three Sisters" in which the characters typically converse without hearing one another, is followed by a second, in which people today (played by the same singers) are shown discoursing incomprehensibly about art, and a third, in which the same characters reappear once again as people of the future, each confined to a plastic tube, enunciating isolated phonemes accompanied by primal sonic soup from the orchestra. The composer's purpose, as he reported it, was to lay bare "the existential problems of man," namely "the impossibility of communication and of mutual understanding, loneliness and absence of a sense of life," which "are not solved but are redoubled in the course of the development of civilization."
The Sartrean or Beckettish message may strike the Western ear as dated, but the music and the dramaturgy were fresh, gripping and so virtuosically executed as to disarm sophisticated cavil. Besides, there was, as it turned out, a charming disconnect between the art and the artist. When discussion following Ms. Frolova-Walker's paper turned vehement and time ran out, it was Mr. Tarnopolski who suggested that an extra round table be scheduled for the sake of better communication and mutual understanding. When it was pointed out to him that he seemed, after all, to believe in what his opera denied, he answered, ingenuously, "Well, I'm an optimist."
Why, then, such a pessimistic opera? Could it be because the composer had grown up in, and learned to resist, a society that demanded that all art be optimistic to the point of mendacity? Big questions are looming, and my space is up. But the most fortifying thought one took away from the Iowa festival was that in the former land of the Soviets there can now be questions without answers.

HEADLINE: HOLIDAY FILMS;
Marooned On an Island, Out on a Limb

BYLINE: By MARGY ROCHLIN; Margy Rochlin, who is based in Los Angeles, writes frequently about movies and television.

DATELINE: SANTA MONICA, Calif.

 BODY:
EARLY last month, Tom Hanks could be found in a Four Seasons Hotel banquet hall in Beverly Hills, seated between his wife, Rita Wilson, and Holly Hunter. On his plate, there wasn't much left of his mesclun greens and goat cheese salad. But judging from how much he was laughing, Mr. Hanks was enjoying more than just his meal.
He was there to present Ms. Hunter, an old friend, with a special career achievement award at Premiere magazine's "Women in Hollywood" luncheon, an annual event known for its high giddiness factor. So while Mr. Hanks heaped praise on Ms. Hunter, he also laced his podium time with teasing ad-libs and did a clipped, weirdly high-pitched imitation of Ms. Hunter's husband, the Polish cinematographer Janusz Kaminski. 
 Mr. Hanks even zinged his host, James B. Meigs, the editor in chief of Premiere. In introducing him, Mr. Meigs described Mr. Hanks's new film, "Cast Away," as a daring departure for someone of Mr. Hanks's stature: a stranded-on-a-desert-island tale in which, Mr. Meigs said, "a major portion of the movie has no musical score, no voiceover, no co-stars and -- oh, yeah -- no food." After bounding onstage, Mr. Hanks turned to Mr. Meigs, fixed him with a look and said accusingly: "Thanks. You really made the movie sound great."
The explosive laughter that greeted Mr. Hanks's feigned umbrage had much to do with his patented brand of genial sarcasm. But this film-industry crowd might have also taken his joke as a display of defensiveness and felt sympathetic toward a Hollywood brand of touchiness that can accompany the wait to see if a very personal project will be accepted by the masses.
Two days later, the 44-year-old Mr. Hanks would watch an almost final version of "Cast Away" in a nearly deserted screening room on the 20th Century Fox lot in Century City. Even though he had invited his own focus group -- Ms. Wilson, his baseball-capped eldest son, 22-year-old Colin Hanks, and his agent Richard Lovett, the president of Creative Artists Agency -- he was still in limbo. When their feedback did not allay his concern, he sought reaction from one of the few other people present in the room -- a reporter divided between taking in the unfolding 2-hour-19-minute movie and searching for meaning in the Hanks family's every flinch and chuckle.
"You liked it, right? Does it work?" Mr. Hanks asked a few days later. "Is the theme of the movie big enough to fill up the screen? Is it interesting enough? I can't tell."
It was an honest declaration of uncertainty from Mr. Hanks, who describes himself as closer to and more involved in "Cast Away" than any project in his 20-year career. How close?
"Mind-numbingly so," said Mr. Hanks, who is credited as an executive producer.
That's because "Cast Away," directed by Robert Zemeckis and written by William Broyles Jr., is based on an idea Mr. Hanks got more than six years ago. After reading that Federal Express flies jumbo jets across the Pacific Ocean every day, Mr. Hanks recalled, he thought to himself, "I wonder what happens when one of those goes down?" From there, he came up with the concept to make a movie of pure behavior and action -- playing a character who would spend the bulk of his time onscreen doing rather than talking. "Chuck of the Jungle," as Mr. Hanks long called it, would be the story of a FedEx systems analyst named Chuck Nolan who as the sole survivor of a plane wreck would be marooned for four years on an uninhabited lump of white sand and palm trees in a remote part of the South Pacific.
When he began telling people about his idea, everyone from potential screenwriters to his friends responded positively to the theme of a life-or-death struggle for food, water and shelter. But there was a different reaction to Chuck's crushing loneliness -- the central emotional theme of Mr. Hanks's scenario. Suddenly, Mr. Hanks said, he was fielding all-too-eager suggestions on how to embellish his spare drama by helping the protagonist find somebody to trade quips with.
"It would be like, 'Well, what if he had a monkey?' " recalled Mr. Hanks.
" 'No,' " Mr. Hanks would reply. " 'He's not going to have a monkey.'
" 'Are pirates going to land on the island?'
" 'No, no pirates.'
" 'He's got to get off the island somehow. Let's say Elle Macpherson comes ashore on a Sports Illustrated calendar shoot!' "
Finally, Mr. Hanks hooked up with Mr. Broyles, the screenwriter of "Apollo 13," the space docudrama that features Mr. Hanks as the astronaut Jim Lovell. Mr. Hanks and Mr. Broyles spent untold hours collaborating on a treatment so that Mr. Broyles could come up with a first draft. Still, later on, pre-production would seem like the easy part. Because barely two months after finishing "The Green Mile," in January 1999, he was in Moscow and the Fiji Islands, still carrying his prison-guard flab and jowls, shooting the pre-crash Chuck Nolan scenes. After that, "Cast Away" took its much-reported unconventional trajectory: Mr. Zemeckis went off to make "What Lies Beneath" with Michelle Pfeiffer and Harrison Ford. Mr. Hanks put away his razor, dropped 55 pounds, became a regular at his local tanning booth and waved good-bye to his barber.
"Ridiculously bush-like" is Mr. Hanks's description of what became of his erupting brown curls. "I looked like one of those guys from Foghat." A year later, Mr. Hanks and the "Cast Away" crew reconvened in the South Pacific, where the only conversations Mr. Hanks's character had were held with the open sky.
The closest thing Chuck gets to a Man Friday is a Wilson volleyball that washes ashore. Out of sheer desperation Chuck calls it by name and treats it like a beloved confidante. (Perhaps a loving nod to his wife.) What Mr. Zemeckis remembered about the filming of these scenes was that the craziness of this plot device wasn't lost on anybody.
"You know what he said to me after we played back the take of when he first meets the volleyball and starts talking to him?" Mr. Zemeckis said. "He said, 'Well, Bob. I didn't know the movie was turning into "Apocalypse Now." And we just laughed. It was like: 'Oh, my God. We just stepped over the line.' "
Yet Mr. Hanks and Mr. Zemeckis, who first worked together on the blockbuster "Forrest Gump," appear energized by such conceptual leaps of faith. In Mr. Hanks's case, perhaps this is because in the past he has had success with what is just unorthodox enough. He made the jump to movies, after all, from "Bosom Buddies," a television sitcom in which he appeared in drag every week. And in 1984, in "Splash," his leading-man debut in film had him wooing a mermaid.
When a handful of middle-of-the-road comedies failed after that, he bounced back in 1988 with "Big," in which he played a 12-year-old trapped inside a grown-up's body, lending poignance to what could have been just a gimmick. What converted him from just another charming funnyman into a mega-star with real acting credentials was a pair of Oscar-winning turns: his lawyer with AIDS suing for wrongful job termination in "Philadelphia" (1993) and the wisdom-spouting man-boy of "Forrest Gump."
Since then, Mr. Hanks has had an almost solid string of box office hits.
That fact and his perpetual air of affable confidence make it hard to imagine that Mr. Hanks was ever a novice -- unless you're a fan of grade-C slasher films and caught Mr. Hanks in first movie role, in "He Knows You're Alone" (1981). The part is so insignificant that his character, a handsome jogger, doesn't even merit a bloody end; after his onscreen girlfriend is murdered, he just never reappears. Still, to Mr. Hanks, just being cast felt like "magic," although a less pleasant sensation followed, on Day 1 of shooting.
"I threw up," said Mr. Hanks. But his fears were soon quelled by the ho-hum reality of a film set. "The camera wasn't as big as I thought it would be, just a small, little box. I thought, 'This is it? This is being in a movie?' Then, I just stumbled around and did what I was told."
Taking direction, after all, was nothing new to Mr. Hanks. Born in Concord, Calif., he was voted best actor in his senior year at Skyline High School in Oakland and graduated to theater productions at Chabot Junior College in Hayward and a stint at the Great Lakes Shakespeare Festival in Cleveland. In his formative years, though, he was not much for following instructions, if only because there was rarely anyone issuing them.
It was 1961 when Mr. Hanks's parents divorced. Mr. Hanks's mother, Janet, kept the youngest child, James. Mr. Hanks's father, Amos, a chef, assumed responsibility for 5-year-old Tom, as well as his older siblings, Sandra and Lawrence. Shuttling his brood around Northern California, the elder Mr. Hanks found work in a variety of steak joints and what his famous son now categorizes as "union dinner houses." Each post required the same long hours, though, and his school-age children were left alone to run their own apartment-sized kingdom.
"It was an extremely fertile time; our interests truly guided us," Mr. Hanks said of a particularly idyllic two-and-a-half-year stretch in Alameda, where he vividly recalls eating every meal in front of the television set and going to bed when his father got home, at 11:30 p.m. "With all that freedom, my inspirations came almost completely through the popular culture. I knew what time it was by what was on TV. It'd be, like, after 'Leave It to Beaver,' it's going to be 'The Woody Woodpecker Show.' We never ran into trouble. We never broke laws. Just furniture. And all we did was laugh."
But it didn't last. Sporadically, his sister or brother moved back in with his mother. Twice, his father remarried, both times to women who brought their own packs of offspring and standards for discipline. These are the times Mr. Hanks resists reflecting upon, maybe because as an adult he feels it is unproductive to carry on about the turbulence and upheaval of one's youth. But those who know him say he has forgotten nothing.
"Once you get to know Tom, you see he has a dark side," said Sally Field, who was Mr. Hanks's love interest in "Punchline" and, later, his mother in "Forrest Gump." "Whether that goes back to his childhood, I don't know. But I certainly think it does. And it weighs on him. He's not a laugh-a-minute kind of guy. I mean, he can be; he's funny and quick. But he's also very intense. And it's one of the reasons he's so interesting to watch."
But try using that as a selling point when it's 1982, "Bosom Buddies" ends abruptly after 37 episodes and you're unemployed in the San Fernando Valley, the father of two infants, Colin and Elizabeth, and you're half of a crumbling marriage to the actress Samantha Lewes.
"It was tough," said Mr. Hanks, whose bread-winning abilities dwindled to unemployment checks and short-term television jobs, the most embarrassing being "Mazes and Monsters," a television movie featuring a 26-year-old Mr. Hanks as a college student who goes psycho after becoming involved in a role-playing game. "I was right back at square one. It was, 'O.K. I'm an actor, but nobody wants me.' I should have been prepared to deal with it, but I wasn't.
"The reality of it was I'd spent two years of working every moment of every day and, all of a sudden, Boom! it was gone. That's when I looked around town and thought: 'Oh, I see. The streets are littered with corpses of guys like me.' "
Not much later, Mr. Hanks landed "Splash." After divorcing, he married Ms. Wilson, his co-star in "Volunteers," an otherwise unremarkable 1985 Peace Corps comedy. At the time, Mr. Hanks was not too choosy about work. "I'd just put my head down and make every movie that came my way," he said. "I didn't know any better. Finally, you realize -- or at least I realized -- you don't have to make movies all the time. And if you're going to, they should be about something." Yeah, yeah, yeah. And John Travolta thought he was using his clout well to don a nose plug and make a cinematic statement in "Battlefield Earth." But coming from Mr. Hanks, the sentiment seemed richly adult and practical.
What he meant, he said, is that he would like to do big, well-thought-out projects that don't require too much time away from home. He has just finished co-producing (with Steven Spielberg) and directing an episode of "Band of Brothers," a 10-hour miniseries about World War II for HBO. So what next? he was asked. A return to the theater?
"Not now," he said, brushing off the idea. "I'm in my child-rearing years." He and Ms. Wilson have two sons, Chester, 10, and Truman, 4. "I was gone so much in my older kids' lives. I don't want to do it to my younger kids."
It was midafternoon when Mr. Hanks was waxing philosophical and he was sitting in a suite at Shutters on the Beach, a hotel in Santa Monica, waiting for a waiter to bring him a room-service lunch of spaghettini. There was something decidedly boyish about the way the cuffs and collar of his wrinkled white Ivy League shirt were unbuttoned and flapping. But when Mr. Hanks spoke, it was with a man's perspective.
"If life is a bell curve, that means the amount of wild successes you have will be equal to your wild failures," he said. "The odds are against my ever making as celebrated a disaster as 'Bonfire of the Vanities.' Or making another movie that'll do better than 'Forrest Gump.' I'll probably never do a movie as effective as 'Saving Private Ryan,' either. But it doesn't mean I'm not going to try. And it's totally freeing."

SECTION: Section 2A; Page 29; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1970 words

HEADLINE: HOLIDAY FILMS;
In the Coen Brothers' Off-Kilter World, The Only Certainty Is Uncertainty

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI

 BODY:
NOTHING comes with a guarantee," says a character in the Coen brothers' very first film. "I don't care if you're pope of Rome, president of the United States, man of the year, something can always go wrong."
That observation could well be taken as one of the signature themes of that 1984 film, "Blood Simple," and every Coen brothers movie since, from "Raising Arizona" (1987) through "Barton Fink" (1991) and "The Hudsucker Proxy" (1994) and now, "O Brother, Where Art Thou?" (which opens Dec. 22). In the off-kilter world of the Coens, the perfect crime inevitably goes awry; the peaceful, humdrum life falls prey to chaos; the carefully plotted scheme unravels. This uncertainty principle is not only the engine that generates comedy and suspense in the brothers' films; it's also the cornerstone of their quirky vision of a world resistant to human will. Indeed, the brothers are artists who manage to combine the knockabout anarchy of Mack Sennett's comedies with the visual incongruities of Magritte, making the ordinary seem surreal and the surreal seem oddly banal, while limning a screwball cosmos in which expectations are routinely subverted and existential banana peels bedevil murderers and mailroom clerks alike. 
 In "Raising Arizona," an ex-con marries a pretty cop and determines to go straight, only to find himself stealing a baby to complete their all-American life. In "Fargo" (1996), a none-too-bright car salesman tries to stage the kidnapping of his wife in order to get his father-in-law to fork over some money but quickly loses control of his criminal hirelings, who begin leaving a trail of dead bodies behind them. And in "The Big Lebowski" (1998), thugs burst into the wrong man's house, ruin his favorite rug and drag him willy-nilly into a messy adventure involving a conniving tycoon, his equally conniving daughter and a group of pancake-eating nihilists armed with a man-threatening marmot.
Equally antic and improbable events animate "O Brother," which recounts the story of one Ulysses Everett McGill, a good-looking Southerner played by George Clooney, who has been sentenced to hard labor on a chain gang for practicing law without a license. Everett wants to escape and return home to his wife, Penny (Holly Hunter), before she can divorce him and marry one of her suitors, so he stages a breakout along with his two comrades in chains, Delmar (Tim Blake Nelson) and Pete (John Turturro, in his fourth role for the Coens). For the three cons, evading the law turns out to be the least of their problems as they run afoul of a series of menacing strangers, including a malicious one-eyed Bible salesman, a trio of seductive women and a lynch mob.
Everett is another of the Coens' common-man heroes, along with Jerry Lundegaard (William H. Macy), the perpetually put-upon car salesman in "Fargo"; Dude, the slovenly, middle-aged hippie played by Jeff Bridges in "Lebowski"; and Norville Barnes (Tim Robbins), the gee-whiz rube who invents the hula hoop in "Hudsucker." They're all slightly larcenous versions of Capra's little men -- "losers or lunkheads," as Joel Coen once put it -- who are willing to bend the law in pursuit of their version of the American dream; they're outlaws or naifs pitted against the fat-cat exemplars of the status quo (who are nearly always represented in the Coens' movies by fat men in expensive suits).
The brothers -- who write their screenplays together, with Joel, 45, directing and Ethan, 43, producing -- invite us to laugh at Everett's vanity and pretensions. An avid user of Dapper Dan hair pomade, he's constantly preening and posing, and like Hi (Nicolas Cage) in "Raising Arizona," he's got a highfalutin way of speaking, using big words where little ones would do. Still, the Coens have an abiding affection for their bumbling heroes, goading us to identify with their foibles and frustrations. Everett is no exception: we're made to see that beneath his swagger and scheming, he's really a romantic at heart, whose one goal is to win back the heart of his wife and their seven daughters.
While the Coens have frequently been described as cynics, satirists and chilly post-modern auteurs and their work has been compared with that of Stanley Kubrick, another director obsessed with the notion that "if something can go wrong, it will," their vision is considerably more humane. Beneath the edgy humor and showy set pieces in the Coens' work (the tommy-gun shootout to the strains of "Danny Boy" in "Miller's Crossing"; the vertiginous tracking shot down a bathroom drain in "Barton Fink"), there's plenty of old-fashioned sentiment to be found -- a quality masked by the brothers' refusal to attach easily explicated endings or easily deciphered morals to their films.
The conclusion of "Raising Arizona" -- in which the hero fantasizes about a Christmas-card-perfect future shared with a bevy of loving children and grandchildren -- can be read either as an ironic comment on the laughable gap between his dreams and means, or as the faintly sugared expression of a heartfelt dream of domestic bliss. Similarly, the end of "Fargo" -- in which its heroine, a very pregnant cop who has just solved a grisly crime, settles into bed with her doting husband -- can be read either as a tongue-in-cheek depiction of corny, naive goodness or as a touching portrait of a pair of decent folk, buffeted but unscathed by the calamity and vice around them.
In "O Brother," Everett's two chain-gang pals, Delmar and Pete, also radiate an offbeat sweetness. They're the latest additions to a collection of grotesques as vivid as any created by Flannery O'Connor or Carson McCullers -- a gallery that includes such memorable weirdos as Walter, the Vietnam-obsessed veteran (John Goodman, another Coen regular) in "Lebowski," and the screwy, stressed out gun-for-hire played by Steve Buscemi in "Fargo." The two cons in "O Brother," however, turn out to be harmless nuts, hillbillies with hidden hearts of gold. Delmar's dream is to one day buy back his family's farm; Pete's is to open a restaurant and work as the maitre d', a job that would enable him to wear a bow tie every day.
Though the parallels are often clumsy and gratuitous, it's clear that "O Brother" is loosely based on the "Odyssey" in much the same way that "The Big Lebowski" was loosely based on Raymond Chandler's novels. In both cases, the Coen brothers have simply used the original as a framework for a picaresque series of adventures -- the first set in Mississippi of the 1930's, the second in a 1990's Los Angeles nostalgic for the 60's. As a result, these movies tend to feel like slapdash shaggy dog tales, especially when compared with such economical masterworks as "Fargo" and "Blood Simple." Structurally, they're little more than a series of allusion-filled episodes, lobbed at the hero as obstacles to his goal, and they lack the fierce, oddball storytelling of the Coens' best work.
Fluent in the post-modernist vocabulary of recycling, the Coens are also adept, like Billy Wilder, at reinventing classic genres. Their tightly constructed murder mystery, "Blood Simple," drew on Grade B horror movies and the hard-boiled work of James M. Cain, as well as the moody cinematography of the films of Hitchcock and Orson Welles. And "The Hudsucker Proxy," their big-budget fable of corporate greed, uneasily combined tropes from the movies of Capra and Sturges. Sly visual allusions to "The Wizard of Oz" pop up in such disparate works as "Hudsucker" and "O Brother," while slapstick techniques lifted from the Keystone Kops and Chuck Jones cartoons help fuel the manic comedy of "Raising Arizona."
It would be a mistake, however, to suggest that the Coens have simply been young magpies, bent on sending up earlier artists. Their borrowings, after all, are used in the service of a voice that is unmistakably the Coens' own. It's a voice that owes equal debts to comic books, supermarket tabloids and old movies, a voice built around dichotomies and juxtapositions, moving back and forth between comedy and violence, cynicism and sentiment to build narrative tension and create a sense of displacement.
THERE'S something heightened and larger than life about the world the Coens' characters inhabit. The landscape Everett and his pals traverse in "Brother" is ostensibly Depression-era Mississippi, but it's a fable-like version of the South, where Faulknerian yokels rub shoulders with American folk icons like the gangster Baby Face Nelson.
By setting so many of their dozen movies in bygone decades, the Coens are able to achieve a measure of distance from their subject matter, creating a stylized look and sound that reflects their playful vision. In the less successful movies, the stylization feels arbitrary and self-conscious and fails to mesh with the story. The glossy, magisterial New York depicted in "Hudsucker" with operatic sets and tricky special-effects shots has more to do with production values than with the plot about a small-town hick who rises to become head of a corporation. And in "Miller's Crossing" (1990), a willfully somber look, indebted to "The Godfather" and 1930's gangster pictures, does little to illuminate a needlessly complicated yarn that lifts moods and motifs from the work of Dashiell Hammett to no emotional purpose.
In their best work, however, the Coens conjure up mythologized places that feel vaguely recognizable and alarmingly peculiar at the same time: a noirish, gothicized Texas in "Blood Simple," a Kafkaesque Los Angeles in "Barton Fink," and in "Fargo" a whited-out Minnesota, presided over by the legendary figure of Paul Bunyan. In these movies, the audience is lured into dream scapes where the colors are a little brighter or a little darker than usual, where stark landscapes and wide-angled shots remind us that we're not in Kansas anymore. More often than not, our sense of disorientation is amplified by memorably bizarre images: a human leg sticking up from a woodchipper in "Fargo," a man being buried alive in "Blood Simple," a neatly wrapped box (possibly containing a woman's head) materializing in a hotel room in "Barton Fink."
In many of the brothers' movies, meticulously rendered dream sequences are used to help define who the central characters are. In "Lebowski," the pothead hero imagines himself as the star of a trippy Busby Berkeley musical, playing the part of a bowling ball, surrounded by Carmen Mirandaesque women dressed as bowling pins. And in "Raising Arizona," the hero imagines himself pursued by "the lone biker of the apocalypse," a biker from hell who likes to lob grenades at unsuspecting people and rabbits. If these fantasies reveal a lot about the mindset of the Coens' heroes, then the surreal happenings in "Barton Fink" -- in which a would-be screenwriter suffering from writer's block finds himself implicated in the murder of a beautiful woman -- could well be read as a kind of metaphor for a psychological journey taking place within the hero's own mind.
The journeys undertaken by the Coens' characters -- both the emotional and the literal ones -- don't follow the usual trajectories from innocence to wisdom, shame to redemption, ignorance to self-knowledge. Not surprisingly, they're more ambiguous than that, and even Everett's road trip -- toward home and hearth, as the "Odyssey" model dictates -- takes some unexpected turns and detours, as he wends his way through the Mississippi countryside. For the Coen brothers, the long strange journeys of their heroes not only give them a showcase for their love of character and incident, but also provide them with the perfect vehicle for laying out their dyspeptic yet affectionate vision of America as a place where everything is possible and anything can happen -- and usually does.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
In Windsor and Bloomfield, an Office Park Grows

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
IN the mid-1980's, when bulldozers first moved onto land in Windsor that was to become part of the Griffin Center office park, the park's 600 acres were largely tobacco fields, stands of hardwood and a few dirt roads. Today, Griffin Center is nearing 2 million square feet of office space, including one of its most ambitious projects ever, a 165,000-square-foot building for a high-technology tenant, JDS Uniphase.
"The JDS project is demonstrating our ability to build to a tenant's need," said Martha Collier, vice president of Griffin Land and Nurseries, the office park's developer. "It's a very complex job on a very tight schedule." 
 Griffin Land and Nurseries, a landscape nursery and real estate development business, is also working with Windsor, a town of 27,000 about six miles north of Hartford, on a proposal for a 6,500-seat outdoor amphitheater at Griffin Center that would be home to summer concerts by the Hartford Symphony Orchestra. Most events would take place after regular business hours or on weekends, so the center's vast parking lots would be available for concertgoers.
Frederick M. Danziger, the president of Griffin Land and Nurseries, said that the mostly single-story office buildings at the center house insurance, software and engineering companies, law firms and some light manufacturing companies. Mr. Danziger said that he had long envisioned some retail use at the northern end of the property and that now that traffic through the center was becoming quite heavy, there has been some interest from grocery chains.
"It's been going very well for a long time now, but it really seems to be picking up steam lately," he said.
R. Leon Churchill Jr., Windsor's town manager, said that the office park had been "a major benefit to the town, both in the taxes they pay and the prestige it brings having that kind of Class A office space."
Mario D. Zavarella, the town planner, said that from the start Griffin had worked closely with the town and had routinely accommodated town requests regarding development. "The transportation impact is what we were most concerned about, for people to get back and forth to their jobs, and to bring freight in and out of there, but it's been very well planned and laid out, and the infrastructure seems to be holding up well," Mr. Zavarella said.
He said that Griffin Center had used a variety of building styles and the naturally rolling landscape to make sure that the office park did not end up looking like a line of brick boxes.
About 130 acres of Griffin Center spills over into the neighboring town of Bloomfield, whose economic development director, Shyama Jaipershad, also praised the quality of construction.
Robert F. Carroll, a board member of the Windsor Chamber of Commerce, said that Griffin Center had many features that made it a good place to work, among them a restaurant, walking paths, duck ponds and exercise areas. And, Mr. Carroll said, it also benefits businesses outside the park.
"It creates a lot of new traffic for the smaller businesses in town, and the potential for some new business," he said. "As a C.P.A., I've got new customers from a number of those offices who would never have shown up here unless they were new in town. People only change C.P.A.'s because the old one made a mistake, or they moved."
Griffin Land & Nurseries started doing business in north central Connecticut as a subsidiary of the Culbro Corporation, a real estate and tobacco company, and has since become an independent publicly traded company. Mr. Danziger, who was a lawyer for the project when it was just beginning, said it would have been hard to envision it becoming as large as it is.
He said the property had a number of advantages. It is within a few miles of Interstate 91, the major north-south artery in Connecticut. Bradley International Airport is only about five miles away, and a rail line that is still active runs out of Hartford and terminates at Griffin Center. In addition, the sandy soil and flat land of the Connecticut River valley make it ideal for development, because it is well drained and there are no geographic obstacles.
He said his preference was to develop buildings for leasing rather than selling land in the park. "We do, and we will, sell the land, but we'd much rather develop ourselves," he said. About a third of the land that has been developed so far has been sold, Ms. Collier said.
THERE has been low turnover in the Griffin buildings -- Ms. Collier said she expected it would involve perhaps 40,000 square feet next year.
So far, on the Windsor portion of the center, the company has constructed 10 buildings, totaling about 1 million square feet, most of it for offices; 15 buildings for research and development and light industrial use, also totaling about 1 million square feet, have been built on the Bloomfield side, the largest a 400,000-square-foot warehouse now used by Home Depot.
One new 40,000-square-foot office building is going up in Bloomfield; Griffin has a permit for an additional 50,000 square feet there, leaving room for perhaps 25,000 square feet more before that portion of the park is filled.
"The new building was supposed to be for a single tenant, but now they only want half of it," Ms. Collier said. "We haven't even begun marketing the rest of the space, and we've already had two proposals come in for it." She declined to identify the potential tenant, whose lease has not yet been signed, or to discuss leasing rates.
On the Windsor side, the largest project under way is the construction of 165,000 square feet for JDS Uniphase, which designs and manufactures fiber-optic telecommunications components. JDS already occupies three buildings in Griffin Center, and has been growing rapidly. It has an option for up to 300,000 square feet of additional space in two adjacent buildings on a 16-acre parcel.
Kevin C. Cubberly, Griffin's vice president for construction, said the new building would have special features such as floors that will not hold a static charge, high-efficiency filtration and humidity control in the ventilation system, and windows that will not let in infrared and ultraviolet rays, which could damage equipment. He said that part of the building would be ready for occupancy in February, the rest by June.
Griffin officials and the town are working jointly on the proposal for the amphitheater, which would be built near some of the original offices on the site, overlooking a large pond. The town would put up $300,000 to cover construction costs, and the amphitheater would be operated by a private nonprofit foundation created especially to run it. The Town Council may vote on the appropriation as early as December.
"Based on the support I've heard for it around town, I would say it has a pretty good chance," Mayor Mary B. Hogan said. "About 25,000 people drive into town on a daily basis for work, and a good portion of them come right into that area. We want to develop things that would convince people to stay after they get out of work."
The town has a long tradition of activity on its green in the town center, but only up to 1,000 people can be accommodated there. Mayor Hogan said the hope is that the amphitheater would play host to community theater, a local ballet troupe, bands, opera, and a summer concert series by the Hartford Symphony Orchestra.
Charles H. Owens, executive director of the Hartford Symphony, said he was looking forward to the possibility of performing in the amphitheater. For the last five years the orchestra has had an outdoor summer concert series in Simsbury, Mr. Owens said, and the series would be moved to Windsor.
"Windsor has a remarkably diverse population," he said, "both living and working there, and Griffin Center a built-in corporate base, which we would hope will generate some support."
Griffin officials said that based on lease inquiries they have received, the office park would likely grow to about 2.5 million square feet over the next three or four years, and that the park would reach capacity when it hit 3 million square feet a few years later.
Mr. Danziger said he hoped that JDS would help Griffin become a magnet for high technology. "We'd like to have Griffin be the first place that comes to mind when someone is thinking about this kind of development," he said.

SECTION: Section 11; Page 5; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1792 words

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/New Haven;
Capitalizing on an Urbane Atmosphere

BYLINE: By LISA PREVOST

 BODY:
JOSIAH B. VENTER does not remember exactly what year it was, but he will never forget the moment. Strolling past Sprague Memorial Hall at Yale University one day, Mr. Venter heard a whirl of jazz notes drifting from the auditorium. He poked his head into the doorway only to discover Duke Ellington himself leading a music seminar for some Yale grad students. Mr. Venter stole upstairs to the balcony, took a seat and treated himself to an unexpected afternoon with a jazz giant.
Mr. Ellington has long since passed on, but Mr. Venter, 55, still tells that story to illustrate why he feels so passionate about life in New Haven. An investment manager for Ingalls & Snyder in Manhattan, Mr. Venter endures a two-and-a-half hour commute so he can stay in New Haven, the city he adopted back in the 70's. "I find it to be a very diversified and interesting community, particularly intellectually," said Mr. Venter, who lives near Edgerton Park, north of downtown in the fashionable East Rock corridor. 
 And he has learned to incorporate his commuting time into his workday by doing all his work-related reading between stops. "I've probably come up with some of my best investment ideas on the train," he said. "No phone calls, no interruptions."
New Haven is the next best thing to New York for many people who cannot afford Manhattan prices but favor an urbane atmosphere. As the home of four institutions of higher education -- Yale being the most prominent in the city center -- New Haven offers some of the finest museums, theater performances and overall selection of cultural opportunities in Connecticut.
But over the last decade, community leaders have struggled mightily to convince outsiders that New Haven is a worthwhile investment. An old industrial center that is still struggling to remake itself, New Haven is a poor city on average, as evidenced by the abandoned and neglected houses that scar some neighborhoods. The city's real estate market, which hit the skids in the late 80's, has only recently recovered from a serious glut of properties.
"New Haven had some serious price depreciation due to overbuilding of condos and overspeculation in multifamily housing," said Gregory Scott, president of the Beazley Company Realtors and of the Greater New Haven Association of Realtors. "But now, all of the condo market has been absorbed, with no new development coming on. And multifamily housing has come back in favor as owner-occupied housing, which has helped to stabilize neighborhoods."
The combination of local revitalization initiatives and a strong economy has revived interest in New Haven in the last couple of years. Yale, after years of maintaining a lofty detachment from city concerns, has assumed a greater responsibility for shoring up the neighborhoods that surround its campus. A Yale homebuyers' program offers incentives to faculty members and other employees to purchase homes in designated areas of the city. More important still is Yale's new willingness to link its biotech researchers with commercial interests, thereby stimulating $800 million in private investment in New Haven in the past 18 months.
"Right now, there's a conscious awareness of the competitive advantages in our economy," said Mayor John DeStefano Jr., who is serving his fourth term in office. "They flow out of Yale, and particularly the school of medicine at Yale, which is a powerful engine for biomedical start-ups."
REAL estate prices are beginning to reflect this newfound confidence, particularly in the East Rock corridor, neighborhoods convenient to Yale and the downtown area. Demand for rentals is also rising in the downtown area. Last year, a city-commissioned study of the downtown housing market reported occupancy rates of at least 95 percent at most rental properties in or near downtown. Monthly rents range from about $400 for studios to more than $1,800 a month for three- or four-bedroom apartments.
Lyn Caliendo was pleasantly surprised to discover this year just how far the market had come after her neighbor's three-bedroom town house on Orange Street in the East Rock corridor sold for $250,000. That price was $100,000 more than Ms. Caliendo paid less than three years ago for a similar town house in the same complex.
Ms. Caliendo reluctantly moved to New Haven from Oceanside, N.Y., in 1989. But after her divorce in 1997, she chose to stay in New Haven rather than move closer to New York City, where she works as a development director for the New York Junior Tennis League. New Haven's relatively manageable size has made it easy for her to get to know people, she said. And many of the people she has met through her volunteer work for Congresswoman Rosa DeLauro, the Anti-Defamation League and Meals on Wheels are now familiar faces at the fine Italian groceries, delicatessens and restaurants she frequents on Orange Street.
Orange Street's Old World flair is also characteristic of Wooster Square, an historic park surrounded by flowering cherry trees and stately brick homes built by the industrialists who made New Haven a manufacturing center for hardware, rifles and carriages throughout the 19th and early 20th centuries. Once predominantly Italian-American, the neighborhood is still home to a number of Italian restaurants, including two renowned pizza shops, Frank Pepe Pizzeria Napoletana and Sally's Apizza, which maintain a friendly rivalry for best pizza status in a city that claims to have introduced pizza to the United States.
New Haven's most exclusive neighborhoods include the St. Ronan Street-Prospect Hill area in East Rock, and Westville, home of United States Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, the Democratic vice presidential nominee. Prices have risen considerably in these areas in the last couple of years, and inventory is extremely low. Only four properties were considered active listings in the East Rock corridor in mid-October, according to Julia Gelbart, a sales associate with the H. Pearce Company.
"On what is considered the best block on Livingston Street -- the block facing East Rock Park -- three houses sold last summer in the $700,000 range," she said.
The St. Ronan-Prospect Hill area is given added prominence by the presence of Albertus Magnus College and Yale Divinity School. Houses tend to be large and architecturally distinct. Neighbors often congregate at Edgerton Park, a 22-acre gardenlike retreat that features walking trails, stables for the city's mounted police and summertime performances of Shakespeare.
Broad lawns and a mix of ranches, multifamilies and elegant older homes give Westville a more suburban feel. Westville is the preferred neighborhood for many Yale-New Haven Hospital physicians, said Louise Tatro, a sales associate with the Beazley Company. Sales prices in Westville this year have ranged from $89,900 to $369,000, though larger properties generally sell in the $400,000 to $500,000 range, Ms. Tatro said.
The Beaver Hills neighborhood, adjacent to the campus of Southern Connecticut State University, is growing in popularity. Developed in the early 20th century, Beaver Hills homes are generally priced from $180,000 to $300,000, though smaller houses can be had for under $100,000. "There are some fine homes here that just need work," Ms. Gelbart said.
The city's 48 public schools face the usual challenges associated with high-poverty populations. But new accountability and remediation measures within the schools are beginning to help overall scores on the state's standardized tests, according to Dr. Eleanor Osborne, assistant superintendent of curriculum and instruction.
In 1999, the New Haven school district was the first in the state to implement mandatory summer school for third-graders not reading at grade level. Students who fail to improve by summer's end must repeat third grade. Last summer, "after five weeks of intensive instruction, 85 percent of our kids in summer school demonstrated enough improvement to move on to the next grade," Dr. Osborne said. The policy was extended to fifth graders this year.
A Saturday academy is open to all students who need extra help on their reading, writing and math skills. A homework hotline provides after-school help by phone.
The district has 15 magnet schools, six of which are interdistrict schools attracting some 800 students from surrounding suburbs. Admission can be quite competitive at some of the most popular magnets, which include an aquaculture school, arts-infused high school and elementary school, and a career-focused high school.
AVERAGE SAT scores last year were 416 for verbal, and 399 for math; state averages were 508 for verbal and 509 for math. Eighty-one percent of the 724 graduating seniors in eight high schools planned to go on to college.
Among the many private schools in Greater New Haven is Hopkins, in the Westville area. Hopkins is a co-ed day school serving about 640 students in grades 7 to 12. Tuition is $17,200.
Shopping in New Haven is somewhat limited, as the city's downtown retail center has struggled to compete with regional malls and discount stores. Just last month, the 113-year-old Yale Co-op closed its doors in the ailing Chapel Square Mall. Mayor DeStefano has thrown his administration's support behind a controversial plan by New England Development of Newton, Mass., and the Fusco Corporation of New Haven to build a $500 million, 1.2 million-square-foot mall at Long Wharf on New Haven Harbor. That project has been stalled by lawsuits filed by Westfield America, which owns three malls in the New Haven area.
New Haven's cultural and entertainment options are plentiful and varied, ranging from the Pilot Pen women's tennis tournament to the Long Wharf Theater to the legendary rock club, Toad's Place.
The annual International Festival of Arts and Ideas is a showcase for the city, having grown into a 17-day summer extravaganza that this year attracted 165,000 people, more than half of whom were from outside of New Haven and its suburbs, according to festival officials. The Metropolitan Opera's outdoor performance of "Madama Butterfly" on the historic New Haven Green was this year's high point. But the largest audience-grabber was a performance by Kool and the Gang -- an estimated 33,000 people swarmed the green for that show.
Paul Collard, the festival's director, credits the festival with helping to improve the local real estate market by raising the city's profile. It wasn't a difficult task, he observed, given that New Haven had an arts infrastructure already in place. "I had to make New Haven work," he added. "When I arrived in 1997, I was quoted in the papers saying, 'It should be as easy as turning on a light.' And it has been."

CODES: Area, 203; ZIPs, 06501 through 06511, 06513, 06515, 06519 through 06521 and 06530 through 06536.
THE KING KILLERS: Founded in 1638 by the Rev. John Davenport and 500 fellow Puritans, New Haven began as a religious refuge. But in the 1660's, the colony also served as a political refuge for two English judges wanted by King Charles II. In 1649, the king's father, King Charles I, had been dethroned, convicted of treason by the High Court of Justice and beheaded. Among the 59 men who signed the king's death warrant were Col. Edward Whalley and his son-in-law, William Goffe. The two regicide judges fled to Boston after Charles II took the throne but eventually moved into Davenport's home in New Haven. When officers for the king came looking for the regicides in 1661, the men were hidden in a cave atop West Rock in New Haven. They stayed in hiding, moving from one place to another, for the next three years, returning to the cave for a second stay in 1664. They were never caught. Their hideout, now known as Judges' Cave, can be visited at West Rock Ridge State Park, off Wintergreen Avenue.

HEADLINE: Few Lobsters, and Now, Fewer Lobstermen

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY

 BODY:
BOB SPONG, 60, has been a lobsterman on Long Island Sound all his life. But last March, when he thought the lobster population might never recover, he decided to get what he calls "the first real job" he has ever held. So now he drives a forklift at the Home Depot store in Commack, N.Y. on the lobster shift -- what else? -- from 10 p.m. to 6:30 a.m.
"The idea was then I could still go fishing during the day," Mr. Spong said. He kept his 1,000 lobster traps in the water through the spring. But instead of hauling in 900 lobsters a day, as he and other lobstermen had when the sound was flush, he rarely brought in more than 40 a day, barely enough to pay for the trip. 
 "I worried about it for months, but I finally made the decision to take the traps out," Mr. Spong said. "There just wasn't enough signs to stay in." He still goes out on his 42-foot boat about once a week to fish for blackfish, but he doesn't expect to make much money from that. He does it just to be out on the water.
Today, of the 20 lobstermen who used to fish out of Northport, N.Y., Mr. Spong's home port, only five or six are still fishing for lobster regularly, and many of them have also taken part-time jobs to help make ends meet. Some 7,000 lobster traps sit in neat piles at the foot of the old town dump in Huntington, N.Y., where town officials have allowed lobstermen to store their unused gear. Mr. Spong checks on his traps every now and then and said that the number of fishermen bringing in their equipment grows each week.
Further west in the Sound, in Glen Cove, N.Y. to the south and Greenwich to the north, there are virtually no lobsters left and consequently no fishermen either. The situation steadily improves heading eastward, so that at the easternmost tip of the North Fork of Long Island, fishermen are reporting that things appear almost normal, state officials said.
Lobstermen and state officials said the good news is that lobsters do not appear to be dying off, as they had been a year ago, but the bad news is that there are many fewer lobsters being caught and virtually no signs of lobsters in the western Sound.
Officials in New York and Connecticut do not have statistics showing how hard the lobster industry was hit last year or how the industry is faring now. But officials said that informal surveys of lobsterman suggest that the lobster haul in the central part of the Sound is still off by more than 50 percent and down by about 30 percent as far east as Mattituck, N.Y.
"It's a stark difference from the way it had been prior to the die-off when there were record-high harvests," said Gordon C. Colvin, the director of marine resources for the New York State Department of Economic Conservation.
According to the latest figures available from the National Marine Fisheries Service, 1998 was the peak year in Connecticut, with 3.7 million pounds caught, worth $12.1 million. Preliminary figures from Connecticut officials show that in 1999, the haul dropped to 2.5 million pounds, worth about $9.2 million.
In New York, the industry hit a peak in 1996, with 9.4 million pounds caught, worth nearly $33 million, and stayed strong through 1998, with 8.5 million pounds worth $29.8 million.
"The only thing that's encouraging is that we have not heard that they're dying in the central sound this fall, and most lobsters seem to be healthy," Mr. Colvin said. "But it's difficult to forecast what might happen, especially in the western sound where there are no young lobsters at all."
Lobstermen and officials agreed that given the current circumstances, it will take at least four to five years -- the time it takes for young lobsters to grow to one-pound size, the minimum for legal harvesting -- for the lobster industry in Long Island Sound to recover.
But if what happened to the scallop industry in Peconic Bay on Long Island is any indication, the lobstermen have little to look forward to. The scallops there were decimated in 1985 when a sudden bloom of algae known as brown tide starved and killed them. The industry has yet to recover fully. Scallops rebounded briefly in 1994, but another bloom of brown tide hit the following year. And despite years of surveys and research, officials have been unable to determine what causes brown tide to appear or how to control it.
It's unclear how many fewer lobster fishermen there are actually fishing this year. The number of licenses issued is down by 20 percent in New York, from 746 in 1999 to only 587 this year, and down by 8 percent in Connecticut, from 419 in 1999 to 386 this year. But officials in both states suspect that many fishermen have kept their licenses but are not actively fishing.
"The people who have stayed seem to be fishing less gear," said Eric M. Smith, the assistant director of marine fisheries for the Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection. "The number of lobster pots out there has been down." Officials estimated there were more than 500,000 lobster traps in the sound last year, but will not know how many there are this year until fisherman submit their tallies at the end of the year.
Lobstermen are very close-mouthed about how much they make. But when Mr. Spong and his friends reminisce about the days of good lobstering, they talk about bringing in between 900 and 1,500 pounds in one day, which means roughly $3,000 to $5,000 in revenue. In the years of plentiful harvests, the summer high season would often run more than two months.
"It was a tough but nice way to earn a living," said Larry Eberhardt, a good friend of Mr. Spong's who now also works at Home Depot. He said the months of April and May would be busy, followed by a slow June when lobsters shed their shells, and then followed again by another busy two to three months.
Marcel Cormier, one of the few fishermen still tending lobster traps out of Northport, estimated that his lobstering income this year will drop by 90 percent. He said that there have been days when he has checked 400 of his 1,000 traps, only to come back with 30 lobsters. The only way for a lobsterman to survive this year, he said, is "to have a wife with a good job."
Faced with last year's catastrophic die-off, in the western sound, last summer the federal government approved $3.6 million in direct aid to lobstermen in New York and another $3.6 million for Connecticut, but the money has yet to be distributed. Mr. Spong estimated that each lobsterman's share would be only $2,000 to $3,000. "Why take it?" he said. "It's not enough to make a difference, and besides we never took help from anybody before."
Officials from both states also are preparing to divide up $6.6 million in federal research dollars to study causes of the lobster deaths. A research team at the University of Connecticut found last November that a parasite had killed the lobsters but has been awaiting further financing for research to determine what might have weakened the lobsters' immune systems enough to make them susceptible to the parasite. The parasite in question is a paramoeba, a tiny, one-celled protozoa that targets the lobster's nervous system and destroys nerve tissue.
Many lobstermen have a different view. Blaming the die-off on last year's pesticide spraying to kill mosquitoes carrying the West Nile virus, about 1,100 lobsterman from Long Island Sound have filed a lawsuit against five pesticide manufacturers, seeking $125 million in damages. But scientific researchers have been skeptical of the pesticide theory, noting that while the lobster die-off peaked last fall, it began last summer, long before pesticide spraying began.
Other possible causes include last year's unusually warm water temperatures, which were generated by tropical storms that moved through the area and brought in large amounts of warm freshwater, and lobster overcrowding, which might have contributed to the epidemic.
The State University of New York at Stony Brook recently received $1 million in state money to create a pathology laboratory so lobsters will no longer have to be shipped to Connecticut, Virginia and Arizona for autopsies.
Jack Mattice, the director of New York Sea Grant, which will coordinate the research with Connecticut Sea Grant and other agencies from both states, said that because it's likely that there were multiple causes for the die-off, the federally funded research would try to cover all the possibilities. The research money also will be used to study causes for shell disease, which has struck mainly in the waters off of Montauk and Fishers Island, N.Y.. Shell disease does not kill lobsters, but leaves their shells eroded and pitted and thus unappealing for the lobster market.
But for fishermen like Mr. Spong, the fruits of the research will come too late.
"The lobsters won't be back in my lifetime," Mr. Spong said with resignation.
Mr. Spong and his friend, Mr. Eberhardt, often scour the ads in fishing magazines looking for a boat with a license for offshore lobster fishing. But those bigger, more powerful boats run between $400,000 and $500,000, significantly more than the $50,000 to $150,000 that a fisherman in the Sound spends on his boat.
"We dream," said Mr. Spong. "But we don't know if we have what it takes at this stage of the game. Off-shore fishing is a young man's game, because you're far out there and you've got to fight the sea."
