HEADLINE: Factory Is Reborn in a Once Busy Valley

BYLINE: By MELINDA TUHUS

 BODY:
IN 1983, when the Seth Thomas clock factory closed for good in the Naugatuck Valley town of Thomaston, the workers from the plant carried a bier bearing an elegant mantel clock through the streets in a mock funeral. Then they burned it -- a measure of their contempt for a company that was no longer owned by the family that gave Thomaston its name, but had been bought by a multinational conglomerate and then shut down.
The 1980's marked the de-industrialization of the Naugatuck River Valley, which had been one of the "most industrialized places on Earth", according to the Connecticut historian Jeremy Brecher. Factories were built throughout the 19th century all along the river, which provided water power and a convenient way to dispose of wastes. The valley had been the worldwide center of the brass industry, with factories like Plume & Atwood turning out brass parts for Seth Thomas timepieces. But in the last quarter of the 20th century the factories closed down, leaving thousands of workers jobless, the Naugatuck River polluted and the land on which the factories sat contaminated by toxic chemicals. 
 But now factories in the valley are being revived.
In May, an old factory started up brass production again after the hard work of many people.
In 1993, churches, unions and community groups in the Naugatuck Valley organized the Naugatuck Valley Project. The primary goal, said Mr. Brecher, was to use the techniques of community organizing to save jobs and create new ones. Working with local, state and federal government officials, the project helped create the Naugatuck Valley Brownfields Pilot in 1996. Its goal is to clean up the estimated 100 brownfields sites -- abandoned factory properties with known or suspected contaminants such as mercury, solvents, or petroleum products in the soil, or asbestos or lead-based paint on buildings -- in the valley and make them productive manufacturing or commercial sites again. The pilot serves the towns of Ansonia, Beacon Falls, Derby, Naugatuck, Oxford, Seymour, Shelton, Thomaston, Waterbury and Watertown.
The pilot has received more than $350,000 from the federal Environmental Protection Agency to do assessments on 16 sites. The agency just awarded the Pilot another $350,000 to create a revolving loan fund to actually begin cleaning up the sites.
No one keeps precise records of the number of shuttered factories in Connecticut that have reopened for manufacturing or commerce, either through a brownfields remediation program or otherwise. But Arthur Bogen, technical consultant to the Naugatuck Valley Brownfields Pilot, said there are at least 30. Some examples are the old American Thread complex in Windham, which has reopened as Windham Mills, housing several light industries; Carpenter Steel mill in Bridgeport, which now builds high-speed ferries, and the Susan Bates mill in Chester, which produced knitting needles and now has been subdivided into several manufacturing concerns.
A few months ago in Thomaston, a dozen employees at American Unibrass began producing welded brass tubing at the old Plume & Atwood factory, built in 1852. The tubing is then made into plumbing fixtures, furniture and decorative railings.
The old Plume & Atwood factory occupies more than 200,000 square feet; about a quarter of it is currently cleaned up and operational. On a recent afternoon, two visitors were able to walk through the plant and converse in normal tones, except when industrial vacuums began forcing pressurized air through the tubing to clean out any leftover brass particles; then it sounded like an airport runway. The floors were clean; the air was clean; the machinery was clean. There was no dust or oily smell.
Jay Horowitz, the owner of American Unibrass, had been leasing space in the Plume & Atwood building and recently bought it from a previous owner who had used some state funding to begin the clean-up. Mr. Horowitz said even though he got no financial incentives from Thomaston to locate there, he did it for sentimental reasons -- to bring brass production back to its roots. The raw materials are made at a plant he owns in Buffalo. He also owns a second company at another site in Thomaston, that produces smaller diameter metal tubing, mostly for musical instruments.
Mr. Horowitz said he is working with the State Department of Economic and Community Development and the Department of Environment Protection to clean up the Plume & Atwood site. It's a phased clean-up.
"I signed off on a remedial action plan," he said. "I'm personally liable for the clean-up. I wouldn't want myself or my employees breathing in dust or chemicals or anything else hazardous from legal, health or productivity points of view. It's a closed-loop system, nothing is discharged into the river. The Naugatuck has fish in it and we plan to keep it that way."
The Naugatuck Valley Project worked to get an environmental evaluation of the site and found it to be less contaminated than was earlier feared. There are no toxic materials in much of the plant, or in the soil beneath those sections. The oils and sludge under one part of the building will be encapsulated and left in place as part of the clean-up.
However, between one of the buildings and the river is a so-called hot spot where nothing will grow. The soil there is going to be further tested. Mr. Horowitz is considering donating this parcel to the town as a park if it can be cleaned up.
Rick Rice, a local insurance salesman and the chairman of the Thomaston Brownfields Committee of the Naugatuck Valley Project said the group is interested in that site.
"We would like to find a way to take that property, clean it up and turn it into a green space along the river," Mr. Rice said.
Now that factories no longer spew pollution directly into the river, and Torrington built a sophisticated sewage treatment plant upriver, the Naugatuck at Thomaston is clean enough to be used for recreation, Mr. Rice said. Mr. Rice said a canoe launch might be nice at that spot. But to make that happen the hot spot would have to be restored to a "clean" standard, which is more stringent than the industrial standard that the rest of the property must meet to be used for manufacturing.
Mr. Rice calls his committee "just a bunch of citizens who wanted to get the community involved and let them know what the risks were at the Plume & Atwood site and how it could be fixed and what would be the effects on the community -- whether water-borne, air-borne, gas or noxious fumes."
The Brownfields Pilot provided $65,000 to the Thomaston Brownfields Committee to have the Plume & Atwood site evaluated. Mr. Rice said once the final survey is complete, if Mr. Horowitz agrees with the final remediation plan, then Mr. Horowitz and the E.P.A. will sign a "covenant not to sue" which will enable him to get bank loans to clean up more of the site.
Mr. Bogen said brownfields remediation is a complicated issue.
"It takes a lot of players to make it happen," he said. "It takes motivated municipalities; it takes the pilot to provide management skills and a way to solve the problems; it takes the state and the federal government to provide money for assessments."
Mary Benedict, a retired social worker from Thomaston, agrees. She became a charter member of the Naugatuck Valley Project in 1983.
"We were the first to focus on brownfields," she said. "Our committee began focusing on Plume & Atwood in 1994. It's a slow process."
The historian Jeremy Brecher said the de-industrialization of the Valley "is part of a huge phenomenon called globalization. That process has left abandoned industrial properties in the hearts of cities. Brownfields development is not a mass solution to globalization. It's more an indication of a positive direction."

HEADLINE: After a 40-Year Layoff, a Return to the Pool

BYLINE: By DONNA CORNACHIO

 BODY:
CHARLES J. URSTADT has lived his life according to the "sink or swim" maxim -- but in his case, he's always swum.
In high school, he won the New York City High School Championships three years in a row. At Dartmouth College, where he was captain of the swim team, he was All-American for two years. 
 Then, for more than 40 years, Mr. Urstadt, a Bronxville resident, concentrated on making a name for himself in another kind of fast lane. He became known as a can-do person in the field of housing and urban renewal. As chairman of the Battery Park City Authority, he turned 100 acres of landfill into six million square feet of commercial, residential and recreational space. He was also state commissioner of housing and community renewal.
Now at 72, he has returned to competitive swimming. In August, he became world Masters champion swimmer for the 50-meter breaststroke in the 70 to 75 age group.
"Water is an element I feel comfortable in," he said simply.
During all the years he had focused on business and government, Mr. Urstadt had remained active.
"I played paddle tennis and squash, ran and swam on my own," he said. "Once you get into the habit of exercising, you miss it, you really do."
On Thanksgiving in 1998, soon after Mr. Urstadt's 70th birthday, his son-in-law, Willing Biddle, an active swimmer himself, suggested he consider Masters swimming. And Mr. Urstadt's dormant competitive swimmer's instinct was revived.
The United States Masters Swimming is an organization of 37,000 swimmers who swim competitively within their age groups. At the time, Mr. Urstadt realized he would be among the youngest in his age group. In February 1999, he entered his first race at the Westport Y.M.C.A. He quickly became aware of how much things had changed in 40 years.
"I had to get up on a platform to start," he recalled. "The last time I had raced, I had started from the side of the pool. I must have hesitated, because the starter said, 'Can I help you up, sir?' "
With his grandchildren cheering, "Go, Gramps, go!" Mr. Urstadt plunged into the water and won the 50-yard breast stroke in 39 seconds. The next race he entered he won again, and the one after that, each time shaving a second or two off his previous time.
Of the 22 Masters races he has entered since returning to competitive swimming, Mr. Urstadt has won 21. He became the National Breast Stroke Champion and All-American in both the 1999 and 2000 United States Masters Swimming competitions. In August, he won the 2000 World Masters Championship title in Munich for the 50-meter breast stroke, beating out 28 swimmers in his age group. "With 20 yards to go, I really poured it on," Mr. Urstadt said.
And how did it feel to win?
"While I'm swimming," he said, "I'm thinking about hitting the water right, about making the turns, about coordinating my arms and legs together. When I win a race, it's not so much a thrill as a sense of satisfaction."
That attitude makes Mr. Urstadt a pleasure to train, said Nick Cavataro, the swimming coach at Iona College in New Rochelle. (Mr. Urstadt also swims daily at Arrowwood Conference Center in Rye Brook.) "Charlie's got great breast stroke technique and terrific legs," Mr. Cavataro said. "More than that, he has great motivation and takes direction and works it into his stroke."
Mr. Urstadt acknowledges that his competitor's instinct has served him equally well in business as in the lap lanes.
He is chairman and chief executive officer of Urstadt Biddle Properties in Greenwich, a real estate investment trust, which owns and manages strip malls in Fairfield, Westchester and Putnam Counties. Much of the day-to-day operation of the company is delegated to Mr. Biddle, who is the chief operating officer. Though he's not considering retiring, Mr. Urstadt says he's now enjoying being able to coast.
"It's like swimming: you have to know when to sprint and when not to sprint," he said. "You learn how to conserve so you can concentrate on what's in front of you."

HEADLINE: Bronx Is in the Name. Drums Are Their Game. P.S. They're French

BYLINE: By LESLIE KANDELL

 BODY:
THE following concert program is rated PG-13: it contains 17 brawny guys with bare arms, pummeling oil drums in violent rhythms, with pickaxes. Although there is no profanity (unless it's in French) one cannot ignore the yelling, or the smashing oilcans. Onsite earplugs are available to the audience at no charge.
Here, here, what's all this? A variant palliative for aggression? A dream evening for the hearing-challenged? Intrepid listeners will have a chance to find out next Sunday when Les Tambours du Bronx, an unusual drumming group from France, muscles into Stony Brook on its first North American tour. 
 To the extent that the culture of hip-hop is about rebellion, this event is a species of hip-hop -- that is, the antithesis of the classical music concert form. If there is an expected appropriate attire, the drummers of Les Tambours don't wear it. As to performing on valuable heirloom instruments: they don't play standard instruments at all, and regularly destroy what they do play on. Quiet, a concert hall norm, is a joke. Even the Bronx reference is a joke.
The men, who no longer have to hold day jobs -- if they ever had them -- come from the outskirts of Nevers, an industrial town in central France known for repairing trains, and also as the resting place of Bernadette of Lourdes, whose body is preserved under a glass bubble, reportedly as fresh as ever. Before Les Tambours was founded in 1987, its members were friends who met to drink at a place in Nevers called the Broadway Bar. Some were students, some had jobs, some were unemployed, but none were musicians. Their little jest, as their evenings at the Broadway Bar ended, was that they were going back home to the Bronx.
According to the group's leader, Ludovic Le Mapihan (known as Map), they got their shot at performing during the city's annual festival of movie shorts.
"We wanted to make a small performance, but we were not sure what," said Map. (The telephone conversation is translated from an ad hoc mixture of French and English, representing a genuine dual effort.) "We had no money, but because Nevers is a city for train repairs, 55-gallon barrels were easy to find free."
They performed 20 minutes at the festival, got all fired up and decided to go to any nearby festival, invited or not. "We played in the street," said Map. "Presenters liked us and we began to be invited."
True to its perverse form, the all-male group, now aged 25 to 42, named its first commercial recording "Silence." It's anything but, though the label name, Naive, is more like it. The rhythms are clean, repetitive in the marching band sense, and seductive but acceptable, probably, to even to the most mannered listener. "Bombast and unity" said one reviewer. Not bad.
Nothing about their performance is gentrified. Some numbers have added clapping or whistling, while in others, oil barrel clangor is augmented by groans, howls and snorts. The recording's final number, "Etouffez la Ventoline" (a title chosen for rhythm rather than meaning) has unintelligible words that might be broadcast over a railroad station loudspeaker.
Comparing Les Tambours to Japan's Kodo Drummers, Map acknowledged the similar visceral effect, and then said: "Our rhythm is very basic. It goes directly to your body. Our instruments are different in the way we play. We smash very loud. When we finish the show, the instrument is destroyed. You can use both sides of the drum, so, two shows maximum."
The destruction factor is handled through copious supplies: "A big truck follows us, with 400 barrels from France and 4,000 sticks," he said. "We break the sticks. You cannot find the barrels outside of France -- not even in Italy or Germany. They're very thin. With thicker metal, you can hurt yourself." After trying different materials for their pickaxe mallets, they settled on beechwood, because it proved strong enough to survive a concert or two.
Since the drummers can't practice separately, they get together in what Map described as a hangar in the countryside. "We are not musicians," he said. "We play and move our arms a special way. We look for new members in the way we would look for a friend, not a drummer."
In Les Tambours' European performances, there is some interaction with the audience, which Map was not sure was happening on this tour. "We try to talk to the audience," he said, "but our English is not so good. We explain and ask what they think. We know they won't sleep."
Les Tambours du Bronx, Staller Center for the Arts, University at Stony Brook, Stony Brook, Nov. 12, 7 p.m.. 516-632-2787.

COMPANY: LES TAMBOURS DU BRONX (90%);

LENGTH: 1230 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/High Technology;
A 500,000-Sq.-Ft. Lease Brings Qwest to Yonkers

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
QWEST COMMUNICATIONS, a supplier of high-capacity telecommunications services, recently agreed to lease a vacant 500,000-square-foot distribution center here and plans to cram it with more than $100 million of computers and other equipment to play host to World Wide Web sites.
The deal encouraged officials of this onetime industrial city, who have been seeking ways to participate in the new economy in the wake of the departure of much of the manufacturing activity that once defined the city. 
 "This is the biggest real estate transaction in Westchester in many years," said John D. Spencer, the mayor of Yonkers. "And it happened without any tax abatements or incentives. They will pay full-rate taxes."
Mr. Spencer said he hoped the presence of the high-technology company would be an inducement for other Web-based businesses to locate nearby. "This is a signal from the corporate world that this is a good location to do business," he said.
Yonkers was once home to the Otis elevator division of United Technologies and numerous carpet mills that have since closed. Like many postindustrial cities in the Midwest, among them Cleveland and Detroit, the city has rediscovered its waterfront and is promoting residential development along the banks of the Hudson River and a $12.5 million waterfront park.
Phil Amicone, the deputy mayor, said construction is to begin on two towers in the waterfront area, costing $150 million to $200 million, before the end of the year. He said they would include about 300 residential units plus retail and office space. In addition, an old trolley barn in the waterfront area is to be converted to residences, and city officials are talking about speedy ferry service from the town dock to the Wall Street area.
Qwest officials emphasized the building's location, half a mile from the region's optical fiber backbone, which is along the right of way of the New York State Thruway.
They also noted that it was ready for the necessary remodeling, an important factor in a business that is developing so rapidly that the time it would take to build a new facility could cost a company an important slice of market share.
Qwest is acquiring and equipping Web hosting facilities, which it calls "cybercenters," as fast as it can. "We are in 11 sites now and we expect to do three more by the end of the year," said John V. McGuire, the company's vice president for real estate. "And we will do 10 more over the next 18 months."
Michael Harnum, the company's director of marketing, said the scramble for market share is being driven by big numbers. "Projections are that Web hosting will be an $11 billion business by 2002," he said. "A company with a 30 percent share is talking about a $3 billion-$4 billion slice of business."
He said the business is expected to grow that rapidly because many new entrants to the Internet economy are not equipped or not inclined to get into the hardware and telecommunications end of the business. "If someone has an idea for an online business, they can either execute the idea or try to become a telephone company," he said. "Most do not want to be telephone companies, and that has become a key shift in the market."
Although the building, at 555 Tuckahoe Road, was used most recently as a distribution site for Saks Fifth Avenue, it was originally built for Western Electric, the equipment manufacturing arm of the old AT&T Corporation. As a result it comes with its own electrical substation and space to install backup generators.
BECAUSE businesses operating over the Web need to be available continuously -- 24/7/365 in the industry argot -- companies in the Web hosting business are most attentive to the importance of a power supply and suspicious of the ability of a deregulated industry to supply it reliably.
"Power grids in the United States are old, patched and at capacity," Mr. McGuire said. "It is good that there is power at the site and we will expand that. This is a very big deal for us."
Although the owner of the building, Alfred Weissman, had initially hoped to develop it as a site for retail stores, Yonkers officials objected because of potential traffic congestion along Tuckahoe Road, and Mr. Weissman would have required a zoning change to do a retail development. "This area is not zoned for retail, so we said to Al, 'Find a better use for the property,' " Mr. Spencer said.
Telecommunications and Web hosting buildings basically house many machines and very few people, so the Qwest tenancy should add only a few cars to the local traffic.
Area brokers said that as a telecommunications center, the building could command annual rents well in excess of a distribution center, although perhaps not as high as retail.
"I have heard of rents in the range of $25 a square foot for these telecom centers, compared to about $10 a square foot for distribution," said Dean J. Shapiro, executive director of the Westchester-Connecticut office of Insignia/ESG, the brokerage and services company.
Mr. McGuire said one of the attractions of the Yonkers location was its proximity to Manhattan, but with much lower operating costs. Average office rents in Manhattan have soared above $55 a square foot, according to a report by Williams Real Estate, a brokerage and services company active in the Manhattan market.
Qwest recently leased space at 32 Avenue of the Americas, a former AT&T long distance headquarters that Rudin Management purchased last year and is converting into a center for multiple telecommunications companies. Mr. Harnum explained that the Manhattan site was intended for switching of calls while the Yonkers building was to be devoted to Web hosting.
Although both involve telecommunications, the company considers them different lines of business, he said.
Alan Weissman, vice president of Alfred Weissman Real Estate, which is named for his father, said Qwest has signed a 25-year lease on the building. He said the company came "out of the blue" early last summer and had agreed to a lease by July.
QWEST, he said, had some demanding requirements for the building, mainly related to preventing any danger of water damage to its delicate equipment. Among them were a new roof devoid of stacks and other penetrations, and the removal of boilers and pipes on the interior.
Qwest expects to begin operations in the building early next year.
Mr. Weissman said the length of the lease indicated Qwest's commitment to the area and said his company has had inquiries from other Internet-related operations that wanted to be near the $17-billion-a-year telecommunications giant.
Mr. Shapiro said the deal may help the city to remake its image, which has remained blue collar as the rest of Westchester has become the home of corporate headquarters and professional firms. "Yonkers has operated outside the norm for Westchester, but this could help redefine itself as high tech," he said.
City officials say they are working hard to make it a friendly place for technology companies, including cutting through the sometimes sluggish process of getting approvals.
"Qwest had a single request, and that was that it get a building permit quickly," said Mr. Amicone, the deputy mayor. "We did everything by the book, but we got it done in six days."
He said the city is prepared to extend similar treatment to other businesses.

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 2617 words

HEADLINE: Retreating to Artists' Towns

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON

 BODY:
IN Brownsville, Vt., Dick Bullard was just leaving to go home, locking up the old farmhouse he has been using for his real estate office ever since he quit the Boston banking business 24 years ago. Visitors driving down the main road had been attracted by the sign announcing the Bullard Real Estate Company, a blue and white placard with the simple word "Duck" hanging right under it.
Did the extra sign mean that Mr. Bullard, 82, was also a hunting guide? "No," he replied, with that North Country glint in his eye. "It means you should duck before you walk into the sign." 
 Like Mr. Bullard's sign, Brownsville offers a quirky welcome. It's a mixture of the down home -- there's the famous (at least as far as neighboring Windsor) baked bean suppers held at the Grange hall, not to mention the dances at the town hall -- and the artistic. Brownsville is one of the smaller villages that surround Cornish, only a few minutes across the New Hampshire border, a scenic environment that has drawn artists since Maxfield Parrish and Augustus Saint-Gaudens settled here before the turn of the century.
This is a part of New England that's off the predictable charm-and-skiing track, the track that leads to Stowe and to Woodstock, which isn't exactly a skiing village but, ever since the Rockefellers discovered it, is certainly high on charm -- and real estate prices.
To find appealing second homes in all price ranges -- but with an eye to a bargain -- the autumn and winter vacation househunter might head to the towns in Vermont, New Hampshire and Connecticut that artists have long been attracted to. The scenery can't be topped, and, in some cases at least, there are still bargains to be found. And while prices here are climbing, according to George Ballantyne, who oversees the Northeast for Sotheby's International Realty, they have a long way to go before they reach the levels found on such celebrity-strewn islands as Nantucket and Mount Desert in Maine.
In Weathersfield, Vt., for instance, a small shingled 1910 hunting lodge at the end of a long dirt road just went under contract for close to its $198,000 asking price -- and 82 acres along with it.
An hour to the southeast in Peterborough, N.H., a village full of shops with names like The Friend of a Gardener, there are a handful of 18th and 19th century houses for sale for under $100,000. Not far away, another house, considerably higher ($539,000), comes with walls in the master bedroom that were stenciled by Moses Eaton, an itinerant artist who applied his craft to New England homes in the early part of the 19th century.
And the bustling village streets are, increasingly, what the house-hunting city-dweller is seeking. More and more often, local real estate agents say, buyers looking for weekend retreats are deciding they want to live in plain sight: on Main Street or along a village green.
Real estate brokers say that in the past, city people -- be they from Manhattan or Mamaroneck -- usually wanted a weekend house that was totally isolated, on a dirt road in the middle of nowhere, full of blessed relief from the incessant traffic noise and jostling of metropolitan thoroughfares.
Four years ago, Heather Peterson, president of The Petersons Real Estate, told a reporter that she had a hard time selling a village house to a New Yorker. "Some don't mind buying a stately Colonial on a village green," she said, "but only if every house on the green is a stately Colonial." In Vermont and New Hampshire, she said then, "We have rich people and poor people and a lot of times, especially in town, they live right next to each other."
But a few weeks ago, she told a reporter returning to Peterborough that things had changed -- and brokers in several parts of New England agreed. While the majority of those seeking vacation homes still seek the uber-rural, there is a growing faction that likes "walking to the post office, to shops, to the general store," she said.
Besides the charm of village living, there may be other, more pragmatic, reasons for the trend.
"Twenty years ago, we were all in our 20's and 30's, and we wanted the rural adventure," said Joseph L. Carini, of Wheeler & Taylor Real Estate in the Berkshires town of Great Barrington, Mass. "Now we're in our 50's, and we want to be closer to shops and galleries -- and hospitals."
FOR house prospectors interested in the arts, of course, nothing is artsier than the Berkshires and the Hamptons, where Eric Fischl, David Salle and Julian Schnabel still own homes and where old timers still remember Jackson Pollock and Willem de Kooning. But, especially in the Hamptons, there is not a lot of room left for struggling sculptors or painters. There are currently two Main Street Colonial-era houses in East Hampton for sale: one for $4 million and one for $2.9 million. An attractive bungalow south of the Montauk Highway in Bridgehampton just went for $775,000, with three people bidding.
In the Berkshires, realtors are offering the former Norman Rockwell Museum, a hipped roof, two-chimney, 14-room mansion in the center of Stockbridge for $875,000. (The new Rockwell museum opened at another site in Stockbridge in 1993.)
In nearby Lenox, within walking distance of Tanglewood, is a sprawling Victorian farmhouse with six bedrooms and three and a half baths as well as a duck pond, small stable and a two-bedroom guest cottage. The price? A cool $1.15 million; not quite East Hampton, but still needing some substantial sales of one's artwork.
So what about some bargains, not only for struggling artists, but for others seeking weekend retreats?
There are still remnants of old artists' colonies in the little towns like Brownsville (population 900) that are clustered around Cornish, N.H., which is just across the state line and home to the Saint-Gaudens Museum (and J. D. Salinger.) "We're not like Woodstock," said Mr. Bullard, the realtor, "where everything's a million dollars."
"The town used to be full of dairy farms, but now it's all horse farms," he said. "The dairy business is a lousy business. You can't make money milking cows."
You can't make money raising horses, either, he added. "It's just a way of spending the money your grandfather made. It's just a fun thing for the crowd coming up here now."
Mr. Bullard got into his Jeep Cherokee and took off for a couple of places for sale on Bible Hill Road, the most expensive street in town. (And incidentally, where he lives himself.) The road is distinguished by one of the town's two covered bridges.
Bible Hill is dotted with horse farms, as well as several new houses and a few extensively made-over 19th century barns and Cape Cods. One property now on the market is one of the latter: a kitchen wing was added several years ago. The house, which sits up off the road and overlooks the grand sweep of the Mount Ascutney, comes with 7.83 acres, asking $350,000, reduced from $399,000. Another 20 acres is available across the road -- an absolute must or you will risk looking at a sea of houses in a few years -- for a total of $475,000.
The problem is that this immaculate house is almost too immaculate; it has been renovated to an inch of its life; every surface, including its blue-painted wide-board floors, gleams. A big barn comes with it. So does a fieldstone terrace out back.
A one-minute walk away is another house, a ranch, nestled down on the mountain side of Bible Hill Road, set farther back from the street. While the almond-colored house probably would not win any architectural awards, the five-acre setting is breathtaking and the price, $285,000, is hard to beat.
Back along a dirt road in the neighboring town of Weathersfield, a hunter's dream house, an entrancing shingled lodge with leaded glass windows on 82 acres, has just gone to contract; the asking price was $198,000 (reduced from $209,000). There is only one drawback: the houses around where you turn into the driveway look a trifle messy -- not as pristine as one could wish for. But there is a gunite swimming pool, even if it does look like something found at an Army base. And look at that icehouse, the real estate agent said: "Isn't that a corker? The workmanship is better than in most homes."
About a half-hour's drive west, Chester, Vt., looks like Vermont's answer to Sag Harbor, N.Y., with its long Main Street lined with galleries and shops and a big white inn with black shutters. This place is awash with artists.
Zena Robinson, a watercolor and collage artist, is a member of two art guilds and estimates there are at least 100 artists around here. "There's a lot of artists here," she said. "I think there is an attitude of you can do anything you want as long as you don't make me do it too." More and more New Yorkers are coming here, she said. "They used to just come to ski, but now it's more year-round outdoor sports like hiking. We've got a short gardening season, but we love to garden."
Philip Atwood of Valley Real Estate said business is booming in Chester. He has made 37 sales so far this year, his best year yet. For urban refugees with a bed-and-breakfast dream: a brick Colonial on 45 acres about two miles out of town is for sale for $499,500 with 5 bedrooms, 10 working fireplaces and a beehive oven. It backs up on the Williams River, good trout fishing "if you know how to fish them," he said.
ANOTHER house, right on Main Street, is an elaborate 1899 Victorian with three porches and two balconies. Within the last two weeks, it went into contract: the asking price was $287,000. Still available is a log cabin on 12 acres, for $125,000.
In Peterborough, N.H. -- about a four-hour drive from New York, a three-hour drive from Boston and a 45-minute drive from Chester -- what had been a dismal railroad depot has become a thriving retail neighborhood. On Columbus Day weekend last month, there was an arts festival, and all the galleries were open, manned by the artists. Michaela Ali-Oglu said Peterborough and the surrounding towns had, within the last five years, become a mecca for artists. When she rented her gallery, its previous occupant had been a television repair shop. "I took a big risk," she said. Property values have grown in this charming town -- which has one of the best antique and used bookstores in New England -- but in spite of that, prices still seem dirt cheap to a city type.
While Peterborough has a fresh-scrubbed feel of a country town of the first rank, home buyers can currently find at least two houses for $50,000 within a 10 minute drive from the center of town. One is a white Cape on two acres, on a scenic road in Francestown, N.H. Taxes are $1,972. One drawback: there's only a wood stove for heat. The other is a big village Colonial that needs everything -- but has frontage on the Contoocook River. That one has a propane stove for heat as well as one bathroom and a shed on a little over half an acre.
At the top end -- and there are lots of fancy houses here -- is a twin chimney 1820 Federal in nearby Hancock, N.H. On seven acres off a gravel road, surrounded by hundreds of acres of the Monadnock Region's protected "supersanctuary." And if that is not tempting enough, there are the (reputed) Moses Eaton stencils -- all for $539,000. (Eaton's own house is for sale too -- but no stencils.)
Then there is the seven-bedroom shingled villa designed by Cummings & Sears, prominent Boston architects before the turn of the century, set on two acres of a Dublin, N.H., hilltop for $345,000. Past owners were part of what was a thriving arts colony there, and the property is right across from the old town commons, which is protected by town ordinance and will always remain open land.
Ms. Peterson and her fellow real estate brokers in Peterborough have lots of cheaper properties too, from an old mill to an unusual group of brick row houses that look as if they could be found in Bath, England. One of these townhouses, completely restored, just sold for $130,000, with three bedrooms and real elegance.
Down in Old Lyme, Conn., a town bordered by both the Connecticut River and the Long Island Sound, there are artists still sprinkled around an area that had been home to the group known as the Old Lyme School -- American Impressionist painters, who included Childe Hassam and Guy Wiggins. Old Lyme has one of New England's most magnificent churches, the Congregational Church, which was itself painted frequently by the town's better known residents, as well as a strikingly beautiful Main Street.
OLD LYME, neighboring Lyme and Essex were hit hard in the real estate recession of the early 1990's and really recovered only in the last couple of years. Prices are now much as they were in the heyday of the late 1980's, said Jeanne Rutigliano of the Strong Agency in Old Lyme -- much higher than the property in remoter Vermont and New Hampshire, but still, some might argue, with more room to rise: Old Lyme is an even two hours from Times Square, and there is an Amtrak stop at Old Saybrook, the next town to the west.
There are not many loss leaders in Old Lyme, Lyme or Essex. An architect, Jonathan Isleib, is parting with his own house, an eclectic mix of hipped roofs, glass and bluestone, which is being sold on 17.6 acres for $2.8 million, with views of the river and Essex Harbor.
At the other extreme, there is a converted red barn, built in 1910, near the Hadlyme four corners, with its herb and antiques shop and a totally authentic general store with great sandwiches. The good news is the price: $259,000. It is close to a tiny ferry that crosses the river here.
For houses around here with charm, Ms. Rutigliano said, "It's impossible to fill the demand." Brokers are seeing more "52- to 55-year-olds: not quite ready to give up their big house in Greenwich, but looking for a weekend house now that they can retire to later," she said.
"More are demanding a main floor bedroom or the potential to make one," Ms. Rutigliano said. And more are eschewing fixer-uppers for perfection -- even if they have to pay more. "They don't want the $350,000 fixer-upper," the agent said. "They'd rather someone else put the extra $200,000 in before they buy it."
In Old Lyme and in the rest of New England, the real estate market for the best vacation homes has not been hotter in a long time. In Vermont and New Hampshire, which lagged behind the old-moneyed summer resort islands -- Deer Island and Mount Desert in Maine and Nantucket and Martha's Vineyard in Massachusetts -- things are still going up, said Mr. Ballantyne of Sotheby's. But in the islands, he said, things have started to cool; prices are not declining, but mellowing out, similar to what is happening to New York City.
On the islands, the creme de la creme -- McKim, Mead & White villas and the like -- are still setting records, Mr. Ballantyne said. But for the rest, "the market is still strong but not setting records."
"The frenzy is gone," he continued. "It makes sense: the properties that went up the first, went up the fastest, are the ones that are starting to slow."
And up in Vermont, where Mr. Bullard holds court, business is very good, better than it has been in years. He just keeps selling the houses to young families. And selling them again. And again.
"Because the young people tend to get sick of things," he said. "They buy a house that costs a couple hundred thousand dollars; they buy it so their kids can learn to ski. But the kids don't like to ski. Or they get sick of it and move to South Carolina, to Florida or to Aspen, and somebody else buys it."
"It kind of keeps the ball in the air," the real estate agent said, grinning broadly.

HEADLINE: MUSIC;
Smashing Drum Display From France

BYLINE: By LESLIE KANDELL

 BODY:
THE following concert program is rated PG-13: it contains 17 brawny guys with bare arms, pummeling oil drums in violent rhythms, with pickaxes. Although there is no profanity (unless it's in French) one cannot ignore the yelling, or the smashing oilcans. Earplugs are available to the audience at no charge.
Here, here, what's all this? A variant palliative for aggression? A dream evening for the hearing-challenged? Intrepid listeners will have a chance to find out Nov. 15 when Les Tambours du Bronx, an unusual drumming group from France, muscles into New Jersey on its first North American tour. 
 To the extent that the culture of hip-hop is about rebellion, this event is a species of hip-hop -- that is, the antithesis of the classical music concert form. If there is an expected appropriate attire, the drummers of Les Tambours don't wear it. As to performing on valuable heirloom instruments: they don't play standard instruments at all, and regularly destroy what they do play on. Quiet, a concert hall norm, is a joke. Even the Bronx reference is a joke.
The men, who no longer have to hold day jobs -- if they ever had them -- come from the outskirts of Nevers, an industrial town in central France known for repairing trains, and also as the resting place of Bernadette of Lourdes, whose body is preserved under a glass bubble, reportedly as fresh as ever. Before Les Tambours was founded in 1987, its members were friends who met to drink at a place in Nevers called the Broadway Bar. Some were students, some had jobs, some were unemployed, but none were musicians. Their little jest, as their evenings at the Broadway Bar ended, was that they were going back home to the Bronx.
According to the group's leader, Ludovic Le Mapihan (known as Map), they got their shot at performing during the city's annual festival of movie shorts.
"We wanted to make a small performance, but we were not sure what," said Map. (The telephone conversation is translated from an ad hoc mixture of French and English, representing a genuine dual effort.) "We had no money, but because Nevers is a city for train repairs, 55-gallon barrels were easy to find free, in gardens."
They performed 20 minutes at the festival, got all fired up, and decided to go to any nearby festival, invited or not. "We played in the street," said Map. "Presenters liked us and we began to be invited."
True to its perverse form, the all-male group, now aged 25 to 42, named its first commercial recording "Silence." It's anything but, though the label name, Naive, is more like it. The rhythms are clean, repetitive in the marching band sense, and seductive but acceptable, probably, to even to the most mannered listener. "Bombast and unity" said one reviewer. Not bad.
Nothing about their performance is gentrified. Some numbers have added clapping or whistling, while in others, oil barrel clangor is augmented by groans, howls and snorts. The recording's final number, "Etouffez la Ventoline" (a title chosen for rhythm rather than meaning) has unintelligible words that might be broadcast over a railroad station loudspeaker.
Comparing Les Tambours with Japan's Kodo Drummers, Map acknowledged the similar visceral effect, and then said: "Our rhythm is very basic. It goes directly to your body. Our instruments are different in the way we play. We smash very loud. When we finish the show, the instrument is destroyed. You can use both sides of the drum, so, two shows maximum."
The destruction factor is handled through copious supplies: "A big truck follows us, with 400 barrels from France, and 4,000 sticks," he said.
After trying different materials for their pickax mallets, they settled on beechwood, because it proved strong enough to survive a concert or two.
Since the drummers can't practice separately, they get together in what Map described as a hangar in the countryside. "We are not musicians," he said. "We play and move our arms a special way. We look for new members in the way we would look for a friend, not a drummer."
In Les Tambours European performances, there is some interaction with the audience, which Map was not sure was happening on this tour. "We try to talk to the audience," he said, "but our English is not so good. We explain and ask what they think. We know they won't sleep."
