HEADLINE: Glen Cove Seeks Waterfront Investors

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW

DATELINE: GLEN COVE

 BODY:
THROUGHOUT his six years in office, Mayor Thomas R. Suozzi has pursued a dream to make Glen Cove Creek, the dowdy, dirty stretch of waterfront at the heart of this city, into an attractive place to dine, drink, dock and stroll. Marshaling federal and state grants, the city has already spent $40 million on bulkhead building, dredging the creek and cleaning up the waterfront area.
Last week, Mr. Suozzi took his show before a paying audience, so to speak, when he announced that the city was seeking to sell to private investors 50 acres on the north side of the 213-acre Glen Cove Creek development zone. Plans call for a major hotel and dozens of restaurants and shops. 
 "Our vision is to restore Glen Cove's waterfront as a Gold Coast destination," the mayor said after a press conference on Tuesday that drew about 100 property developers, local residents and federal, state and local officials.
"Of the 10 miles of Glen Cove waterfront, 9 are already beautiful," he said. "But one mile is an industrial area that was once a contaminated site and is now abandoned and being cleaned up for development. This vision for a waterfront festival marketplace was developed with input from numerous planners, developers, public officials, environmental groups and the community.
"Just picture yourself dining on lobster while enjoying a sunset over Hempstead Harbor," he said.
His vision is a far cry from today's reality. Glen Cove Creek includes industrial sites that were piled with garbage and rubble and contaminated with chemical waste from the former Li Tungsten ore refining plant. Some of the contaminated industrial land remains on the federal Superfund cleanup list.
Nevertheless, the city is seeking minimum bids totaling $24.5 million for the land now up for sale, divided into four projects: a 250-room luxury hotel, conference center and banquet hall (suggested minimum bid: $6 million); a waterfront marketplace containing 200,000 square feet of restaurants, boutiques and other retail shops ($9 million); a high-speed ferry service to Manhattan ($6.5 million) to operate from a $2 million ferry terminal to be built by the city; and 70,000 square feet of bookstores, galleries or sports and health facilities ($3 million.)
Successful bidders will be required to work with the city to develop their properties in harmony with the overall plan for the area, which is to include a waterfront promenade.
Clearly, the linchpin of the proposal is the hotel. The city commissioned a marketing study from HVS International, a hospitality consulting firm whose president, Steve Rushmore, reported: "Nassau County is under-hoteled and desperately needs a luxury hotel. Occupancy rates are at record levels, and the Glen Cove waterfront is a premier site for a hotel in the style of a Hilton or Ritz Carlton."
The mayor said, "There has been a lot of interest from developers and hotel chains, but until there is a firm offer I'm unable to divulge any names." Bids for all four projects are due by Jan. 15, and winners are expected to be announced on Feb. 1.
Successful bidders will have to have good imaginations. Though cleanup efforts have been underway at least since 1986, when Glen Cove was identified as the most polluted harbor on the North Shore, much remains to be done.
The pace of cleanup accelerated after 1994, when the state's Long Island Sound Coastal Management Program designated Glen Cove as one of only three areas along New York's 314-mile Long Island Sound coastline where concentrated waterfront redevelopment should occur. (The other two were Mamaroneck and Port Chester.) Then in 1998, the city was selected as one of 16 national Brownfields Showcase Communities, making it eligible for additional grants dedicated to reclaiming "brownfields," polluted industrial sites. Glen Cove has been awarded more than $23 million in federal and state money.
In 1996 the federal Environmental Protection Agency began cleaning up the Li Tungsten site, near the head of the creek. In 1998, the city demolished the 250-foot Li Tungsten smokestack. Last year, the city purchased the Li Tungsten site and Captain's Cove, an abandoned condominium and a New York State-designated inactive hazardous waste site at the mouth of the creek, and has begun cleanup work there.
Maria Stanco, the E.P.A.'s brownfields coordinator for Glen Cove, projected that the waterfront piece of the Li Tungsten property will be removed from the Superfund list by the end of this year, with the remaining portions to follow within two years.
During the cleanup, the city has occasionally clashed with the Coalition to Save Hempstead Harbor, a local civic group, particularly over the inauguration in March of a high-speed ferry service to New London, Conn., operated by the Foxwoods casino.
The coalition objected to the noise and pollution of the ferry, and it is still a source of debate, said Corin Dunne, the group's co-president. But overall, she said, it has won the support of the community. And she said the coalition was backing the overall waterfront development.
"We support the city's master plan as the best possible kind of development," Ms. Dunne said. "We have been watching, and will continue to watch, for any problems."
When plans for a ferry terminal were first announced, the city met with resistance from neighboring Sea Cliff and the North Shore Environmental Alliance, which jointly filed a lawsuit against the city. On Oct. 5, a settlement was reached which, according to the Sea Cliff Court Clerk, Pete Hesse, reduced the proposed waterfront construction projects from 1.1 million square feet to 700,000, set back the proposed hotel from the waterfront to create a landscaped buffer area between the building and pedestrian esplanade, and moved the permanent ferry terminal into the creek and away from the harbor.
It also called for the city of Glen Cove to conduct an environmental impact study with respect to the operation of the commuter and excursion ferries, and the construction and use of the permanent ferry terminal and parking facilities at the Li Tungsten property.
Mr. Suozzi said the development would create 1,700 full-time jobs and generate $200 million in annual sales, $9.8 million of which would come back to the city and the local school district as property taxes.
"Our goals are threefold: to clean up the pollution, to bring back jobs and the economy, and to recycle the once-polluted areas rather than using up any remaining open space," the mayor said. "Where else can you find 50 acres of waterfront property? This is a unique opportunity to create something beautiful and to improve our city's image."

HEADLINE: Mission District Fights Case of Dot-Com Fever

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 4

 BODY:
By day, the Mission District still looks like the workhorse immigrant neighborhood it has been for a hundred years.
Old women wearing kerchiefs, pulling shopping carts to mom-and-pop grocery stores, still own the streets. Young mothers wheeling strollers chat in Spanish on street corners. Taquerias selling $3 burritos are packed. 
 But by night, it becomes clear why the Mission is at the center of one of the most tense battles over the future of San Francisco in decades. This is when the newcomers -- mostly young, white and affluent -- come home from the jobs that afford them $700,000 loft condominiums in former warehouses, and when the limousines pull up to the bistros that have taken over the butcher shops and bakeries on Valencia Street. This is when the warnings -- "Artists Evicted!" stenciled in red paint on the sidewalks, posters that say "Gentrify Me" under the head of Medusa, graffiti that says "Dot Com" with a line across it on buildings in progress -- begin to make sense.
It was only a matter of time before San Francisco rebelled against its latest incarnation as a combination bedroom, home office and den for Silicon Valley. The city's artsy, bohemian soul could only absorb the biggest, fastest money-making machine ever for so long without a crisis. And as artists, nonprofit organizations and working-class tenants are being evicted in record numbers to make way for richer, glossier arrivals, the hue and cry against the dot-com world has reached fever pitch.
This is not to say that San Francisco, where two competing initiatives on the Nov. 7 ballot are being promoted as the solution to unbridled growth, is the only city in the Silicon Valley web saying "enough is enough." Palo Alto, the heart of Silicon Valley, has enacted an emergency ordinance banning companies from setting up in street-level retail spaces. Redwood City, the headquarters of Oracle, Excite@Home and Napster, imposed a moratorium on most new office development to assess the consequences of such growth. Other strongholds of the new economy, including Menlo Park, San Carlos and San Mateo, have either enacted or plan to enact similar moratoriums on high-tech development. San Jose expects a long legal battle and Seattle-style protests after approving a $1.3 billion, 20,000-worker complex for Cisco Systems.
But it is here in San Francisco, a city that boasts that it is one of the top cultural destinations in the country, that the dot-com backlash is seen and felt the most.
In part, this is because the city's quirky landscape has changed so much so quickly. No vacant lot is safe. Neither is any small company with an expiring lease. The dot-com economy, which hit its stride here in 1996, has dictated real estate costs, which have reached unaffordable levels downtown for all but the richest companies. The price of prime downtown commercial real estate has more than tripled in five years, to $85 per square foot today from $25.25 per square foot in 1995.
These costs have reverberated throughout the city. Small companies eager to be in San Francisco have set up shop in a former warehouse district known as South of Market, or SoMa, and, more and more, in the Mission. At least a dozen arts groups have been forced to close because of rents that have jumped to $10,000 a month from $2,500, or because they were evicted when buildings were sold for new offices.
Just the fact that the Mission, with its homely tenement buildings, squashed-together houses and teeming streets, has come to symbolize the housing crisis underscores how desperate the real estate situation has become in this city. The neighborhood, which is 62 percent Latino, is poorer than most in San Francisco: 83 percent of the residents are tenants, compared with 65 to 70 percent in San Francisco as a whole, and the per capita income is $20,112, versus $32,441 citywide. In recent years, rents here have gone from about $500 for a 250-square-foot studio apartment to $1,200 for that same studio, in a plain building with no amenities.
But because the Mission is the neighborhood of choice for the city's large array of activist groups, it is not taking its new-found popularity among the wealthy lying down.
Several groups have been formed to fight gentrification, including the Artists Eviction Defense Coalition and the Mission Anti-Displacement Coalition, an umbrella group of at least a dozen neighborhood organizations. The antigentrification groups have organized sit-ins at dot-com buildings and protest rallies, and they plan more in the coming weeks.
"I think it's O.K. to say that in residential neighborhoods, especially in low-income neighborhoods, we can't go with the whole idea of supply and demand," said Luis Granados, executive director of the Mission Economic Development Association, which assists residents and small businesses. "If we were to do that, the entire neighborhood will become a giant dot-com office park, and it's coming to that. It's really coming to that."
Even now, when Internet companies are shaky, with seemingly more of them shutting down than starting up, the hideous traffic jams, housing prices that are the highest in the country and record numbers of evictions have led to such resentment that Mayor Willie Brown, in his recent state-of-the-city speech, sternly lectured residents against blaming dot-coms for the city's problems.
"There is absolutely no justification for scapegoating anyone," he said. "Dot-commers! If I hear that one more time, I'm going to scream!"
The mayor also used his state-of-the-city speech to campaign for an initiative known as Measure K, which is backed by his main campaign contributors, the downtown development interests.
Measure K would impose a two-year moratorium on new projects larger than 25,000 square feet in the Mission and an adjacent neighborhood, Potrero Hill, and allow a one-time lifting for the next 15 months of the city's annual limit on office space of 950,000 square feet to ease the space shortage. It would also exempt many areas from the growth limit and create the post of development czar, appointed by the mayor, to oversee projects.
The competing initiative, Measure L, which is sponsored by artists and neighborhood activists, bans new development in parts of the Mission and South of Market districts, applies an indefinite moratorium on new development in two neighborhoods and other parts of SoMa, and bans so-called live-work loft construction, with far fewer exemptions from the annual growth limit.
Live-work lofts have become contentious. They were designed to create affordable housing for artists. But larger developers have used loopholes in the live-work loft laws to put up buildings exempt from certain development taxes that dot-com companies have used for office space only, or affluent renters or buyers have used only for housing.
For some longtime residents of the Mission, however, neither measure much matters; the neighborhood is already nearly gone. Pedro Linares, a drummer who moved here from Lima, Peru, 10 years ago, said most of his neighbors had moved. "No one can afford it here anymore," he said. "The old neighborhood we knew doesn't belong to us anymore."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 21, 2000, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Nov. 5 discussed growing cultural and economic conflicts in the Mission District of San Francisco between the working poor who inhabit the neighborhood by day and the Silicon Valley rich who return to its bistros and loft apartments by night. The article included statistics on income level in the district.
The figures were from a study by a San Diego marketing research firm, Claritas, commissioned by The San Francisco Examiner for an article it published on Aug. 29 about conflicts between newcomers and long-term residents. The figures should have been attributed. In addition, the Times article described them incorrectly. The statistics applied only to the section known as the Inner Mission, not to the entire district.

HEADLINE: He Did It His Way

BYLINE: By Deborah E. McDowell; Deborah E. McDowell is a professor of English at the University of Virginia. Her most recent book is "Leaving Pipe Shop."

 BODY:

 A Personal Odyssey
 By Thomas Sowell.
 Illustrated. 308 pp. New York:
 The Free Press. $25. 
 "A side from the pleasure of sharing reminiscences," Thomas Sowell writes in the closing lines of "A Personal Odyssey, "the whole point of looking back on my life . . . is to hope that others will find something useful for their own lives." He takes his final words from Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes: "If I could think that I had sent a spark to those who come after I should be ready to say Goodbye." One could say that for the last three decades, Sowell, a senior fellow at the Hoover Institution, Stanford University, has been sending sparks into the highly charged arena of civil rights debate. Sowell, an economist by training, rose to national notice in the early 1970's, when he challenged, in The New York Times Magazine, "the prevailing assumptions behind admissions policies for minority students." The article linked him ever after with political conservatives, though he has long disavowed Republican Party affiliation.
"A Personal Odyssey" is cast in that most American of autobiographical molds: the narrative of the self-made man, from hardscrabble beginnings in Charlotte, N.C., to the Olympian heights of boardrooms, think tanks and the premier universities. While the narrative is strictly linear, Sowell's path from want to privilege is anything but straight.
Adopted as an infant by his paternal aunt, at 9 he moved with her to Harlem, joining relatives who bounced from apartment to apartment. A model student, he was admitted to Stuyvesant High School, but domestic tensions and financial strain soon proved too distracting and he dropped out, landing in a home for homeless boys. These lean years, during which he pawned his one suit for food and was estranged from his family, Sowell says taught him much about the virtues of perseverance, standards, grit and integrity, lessons failed by most people he encountered. At each juncture of his progress, which included the Marine Corps, the Labor Department and AT&T, he met with petty and unprincipled personalities, most quick to trade integrity for political gain -- types he also finds abundant in academia.
From Howard to Harvard, Douglass College-Rutgers to Cornell, Brandeis to U.C.L.A., the picture he paints is much the same: grade-hungry students abetted by unethical administrators who negotiate on their behalf for looser standards. Alone able to remain faithful to the "convictions of his own mind" and soured on deans and department chairs usurping his authority, Sowell ultimately abandons academia altogether.
It simply never occurs to him that those with whom he clashed during the tempests of the l960's and early 70's could likewise have been following the convictions of their minds, however flawed and misguided they might appear to him. While he freely admits his "views were certainly not in tune with the spirit of the l960's," this is hardly a license to scapegoat the entire period or to smear those committed to its causes. Sowell's descriptions of them function as epithets: "white liberal activist," +black militants,"+ "freelance black 'spokesmen,' "+ "white faculty patrons."
Sowell takes issue with the most significant social policies, programs and legal decisions of the 20th century, from Brown v. Board of Education in 1954 to the Civil Rights Act of 1964. The Civil Rights Act figures solely as a measure vindicating him; he had already begun his career when it passed, he notes, and so was spared the "hang-ups" of black intellectuals stigmatized by the popular notion that they owed their careers to affirmative action. He entered U.C.L.A. by the front door and earned his achievements through hard work and merit, he says: they squeaked by on white guilt and largesse. Such shopworn sentiments are Sowell's stock in trade.
"A Personal Odyssey" is a bitter, brittle, captious book, despite its avuncular conclusion. There is no odyssey here, no journey. There is instead movement without growth in this largely unfaceted and self-regarding self-portrait.

HEADLINE: Living the Missing Life

BYLINE: By Langdon Hammer; Langdon Hammer is the author of "Hart Crane and Allen Tate: Janus-Faced Modernism."

 BODY:

 Time's Fool
 A Tale in Verse.
 By Glyn Maxwell.
 396 pp. Boston:
 Houghton Mifflin Company. $27.
 
The Boys at Twilight
 Poems, 1990-1995.
 By Glyn Maxwell.
 160 pp. Boston: Mariner Books/
 Houghton Mifflin Company. Paper, $14. 
 WHEN he published his first book of poems in 1990, Glyn Maxwell seemed to capture, for British readers, a new generation's ways of speaking and feeling. Here was poetry that was literate and sophisticated but not stuffily literary, and sentiments that were liberal and democratic but not piously held. Maxwell could be poignant and cheeky, and often at the same time; the work felt fresh in both senses. One challenge for such a poet is how to grow older. So it seems fitting that the hero and narrator of Maxwell's new novel-length "tale in verse," "Time's Fool," lives under a curse, unable to age beyond 17. The poem comes to American readers alongside "The Boys at Twilight: Poems, 1990-1995," a selection from Maxwell's three early books published in Britain.
The plot of "Time's Fool" is a variation on the supernatural tales that attracted Coleridge in "The Rime of the Ancient Mariner" and Wagner in "The Flying Dutchman." Edmund Lea rides a "ghost train." Every seven years, on Christmas Eve, the train returns him to his hometown, Hartisle, and the doors slide open for the night, temporarily allowing him out. This ritual repetition begins in 1970, when a stranger arrives in town and seduces Edmund's beloved, Clare. When Edmund confronts him, the stranger tells a mad story: long ago he killed a man where he and Edmund now stand, and he has been doomed to wander ever since. Edmund is driven to repeat his crime, and he falls under the same spell. Over the next five decades, during his nights in Hartisle (the name suggests the island of the heart, surrounded by oceans of wasted time), Edmund seeks his freedom through love, repentance and death, only to find himself back on the train each time.
Meanwhile, the world Edmund knew has been transformed. Clare marries and divorces. Her memory of Edmund grows fainter until she can't remember having loved him. In 1991 she says of her younger self, "There's not one cell of me the same / as her. Only the name. Or one of them." Hartisle too changes, cell by cell. Still rooted in a rural village culture in 1970, it soon dissolves into the global economy. The town center is displaced by a mall, and Edmund's parents move from their quiet lane into a "gated community," watched over by a uniformed guard in the blue glow of his television. Edmund's local pub, the Oak, is replaced by a brasserie in a "silvered office block," later by an "Ice-o-theque" and a chain restaurant called "Happy Eater." Edmund wonders what "software" is. His story becomes the subject of a rock album, then the focus of rival New Age cults.
This much is social satire, trenchant at times, trivial at others. Maxwell's deeper concern is with the solitude and emptiness of Edmund's suspended existence. Once he knows there is nothing left for him in Hartisle, he sees that "Home is the ride." During the seven-year periods between visits to Hartisle, Edmund is alone on the train, save for the train's spectral driver, a certain Inspector Stick, and a man Edmund nicknames Happy Hour, who gives him food and drink while speaking a language Edmund can't understand. Looking out and writing, yet always "going nowhere," Edmund experiences time as a featureless medium passed through and viewed, not grasped and lived in. He is the embodiment of an expatriate writer's homelessness. "It's living a missing life," he explains. But in this there is nothing very strange. "We all live one, / really." Only our homes and our families convince us we belong.
The feeling that life is somehow being missed is a central theme of modern English poetry, from William Empson to Philip Larkin. "The Boys at Twilight" belongs to this lyric tradition. Maxwell's contribution is to treat missed experience not as a private, psychological condition but as a social one, defining the blank quality of contemporary public life. A poem titled "Tale of a Chocolate Egg," from Maxwell's first book, is a virtuoso treatment of the theme. Antic and rambling, Maxwell's narrator follows a few stock types, including a skinhead, an Indian girl and a "brown-haired bloke," as they make their ways through a usual day, drawn by the magnetic appeal of a new product, a chocolate egg. The egg, which has no "slogan" but its own "O," is pure advertisement, a symbol for the hollow center of a consumer society.
The vacancy of political discourse is the issue in other early poems. "The People's Cinema" describes a screen on which myths of collective identity are projected: bare and blank, it is "how riches look in daylight when there are none." In "We Billion Cheered," Maxwell speaks of an unspecified social or political threat -- an "it" without a definite referent -- against which the national "we" gathers and defines itself, although "We missed it how / You miss an o'clock passing and miss now."
Many of the poems in "The Boys at Twilight" are about England and Englishness. The style of living they depict is suburban, bland, gently self-mocking ("We shrugged the Home County shrug"). But the loss of weight and depth that Maxwell evokes touches the whole world, and it requires a new cosmology:
The Earth is of course quite flat, and the heavenly bodies
Twinkle explicably. One is as big as a Swatch.
Today they are all gone away, gone away where God is,
Where the dead play whist and the unborn ask can they watch.
This is grim but fun. The mood can be darkened simply by changing the channel, so to speak, to the news from Eastern Europe. Maxwell does so in moving poems about violence in Bosnia and elsewhere. In "a world that had forgotten it was round," not flat, Maxwell's fighting men fail to recognize that the other men "up ahead, quite mad," are only "their own tail," and "they cut them to the ground." Here is the brilliant first stanza of a poem called "The Sarajevo Zoo":
Men had used up their hands, men had
offered, cupped, or kissed them to survive,
had wiped them on the skirts of their own town,
as different men had shinned up a ladder and taken
the sun down.
As these quotations suggest, Maxwell is a formal poet who uses rhyme and meter nimbly but often loosely, as if to be too exacting would be to risk pretentiousness. His shorter poems, even the most serious, resemble light verse and popular songs. He can be brisk and cutting (as in "The High Achievers," a poem about people on the fast track: "Made, / they counted themselves free"). But he seldom has the concentration to be pithy. His unique effects derive from rapid modulation between voices, levels of diction, tones. The poems in "The Boys at Twilight" race forward in run-on sentences, rubbing against the restrictions of traditional prosody, refusing to be mistaken for merely well-made things.
Maxwell has an ear for empty statements, syntactic stumbles and conversational filler, the expressive contentlessness of so much that we say. Even when there are missing pieces or semantic gaps, however, Maxwell's poems plunge on, with the implication that life is like that -- a little out of control, a little out of reach. This rush of speech is hard to manage and sustain, even in a short poem. In the 396 pages of "Time's Fool," there are passages where the writing thins out, and Maxwell's calculated slipperiness begins to feel like sloppiness.
To be redeemed, Edmund must enter ordinary time and age. This he does magically and almost violently at the close of "Time's Fool," passing from 17 to 66 in little more than an instant. This ending is less of an answer to the problem of how to grow older than a release from it. The sense of experience Edmund had missed is suddenly restored, but it remains impossible to articulate. Early in the poem, Edmund speaks of "the present" -- punningly -- as something to be unwrapped; and when he tries to get at it, he can't. At the end of the poem, as he watches the sunrise, Edmund is at last alive in the moment, but this new sensation is not so different from his former emptiness. The word that forms in him, Maxwell writes in a beautiful final couplet, only "fades again, too bright in the bright day / for ink to cling to or for soul to say."

SECTION: Section 11; Page 2; Column 4; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1425 words

HEADLINE: High-Technology Revival for Historic City

BYLINE: By JAMES R. HARDCASTLE

DATELINE: MANASSAS Va.

 BODY:
The opening of a semiconductor memory plant and the sudden proliferation of Internet facilities have contributed to a spectacular change in fortune for the Old Town district in this small city 30 miles southwest of Washington, D.C., best known for its key role in two Civil War battles fought nearby.
Five years ago, 33 buildings were vacant in the city's Old Town, an area of mostly two-story late 19th century or early 20th century brick buildings built close to the road in four short blocks along three narrow streets and a railroad. 
 The reason for the economic distress was the same as in many small towns and cities across the country, said Roger Snyder, the city's director of community development. During the late 1960's and early 1970's, Virginia decided to widen roads leading to Washington and its closer-in Northern Virginia suburbs to four lanes.
Key businesses left the Manassas area to be near the four-lane roads, he said. A regional shopping mall that opened in 1971 on one of the new four-lane roads on the outskirts of the city accelerated the hollowing out of the Old Town.
The decline worsened when the city's major employer, the International Business Machines Corporation, began to trim its work force. In 1990, I.B.M. had 5,300 employees working at its manufacturing and federal systems facilities in Manassas. By 1994, the manufacturing operations had moved elsewhere, and there were 1,800 employees remaining at the federal systems division, now owned by Lockheed Martin.
Today, all of the buildings in the Old Town area of this city of 35,000 are either occupied or undergoing renovation. Many of the buildings are used by new businesses appealing to the million tourists a year who visit the Manassas National Battlefield five miles to the north or the Manassas Museum, to antiques collectors and to Washington-area residents taking day trips.
The new businesses include an out-of-print bookstore, a fine furniture shop, a wine and food shop, a cooperative pottery studio, a clocksmith, a tearoom, a coffeehouse, a jewelry store, a dress shop, two gift stores, an establishment designed to look like a tavern in colonial Philadelphia and three new restaurants.
Adding life to the Manassas Old Town at night are people who have moved into some 20 modern apartments recently added to the upper floors of rehabilitated commercial buildings. The idea of building modern apartments on the second floors of old commercial buildings in Old Town Manassas originated with the late Loy E. Harris, a long-time insurance broker in the city.
Mr. Harris had long been active in city task forces and business groups promoting the revitalization of the city's Old Town. In 1995, he bought a large vacant commercial building, built in 1906, that originally had a grocery store on the first floor and a large hall on the second. The hall, locally known as the Opera House, had at various times been used for plays and movies and once, in 1916, for a reunion of a Confederate Rangers unit attended by its leader, Col. John S. Mosby.
In the first floor space, Mr. Harris opened a business called the Opera House Gourmet, which specializes in wine, fine foods and cigars. On the second floor, he built four 1,000 square-foot two-bedroom loft apartments that rent for around $1,000 a month. They are so popular that at one point, 10 people were vying for one vacant apartment unit, said John Weber, a Manassas real estate broker.
Mr. Harris next bought the neighboring bank building, which is now a gift shop, and added four more apartments. Next, he bought a third building nearby, and it now has offices for a stock brokerage firm on the first floor and two smaller offices on the second.
When Mr. Harris bought the Opera House, "everyone thought he was crazy, but he started the energy flowing," said Creston Owen, the owner of a Manassas company that provides telecommunications systems to local companies.
In 1996, Mr. Owen followed Mr. Harris's example. He bought a vacant one-story brick building that had been a catalog store on the western edge of the Old Town and renovated it for his own company's use. He has since bought seven other properties in Old Town and has an eighth under contract. Several other business owners have also bought properties and added apartments on the upper floors.
Mr. Owen's contractors are now putting finishing touches on a new three-story structure built on a lot near the tracks left vacant by a fire over 20 years ago. Its first floor has 2,200 square feet of commercial space, which will be leased to The Washington Post as a news bureau. The upper floors house six two-bedroom apartments renting for around $900 a month. Rent for commercial space in Mr. Owen's building is $19 to $20 per square foot a year, with utilities not included, he said.
City officials and business leaders agree that Northern Virginia's booming high-technology economy has provided the economic atmosphere needed for Old Town revival. Until recently, the city had been seen as too far away from the Northern Virginia's high-technology corridor in the Dulles Airport-Reston area, some 15 miles to the north, to benefit much from economic expansion.
That changed in 1995 when Dominion Semiconductor, a joint venture of I.B.M. and Tokyo-based Toshiba, announced plans to build a $1.7 billion plant to manufacture memory chips at a site owned by I.B.M. within the city about a mile west of Old Town. The plant employs about 1,000 people and another 150 contractor employees. Last May, Toshiba, which is buying I.B.M.'s share of the plant, said it had formed a venture with SanDisk, a Sunnyvale, Calif., manufacturer of nonvolatile memory products, to add a $600 million module to the plant and employ an additional 600 people to produce flash memory chips.
The Dominion Semiconductor announcement put Manassas on the national map, but the 10-square-mile city has only limited space for new facilities. So recently, a number of companies attracted to the area have selected sites west of the city in neighboring western Prince William County.
Last year, America Online opened a technology center in a 220,000-square-foot industrial building on a 25-acre parcel next to the Manassas National Battlefield in Prince William County. AOL paid $3.9 million for the site. Row after row of computers and peripheral equipment used to support the AOL service and other on-line services brought the total cost of the facility to $520 million.
Late last month, AOL began construction of a second $555 million technology center about five miles west of the first. The new Prince William County tech center will be AOL's fourth in Northern Virginia and its eighth worldwide.
AOL's technology center brought improved telecommunication and electrical services to the area. The new infrastructure brought to serve AOL is now attracting additional companies.
This spring, Data Centers Now, a division of Beco Management of Rockville, Md., paid $2.75 million to buy a 7.3 acre site adjacent to AOL's first data center. The company is currently building a 109,800-square-foot, two-story speculative data center there -- the first of three speculative data center buildings totaling 250,000 square feet that will be built at the site.
The highly fortified building is designed to withstand winds of up to 150 miles an hour and to provide security against assaults. Backup power and extensive fuel storage will be provided.
Along the same lines, U.S. Data Port of San Jose, Calif., said last month that it would develop a 153-acre campus designed to accommodate 10 to 20 different data center buildings inside a high-security perimeter next to the second AOL center in Gainesville.
The company's partner, the Calpine Corporation of San Jose, Calif., plans to use equipment on site to provide electrical power and chilled water much more reliably than utilities can provide.
Late last year, Prince William County sold 17.7 acres to Covad Communications, a leading provider of broadband DSL communications services, for $1.17 million so that it could build a 100,000-square-foot network operations center and a technical support facility. The center opened in September.
The county, which acquired 529 acres four years ago to promote economic development, is negotiating the sale of 155 acres to Gilbane Properties, a Providence, R.I., developer for $7.8 million. Gilbane has promised to begin at once to build a speculative building on the property that could be used for office or industrial uses.

HEADLINE: Impoverished Russians

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The United States government cannot pass the buck by asserting that Russia's post-Communist economic debacle is due mostly to that country's "failure to embrace change" (news article, Nov. 2). 
 If this charge is applied to the ordinary citizens of Russia, why should one expect them to embrace a system of shock therapy that has resulted in hyperinflation and virtually wiped out the life savings of millions? Why should they embrace a system that took economic power and control out of the hands of their government and gave it to a small handful of private individuals -- many of them with strong ties to the old government?
Had Boris N. Yeltsin allowed a truly democratic system to emerge -- and had Washington insisted that he do so -- the story might have been different for Russia's now impoverished people.
 
CRAIG BUTLER
Executive Director, Fund
for New Priorities in America
New York, Nov. 2, 2000

HEADLINE: Mideast Democracy

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In their attempt to show inter-Arab solidarity by reopening ties with Saddam Hussein (front page, Nov. 1), Arab intellectuals highlight deficiencies in their own governments.
You quote a Cairo lawyer, Muhammed Monieb, as asserting that rapprochement with Iraq demonstrates support for Palestinians and opposition to Israel. "All Arab regimes are dictatorships," he said. "If the Americans consider Saddam a dictator, then let them tell us who is not a dictator in the region." 
 There is one country in the Middle East region that is not a dictatorship, one country that shares American values of democracy and freedom. That country is Israel.
If he gave some thought to the matter, Mr. Monieb might realize why America supports Israel so staunchly and why Arab citizens might be wiser to protest their home-grown dictatorships rather than rail against the only democracy in their midst.
 
AARON DALTON
New York, Nov. 1, 2000

HEADLINE: New Economy;
As Internet stocks fell, other emerging technology issues suffered with them.

BYLINE: By Alex Berenson 

 BODY:
THEY began going public several years ago, promising to use exciting new technology to revolutionize the way people around the world live and work. Though they were rarely profitable and many barely had sales, their potential captivated investors. As their stocks soared, analysts and commentators offered ever more grandiose predictions of the companies' impact, and investment bankers rushed to take more and more of them public.
By the peak of the frenzy earlier this year, many carried multibillion-dollar market valuations. Then the boom ended. In a matter of months, the stocks plunged by half or two-thirds from their highs. Some have fallen even further, leaving unwary or overly enthusiastic investors with near-total losses. 
 And no, they are not Internet companies.
Amid the meltdown of Net stocks, less noticed has been the fact that investors have also fled former highfliers in other emerging industries, ranging from alternative energy and fuel cell developers like Plug Power to second- and third-tier biotechnology and genomics companies like SuperGen and Axys Pharmaceuticals.
These are what Wall Street calls "concept stocks," and they have had a very bad year. Plug Power, for example, has fallen to $23.63 from its January peak of $156.50, an 85 percent drop that has cost its shareholders $6 billion. SuperGen has lost about three-quarters of its value in eight months, sliding from $77.31, to $19.38.
The boom and bust was inevitable, said Roger McNamee, general partner of Integral Capital Partners, a Menlo Park, Calif., money management firm that invests in public and private companies. "Every major economic wave in the United States has been driven by financial mania," Mr. McNamee said.
After watching information technology companies like Cisco Systems and Dell Computer grow seemingly overnight from fledgling start-ups to hugely profitable corporate giants, by the late 1990's investors were clamoring for the chance to buy shares in all sorts of extremely young companies with novel technologies -- the kind of businesses that in less giddy times had relied solely on venture capitalists for financing.
Investment banks were more than willing to indulge them, selling shares in ever weaker and younger companies as the decade progressed. The performance last year of Internet stocks like Amazon.com, whose share price soared as investors focused on the company's growing customer base and disregarded its growing losses, only furthered the frenzy, said Ken Pearlman, director of research for Firsthand Funds, a $6.5 billion mutual fund company in San Jose, Calif.
With Internet stocks rising despite big losses, investors and analysts in other emerging, technology-driven industries began to believe that their stocks should also be valued on hypothetical measures like ultimate market size, rather than on the basis of more traditional measures like price-earnings or price-sales ratios.
Speculative bubbles are most often the result of efforts to measure the unmeasurable, according to Mr. Pearlman. "When you're talking about a concept, your mind is free to go wherever you want," he said. "And so are the valuations."
Now those investors have had to face the truth, long known to venture capitalists, that big returns do not come without big risks and that most young companies fail, said John P. Whaley, a partner at Norwest Venture Partners, which manages $1.2 billion. "Before the last nine months, the market had been generous to virtually every company that had a strategy that led to a big market," Mr. Whaley said. "Now the market is more discriminating."
Inevitably, this year's sell-off has led to hand wringing about the proper role of the public markets in financing young companies and complaints that investment bankers and greedy venture capitalists took advantage of naive public investors.
"A lot of the ideas that were being floated were a lot of vapor and not a lot of substance," said Michelle Clayman, chief investment officer of New Amsterdam Partners, which manages $1.1 billion. "We did get into a speculative frenzy."
But Mr. Whaley and other venture capitalists say the truth is more complicated. Despite the frenzy, some of the concept stocks have remained good investments, at least for the people who bought early. Among Internet plays, Yahoo was losing money and had only $1.4 million in trailing annual revenue when the Web site company went public in 1996. Investors who bought it then have seen their investment increase 68-fold -- despite the 72 percent drop in Yahoo's share price since its January peak. In biotechnology, stock in Affymetrix, which makes chips that are used to analyze genes, has risen elevenfold since its 1996 initial public offering, even though it is still unprofitable. Compared with that of Yahoo, Affymetrix's performance may seem downright mediocre. But in the past, elevenfold returns were available only to venture capitalists who could buy into in companies before they went public.
"Why should just the private venture capitalists just have access to those growing companies?" Mr. Whaley said. "On the other hand, you're asking the public market to take risks that it perhaps doesn't know it's taking."
Steve Lazarus, general partner of ARCH Venture Partners, is one who argues that investors should be free to make their own mistakes. "I don't worry about setting up rules of behavior for the public marketplace," Mr. Lazarus said.
Now, some of the non-Internet concept stocks have fallen so far that they may actually be ripe for a second look, Mr. Pearlman said. "The pendulum has swung pretty far over," he said. "I suspect people are going to come back to them in a quarter or two and value them again."

HEADLINE: MediaTalk;
Paper Delays Publication of Critic's Column

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
Walter Mossberg, The Wall Street Journal's protean critic of the new economy's tools and toys, did not like the device that a Dallas concern, DigitalConvergence, rolled out this fall. Called CueCat, it plugs into an armchair shopper's computer. When the shopper moves the "cat's" nose across bar codes in a catalog or an advertisement, relevant Web pages pop up on the screen.
Mr. Mossberg's column panning the gizmo on Oct. 12 began: "Just because technology makes something possible, that doesn't automatically mean it's beneficial or convenient for people to use." 
 A week or so later, Mr. Mossberg found out that just because The Providence Journal usually features his columns promptly and prominently on Sundays did not mean it was rushing into print with this one. The article has yet to appear in Providence. The Dallas Observer, a weekly newspaper, pointed out that Belo -- The Providence Journal's parent -- is backing the device. Belo has spent $4.4 million promoting CueCat and related products, according to its last earnings release.
Mr. Mossberg said his columns usually run in The Providence Journal -- his hometown paper -- without incident. He was surprised, he said, because the paper always had "a strong separation of its news decisions from its business interests."
Joel P. Rawson, The Providence Journal's executive editor, first declined to discuss his decision to hold the column. In a second interview, he said he planned to publish it -- and other reviews -- when distribution of CueCats in the area begins on Nov. 12. FELICITY BARRINGER

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Omnicom wins advertising's big race by gaining the consolidated account of the Chrysler Group.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
THE Madison Avenue version of Election Day came four days before the real thing when the Chrysler Group ended a closely fought, two-month battle for its massive consolidated account by choosing the Omnicom Group in New York over True North Communications in Chicago.
The decision, made late on Friday, created what is probably the world's biggest single automotive assignment, with estimated total billings of $1.8 billion; though spending by the Chrysler Group's competitors is larger, it is divided among various agencies. For Omnicom, it is a major vote of confidence in an agency company that is already one of the industry's Big Three in revenue and billings. For True North, smaller than Omnicom on both those measures, it is a serious setback that will wipe out $140 million, or 9 percent of revenue, and up to 15 percent of earnings. 
 "Psychologically, it's huge for Omnicom," said Lauren Rich Fine, an analyst for Merrill Lynch who follows the advertising industry. "For True North, it's a genuine economic loss."
Indeed, David Bell, chairman and chief executive at True North, has scheduled a conference call for this morning with investors and analysts to reassure them that it will not be devastated by the departure of its largest domestic client, despite a projection that earnings per share for 2001 will fall 15 cents to 22 cents below previous estimates of $2.41.
"Our management has met such challenges before," Mr. Bell said in a statement.
For instance, "we will move swiftly in pursuing a new automotive account," he added, because "we are confident that there will be opportunities opening up in the marketplace." That was an allusion to reports in trade publications that auto makers like Toyota might be considering changing agencies.
Mr. Bell's statement was released after executives of the Chrysler Group, part of DaimlerChrysler A. G., told him on Friday afternoon that the True North incumbent agency, FCB Worldwide in Southfield, had lost out in the consolidation to two Omnicom agencies, the BBDO Detroit office of BBDO Worldwide and PentaCom in Troy, Mich.
FCB has created corporate campaigns for the Chrysler Group as well as ads for the Chrysler, Jeep and Plymouth vehicle brands and dealers. FCB and predecessor agencies handled those tasks for the auto maker and its predecessor, the Chrysler Corporation, since 1979. BBDO has created campaigns for Dodge products and dealers from 1960 to 1979 and then from 1982 onward. PentaCom has handled media buying since 1992.
"If I were True North, I'd think of it not as a lost account but as an open category," said Alan J. Gottesman, who follows agency performance as managing director at West End Communications/Consulting. "To protect profitability, they either have to replace this or retrench."
There is another alternative.
Michael J. Russell Jr., advertising analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, "Some investors may look at this as an opportunity to talk about strategic issues," said Michael J. Russell Jr., advertising analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, because True North's big advertising agency "now is without an automotive conflict."
Translation: Losing the Chrysler Group as a client makes True North more likely to be acquired by or merge with a rival like the Interpublic Group of Companies or the Publicis Groupe.
"Maurice is waiting for an invitation," Ms. Fine said, laughing, of Maurice Levy, chairman and chief executive at Publicis, which is the biggest True North shareholder.
During the review pitting Omnicom against True North, which the Chrysler Group attributed to a need to cut costs after reporting its first quarterly loss in nine years, the two agency companies spoke about sharing the consolidated assignment or merging. Nothing, however, came of those discussions.
"I'm delighted at the decision," John D. Wren, president and chief executive at Omnicom, said in a telephone interview after being told by Chrysler Group executives on Friday that his agency company had prevailed in the review.
"It's a confirmation of a trend going on for some time," he added, "where the big are able to bring benefits to their clients in a complicated, competitive world where they need to streamline the way they articulate their objectives."
Omnicom is ranked No. 2 in revenue among agency companies, behind the WPP Group, and No. 3 in billings behind WPP and Interpublic. True North is ninth in revenue and eighth in billings.
"We did look at the whole Omnicom picture," said Arthur C. Liebler, senior vice president for marketing at the Chrysler Group in Auburn Hills, Mich. "I think there was an edge on that side."
The size of Omnicom and its other assignments from DaimlerChrysler, like customer relationship marketing for the Chrysler Group, were "very important to us," he added, particularly "in thinking where do you want to be down the road, 5 years from now, 10 years from now."
To handle the consolidated assignments, Omnicom will form an agency named PentaMark Worldwide, incorporating the BBDO Detroit and PentaCom operations along with, at Mr. Liebler's request, "much of the top talent" of FCB Detroit.
In a nontraditional step, the Chrysler Group will have a representative on the PentaMark board. Mr. Liebler told both agency companies that the winner of the review would be asked to provide such a board seat.
Or in other words, no consolidation without representation.
"In many respects, it's a new paradigm," said Allen Rosenshine, chairman and chief executive at BBDO Worldwide, who spoke after learning of the Omnicom selection.
While Mr. Rosenshine declined to discuss what specifically made the Omnicom proposals preferable to True North's, he acknowledged that "the depth of Omnicom resources certainly played a role."

HEADLINE: Patents;
As the scooter market grows crowded, Razor USA sues 16 rivals for patent infringement.

BYLINE: By Sabra Chartrand; Patents may be viewed on the Web at www.uspto.gov or may be ordered through the mail, by patent number, for $3 from the Patent and Trademark Office, Washington, D.C. 20231.

 BODY:
A YEAR ago, a scooter was probably a clunky, red steel icon from a bygone era. By last spring, though, streets, sidewalks and parks across the country suddenly teemed with adults and children whizzing along on sleek, aluminum scooters with brightly colored rubber wheels.
Retailers seized on the craze, and scooters went on sale in sports equipment and department stores, toy and gift stores, catalogs and then even drug stores, minimarts and coffee bars under names like Razor, Oxygen, Stinger, Street Glide, Kickin' Mini and Rush Rider. 
 The Razor started the trend, and last week the company that sells that brand announced that it now owns a patent for its brake design. With that in hand, Razor USA immediately filed a lawsuit charging 16 competitors with infringement. The president of Razor USA, Carlton Calvin, says dozens of companies copied the Razor design in a rush to exploit the fad.
"The patent is on the brake, and the reason it is important is because the people who came to market so quickly after we became popular didn't have time to design their own product," Mr. Calvin explained last week. None of the companies had yet responded to the suit, which was filed on Thursday in California and demands that the defendants stop manufacturing or selling the scooters, Mr. Calvin said. His company had not yet decided whether it would license the patent to anyone else.
"This is just the beginning," Mr. Calvin said. "There may be as many as 50 other infringers. We tried to go after the infringers we felt were the most significant, but as we track others down, we'll try to stop them, too."
The intellectual property world has changed greatly in recent years, with intellectual property increasingly valued as intangible wealth, with the importance of software and computer patents to the new economy, and amid controversies over business-method and biotechnology patents.
But the scooter phenomenon is a reminder that an inventor with a good idea that captures the public's fancy can claim tremendous profits with a conventional patent for a simple mechanical device.
Razor USA represents the JD Corporation, the Taiwanese company that manufactures the scooters. It makes three models, and new versions are planned for next year. Mr. Calvin estimated that about eight million of the collapsible, lightweight scooters have been sold since last November, and he said five million Razor scooters will have been sold by the end of this year.
As with any consumer frenzy, the scooter fad might fizzle as quickly as it erupted. Mr. Calvin said he believes that using a patent infringement lawsuit to shut down competitors will help prolong the popularity of the scooters.
"One thing that hurts the perception of the scooter as a serious product is if you go to your video store or neighborhood deli and can buy your scooter there," he explained. "And that's where a lot of the infringers are going."
"We don't think the popularity is going to die," he added. "There were 28 million active participants in in-line skating last year. That's 28 million pairs of skates. Only seven or eight million scooters have been sold, and it's easier than in-line skating. Hopefully, new products and enforcing the intellectual property will keep the market alive for longer."
A motorless scooter usually has two wheels and none of the gear or chain mechanisms found on a bicycle. Instead, a rider propels it by pushing with a foot -- hence the name "kick scooter." The modern aluminum model can be used like a skateboard, for jumping and performing stunts and trick landings.
Patents for scooters with two wheels date to the 1920's. In July of 1999, a California inventor name Juan Banda won patent 5,927,733 for a "folding, portable, nonmotorized two-wheel scooter." Mr. Banda's design uses a foot brake, too, but with a mechanical assembly that differs from the Razor design. His patent is cited in the patent that now belongs to Razor USA, meaning the patent examiner who approved the latter found it to be different from Mr. Banda's design.
The importers and distributors named in the Razor USA lawsuit are K2, Gen-X Sports, Asa Products, The Children's Place Retail Stores, H.L. USA, Kash 'n' Gold, Rapid Suspension Technology USA, Sun Rams Products, Titan, Todo Dollar Wholesale, Variflex, Wysco, Yunn Haaur Enterprises, Z Scooter, and Zenital.
The patent on which the lawsuit is based is 6,139,035 and was issued to Shui-Te Tsai, a Taiwanese inventor, who assigned it to Razor USA.
If scooters do continue to be popular, other inventors may earn a piece of the market with variations on the theme. Steven Patmont, who lives in Pleasanton, Calif., invented an all-terrain scooter. His design includes enlarged wheels that can roll on "off road" conditions like dirt, grass, trails or fields. The scooter would be sold with the "some assembly required" caveat, since the larger wheels must be shipped alongside the scooter to reduce the size of packaging. The consumer would attach them with bolts. Mr. Patmont received patent 6,012,539.
Robert Brock, who lives in Anchorage, last month won a patent for a scooter with a tow bar extending from its front. A tow rope can be fastened to the bar and attached in turn to one or more dogs. The tow bar is low enough on the frame to ensure that the scooter will remain upright and stable while being pulled. Though he calls his invention a "dog training and exercising device," Mr. Brock also suggests that the scooter chassis can be lengthened (with more wheels added) to carry loads, just like a dog sled. He received patent 6,135,059.

HEADLINE: The Cray Legacy: Taking A Turn Toward Complexity

BYLINE: By CHRIS GAITHER 

 BODY:
The final supercomputer designed by Seymour R. Cray will look nothing like a Seymour Cray supercomputer.
This week, SRC Computers, the company Mr. Cray founded months before his death in 1996, plans to introduce its first machine since the loss of the man known widely as the father of supercomputing. After years of secretive development, the SRC-6 will be shown in Dallas at SC2000, the high-performance computing industry's trade show. 
 Absent from the SRC-6, industry experts say, is the simple and elegant architecture of custom-designed and configured processors that was Mr. Cray's trademark. In its place is an idea billed by the company as a virtuoso designer's final revelation, the use of off-the-shelf microprocessors and widely used hardware to build very powerful computing machines.
"The legend does continue," Michael J. Henesey, vice president of marketing and sales, said in an interview last week. "You start to see some of the brilliance in some of the fundamental designs on the machine."
Despite the change in internal architecture, SRC Computers says the new approach provides the same result that won Mr. Cray so many accolades: a revolutionary computer that calculates with blazing speed. Industry experts are more cautious, awaiting the chance to perform benchmark tests.
The SRC-6, a black-and-red cabinet about the size of a commercial refrigerator, links as many as 512 Intel Pentium Xeon chips with a hardware technology called field programmable gate array, or F.P.G.A., a reconfigurable chip frequently used in consumer products like cellular phones and other products that need to be rushed to market quickly.
The use of F.P.G.A.'s is an innovation in high-performance computing, an industry that has seen a recent lull in innovative architecture, said Debra Goldfarb, vice president of worldwide systems and servers for International Data, a market research firm based in Framingham, Mass.
SRC Computers says the SRC-6 allows a user to completely change the machine's "'personality," or way it runs its calculations, based on the task. This permits the machine, for example, to race through weather calculations, then be reconfigured to model the flow of air over an automobile surface.
Mr. Cray began his career in the late 1950's as a young electrical engineer at Control Data Corporation, an early maker of computers, now defunct, in Minnesota. There he led the design of one of the early transistor-based computers, the first of many innovative technologies that the industry would later adopt.
He went on to start three companies: Cray Research, which became the world's leading maker of supercomputers, in 1972; Cray Computer Corporation, which ended in bankruptcy, in 1989; and SRC Computers in July 1996. Cray Research combined with Tera Computer Company to form Cray, Inc., based in Seattle.
Jack Dongarra, a professor of computer science at the University of Tennessee, said Mr. Cray's designs were noteworthy for their meticulous attention to the way data moves inside the computer, with an absence of unneeded delays.
"I don't see that in this design," Mr. Dongarra said. But he added, "This machine is a question mark."
Those who worked with Mr. Cray in his last years said the rapid technological improvement across the industry caused him to change his views on design. The low prices of off-the-shelf components persuaded Mr. Cray that he could design fast machines without spending time devising aesthetically elegant designs.
Mr. Cray founded SRC Computers in July 1996 and assembled a team to put his concept of reconfigurable hardware into practice. The company's dreams were shattered in October of that year, when, at the age of 71, Mr. Cray died of injuries he received in an automobile wreck.
"It's like losing Michael Jordan on the Chicago Bulls," said Steven J. Wallach, an industry pioneer who is the keynote speaker at SC2000. "You can't replace Seymour Cray."
After a short debate on whether to continue with Mr. Cray's dream, a small group of executives ran daily operations while the 10-person design team labored on development.
After the SRC-6's unveiling, Mr. Cray's legacy will be tested in the marketplace. The company he left behind will go to research institutions, governmental agencies and the commercial market to sell them on Mr. Cray's last design.
"We believe this is the way all computer architectures will be working in the next century," Mr. Henesey said.

HEADLINE: Ex-Rival Helps Microsoft Find Wireless Future

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: REDMOND, Wash.

 BODY:
Much has been written about Microsoft's brain drain and the continuing string of newly minted multimillionaires leaving for early retirement.
So how to explain Dick Brass, who made millions during a decade at the Oracle Corporation and made even more as an early investor in the wireless company Omnipoint? 
 As others were cashing out of Microsoft, Mr. Brass came to work for the software publisher three years ago, in order to pursue his personal mission of introducing the world to a new kind of computer: a fully powered Windows "tablet," unfettered by keyboard or cables, that would always be with its owner, always turned on and always wirelessly connected to the Internet.
Mr. Brass is all the more anomalous in Microsoft's hothouse hacker's culture, because he is probably known more for his love of good food and wine and his passion for yachting than for his technical accomplishments. And yet Mr. Brass, who also has a well-known flair for hyperbole and was once the speech writer for Oracle's colorful and occasionally outrageous chairman, Lawrence J. Ellison, may be the best evidence that Microsoft is in the midst of a fundamental cultural shift, even as lawyers appeal the antitrust verdict that would break up the company.
Mr. Brass's supporters say the 47-year old former New York Daily News reporter and editor has the vision and leadership the company badly needs as it searches for new directions, now that Microsoft's chairman, William H. Gates, has turned over the day-to-day running of the company to Steven A. Ballmer.
Certainly, in a relatively short period Mr. Brass has made his mark here as Microsoft's impresario of electronic books.
But the e-book is just a small part of a bigger idea -- tablet computing -- that Mr. Brass predicts will extend the personal computer to the 50 percent of the population that does not use a PC today. Just two weeks after he came to Microsoft to work on electronic books in 1997, he was able to convince Mr. Gates of the importance of his idea after showing him an ultra-slim wooden model of the dream machine that had been put together by a cabinet maker who had worked on Mr. Brass's yacht.
Three years later, Mr. Brass runs four product development teams comprising almost 400 employees, including those doing research in handwriting recognition and computer systems for use in automobiles.
On Nov. 12, Mr. Brass's role in the company should become much more publicly visible when he joins Mr. Gates at the Comdex computer show in Las Vegas, where Mr. Gates plans to give the first detailed demonstration of the tablet computer still under development by almost almost 100 designers on Mr. Brass's team.
The tablet computer is one of the best examples of Microsoft's multibillion dollar effort to reinvent itself for the presumed post-PC era.
And Mr. Brass, the project's evangelist, has already traveled the globe spreading the word. In October, he even went to the Vatican for a joint news conference on the future of electronic books, an effort on which the company and the Vatican plan to cooperate.
"This is not a crass attempt to get people to buy gizmos they don't need," he said in an interview. "I truly believe that a tablet computer will have a profound impact on the world." Among other impacts, he predicts that The New York Times will publish its last version on paper in 2018.
In Mr. Brass's view of the new information-centric world, tablet computing is the Next Big Thing. But it is also a huge gamble. Sought by many in the computer industry over the last three decades, tablet computing has already been a Waterloo for some of the best and brightest minds in Silicon Valley.
Beginning with the Dynabook proposed in 1971 by the Xerox PARC computer scientist Alan Kay, the idea has died aborning many times and has led to some of the Valley's most celebrated failures -- most memorably in two abortive start-ups, the Dynabook Corporation and the Go Corporation, and the debacle of Apple Computer's notorious Newton.
Mr. Brass acknowledges the peril."We risk the same kind of boomerang that the Newton received when it debuted and championed its handwriting recognition and turned into a two-week hilarious run on Doonesbury," he said.
But there is no turning back, Mr. Brass said, citing plans to put commercial versions of Windows tablet computers on dealers' shelves in less than two years.
Microsoft is wagering that the time is finally right for a tablet computer in the form of an ultra slim slate the approximate size and thickness of a yellow notepad with an ultra-high resolution screen, an all-day battery and the ability to recognize handwriting -- all with a wireless, high-speed connection to the Internet.
Of course, not everyone is buying Microsoft's Next Big Vision.
"The problem with this is that it's still Windows," said Paul Saffo, a computer and publishing industry consultant. "It's like trying to put wings on a pig; you cannot mutate Windows to give a satisfactory experience in hand-helds or tablets."
While begging to differ, Mr. Brass says that however long it takes to reach tablet computing's promised land, it is a journey he has been on for years. In 1979, while he was a features editor for The Daily News of New York, it dawned on him while writing at his computer terminal one day that it might be possible to turn a thesaurus into a computerized reference.
He did just that and today is still credited as the inventor of the first electronic thesaurus and first dictionary-based spelling checker software. The resulting company, Dictronics, which placed various reference works in a form for use on PC's, was acquired by Wang Laboratories in 1983. "I'm a one-trick pony," he said. "I've been trying to turn books into software since 1981."
Born in Brooklyn, and raised in the affluent New York suburb of Scarsdale, he evinces a streetwise style that has more in common with New York's garment district (his father, Sanford Brass, was one of the inventors of Supp-Hose hosiery) than with Silicon Valley's world of software and hardware engineers.
While Mr. Brass's business timing has usually been good, he has also been luckier than most. In 1989 he bought a Macintosh computer for his friend Doug Smith, so that Mr. Smith could produce a proper business plan for his new venture, Omnipoint, a wireless telephone network that was eventually acquired by VoiceStream for $2 billion. Because he was given a 1 percent stake in Omnipoint in exchange for the Macintosh, the favor made Mr. Brass a millionaire many times over.
He has also had his setbacks, though. He moved to Seattle in the mid-1980's with a friend, the late technology writer Cary Lu, to start a company called General Information, which created the first PC-based phone directories. It was an idea that would blossom a decade later, but General Information was ahead of its time and the two men were eventually forced to sell the company without a profit.
Ever intrepid, Mr. Brass was hired in 1989 by the software giant Oracle after persuading Mr. Ellison that there was money to be made from broadcasting the content of newspapers to PC's. Because Oracle was soon brought to near-death by accounting missteps and a wrenching revamping of the company, Mr. Brass's ideas were put permanently on a back burner.
But Mr. Brass stayed on at Oracle for eight years, as senior vice president of corporate affairs, involved in strategy and writing speeches for Mr. Ellison -- who is known for having publicly taunted Mr. Gates. In one speech at a computer conference with Mr. Gates in the audience, for example, Mr. Ellison vowed to buy a surplus Russian fighter jet and fly it over Lake Washington -- the setting of Mr. Gates's waterfront mansion.
Mr. Brass even acknowledges being an accomplice to the group of Silicon Valley executives that worked behind the scenes to help persuade the Justice Department to bring its antitrust suit against Microsoft. In this context, Mr. Brass's move from Mr. Ellison's inner circle at Oracle to Mr. Gates's at Microsoft was a change of allegiance worthy of the novel "Shogun."
In that capacity, Mr. Brass has churned the waters in the traditional paper-based publishing industry. A few months ago, he stood before a room of executives from the paper-making industry, whose jobs he predicted would be made obsolete by e-books and tablet computers, and said, "I see dead men everywhere."
 Mr. Brass has converted at least one former critic -- his wife, Regina Dwyer. Ms. Dwyer, a physician, said she, too, had been skeptical about electronic publishing but had a change of heart earlier this year on a cross-country flight, during which she read Jack London's "Call of the Wild," on a Hewlett-Packard Jornada hand-held computer that was running the Reader software Mr. Brass's team had developed.
"I realized I had forgotten that I was reading on a display," she said.
