SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1462 words

HEADLINE: Fissures in Sunday Papers' Pot of Gold

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
During the first years of the long, slow slide in daily newspaper circulation, Sunday newspapers were the industry's hope and consolation. Weighing as much as a small stack of two-by-fours, filled with enough discount coupons to wallpaper a room and enough sections to keep a reader curled up for hours, they kept on selling.
Imagine, then, how top newspaper executives felt when these behemoths, which account for 40 percent or more of the industry's total revenue, began to lose their appeal. Circulation reached its most recent peak of 62.6 million in 1993. Six years later, Sunday circulation was down 2.7 million copies, or 4.2 percent. 
 While that decline is far less steep than the drop in weekday newspaper circulation -- down 11 percent from a 1987 peak of 62.8 million -- Sunday papers were the industry's safety net, scooping up advertisers and readers that seemed lost to the daily papers. Now, the net is fraying.
As Gary B. Pruitt, chief executive of the McClatchy newspapers, put it, "the loss of a Sunday reader has a disproportionate impact." John Murray, vice president for circulation marketing at the Newspaper Association of America, said, "Losing a Sunday sale is a bigger loss than any single day, and in some cases than all six other days put together."
So what is happening? Industry executives are not sure; they are looking at the usual suspects blamed for daily circulation troubles -- television, the Internet, lives overflowing with long commutes, undone laundry and children's soccer tournaments.
Then there are changes that hit Sundays harder, like the substitution of multiple three-day weekends for the old two- or three-week vacation, so people are not around on Sundays to buy the paper. Or, perversely, the introduction of color and multiple sections in the daily paper, which makes its Sunday sister seem less distinctive.
The explanations are anecdotal; the threat is real. In recent financial quarters, as advertising rose to flood tide levels, the circulation decline had no palpable effect on revenue. But newsprint prices increased this summer, and Wall Street has grown increasingly bearish on the industry. Problems like Sunday circulation are moving to the front burner.
One option that advertisers support is supplementing circulation data with new data on readership. A spokeswoman for the Gannett Company, Tara Connell, said that even if circulation is declining, the number of readers may increase as copies are shared with family members and friends. "Some of the trends that seem disheartening aren't so disheartening," Ms. Connell said. "People are passing newspapers along, particularly on Sunday."
The most vulnerable element of Sunday circulation is the newsstand copy. Like daily papers, Sunday editions are sold two ways: by subscription, and copy by copy from news boxes, newsstands and grocery stores. Since the greatest drop-off is coming in single-copy sales in many markets, more and more executives are focusing on that issue.
William P. Johnson, circulation marketing chief at the Newspaper Association of America, said, "Grocery stores are basically newspapers' highest sellers of single copies." To stimulate business, he said, "you can sell the $1.50 newspaper for 99 cents."
Another worry is the chronology of Sunday readers. The median age of people who read the papers regularly in a recent survey was 50.8, and 44 percent listed themselves as unemployed -- a group including many retirees. In addition, demographic trends make it clear that women -- 54 percent of regular Sunday readers -- have less time for anything, newspapers included.
In some markets, the Sunday declines are stark. Over the last decade, The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette's Sunday circulation dropped by 142,000 copies, or 25.6 percent; The San Francisco Examiner & Chronicle's by 160,000 copies, or 22.4 percent; The Philadelphia Inquirer's by 180,000 copies, or 18.4 percent.
Bitter strikes and aggressive rivals helped decrease Sunday circulation at The Daily News in New York and at The Detroit News and Free Press by about 40 percent, for a combined loss of more than a million Sunday papers in the two cities.
Right now, a major project studying the declines, both daily and Sunday, is under way at Northwestern University's Media Management Center. A consultant's report on Sunday circulation was a major item at the last annual meeting of the Newspaper Association of America.
Sometimes, lower circulation is intentional. Mike Huot, The Courier-Journal's circulation manager for the last two years, said the newspaper continues to pull back on money-losing circulation in distant parts of Kentucky, staying closer to its core market in the Louisville area. "We just pulled out of 70 communities," he said, adding that, while overall Sunday circulation is down, it inching upward around Louisville.
But for how long? Tim McWilliams, 46, is the owner of Mission Data, a Web development company. He gave up the daily Courier-Journal a decade or more ago, he said, but still reads the paper on Sunday. So does his wife, Ann.
Would they give it up? "This is going to sound terrible," Mr. McWilliams said, "but if it didn't have the TV listings, I'd say, 'Just cancel it.' I can get the news via either radio or TV or the Internet."
For Mr. Huot, the McWilliamses matter. They are an audience that Sears, or the local drugstore or supermarket, would want: homeowners, small-business people with an anchor in the new economy. To attract other busy people who have news alternatives, Mr. Huot thinks he may have to re-emphasize Sunday-only marketing, which had fallen out of favor.
"There's been a shift from thinking that we ought to be selling seven days." he said. "As a result, we may have neglected some of the people who don't have the commitment -- don't want to read seven days."
For advertisers, particularly big retailers, the Sunday trends are a significant concern. While newspaper circulation may decline, newspaper advertising rates rarely follow suit. So some big retailers are letting it be known that while they love newspapers, they could develop an affection for direct mail or smaller daily or weekly papers.
"The loss of the Sunday reader impacts us to the greatest extent," said Terry Prill, who holds the job of newspaper strategist at the Minneapolis-based Target Corporation, owner of major retail stores that sell everything from jeans to cameras to holiday lights. "For our urban stores, we do some midweek inserts," she said, but then added, "Sunday is still where we have a lot of our newspaper advertising."
The corporation, with 1,023 stores in 45 states, loves Sunday papers for their reliable delivery schedules and sizable audiences. Of the hundreds of millions of dollars it spends on advertising annually, a large share goes to Sunday newspapers, which deliver glossy inserts beckoning consumers to stores full of discounted wares. But in 15 of the 21 major markets where Sunday newspapers carried ads for Target's merchandise, circulation has dropped. Sunday circulation for all 21 markets combined has fallen by at least 335,000 copies, or 1.6 percent, since 1996.
As a result, Ms. Prill said, Target and other big preprint advertisers are pushing for more analysis of newspaper readership. (The Newspaper Association, which has been refining these estimates for two years, now figures that each Sunday paper is read by more than two people.) "That is the more compelling information," Ms. Prill said. "We want to know if readers are homeowners; we want to know their ethnicity, their income, their age."
So far, Target has only dabbled in direct mail, but Ms. Prill rules nothing out. Matthew Spahn, director of media planning for Sears, Roebuck, said his company had recently abandoned Sunday inserts in two major markets in the West and Midwest, because ad rates climbed too high while circulation fell too low.
The Newspaper Association, ever upbeat, takes note of the success stories. Among them is the McClatchy Company's Sacramento Bee, in one of Northern California's fast-growing markets, where Sunday circulation is up 7.3 percent, or 24,000 copies, over the last decade.
Mr. Pruitt, the McClatchy chief executive, whose company makes circulation gains a primary goal, said that focus creates "a constant feedback loop, based upon market studies and how we believe we can improve the paper."
For the industry as a whole, Mr. Pruitt said, declining Sunday circulation may be a piece of a more positive picture. In a world of media proliferation, the number of Sunday papers changes little. "The newspapers' saving grace," he said, "may be that they are not proliferating. We are maintaining a mass-market reach much better than our competitors."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: MONTANA;
In Montana, Watching to See If Independent Streak Is Fading

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: MISSOULA, Mont., Nov. 2

 BODY:
When Democrats dream of regaining control of the House and the Senate, their thoughts turn to Montana, a rugged, rural outpost of gun rights, individualism and a sizable disdain for government.
But does that make sense, betting on a state where Ross Perot won 26 percent of the vote in 1992 to help Bill Clinton narrowly defeat President George Bush, where Bob Dole beat President Clinton in 1996 and where polls showed that Vice President Al Gore has almost no chance of winning the state's three electoral votes? 
 Apparently so, judging by the tight race for Montana's open at-large seat in the House and the unexpectedly tense battle that Conrad Burns, a Republican, has encountered to win a third term in the Senate.
The latest statewide polls, conducted by Mason-Dixon Polling and Research, showed the Congressional races to be statistical dead heats even as Gov. George W. Bush of Texas nursed a comfortable lead.
In the race to succeed Representative Rick Hill, a Republican who is retiring, Nancy Keenan, a Democrat and the superintendent of public instruction, was virtually even with her Republican opponent, Dennis Rehberg, a former lieutenant governor. The poll showed that after trailing Mr. Burns by as many as 28 points, Brian Schweitzer, a Democrat, had almost completely closed the gap. In both races, the number of undecided voters was 10 percent.
"Montana is fiercely independent," Ms. Keenan said on Wednesday at a stop here, explaining how she, Mr. Schweitzer and Mr. Bush could all win on the same day. "Some people like to paint Montana as a Republican state. I paint it as a fiercely independent state. Rarely do coattails work here."
Mr. Rehberg echoed her assessment of voters, using the same phrase, "fiercely independent." But this year, the notion is compounded by the condition of the state's economy. According to figures from the state Department of Labor and Industry, Montana ranked 48th among the states in per-capita income in 1999, last in wages and tied with North Dakota for highest percentage of wage earners, 10.3 percent, holding more than one job.
As a result, political analysts here said that residents are angry and frustrated, so much so that they might be willing to vote in change for the sake of change in all major races, including the one for governor, which is also tight. With Marc Racicot, a Republican, barred from seeking a third term, the lieutenant governor, Judy Martz, and her Democratic challenger, Mark O'Keefe, are in a race considered too close to call.
But beyond that, the elections may offer a hint of whether Montana, for the time being, anyway, may be leaning more toward one political ideology or another.
"Historically, Montana has had some of the most two-party competition of any rural state," said Jim Lopach, a professor of political science at the University of Montana here. "But the big issue is whether we are becoming more like Idaho and Wyoming, which are conservative, or more like Oregon and Washington. These races could help answer that."
If Ms. Keenan wins, she would become only the second woman to represent Montana in Washington, following Jeannette Rankin, a Republican elected to the House in 1916 and 1940.
Ms. Keenan has pledged to improve the state economy and education, emphasizing that improvements in education would help attract new jobs and diversify a state dependent on natural-resource industries like timber and mining. She said the information superhighway passed right though Montana, "without enough exit ramps" to connect small businesses and help them cut through bureaucracy.
Mr. Rehberg, who ran unsuccessfully in 1996 against Montana's Democratic senator, Max Baucus, agreed that the state needed to diversify but not at the expense of its "old economy."
"We've turned our backs on natural resources before we've built the infrastructure to take advantage of the new economy" of technology-based jobs, he said. "We have to do both simultaneously by not overtaxing and not overregulating."
Pat Williams, a Democrat who held the House seat for 12 years through 1996 and now teaches environmental studies at the University of Montana, said the race could be decided by nothing more than Ms. Keenan's sex, an assessment reflecting another part of the culture. "I don't know if Montana men will vote for a woman," Mr. Williams said.
In the Senate race, Mr. Schweitzer, a rancher in his first run for office, has also used the flagging state economy to elicit support, saying Mr. Burns has not used his years in Washington to help the state.
"It's all about leadership," Mr. Schweitzer said before reciting the economic statistics that he repeats in campaign stops. "At least we're ahead of Guam."
Mr. Burns, who once promised to step down after two terms, said his poll numbers had slipped because of an onslaught of negative advertisements and out-of-state money helping his opponent.
He also disputed any suggestion that he had failed state residents, insisting that Montana ranks 15th among states in attracting high-technology jobs, an assertion the state labor department could not confirm. As chairman of the Senate telecommunications committee, he said, "I'm in a position to foster that growth."
Bowing to the slight lead that could make Mr. Burns a winner again, Mr. Williams said the senator reminded him of President Lyndon B. Johnson. "He wears a big hat and has dirt on his boots," he said. "That plays well in Montana."

HEADLINE: In America;
Why So Close?

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
The polls have told us little, and the pundits even less. Nobody knows anything.
For Democrats, the best part of the campaign has been George W. Bush's zany zigging and zagging among the land mines of the English language. 
 "They have miscalculated me as a leader," he says.
No doubt. But Mr. Bush's missteps with the language are about the only things that have been fun for Democrats in this campaign.
With the campaign in its final hours, Democrats are still wondering how a nation at peace and benefiting from the greatest economy in its history could consider deep-sixing a highly qualified vice president in favor of a man who frequently finds himself lost in the thickets of national policy.
Speaking last Thursday in St. Charles, Mo., Mr. Bush said of his plan to partially privatize Social Security: "This frightens some in Washington because they want the federal government controlling the Social Security like it's some kind of federal program."
Well, it sure is some kind of federal program. It's the one that put the skids to rampant poverty among the elderly.
The Times's Frank Bruni wrote: "For all the confidence and ebullience that he projected today, Mr. Bush at times seemed a bit scattered, and not only when he misstated the nature of Social Security in St. Charles. At the same event, he seemingly tried to say that prescription drug coverage would be an 'integral' part of his suggested overhaul of Medicare, but he came up with 'in-grit-able.' "
And yet the race is too close to call. Obviously there are many factors, including a weariness with all things Clinton and the media's relentless fascination with the trivial. But I think the main reason the election is close is that George Bush and the Republicans have done a much better job appealing to Republican voters than Al Gore and the Democrats have been able to do with their own unruly Democratic constituencies.
Forget all the chatter about education and prescription drugs and the finer points of a patients' bill of rights. For hard-core Republicans the big issues are the big tax cuts and the opportunity to raid Social Security, one of the Democratic Party's proudest achievements. George W. Bush has not wavered on those issues.
Meanwhile, the Democrats have refused to hammer home their best issue -- the economy; have downplayed their most progressive themes (the environment, to cite one example); have wallowed in their love-hate relationship with Bill Clinton; have flirted with Ralph Nader; and have taken every opportunity to rant about Al Gore's deficiencies as a candidate.
The campaign has been anything but coherent. Now, with the election just hours away and Mr. Bush a half-step ahead in most polls, there is dismay among the party faithful.
"I'm getting ulcers," said Lucille Moyers of San Jose, Calif., a Democrat who had considered voting for Mr. Nader. Now, with the possibility of a George W. Bush presidency staring her in the face, she has changed her mind.
"I'm amazed that Bush has gotten this far," said Ms. Moyers, who is 53 years old and has a 15-year-old son. "I am going to vote for Gore because I'm afraid of what will happen to the Supreme Court if Bush becomes president."
Al Gore was portrayed early on as a viciously partisan fighter, but his campaign was not like that at all. It was restrained. There never was a full-scale assault on the other side.
David McCullough, writing about Harry Truman's famous 1948 campaign, told how Truman traveled the country telling voters the Republicans were up to their old tricks, "trying to fool the people into voting for the interests of the few." Truman urged voters to remember "it wasn't the Republicans who pulled the country back on its feet." And he said the "real leaders" of the "do-nothing" 80th Congress had been "sent off into the bushes to hide until the campaign was over."
Al Gore may know something. Maybe the public really is tired of political conflict. Frightened Democrats may still turn out in droves. And maybe there is enough concern about Governor Bush's qualifications to shift this very close election to Mr. Gore.
Maybe. But it would have been fun to witness some of that old partisan fire.

HEADLINE: The Ambitions of Hugo Chavez

 BODY:
President Hugo Chavez of Venezuela clearly means to be an influential symbol of resistance to American influence, not just in Latin America but around the world. Whether he can succeed remains to be seen, though he is backed by one of the world's largest petroleum reserves at a time of high oil prices. Washington will have to watch him warily, though it should avoid unnecessary confrontations.
Since winning election to Venezuela's presidency nearly two years ago, the former paratrooper has quickly established himself as one of the more outspoken leaders of the developing world. At home, through a series of constitutional changes and national ballots, he has consolidated near-dictatorial power and now seeks authority to rule by decree. Abroad, he has helped revitalize the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries as a price-setting force, embraced Saddam Hussein and reached out to Marxist rebels in neighboring Colombia. He recently received Fidel Castro in Caracas and agreed to supply Cuba with subsidized oil in exchange for Cuba's dispatch of medical and other specialists to Venezuela. These are not constructive steps. But the rise of a demagogic leftist leader in Latin America need no longer be considered the threat it was during the cold war. 
 It is disturbing to see Mr. Chavez extend an economic lifeline to the Cuban dictatorship, particularly when so many Venezuelans remain mired in poverty. But concessionary oil sales are a familiar tradition in Latin America. Cuba, even with Venezuelan oil, presents little threat to the United States today. The spectacle of Mr. Castro and Mr. Chavez happily bantering in Caracas will not change that.
By reaching for a leadership role in OPEC, Mr. Chavez is clearly hoping to gain Washington's attention and respect. Certainly, prolonged high oil prices could weaken America's economy. But the real power in OPEC is Saudi Arabia, which, for its own reasons, responds positively to American requests to increase supply. Caracas and Washington both have a strong interest in continuing Venezuelan oil sales to the United States. America is by far Venezuela's biggest international customer.
Mr. Chavez's courtship of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, known as the FARC, has added an unhelpful new complication to Colombia's long and murderous civil war. He is unlikely to heed American advice on this issue. But other Latin American leaders, like Brazil's president, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, should urge Mr. Chavez to put his influence with the FARC to more positive use by encouraging it to take part in meaningful peace talks with the Colombian government.
Mr. Chavez's vague "Bolivarian" ideology -- inspired by the achievement of Venezuela's national liberator, Simon Bolivar, in briefly uniting present-day Venezuela, Colombia and Ecuador -- understandably worries neighboring governments. But Washington can reinforce the political stability of Venezuela's troubled Andean neighbors by helping them strengthen their judicial systems, combat official corruption and develop new export industries.
The biggest challenge to Mr. Chavez's grandiose ambitions lies at home. He has repeatedly promised to revive Venezuela's depressed economy and raise the depressed living standards of the country's poor majority. So far, even with this year's oil price windfall, he has not been able to deliver.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE HISPANIC VOTE;
Candidates Woo Latinos With Ads, but Not Policy

BYLINE: By JOHN W. FOUNTAIN 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Here in Little Village, a world away from the presidential campaign trail, Mexican music spilled from storefronts and passing cars. Young men up and down West 26th Street hawked sliced melon, pineapple and corn from stands in this working-class West Side neighborhood.
Ruben Gonzalez, 37, who owns Gonzalez Liquors, stood in his store as workers installed a shelf, his mind finally made up about the election. 
 "I really don't care for either candidate," Mr. Gonzalez said. "But I think Gore is more for the people. In the community, it's all working people. We've got to vote for him."
His wife, Danila Miranda, 31, is likely to vote for Vice President Al Gore too, but "not because of any campaigning."
"There really haven't been any discussions of any of the issues, no Latino issues, absolutely," she said. "It's a foreign election."
Despite intensive courting by Republicans and Democrats, many Hispanics to some degree feel left out in the cold, said Cecilia Munoz, vice president for policy of the National Council of La Raza, the nation's largest Hispanic civil rights group.
"We seem to have made one transition, which is that candidates get it, that they need to be campaigning in our community," Ms. Munoz said. "And that's been reflected in their use of the Spanish language and in the overall tone and tenor of the campaign, and in the extraordinary amount of marketing that is being aimed at our community."
But "for the most part, the focus has been on marketing and not on policy," Ms. Munoz said. "We would note that Latinos didn't come up in any of the presidential debates."
Among the major issues of concern for Latinos are education, employment, health care and immigration. While these issues may have been discussed by the presidential candidates, how their policies would specifically affect Hispanics was not addressed, some leaders contended.
"The major issue Latinos care about is education," said Rodolfo de la Garza, vice president of the Tomas Rivera Policy Institute at the University of Texas. "The next issue is the economy. On neither of those two major points has Bush come forward with positions that are addressing the Latino concern."
A year ago, the Latino vote was seen as a potential key to the presidential race, an increasingly energized constituency that would be courted by both camps. After millions of dollars in advertisements by the parties and a big voter registration campaign by Hispanic groups, the fruit of that labor finally will come to bear -- or not -- on Tuesday.
What is clear is that the number of Hispanics registered to vote has grown to an estimated 7.7 million, about 5.8 million of whom are projected to go to the polls on Tuesday. In 1996, 6.6 million Hispanics were registered to vote and 4.9 million of those voted, according to the William C. Velasquez Institute, a nonpartisan Hispanic research and public policy organization in San Antonio.
Also evident is that the wooing of Hispanic voters has heightened the attention paid to a community that has long felt overlooked. But some Hispanic leaders and residents say what they still lack as a potentially potent voting bloc is respect.
"I don't think either candidate has done enough" to earn the Latino vote, said Adolfo Aguilar, a spokesman for the Association of Hispanic Advertising Agencies. Last year, the agency started a $10 million advertising campaign to encourage Latinos to register and vote, he said.
"I hope we are not faced with another situation that no matter which candidate wins, that as soon as the election is over they kind of take a back seat and it loses its priority status that it seems to be receiving today," Mr. Aguilar said.
The number of Hispanics registered to vote nationally has increased 164 percent over the last 20 years, while voter turnout among Hispanics has grown 135 percent in the same period, said Juan Andrade Jr., president of the United States Hispanic Leadership Institute, a nonpartisan organization in Chicago that helps organize voter registration and get-out-the-vote campaigns.
In the next decade, Hispanics are expected to become the nation's largest minority group. This year, they represent about 6 percent of voters. With polls showing the presidential race as one of the tightest in years, a strong showing by Latino voters in states like California, and in New Mexico where they represent 40 percent of the state's voting-age population, could make the difference.
Over the weekend, Representative Luis V. Gutierrez, Democrat of Illinois, joined the former Housing Secretary Henry G. Cisneros and other Hispanic leaders on a tour across the country to help rally Latino voters.
On the Republican side, Gov. George W. Bush's use of Spanish while campaigning and the display of inclusiveness at the Republican National Convention last summer have at the very least won the respect of some Hispanics. But many say that did not overcome the ill feelings for Republicans, who are still seen by many Hispanics as being insensitive toward Latino immigrants.
Mr. de la Garza criticized the use of what he contends have been exclusively Spanish-speaking commercials on Spanish television and radio stations by the Bush campaign. He said it might be interpreted as an effort to appeal to Hispanic voters, but not at the expense of alienating his core constituency.
"The Bush people have long known that the way to reach Latino voters is in English," Mr. de la Garza said. "It's the immigrants who are Spanish dominant and who focus on Spanish language television. They can continue to make the symbolic claim of reaching out to Latinos, but substantively their natural constituency does not see it. So there's very little possibility of a backlash. If it's deliberate, it's a very sophisticated achievement."
Political observers say Mr. Gore will benefit from the tendency of Latinos to vote Democratic.
"What I have seen in surveys is simply the Latino electorate is one where Gore does get the benefit of being associated with Bill Clinton," said Antonio Gonzalez, president of the Velasquez Institute. "He gets some of that sheen on him because Latinos are just wild for Bill."
But there is support for Governor Bush among Hispanics who have found appeal in his message of "compassionate conservatism."
Elvis Garcia, 24, a senior in accounting at Robert Morris College in Chicago, plans to vote for Mr. Bush "not just because I'm a Republican."
"I like his proposal for tax cuts," he said, and his emphasis on less government. "I'm actually prideful that the guy is running for president and he is up there trying to speak Spanish. I like that."
In Little Village, at La Justicia Restaurant, Julio Martinez, 32, the owner, says he is looking forward to voting for Mr. Bush. But Mr. Martinez says he is sure his late father, who founded a chain of grocery stores, would not have approved.
"He's from the old school. He's always been Democratic," Mr. Martinez said. "He started from the bottom up. Me, I sort of grew up with a silver spoon in my mouth.
"When it comes down to the presidency, you don't go toward Democrat or Republican," Mr. Martinez said. "You go toward the one who is going to do the best job."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE DEMOCRATIC RUNNING MATE;
Lieberman Races to Energize Democrats in Swing States

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Making a last frenetic dash through Western swing states, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman worked today to motivate core Democratic voters to turn out on Tuesday, saying that every vote matters in a presidential race that is closer than any in a generation or more.
"I take it as an omen that fate has called me not just to worship, but to worship at a church called Victory," Mr. Lieberman, the Democratic vice-presidential nominee, told parishioners at Victory Missionary Baptist Church, one of two black congregations he addressed in this city. "It's a last lap around America, and with your help, the good Lord's help, for Al Gore and me it's going to be a victory lap." 
 Mr. Lieberman began the day in New Mexico, kicking off what was planned as an almost uninterrupted 36-hour final push. Next, he went to Nevada, then to Oregon and Washington to rally supporters in those states. Tonight, he was flying to Minnesota, then Wisconsin, Maine, New Hampshire and Pennsylvania by Monday night. Some of those states are commonly in play in presidential races, but it is a surprise that Democrats are still fighting for Washington, Oregon and Minnesota -- normally reliably Democratic -- on the campaign's final weekend.
Polls show all of the states Mr. Lieberman is scheduled to visit in his last swing, along with several others, to be in play just two days before the vote, evidence that the race is shaping up to be the closest since 1976, or even 1960. The candidates' chief mission now is to energize their most stalwart supporters and generate the highest possible turnouts in areas where they are strong.
"What is on the line is the future of America," Mr. Lieberman said here, to shouts of assent from the worshipers. "Prosperity is on the line. Jobs are on the line. A balanced budget is on the line. Education is on the line. One hundred thousand new teachers. Health care is on the line. Prescription drug help for seniors is on the line. A patients' bill of rights is on the line. The minimum wage is on the line. Affirmative action is on the line. And environmental protection is on the line."
In Albuquerque this morning, Mr. Lieberman visited two diners, hoping not only to persuade voters leaning toward Mr. Gore to go to the polls, but to close the sale with people who remain undecided. "We've got a plan to move the economy forward," Mr. Lieberman told David Mishler, 33, who was having breakfast with his 5-year-old son, Gabriel, in the Frontier Restaurant. "The other team would take us back to deficits, which won't be good for the economy."
Mr. Mishler said afterward that he was undecided, but that his conversation with the senator would "help me decide."
Minutes later, Mr. Lieberman implored Terry Latham, 45, and Ellen Rennard, 46, both teachers who said they were Gore supporters, to vote and to bring as many people with them as possible. "New Mexico is not a big state, but this thing is going to be so close," Mr. Lieberman said. "There are actually scenarios that people have written, that it could be tied in the Electoral College."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: VOICES ABROAD;
Other Nations Regard Campaign With Interest and Wonder

BYLINE: By WARREN HOGE 

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Lawn party guests at Murli Deora's bungalow feasted on spicy lamb and chicken dishes, curried fish, dal and freshly baked nan. Then Mr. Deora, a Bombay businessman and Congress Party leader, offered his guests comments on a faraway subject that has become daily domestic fare for people around the world.
"You wait and see," Mr. Deora said. "Bush will carry California." 
 At a time when the United States is considered the sole superpower, its economy the engine of international growth and its presidency an office with unchallenged influence on lives far beyond America's shores, people abroad are following the election with keen interest.
Satellite and cable television and the Internet have put people in touch with more details than ever about arcane mysteries like the role of the Electoral College, the importance of winning individual states and the participation of talk show hosts like Jay Leno and David Letterman, whose reputations are global.
"Suddenly we're talking about earth tones, alpha males and 'the kiss' instead of the Balkans," said Gordon Corera, the London-based American affairs analyst for the BBC. "These aren't words that are normally part of the British political vocabulary."
Along with the fascination, there is widespread concern -- and, even among aficionados, bewilderment -- over the American manner of choosing a chief executive. "For a European like me, it is rather like being a Christian at a bar mitzvah or the Jew at a Catholic confirmation," said Philip Stephens, a columnist for The Financial Times. "The narrative is straightforward enough. But you cannot quite share in the secret."
Some baffled foreigners wonder uneasily if Americans understand the consequences to the world.
"On Tuesday," noted the German daily Die Tageszeitung, "the most self-absorbed and least politically interested people in the world are going to elect the most important government in the world."
Pal Martins, a management consultant in Johannesburg who is a member of the African National Congress, said: "What worries me is that the American public is so politically naive. They fall for all the razzmatazz, and they vote for a candidate who is better looking!"
Standards of personal behavior, churchgoing habits, proof of faith and ease with talk show hosts do not figure in the public life of most countries. Issues like abortion that are central to American politics attract less attention abroad. At the same time, issues like executions, which provoke the most passionate opinions in countries like France, where Gov. George W. Bush is called "Mr. Death" in the news media, are not the pressure points for Americans.
The importance of personality politics is understood in Mexico, where a premium is put on good neighborliness and close cooperation. Mr. Bush is liked because of his Spanish-speaking ability and because the country's newly elected president, Vicente Fox Quesada, let it be known that he found his August visit with the governor more agreeable than his drop-in with Vice President Al Gore.
Elsewhere in Latin America, which has received little attention and still smarts over past instances of American highhandedness, there is also an appreciation for the election as beauty contest.
"For the majority of Brazilians, the leader of the United States is, above all, a celebrity," said Paulo Sotero, a writer in Sao Paulo. "He is noticed less for what he says or does than by the star quality his office affords him."
There is widespread dismay over the small role that foreign policy plays in the national debate. "Here you have the choice of the man to occupy the most powerful seat in the world, a 'president of the world' if you will, and the campaign doesn't seem to speak to that," said Gary L. McDowell, director of the Institute of United States Studies at the University of London.
Europeans are surprised that Mr. Bush is doing as well as he is, given his limited involvement with the world outside the United States.
"Whether in London or Berlin or Paris or wherever," said Anthony King, professor of government at Essex University, "you hear people say, 'We don't know anything about this fellow,' and the noises he makes are of a neo-isolationist character, and it is causing a lot of nervous apprehension in the political class. You get Gore, and you get somebody in direct line of succession from Dean Acheson, but you get Bush and you're not even in direct line to George Bush the first, who was so well networked and knew everyone on the international stage."
Professor McDowell said, however, that many Britons felt Mr. Bush was not the only candidate who had demeaned foreign affairs. "They think that Al Gore has reduced foreign policy to a 'who can name world leaders' and 'I bet you can't pronounce that name' kind of strutting," he said.
Mr. Stephens, the columnist, said the European experience with Ronald Reagan suggested a less patronizing attitude toward Mr. Bush. "Foreigners tended to make fun of Reagan, and as it turned out, cutting taxes and defeating Communism were pretty potent ideas," he said. "There is a lesson here. Anyone smart enough to get to the Oval Office is probably smart enough to serve as president."
While President Bush's experience can throw his son's limited firsthand knowledge of the world into embarrassing relief, it plays somewhat to the governor's advantage in places like China where the Bush name is associated with an interest in the region. The elder Mr. Bush was the American ambassador there, and Governor Bush spent six weeks visiting his father in 1975.
Outside of frequent trips to Mexico, Mr. Bush's only other overseas travels have been to an celebration in Gambia as his father's representative, to see a daughter in Italy and to tour the Middle East with other governors in 1998.
While Europeans generally follow American events closely, Russians, mired in their own woes and perhaps less willing to cede to America the title of sole superpower, are so uninterested that only two in five know who the candidates are, said Moscow's Public Opinion Foundation. Leonid Sedov, the foundation's head, attributed this to a shift in attitudes toward America. "We expect less, and therefore we have less disillusionment," Mr. Sedov said.
In India, where interest in the race is intense, Mr. Gore profits from his association with President Clinton, an immensely popular figure since his triumphant visit there in March, and Mr. Bush suffers from his identification with his father, whose administration was viewed as too friendly to the Pakistani military.
Center-left governments in Europe are pulling for Mr. Gore and wary of the consequences of a Bush victory. Anthony Howard, a public affairs broadcaster and writer, said the New Labor government of Prime Minister Tony Blair, in particular, would take a Gore loss very hard.
Foreigners' questioning of the way Americans choose their presidents is nothing new, said Professor McDowell of the University of London, and he pointed to a passage from an 1888 book, "The American Commonwealth," by James Bryce, a longtime British ambassador to Washington.
"Europeans often ask," Mr. Bryce wrote, "and Americans do not always explain, how it happens that this great office, the greatest in the world -- unless we accept the Papacy -- to which anyone can rise by his own merits is not more frequently filled by great and striking men."

LENGTH: 1921 words

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE POLLS;
Poll Shows Either Candidate Within Reach of Victory

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE and JANET ELDER 

 BODY:
The finish line is finally in sight, but Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush remain ensnarled in one of the closest presidential races in a century, according to the final New York Times / CBS News poll.
The poll suggested that the candidates were still struggling to lure a tiny pool of undecided voters. Among people likely to vote on Tuesday, Mr. Bush draws 46 percent, Mr. Gore 41 percent, Ralph Nader 5 percent and Patrick J. Buchanan 1 percent. While Mr. Bush's advantage is in itself statistically insignificant, it reflected an edge that he has maintained in this and most other national surveys. 
 But the national figures are only one gauge, because the outcome ultimately hinges on state-by-state contests. And the map is something of a jumble: it shows that either candidate is within reach of assembling the 270 electoral votes needed to win.
Beyond being so stubbornly close, the race has been extraordinarily fluid over the last month or so, with Mr. Bush and Mr. Gore trading places in many vital states, often within the margin of error. The numbers seem so mercurial that some analysts have begun referring to the Gallup Poll as the Nasdaq.
Several fresh polls yesterday did little to yank this race out of the nail-biter category. They suggested that while Mr. Bush held a slight edge, neither candidate was ahead in some of the most important states.
In Florida and Wisconsin, the margin was one percentage point. In Pennsylvania, it was two. It was dead even in New Mexico and Tennessee. Each candidate has far more votes in his strongest states than he needs to win the electoral votes in those states. For example, Mr. Bush leads by daunting margins in Texas, while Mr. Gore has impressive support in New York.
The national poll conducted by The Times and CBS News was of 1,356 registered voters, including 862 likely voters, and was taken Wednesday through Saturday. It has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Some internal findings in the survey give Mr. Gore less comfort than the overall horse race.
Mr. Gore's unfavorable rating has risen more briskly than Mr. Bush's since Labor Day. It now stands six points higher than Mr. Bush's, although neither candidate has been able to break through the 50 percent favorability mark. Sixty percent of respondents said Mr. Gore says what he thinks people want to hear, while only 48 percent said that of Mr. Bush.
And in another favorable sign for Mr. Bush, 59 percent of his backers described their support for him as "enthusiastic," while only 44 percent of Mr. Gore's supporters said the same about him.
Probably the biggest differences between the candidates, as indicated in the poll, is their divergent stands on issues. The most striking is on abortion. Nearly 6 in 10 voters said they thought Mr. Bush was unlikely to appoint Supreme Court justices who would vote to keep abortion legal. More than 7 in 10 said the opposite about Mr. Gore; they expected he would appoint judges who would support abortion rights.
Mr. Gore is seen as more likely than Mr. Bush to preserve Social Security. Both men are seen as equally likely to improve education. And while they are both seen as inclined to keep the economy strong, voters say they are more likely to think that of Mr. Gore.
Though neither candidate had particularly high favorability ratings, nearly two-thirds of registered voters said they were satisfied with their choice -- more so than they have been in the last three elections.
Satisfied or not, voters were overwhelmingly pessimistic about the likelihood that either candidate would accomplish much as president. They agreed that a president's efforts to deliver on promises were inevitably hamstrung by the whims and desires of Congress and special interest groups. Only 2 in 10 voters said they thought it was possible for presidents to fulfill their promises.
"I don't really listen to their promises, I think they're mostly hopes and dreams," said Kathryn Smelser, 51, a poll respondent from Visalia, Calif., who has yet to make up her mind. "I don't think they're going to keep their promises unless Congress wants them to."
While neither candidate has broken away with a lead, the poll did indicate that there have been some shifts in the underlying dynamics in the three weeks since the final debate. Mr. Gore has picked up support in the Midwest, which helps explain the tight race in several states there, while Mr. Bush is doing considerably better than he had been in Western states and among women.
Other national polls have also suggested that, at least at first blush, the revelation late last week that Mr. Bush had been arrested for driving while intoxicated in 1976 has not appeared to move voters.
Karl Rove, Mr. Bush's chief strategist, said the poll confirmed his belief that his side had a slim yet unmistakable edge. But he predicted a resounding victory for Mr. Bush.
"We're going to have a six- or seven-point victory and a substantial margin in the Electoral College of 320 votes or so," Mr. Rove said.
Although William M. Daley, the Gore campaign chairman, predicted a Democratic win, neither he nor his colleagues sounded quite as confident as Mr. Rove and his team -- or were as willing to suggest as large a margin of victory.
"I think we're somewhere around 290 in electoral votes," Mr. Daley said, "and in the popular vote, two and a half or three percentage points. I absolutely believe we're going to win. But I'm not going to spin you and say, 'it's done, it's over.' The Bush people are trying to build a little momentum by saying that."
Edward G. Rendell, the Democratic National Committee's general chairman, said of the outcome: "I think it's up for grabs. I don't think we're far enough ahead in Florida, Pennsylvania or Michigan to have nailed this down. But we're close."
If the race stays this close, it may be a long night on Tuesday for the ballot counters, not to say the candidates. It could be that any small factor could turn the election, from the weather in Minnesota cutting or increasing turnout to the final advertising flourish from Mr. Nader. While Mr. Nader's Green Party candidacy could cost Mr. Gore a victory in some states, Mr. Gore would not be ahead in the Times/CBS poll if Mr. Nader's support collapsed.
Another possibility is that one candidate will gain momentum in the closing 24 hours and claim a more decisive victory, as happened with Ronald Reagan in 1980, according to polls at the time.
The outcome may hinge on the verdict of an estimated 10 percent of likely voters who are still undecided. Almost half of them said they would probably not decide until Tuesday.
For all the attention these undecided voters have drawn, exit polls in past campaigns suggested that the proportion of these down-to-the-wire voters is no greater in this election. According to exit polls from the last three presidential elections, between 14 percent and 24 percent of voters have waited until the closing week -- if not the closing three days -- before making up their minds.
It could be that some of those undecided voters do not vote at all. Those who were sampled are more likely than other voters to say that it did not matter all that much who wins the presidency. When pressed, those undecided voters divide their support evenly between Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush.
In follow-up interviews yesterday, some voters confessed to having trouble deciding. "Neither of them have the vision of an Eisenhower or the fortitude of a Truman," said Dale Winblad, 57, a cabinet maker in Chicago. "It's going to be a crapshoot when I walk into the voting booth. I may even go the route of Ralph Nader."
Henrietta Hicks, 55, a correctional officer in Frankston, Tex., said: "This election is going to make a big change in everybody's lives. I think it's very important that people vote. I've talked to several people who have never voted in their lives, who decided to vote this year."
But for whom? "I probably won't know whom I'm voting for," Ms. Hicks said, "until I walk into the booth."
While the shadow of President Clinton has hung over the race, he does not seem to register much with voters. Only about 1 in 10 voters said they consider their vote to be one against Mr. Clinton, and more than two-thirds said their decision had nothing to do with their sentiments for the president.
Neither side said there seemed to be much fallout from the saturation coverage of Mr. Bush's arrest in 1976. Mr. Rove said his campaign conducted polls in Washington State and California to see if Mr. Bush was affected by the arrest and found that, if anything, news of the arrest emboldened Republicans who thought Democrats were using the matter as a tactic to damage his prospects.
"There's no evidence it had any effect except to intensify our side," Mr. Rove said.
Mr. Rendell countered, saying, "For the undecided voter, it just added another factor in the mix which makes them uncomfortable about whether this guy is really ready."
But he conceded that the Bush camp seemed more eager than his side to begin measuring for drapes in the Oval Office.
"They're awfully confident," Mr. Rendell said. "We're not doing what they're doing, we're not working on the transition. They must know something we don't."
 
How the Poll Was Conducted
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Wednesday through Saturday with 1,650 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 1,356 said they were registered to vote.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was randomly selected by a computer from a complete list of more than 42,000 active residential exchanges across the country.
Within each exchange, random digits were added to form a complete telephone number, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to geographic region, sex, race, age and education.
Some findings regarding voting are based on "likely voters," weighted to an overall probable electorate, which uses responses to questions dealing with voting history, attention to the campaign, and likelihood of voting in 2000 as a measure of the probability of the respondents' turning out on Election Day. The method assumes a turnout of approximately 50 percent tomorrow.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
For smaller subgroups the margin of sampling error is larger.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Variations in the wording and order of questions, for example, may lead to somewhat different results.
In a poll conducted just before an election, like this one, there are additional potential difficulties, like dramatic events or campaign appeals made by the candidates between the interviewing and Election Day, unusual patterns of voter turnout and the ultimate decisions made by those voters who said they were undecided or might change their mind or were supporting minor parties at the time of the poll.

INTERNATIONAL A3-16
 
C.I.A. Links in Arms Deal To Peru That Backfired
What seemed a modest arms deal last spring turned out to be anything but, as C.I.A. officials told the Clinton administration that they had discovered that thousands of rifles had gone not to Peru but to leftist guerrillas in Colombia, perhaps the most baneful of Washington's enemies in Latin America. The C.I.A. had given the green light to the sale. A3
 
Muted Hopes for Mideast Talks
The White House said the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, will meet separately with President Clinton in the coming days, but with Mr. Clinton by then a lame duck president, expectations were low that he can achieve much beyond trying to exercise a calming influence. A14 

Both Israeli and Palestinian leaders are facing sharp criticism from their own people as clashes continue, with two more Palestinians killed, bringing the total dead to at least 183. A14
 
Troubled Taiwan Leader
President Chen Shui-bian of Taiwan is mired in an ugly and divisive stalemate with his opposition parties, who freely talk about forcing him from office less than six months after he was inaugurated in Taiwan's first democratic transfer of power from the long-ruling Nationalists. A12
 
Sierra Leone Protesters Shot
United Nations peacekeepers and Sierra Leone police officers opened fire to disperse youths who were burning tires and demanding that a curfew be lifted, witnesses said. The government had imposed the curfew to prevent rebel attacks, but people were angry over a spate of armed robberies during curfew hours. A10
 
Passenger Flights in Iraq
Iraq sent domestic passenger flights into areas patrolled by American and British warplanes, challenging the no-flight zones it considers infringements on its sovereignty. A14

PUB-DATE: November 6, 2000

SECTION: Section A; Page 38; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 826 words

HEADLINE: Down to the Wire

 BODY:
The last day of the long presidential campaign brings an end to a remarkable journey for Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush. It also concludes, for the public, a compelling competition of ideas and personalities. A year ago, both men were aware of the tough challenge that awaited them in capturing the nomination, uniting their parties and slugging their way state by state through the fall. But few predicted that their fight would bring out so many ambivalent feelings among the voters, with so many states in contention at the end. A great deal depends now on the last-minute decisions of swing voters, the effectiveness of major drives to get out the vote, and the final barrage of slashing attack ads paid for by this election's record fund-raising.
The best election eve analyses show that for all the candidates' exhaustive crisscrossing of the nation, neither is ahead in enough states to assure a relaxed evening as they watch the electoral count. Mr. Bush seems to have sewn up most of the Sun Belt and Rocky Mountain West, while Mr. Gore leads in California, New York, New Jersey, Illinois and Pennsylvania. The surprise is that states that should have been part of each side's base are still in play. Mr. Bush has been forced to campaign in Florida, which his brother, Gov. Jeb Bush, was supposed to have no trouble delivering for him. Mr. Gore has had to spend precious time in a push in his own home state of Tennessee. 
 Turnout is being marshaled not only by party organizations, but also by like-minded groups like labor and women's organizations for the Democrats and pro-gun and right-to-life organizations for the Republicans. Get-out-the-vote drives are also considered decisive for toughly contested Senate races in New Jersey and in New York, where the campaign between Hillary Rodham Clinton and Representative Rick Lazio is filled with high-decibel exchanges. Mrs. Clinton, slightly ahead in the polls, has been campaigning with President Clinton in loyally Democratic parts of the state. That is a smart tactical move for her, just as Mr. Gore was smart to emphasize his determination to move out from the president's shadow by campaigning on his own.
One thing about this race has turned out to be depressingly predictable. It has demonstrated the need for the sweeping campaign finance reform that Mr. Gore has promised to deliver if elected. The amount of "soft money" -- the huge unregulated campaign donations raised from corporations, labor and wealthy individuals -- is coming in at more than $500 million this year, twice what was spent by the parties in 1996. Yesterday Senator John McCain estimated that the truly obscene sum of a billion dollars has been spent in this campaign on television ads. The money is so out-of-hand that even Republicans who oppose reform have been quoted as having second thoughts, since many of their Congressional candidates are being bombarded by unrestrained broadcast spending of the sort that the G.O.P. has favored in past contests.
Another reminder of the need for campaign reform came a month ago from the Committee for Economic Development, a business group favoring a cleanup of the system. The committee's recent survey of business leaders found that three out of five were resentful of being pressed to give campaign money in exchange for access and wanted a soft-money ban. The increasing feeling among businesspeople that they are victims of a shakedown scheme should embolden Mr. McCain and other reformers, who have already promised to make campaign reform a major early fight in the next Congress. On this, as on other policy issues, Mr. Gore has offered a clearer map of the policy he would pursue. That is a point that should not get obscured by the sheer drama of the contest.
To be sure, the race is so tight that some say it is possible for one candidate -- most likely Mr. Gore -- to lose the popular vote and win in the Electoral College. Three times in American history Democrats have won the popular vote but lost the presidency. The campaign in its final phase has provided a gripping horse race. Mr. Bush, with his energy and enthusiasm, continues to draw strength from the voters' view of him as a relatively straight talker. But as this page has argued in endorsing Mr. Gore, voters need to take a balanced look at the future of the economy, the fairness of the federal budget and the depth of the candidates' ideas for promoting social justice and for preserving a strong American role in the world. History teaches that confidence and a genial personality are assets for a president, but that there is no substitute for experience and knowledge in the fields of domestic policy and international diplomacy. These are the qualities by which presidents secure a brighter future for all citizens. If Americans dwell on the depth of Mr. Gore's preparation for the office he seeks, tomorrow should be a bright day for him and the nation.

HEADLINE: Nagging Doubts Linger for the Unsure;
Leaning, but Not Leaping, to Clinton

SERIES: UNDECIDED: The Final Three

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS 

 BODY:
While last year's Christmas decorations were still hanging from Buffalo to Babylon, N.Y., 11 undecided voters began sharing their thoughts on the United States Senate race in New York. That race ends tomorrow, and only three remain uncertain. All three say they are leaning toward Hillary Rodham Clinton, and all are still focused on the same issues that have nagged them from the start.
Much has changed, starting with the Republican candidate, since these voters agreed to frequent interviews with The New York Times. But for Bob Harrison, a high school history teacher near Albany and an enrolled Republican, the crucial issue is still the upstate economy. For Tom Smith, a customer service manager at a Wal-Mart near Saugerties and an enrolled Democrat, it is "mudslinging," which he says dominates American political campaigns. And for Doug Taggart, a vice president at a Wall Street financial services firm and an independent voter, it is campaign finance reform. 
 These three men have much in common. All are in their 40's, and married with children. All have a history of crossing party lines. All are avid consumers of news, which they say influences them more than political advertising. All had hoped for an issues-oriented campaign, especially after Representative Rick A. Lazio replaced Rudolph W. Giuliani as Mrs. Clinton's opponent, and all are offended by what they consider both candidates' hypocrisy about raising and spending campaign money.
All began with a fervent dislike of Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Giuliani, and they followed with rapt attention the mayor's health and marital problems. All were skeptical and then enthused by Mr. Lazio, a spunky Long Island congressman, but they say that in the end, they did not believe that he had the presence, the experience or the gravitas for the job.
All said they were impressed by Mrs. Clinton's dogged campaign, which won unusual support in Republican strongholds upstate and slowly seemed to them to smooth the edges of her White House reputation. All agreed that she had won the first debate, the only one of three that all had paid attention to.
Their fellow undecided voters, culled from early New York Times/CBS News polls, made their decisions consistent with their previous party leanings. Of the original 11, two withdrew from the project, three chose Mr. Lazio and three chose Mrs. Clinton. These are the accounts of the remaining three, each of whom says he is close to choosing Mrs. Clinton but undecided enough to expect not to make a decision until tomorrow.
 
Caring About Upstate
Bob Harrison, a lifelong resident of Amsterdam, about 20 miles northwest of Albany, never uses stronger language than "gosh" or "golly," blushes when the subject turns to the Clinton marriage and gets misty at Lazio family photos fit for a greeting card.
Add to that a solid Republican upbringing -- Mr. Harrison's father, a draftsman for General Electric, ran two losing Republican campaigns for town supervisor -- and he would seem like a natural Lazio voter. But at the start of the race, Mr. Harrison was turned off by Mr. Giuliani's temperament and downstate focus. His vote was up for grabs, so he paid close attention to Mrs. Clinton's frequent early visits upstate.
The first lady seemed to care about shuttered carpet mills and toy factories, about places like Amsterdam, where the population has plummeted to 19,000 from 30,000. He found her regional attention flattering. Except for "the group that despises her just because she's Hillary," Mr. Harrison said, "people up here recognize her enthusiasm and like her."
Still, when Representative Lazio entered the race, he seemed an attractive candidate, upbeat and "family-oriented." Mr. Harrison did not buy the notion that the congressman was a pawn of Newt Gingrich. But Mr. Lazio did not seem to him to court the upstate vote. He was quoted in The Times Union of Albany as saying Mrs. Clinton was preaching gloom and doom about the upstate economy, and he made no specific proposals for economic renewal.
Then came the first debate, in Buffalo, where upstate reporters asked questions specific to the region. Mr. Harrison said he thought Mrs. Clinton answered with detail and assurance. Just as important, to this chivalrous man, was what he called Mr. Lazio's rude treatment of his opponent.
Soon, the soft-money pledge that Mr. Lazio extracted from the first lady became the campaign's central issue. Mr. Harrison found no moral high ground here. It was, he said, nothing more than "a political game."
Mr. Harrison said it bothers him that Mrs. Clinton may be using New York as a steppingstone to higher office and may be less than a model of integrity.
He says he questions Mr. Lazio's ability to lead and his indebtedness to the right wing of the Republican Party. In the last week, he said, he has been "turned off by the negative campaign style and ads by both candidates," as they have argued harshly about Arab terrorists and support for breast cancer patients. But, he said, "I have to ignore this" and focus on the issues.
"It's such an important yet such a hard election," Mr. Harrison said yesterday. "But I am starting to finalize a decision."
 
Allergic to Mud
Tom Smith does not expect much from politicians.
Nothing they do or say changes the fact that he scrapes by on $18,000 a year, that his ailing wife works two jobs, that he cannot afford a newspaper subscription or even a secondhand car.
What Mr. Smith looks for in a candidate or a campaign is both simple and elusive: honest talk and no mudslinging. Mainly no mudslinging, a word he has used in every conversation with The Times since January.
When Mr. Lazio entered the race dwelling on the assertion that Mrs. Clinton had moved to New York only to run for the Senate, Mr. Smith called it mudslinging. "That's beating a dead horse to me," he said. "Get to the issues."
When the first lady accused her new opponent of being a pawn of the conservative Republicans, that was mudslinging, too. "It gets old real quick," Mr. Smith said. "I'm still waiting for meat and potatoes."
Mr. Smith characterizes himself as "cynical," saying, "It takes a lot to impress me." In fact, he had nothing nice to say about either candidate (or any of the three, counting Mr. Giuliani) until Mrs. Clinton passed up the opportunity to take what Mr. Smith would have seen as a "cheap shot" at the mayor over his marital infidelity.
"He was wide open to be ripped and she declined," he said. "I like that."
Like his fellow undecided voters, Mr. Smith said he was energized by the prospect of Mr. Lazio's candidacy. He liked his "kid smile" and the way "he exploded out of the blocks." But he was turned off by the congressman's performance in the first debate.
"He's too busy trying to destroy character to come up with any concrete ways of improving things," Mr. Smith said that night at a Saugerties firehouse, where he is a volunteer. "If the vote was taken now, I'd probably go for Hillary."
Echoing Mr. Harrison, Mr. Smith found the tit-for-tat over campaign financing a wash. "They're both using it for their own purposes," he said. "The image of the typical politician is that they're basically dishonest. That's the view most people have."
Mr. Smith said neither candidate had done well articulating positions on state issues. But, he said, Mrs. Clinton has been "pretty straightforward about what her beliefs are, by carrying over what she was for in the White House." Mr. Lazio's chances of "winning me over are slipping away," he concluded. Not gone, mind you, but fading.
 
Seeking Finance Reform
Back in January, Doug Taggart had three main thoughts about the Senate race in particular and the state of American politics in general.
He was growing "more and more disdainful of the whole money situation," he said. Senator John McCain of Arizona was the only candidate who appealed to him. And he said he considered his vote "an extension ofwho I am" and would withhold it if it was not earned.
Much has happened since then, and Mr. Taggart has come full circle. He began by labeling Mr. Giuliani and Mrs. Clinton so unlikable as to be "monstrous," but said he detected a "softening" in the mayor after his cancer diagnosis. He bought into the idea of "a new Rudy" and thought Mr. Giuliani's brush with mortality would work to his favor as a candidate.
When the mayor withdrew from the race, Mr. Taggart concluded that the first lady's election was a fait accompli. That feeling did not last long, though, and Mr. Taggart soon declared Mr. Lazio a viable candidate, if only "because of the extent of the pure negativity toward her," he said.
He said he found the new Republican candidate telegenic, "made in New York," with attractive family values. He said he saw himself in the young candidate, who was the same age and also had a wife, two young daughters and a home in the suburbs.
Mr. Taggart said he forgave Mr. Lazio his fervor in hopping aboard the Gingrich bandwagon early in his career. He laughed off a minor stock transaction that may have been a conflict of interest. Mrs. Clinton, after all, had had a windfall of her own.
But the first debate closed Mr. Taggart's mind to Mr. Lazio's candidacy.
Mrs. Clinton made her opponent look like an agitated adolescent, Mr. Taggart said as he watched with his wife in their living room in Cortlandt Manor. There was nothing the least bit senatorial about him, he said; he seemed like a bully. The second debate was a more muted exchange in which Mr. Taggart said he found no winner or loser. He was about ready to declare himself for Mrs. Clinton.
But campaign finance improprieties were bubbling to the surface. When Mr. Taggart read about the first lady's use of a White House invitation list for solicitations, "I blew my top," he said. He ridiculed her insistence that it was an honest mix-up.
Mr. Taggart intends to vote for Al Gore for president. But on the Senate line, he may abstain. "I feel I've been robbed of something," he said, "because she holds more of the values that I hold dear. But where do you draw the line in terms of propriety?"
Abstaining, to Mr. Taggart, is the ultimate undecided vote. "Lazio is definitely out of the running for me," he said. "It's not an external choice -- him or her. She is running against my conscience at this point."
 
Undecided
 
This is the 10th article in a series following a group of New York State voters as they make up their minds on which candidate to support for the United States Senate.
