PUB-DATE: November 6, 2000

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1746 words

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
Focus Is on Crucial States in Campaign's Final Hours

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE and KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., Nov. 5

 BODY:
On another 19-hour campaign day that included a swing through four states where the race is nip and tuck, Vice President Al Gore resurrected the name of Bill Clinton today as he declared to blacks in Philadelphia and union members here that Tuesday's election was about not only material prosperity, but also "prosperity of the spirit."
"Thank you for allowing Bill Clinton and me to bring change," Mr. Gore said at the Morris Brown A.M.E. Church in North Philadelphia. It was the first time in days that he invoked the president who has bedeviled him throughout the campaign but whose popularity in certain circles is undeniable. 
 Mr. Gore credited the "change" wrought during the Clinton administration to the strong economy, adding that "progressive policies are more easily pursued when we have a sound economy."
At an outdoor rally here, he recalled the debt and high unemployment of earlier years and said: "Now, because you gave Bill Clinton and me a chance to change our economic policy, instead of the biggest deficits, we've got the biggest surpluses. Instead of repeat recessions, we've tripled the market."
Mr. Gore pushed himself hard on this final Sunday before the election on Tuesday, attending three events in Philadelphia before heading to three other states in which the election seems nail-bitingly close -- Michigan, Wisconsin and Iowa.
Though he refrained from direct assaults on Gov. George W. Bush, he clearly delighted in the increasingly vocal and harsh reaction in his crowds to his Republican rival. As people in the crowd here called out slurs against Mr. Bush, Mr. Gore chuckled and said, "I'm getting some good lines here."
The lines were inappropriate for a presidential candidate to utter, of course, but the vice president egged on his listeners anyway. "I can't use them," Mr. Gore said, "but you can use them."
Mr. Gore's campaign also quickened the drumbeat against the governor by deploying various allies to go after Mr. Bush on a range of issues, including his intelligence, his service in the National Guard, his 1976 arrest for drunken driving, and his spurning of pleas for a hate-crimes law from the family of James Byrd Jr., a black man who was dragged to his death in a racially motivated attack in Texas in 1998.
Perhaps the harshest assessment came from Senator Bob Kerrey, Democrat of Nebraska. At a rally in Pittsburgh on Saturday night, Mr. Kerrey noted that Mr. Bush said he had not disclosed his drunken-driving arrest because he wanted to protect his daughters, an excuse Mr. Kerrey flatly rejected. "That reminded me of the old song by Willie Nelson, 'Are You Gonna Believe Me or Your Lying Eyes?' " Mr. Kerrey said. "You're covering your rear end," he said of Mr. Bush. "How dare you say that your character is superior to Vice President Gore's?"
At an outdoor rally in Philadelphia this afternoon, Mr. Gore was joined by Louvon Harris, the sister of Mr. Byrd. Ms. Harris, a single mother from Houston, described her brother's death in graphic detail. She added that Mr. Bush had rejected her family's pleas to memorialize him with a statewide hate-crimes law.
Ms. Harris said Mr. Byrd's attackers "spray-painted him black, chained him to a truck, dragged him three miles. His head came off, his arms -- dismembered his whole body. We have a governor of Texas who doesn't think that's a hate crime.
"My question to him is, if that isn't hate, what is hate to George Bush? We had an opportunity to do something for our family. He did nothing."
As Ms. Harris spoke, silence gripped the previously rowdy and distracted crowd of about 1,500 people in Fairmont Park.
Her story prompted Mr. Gore to instruct Governor Bush, long-distance, on the nature of hate crimes.
"Those who take the position Governor Bush takes say that all crimes are hate crimes," Mr. Gore said. "Well, is shoplifting a hate crime? There are crimes committed by people who have various motivations, and all crimes are wrong, and all crimes that result in the loss of a life must be severely punished, of course.
"But crimes that are motivated by hatred are different, and here's why," Mr. Gore said. "They are intended to have more than one victim. They are intended and aimed not only at the victim who is initially singled out for the tragedy. They are intended to intimidate and dehumanize an entire group of people, to give expression to the hatred that corrodes the soul."
The Byrd saga provided the emotional high point for Mr. Gore during another long day of frenetic campaigning.
Much of Mr. Gore's message was aimed at core Democrats, especially blacks and union members, whom Mr. Gore needs to push to the polls.
Many of the people in his crowds were die-hard partisans, anxious about the closeness of the race and bewildered by Mr. Bush's appeal.
"I'm definitely nervous," said Beth A. Freshwater, 36, an insurance underwriter in Philadelphia who came to the rally in the park. "It's so close, and I can't understand why. It seems pretty clear-cut to me. I just think Al Gore has so much more experience and his ideas are so much better. The comments I keep hearing about Bush are, 'He seems like a nice guy,' or 'I don't think he'll do that much harm.' It's like they don't even listen to what he's saying."
George W. Griscom, a retired high school teacher who drove from his home in Mount Laurel, N.J., to hear Mr. Gore in Philadelphia, said he too could not comprehend Mr. Bush's appeal.
"The only people that should be voting for him are those making $300,000 or more, and that's not 48 percent of the public," he said, referring to the level Mr. Bush is registering in some polls.
From the pulpits, Mr. Gore said material prosperity was not enough.
"The most important form of prosperity we need to focus on is the prosperity of the spirit," Mr. Gore said at Mount Carmel Baptist Church in Philadelphia. "We must decide in America whether or not we're going to make a path toward inclusion, investment and growth, toward justice and opportunity and hope, or whether we're going to be satisfied to stop the journey and tread water."
Reactions from the congregants varied. Claudia Bell, a secretary for the Philadelphia Housing Authority, said that Mr. Gore seemed "direct," but added that compared to Mr. Clinton, "he is not a starburst of charisma." Ms. Bell said her friends were not enthusiastic, per se, about the election, "but people who were not going to vote are paying attention to the point that they realize they need to vote."
Ann Edmonds, 76, a retired machine operator and a soprano in the church choir, said she was voting for Mr. Gore because "I've been a Democrat all my life."
"I remember Hoover," Ms. Edmonds said. "We don't want anymore of that. No, no."
More ambivalent was Kevin Wilson, 41, a portfolio manager for high-income investors. "I don't think either side is capable of doing what they say they're going to do." Mr. Wilson said he was especially skeptical that Mr. Gore could keep his pledge to stand up to the big pharmaceutical companies. "There's no way Merck and Pfizer and Lilly are going to roll over and play dead," he said.
In addition, Mr. Wilson added: "I'll miss Clinton's charisma and the eventfulness of Clinton's term, but do you think George W. Bush is competent or capable of running the country?" He answered no to his own question and said that he might vote for Ralph Nader, the Green Party nominee.
Between church visits, Mr. Gore visited the Melrose Diner, a Philadelphia institution, where the cooks hummed "Hail to the Chief" as he walked by. And there, his pitch about being a Vietnam veteran paid off with Ed Domenick, 67, a maintenance worker at the diner and a veteran. When he saw Mr. Gore, Mr. Domenick told him, "You've got my vote, 'cause of Vietnam."
The Gore campaign has been making a concerted effort to rally veterans around the vice president, who enlisted in the Army. On Saturday night, Mr. Kerrey and Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, both highly decorated Vietnam veterans, railed against Mr. Bush at a union rally in Pittsburgh.
Mr. Kerry said: "Those of us who were in the military wonder how it is that someone who is supposedly serving on active duty, having taken that oath, can miss a whole year of service without even explaining where it went," he said of time that Mr. Bush had not accounted for.
Mr. Kerry also questioned Mr. Bush's intelligence.
"I'll tell you, all over this country people are asking whether or not George Bush is smart enough to be president of the United States," he said. "And I'll tell you what's really scary -- one of the people asking me was Dan Quayle."
 
In His Own Words
AL GORE
 
From remarks yesterday in Dearborn, Mich.:
"There's a lot that he's said that I think needs more attention. Why, after the tragedy that befell James Byrd, should he oppose a hate-crimes law? I think that we need a hate-crimes law because those offenses are different. They are intended to dehumanize a whole group of people. African-Americans have suffered. Arab-Americans have suffered also. Hispanic-Americans have suffered. Jewish-Americans have suffered.
I think that we need to enforce our civil-rights laws. I think it's very important that we respect the rights of all Americans. I think it's very important that the Conyers-Bonior bill pass that bans the use of secret evidence. I think we need to stand up for the rights of all Americans. . . .
Now, I'm asking for your support because I'm for the people and not the powerful. I know very well, as I've said before, that I won't always be the most exciting politician, like Carl Levin. But I will work hard for you every day and I will never let you down and I'll fight for you with all my heart. I know how to take on the special interests. I know how to win for you. I've got 24 years of experience and I've never hesitated to take on special interests.
Now, Governor Bush says that he'll get along with everybody in Washington. Now, there's a lot to be said for that. I think that we need less partisanship. But the question remains, Who does he want to get along with? The top one percent? The H.M.O.'s? The big oil companies? The insurance companies? The drug companies? Sometimes, a president has to be willing to say no in order to say yes to you -- has to say no to the special interests to say yes to the public interest. I know how to do that. And I can say no to the special interests with a smile."

PUB-DATE: November 7, 2000

SECTION: Section F; Page 5; Column 2; Science Desk

LENGTH: 1218 words

HEADLINE: Cell Phone or Pheromone? New Props for the Mating Game

BYLINE: By NATALIE ANGIER

 BODY:
"Is that a cell phone you're taking out of your pocket? Well, then, I'm glad to see you!"
That, it seems, is the fondly imagined fantasy of the ambitious young lads of Liverpool, who, a new study shows, regard their mobile phones less as practical business tools than as handy little mate lures. 
 Observing patrons at an upscale pub frequented by lawyers, entrepeneurs and other single professionals, researchers from the University of Liverpool discovered that men had a markedly different relationship to their cell phones than did women.
Not only did significantly more men than women appear to own cell phones, but they clearly wanted everybody else to know they owned them, too. Whereas the women in the pub generally kept their phones in their purses and retrieved them only as needed, the men would take their phones out of their jacket pockets or briefcases upon sitting down and place them on the bar counter or table for all to see.
Lest they be overlooked, the men fiddled with them often, picking them up, moving them here or there, checking to be sure the battery was charged.
As the researchers see it, the men are using their mobile phones as peacocks use their immobilizing feathers and male bullfrogs use their immoderate croaks: to advertise to females their worth, status and desirability.
The study, which appears in the current issue of the journal Human Nature, shows how new technology subserves primal impulses -- specifically, the impulse to strut.
It also suggests that the breathless evolution of today's technology is driven, not merely by scientific innovations or the demand for heightened worker productivity, but by the social need of people to find novel ornaments and status symbols that distinguish them from the pack.
Pulling no punches, John E. Lycett and Robin I. M. Dunbar of the Center for Economic Learning and Social Evolution, entitle their report, "Mobile Phones as Lekking Devices Among Human Males."
In nature, a lek is a communal mating area where males gather to engage in flamboyant courtship displays, and females stroll by to judge the performers and presumably choose the fittest, most resourceful or most amusing of the lot.
Hammer-head bats, sage grouse, bowerbirds, walruses, Ugandan kob and fallow deer are among the species that engage in a lekking-style courtship system. And so, too, it seems, do some humans, at least in the pubs of Liverpool.
"This is quite an interesting paper," said Dr. Geoffrey F. Miller, an evolutionary psychologist at the University of California at Los Angeles and the author of "The Mating Mind." Mobile phones are a "clever positional good," he said, a positional good being something that marks one's social position.
"The phones have an ostensible purpose, an excuse for carrying them around," Dr. Miller said. "If somebody brought a laptop computer into bar and started clicking away on it, even though it might be 20 times more expensive, it would be considered really tasteless to be seen using it in a bar."
On the other hand, a person who pulls out a phone and starts yakking away on it looks for all the world like a smooth operator -- even when that phone is phony. Dr. Lycett said that the new study was inspired by newspaper accounts of how, when night clubs in South America began requiring patrons to check their cell phones at the door, it was discovered that a huge percentage of the phones were fake.
"At the same time, stores in the U.K. were selling fake mobile phones, and some were quite sophisticated -- they even would ring and light up," said Dr. Lycett, in an interview on a conventional telephone. "We wondered, Why would anybody buy a fake phone?" The researchers also had casually noticed that men seemed to play around with their phones more than women did, prompting them to wonder if there were sex differences in cell phone behavior.
They chose to study the behavior formally in a pub, which is the center of social life in Britain, and to focus on professionals, a socioeconomic group with the means and presumed need to own cell phones.
Attending the same pub on 23 evenings over a four-month period, the researchers, financed through a grant from the university, discreetly kept track of all patrons who sat at the pub's 13 tables. They recorded who obviously had a phone -- that is, used it or displayed it -- and how he or she handled the phone. Over their study period, 54 percent of the pub patrons were men. Of the men, 32 percent were recorded as possessing a cell phone, whereas only 13 percent of the women did.
"It's possible that more women had phones than this and we never saw them, but that goes to the heart of what we're saying: that there's a gender difference in the way they're displayed and used," said Dr. Lycett.
To the women, a phone was just a phone, while the men fingered theirs so often you'd have thought it was, well, a cigar.
The researchers noted also that the amount of time the men spent toying with and displaying their phones increased significantly as the number of men relative to women increased, rather as male peacocks fan open their feathers more vigorously the greater the number of competing suitors in view.
Whether the exhibiting of a cell phone ever worked as a male courtship display -- that is, whether it attracted any women -- the researchers could not determine. Dr. Miller pointed out that, as status symbols go, cell phones were not mere indicators of one's bank account, as a Rolex watch or a Jaguar roadster might be. "What's being displayed here is not so much wealth as social importance, and the fact that you're plugged into social network and are important enough to be able to be reachable all the time," he said.
That association, said Dr. Miller, could explain why cell phones are status symbols not merely for young male barristers in Liverpool, but also for, say, female adolescents in Southern California. "Teenage girls have a high variation in the size of their social networks, which they love to advertise, particularly to other girls," he said. "It's a form of female-female competition."
Such tele-competition may even be healthy -- for girls and boys alike. In the current issue of The British Medical Journal, Clive Bates and Anne Charlton of the Action on Smoking and Health organization in London posit a link between recent declines in smoking rates among British adolescents, and the concommitant rise in the number of teenagers who own cell phones.
The researchers point out that cell phones, like cigarettes, keep the hands, mouth and weekly allowance well occupied, and that both objects satisfy a pubertal desire to appear mature, worldly, involved, indifferent, rebellious, ambitious, autonomous, fashionable and fully peer-bonded.
Fashion, though, is a ruthless slave master. Dr. Lycett said that, since his data were collected a couple of years ago, basic cell phones have become comparatively cheap and practically universal. Hence, the pressure is on to own a cell phone with the largest suite of extraneous features and, paradoxically, the smallest dimensions.
But small does not mean invisible or unlekkable. Small means -- you need a headset to go with it! Now if only somebody could figure out how to rig up a pair of antlers to this thing!

HEADLINE: Single Mothers, Working

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Far More Single Mothers Are Taking Jobs" (news article, Nov. 5):
It is good news that increased numbers of single mothers can leave welfare and earn more income in times of economic boom. Independence from a humiliating bureaucracy and improved self-esteem are pluses. 
 But gains are offset by a lack of other resources, including health care. As you report, the poorest fifth of female-headed households have experienced a drop in disposable income. Nor is data provided regarding the quality of child care that such women must rely upon, especially in the context of absent father figures in the lives of small children.
A culture tuned into "where is the money?" can certainly ask "where are the men?"
 
SUE MATORIN
New York, Nov. 6, 2000
 
The writer is an adjunct associate professor, Columbia University School of Social Work.

HEADLINE: Bill Gates, Skeptic

 BODY:

To the Editor:
I have worked in high technology for 16 years, and I share Bill Gates's skepticism that technology and capitalism alone will somehow solve fundamental problems like poverty, illiteracy and lack of health care around the world (news article, Nov. 3). 
 In the United States, where it should have been easiest to accomplish major social changes through technology (given the wide proliferation of high technology, a very strong economy and a high rate of literacy), it is clear now that the gap between the rich and the poor has actually increased over the last decade. In the same period in India, at a time when that country was turning into one of the leading software centers in the world, the percentage of the population living in poverty increased significantly.
It will take more than simple faith in technology to solve major social problems.
 
KUMAR VENKAT
Cupertino, Calif., Nov. 3, 2000 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Choices For the Election

 BODY:
As they vote in schools, libraries and community halls across the country, Americans will be doing more than electing a new president and Congress. In some mysterious but highly ritualized way, Election Day also marks a familiar transition in our political process. With the selection of new officials, we move from a highly charged period of partisan debate toward a new season of unity, cooperation and accomplishment. At its most idealized, Election Day brings the voters a sense of unity with the presidential candidates. The candidates fresh from the trail and the voters entering their millions of voting booths are joined in the quadrennial enterprise by which the shining Republic renews its strength.
Paradoxically, in this election many people have probably felt distant from the presidential process even while being in suspense about it. Those citizens not living in the decisive battleground states have gotten little of the candidates' time and a smaller share of their advertising budgets. 
 But the fact that the presidential campaign feels as if it were being waged someplace else should not be taken as an excuse for not voting. In every state, hundreds of local, state and national offices are in play, and the outcome of those races, in catalytic combination with the presidential contest, will determine the political texture of the next four years. We regard a heavy vote as particularly important in the close Senate races in New York, where we have endorsed Hillary Rodham Clinton over Rick Lazio, and in New Jersey, where our choice, Bob Franks, has moved ahead of Jon Corzine in the final polls.
The tone of this campaign year should stimulate enthusiasm among those voters who have asked for more civility in the process. Except for some nastiness in the early phases of the Republican presidential contest, this year has been largely free of the calculating use of divisive issues touching on race or religion. Unlike past Republican presidential nominees, Gov. George W. Bush has not sought to use school prayer as a wedge issue. The Democratic candidate, Vice President Al Gore, has been accused of waging class warfare, but in fact he has offered a well-documented critique of a Bush tax plan that unfairly rewards the rich. We would argue that turnout is important not only to the chances of the candidate we have endorsed, Mr. Gore, but also as an affirmative public response to the serious tone of the campaign.
Below we list again our choices in the presidential election and in selected competitive races in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. We hope our recommendations will receive serious consideration, but our final exhortation for the 2000 campaign is for everyone to vote, regardless of choice of party or candidate. Participation is what makes the system work, infusing it with credibility and renewal. Both qualities will be needed as the country moves toward new leadership in the White House, a new Congress and a new chance to address pressing needs at the local and national levels.

HEADLINE: May Stores Says Profit Fell 38%

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The May Department Stores Company, which operates Lord & Taylor, Filene's and other chains, posted a 38 percent decline in third-quarter earnings yesterday because of markdowns to clear spring and summer inventory.
The company, based in St. Louis, reported net income for the quarter ended Oct. 28 of $85 million, or 27 cents a share, compared with $138 million, or 38 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Sales rose 5 percent, to $3.33 billion from $3.17 billion. Same-store sales -- sales at stores open at least a year -- fell 0.1 percent, the company said. 
 Analysts had expected the retailer to report a profit of 25 cents a share, according to First Call/Thomson Financial.
Shares of May rose 31 cents, to $28.44.
Sales at many department stores have been sluggish since May as consumers, wary of a slowing economy and rising fuel prices, cut back on spending. As a result, many retailers have had to cut prices to encourage sales.
Looking ahead, May said that the clearance of spring and summer merchandise was complete and that inventories were in good shape.
One Wall Street analyst said May shares were trading higher because the company surpassed forecasts and because its sales of fall merchandise were healthier than those of this summer.
May operates 428 department stores and 118 David's Bridal stores in 43 states, the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico. Its other chains include Hecht's, Foley's and Kaufmann's.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Cautious Investors Sell Treasuries and Wait for Election Day

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Bond prices fell yesterday in cautious trading as a hesitant market braced for the results of today's elections and prepared for new government debt supply expected this week.
With the outcome of the presidential and Congressional races too close to call, analysts said investors sold Treasuries to stake neutral positions and to prepare for a potentially volatile market reaction after the election. 
 "It's too close to call for anyone to feel comfortable," said Gemma Wright, director of market strategy at Barclays Capital in New York. "I think everyone is expecting a certain amount of volatility once we get the results."
Analysts also said bonds came under pressure as dealers made room for the Treasury's planned sale of $12 billion of five-year notes today and $8 billion of 9 3/4-year notes tomorrow in its quarterly refinancing.
The price of the closely followed 10-year note fell 8/32 , to 997/32 , while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.86 percent from 5.82 percent on Friday.
The 30-year bond fell 12/32 , to to 1053/32 . Its yield rose to 5.88 percent from 5.86 percent.
Economists said market participants were nervous about the election because the fiscal proposals of both candidates leave little room for future paydowns of government debt.
Expectations of limited Treasury supply as the government runs surpluses have lifted the price of Treasuries for most of this year.

HEADLINE: David Brower, an Aggressive Champion Of U.S. Environmentalism, Is Dead at 88

BYLINE: By RICHARD SEVERO

 BODY:
David Brower, an uncompromising environmentalist who spent more than half a century fighting to protect America's wilderness areas against speculators, developers, state agencies and the federal government, died on Sunday at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 88.
Mr. Brower was widely regarded one of the most articulate and powerful conservationists of the 20th century, and at various times led a number of environmental groups, including the Sierra Club and Friends of the Earth. 
 Long an opponent of compromise in the face of efforts to tame wild lands, he was a primary force during the 1960's in preventing the construction of two major government dams in the Grand Canyon. He also played a pivotal role in blocking a dam, proposed for the Green River in Utah, that would have flooded parts of Dinosaur National Monument.
Over the years he also fought, sometimes alone, to maintain the wilderness of the Northern Cascades in Oregon and Washington, Point Reyes and Kings Canyon in California, the Great Smoky Mountains in Tennessee and North Carolina, the Red River Gorge in Kentucky, the Allagash Wilderness in Maine and the Everglades in Florida.
He sought to protect redwoods from loggers, animals from furriers, porpoises from tuna fishermen and the public from nuclear energy and any number of projects proposed by the Army Corps of Engineers and the Federal Bureau of Reclamation.
Mr. Brower (the name rhymes with "hour") also spoke against the indiscriminate use of herbicides and pesticides.
"You are villains not to share your apples with worms," he would tell his audiences. "Bite the worms. They won't hurt nearly as much as the insecticide does."
Mr. Brower's life seemed to be a perpetual joust against what he found to be the careless use of land for commercial purposes.
"We're not blindly opposed to progress," he said, "we're opposed to blind progress."
In a book about Mr. Brower, "Encounters With the Archdruid" (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, 1971), John McPhee likened him to a circuit-riding preacher on environmentalism, who referred to his standard conservation talk as the Sermon.
"Brower," Mr. McPhee wrote, "has computed that we are driving through the earth's resources at a rate comparable to a man's driving an automobile a hundred and twenty-eight miles per hour -- and he says that we are accelerating. He reminds his audiences that buffalo were shot for their tongues alone, and he says that we still have a buffalo-tongue economy.
" 'We're hooked on growth. We're addicted to it. In my lifetime, man has used more resources than in all previous history.' "
If Mr. Brower was a druid, he was an angry one; he seemed to maintain a level of indignation that would have burned out a lesser man.
"I wish we didn't have to be angry all the time," he said. "But someone has to get angry."
Russell Train, who in the early 1970's was administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, once observed: "Thank God for David Brower. He makes it so easy for the rest of us to be reasonable."
In 1952, Mr. Brower became executive director of the Sierra Club, the conservation organization founded in 1892 by the naturalist John Muir. It had a membership of 7,000 and an annual budget of $75,000 when Mr. Brower started. By 1969, when he stepped down under pressure by members who thought he had gone too far too fast, it had 77,000 members and assets of $3 million, and had probably blocked or delayed construction of at least $7 billion.
Because of its opposition to the two proposed dams in the Grand Canyon, the Sierra Club lost its tax-exempt status in 1966, on the ground that it had become much a political organization. Mr. Brower later told the membership that it owed thanks to Sheldon Cohen, the commissioner of internal revenue, because his ruling had attracted new, militant members who did not care whether joining gave them a tax advantage.
Even as it moved from the gentility of Muir's time to the militancy of Mr. Brower, the Sierra Club attracted favorable notice from more traditional conservationists with its handsomely illustrated books, which argued the cause of nature with photographs. The books were Mr. Brower's idea, and among those for which he was editor and publisher were "Summer Island -- Penobscot Country"; "Time and the River Flowing," which described the Grand Canyon; and "Gentle Wilderness -- The Sierra Nevada."
But the Sierra Club's militancy continued to irritate some members, none more so than the photographer Ansel Adams, who described Mr. Brower's followers as "almost inquisitorial" toward those accused of despoiling the environment. Some in the club, for instance, were open to proposals for the construction of the Diablo Canyon nuclear reactor in California; Mr. Brower despised the project, which was ultimately built at 17 times the cost originally estimated and began operating in 1985, fully 13 years behind schedule.
In 1969, after the defeat of a slate of candidates for Sierra Club positions who were friendly to him, Mr. Brower resigned as executive director and founded two new groups: Friends of the Earth and the John Muir Institute for Environmental Studies.
He was dismissed as chairman of Friends of the Earth in July 1984 amid complaints that he had been too dictatorial and too wasteful in refusing to carry out staff cuts ordered by the board. He was reinstated a month later but resigned from the board in 1986.
In the meantime, there had been a reconciliation between Mr. Brower and the Sierra Club, which appointed him to its board in 1982. Over the years, the Sierra Club's 600,000 members would re-elect him to the 15-member board by overwhelming margins. He was last elected in 1998 but resigned this spring, once again citing differences between the board's agenda and his.
"The world is burning, and all I hear from them is the music of violins," he said in resigning. "May the Sierra Club become what John Muir wanted it to be and what I have alleged it was."
In his last years, Mr. Brower, still a fit and imposing man of 6 foot 3, with a shock of white hair, continued to stake out a militant's view of conservation, winning new adherents to the cause. He helped establish an organization of steel workers and environmentalists called the Alliance for Sustainable Jobs and the Environment, based in Portland, Ore.
A supporter of Ralph Nader, Mr. Brower flew to Denver in June for the Green Party convention and cast his absentee ballot for president the day before he died, said Mikhail Davis, his assistant at the Earth Island Institute in San Francisco, which Mr. Brower founded in 1982 to promote conservation projects around the world.
Mr. Brower is survived by his wife of 57 years, the former Anne Hus; three sons, Robert and John, both of Berkeley, and Ken, of Oakland, Calif., and a daughter, Barbara Brower of Portland.
David Ross Brower was born on July 1, 1912, in Berkeley, the son of Ross J. and Mary Grace Barlow Brower. His father, who took the family on frequent camping and hiking trips, taught mechanical drawing at the University of California and then, having lost that job, managed and did janitorial work in two buildings he owned.
Mrs. Brower, also a lover of the outdoors, lost both her sight and her sense of smell to an inoperable brain tumor when David was young; he later recalled taking her on walks after she had lost her vision. He became permanently interested in both mountain climbing and butterfly collecting, enjoying his ability to identify almost any butterfly that fluttered near him.
Mr. Brower was admitted to the University of California at Berkeley and studied there in the early 1930's, but dropped out in his sophomore year. He would later tell his friends that he was "a graduate of the University of the Colorado River."
During World War II, he was an officer with the 10th Mountain Division, which fought in northern Italy, and wrote a manual of instruction for mountain troops.
After the war he went back to an old job at the University of California Press, where he edited manuscripts, and remained there until assuming the leadership of the Sierra Club, of which he had been a member since 1933, nearly two decades earlier.
In the 1960's and 70's, environmentalists were sometimes perceived as elitists who did not care if their activities contributed to unemployment. In his autobiography, "For Earth's Sake: The Life and Times of David Brower" (Gibbs Smith, 1990), Mr. Brower said, "We are in sympathy with the straits of unemployed loggers, but before we let sympathy be an easy route to expedience, let us consider who else needs some sympathy."
As a man who disliked cars, Mr. Brower added, "We can, upright people that we are, rediscover the foot; we can save a place to walk in, and an antelope, too."

HEADLINE: Philippine Panel Sends Impeachment Case to Full House

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Nov. 6

 BODY:
A Congressional committee in the Philippines sent an impeachment complaint today to the full House of Representatives, where more than enough members have said they will vote to remove President Joseph Estrada on charges of corruption.
If that happens, the complaint would move to a vote in the Senate. 
 The rapid committee action, cutting short what could have been a two-month process, was taken as public and political pressure grew for the removal of Mr. Estrada, whom a crony has accused of accepting nearly $11 million in bribes, mostly from an illegal gambling operation.
Publicly, Mr. Estrada continued to stand firm against widespread calls for his resignation. "I am not negotiating for any deals and have no intention of doing so," he said today. "I declare my steadfast commitment to defend my innocence against my accusers in the proper venue of our constitutional process."
But Manila was filled with rumors that private discussions were under way for a graceful exit for the president, who has been in office since June 1998.
Finance Secretary Jose Pardo, who is close to the president, said, "I have offered myself as a channel of communication" with Mr. Estrada's critics. The critics are led by former President Corazon C. Aquino.
The president's chief aide, Ronaldo Zamora, denied published reports that Mr. Estrada was seeking a negotiated exit.
"We don't know anything about that," Mr. Zamora said. "President Estrada has not given anyone permission to start any kind of negotiations, because he is determined to hold on to his position."
The view of most experts in Manila was that it was only a matter of time before Mr. Estrada left office, through either impeachment or resignation.
Though he was elected by an overwhelming popular vote, Mr. Estrada's base is among the poor, and he has never had the respect of the political and business elites. The economy has suffered under him from mismanagement and lackadaisical leadership, as well as from an atmosphere of corruption and cronyism.
The fast-growing momentum toward his removal drove the Philippine stock market to rise 16 percent today, its biggest one-day gain in 13 years. The currency, the peso, which has plummeted since the corruption accusations emerged last month, rose to 49 to the dollar today, up from a record low of 51.59 last week.
The crucial factor appeared to be the defections over the weekend from Mr. Estrada's party by the Senate president, the House speaker and more than 50 other members of Congress. Filipinos were also stirred over the weekend when tens of thousands of people rallied against the president.
The image was compelling. The anti-Estrada forces are led by what are known as the heroes of the peaceful ouster of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos in 1986 -- notably Mrs. Aquino and the influential Roman Catholic cardinal, Jaime Sin.
As in 1986, opposition forces are creating a sense of inevitability that could be self-fulfilling.
After the legislative defections, 99 House members signed a resolution endorsing impeachment, well over the 73 members needed for a one-third vote to send the articles of impeachment to the Senate.
Speaker Manuel Villar said the resolution would most likely be submitted to the Senate after Congress resumed its regular session, on Nov. 13. A two-thirds vote in the 22-member Senate would be needed to remove the president from office.
The Senate began preparations today for its impeachment vote. Senate President Franklin Drilon ordered the drafting of rules for a procedure that has never been used.
Mr. Estrada was buoyed by the release of a survey that showed that his popularity remained strong among much of the public that loves his tough-guy persona, derived from years as a B-movie star. The survey, conducted from Oct. 26 to Oct. 30 by a respected polling group, the Social Weather Stations, found that just 20 percent of the respondents believed the corruption accusations, despite the furor that has gripped the press and the political establishment. Forty-four percent opposed his removal.
The accusations were raised a month ago by a friend of Mr. Estrada, Luis Singson, a provincial governor who is also an admitted illegal gambling lord. At a Congressional hearing, he presented documents that he said showed that he had provided Mr. Estrada with $8.6 million in gambling payoffs and $2.8 million siphoned from provincial tobacco taxes.
Mr. Singson said he was making his accusations after Mr. Estrada had cut him out of the profits of a new legal gambling scheme that was meant to replace the illegal one.

HEADLINE: Nurse in Malawi Wages War on AIDS and Apathy

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 6

 BODY:
A personal tragedy taught Catherine Phiri that people have more to lose under dictatorship than their civil and political rights.
Mrs. Phiri lives in Malawi, which under the dictatorial rule of Hastings Kamuzu Banda refused to allow any public discussion of H.I.V. or AIDS. By the time a democratically elected government replaced the long-running Banda government in 1994, it was too late for Mrs. Phiri, a nurse. Victim in part of the silence that surrounded the disease, she tested positive for the virus in 1990, after her husband died of AIDS. 
 Watching the devastation of AIDS spread all around her in a country with one of the highest infection rates in Africa, Mrs. Phiri decided in 1994 to take advantage of the new democratic atmosphere. She founded a support group for people who were suffering not just from AIDS but also from the neglect of a society unschooled about the disease.
Last last month, Mrs. Phiri was in New York to receive a United Nations award for her work, one of four people from around the world to be recognized by the United Nations Development Program and Unaids for waging an exceptional fight against poverty and AIDS.
The other winners of the Race Against Poverty Awards were Maire Bopp Dupont, a radio journalist from French Polynesia who has led a drive to educate Pacific islanders about the epidemic; Rita Arauz, a psychologist and human rights campaigner from Nicaragua who established a foundation to study and confront AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases, and the Rev. Arkadiusz Nowak, a Polish priest who opened the first AIDS hospice in his country.
Mrs. Phiri credited her nation's new president, Bakili Muluzi, with raising awareness of the disease. The press became free enough to focus on the spread of H.I.V.-AIDS in Malawi, where 25 percent of the urban work force is expected to die of the disease by 2010. It was through newspaper reports, Mrs. Phiri said, that Malawians learned that 29 government ministers were H.I.V. positive.
But Malawi still has a long way to go, said Mrs. Phiri, who uses her slim and erratic earnings as a consultant on H.I.V.-AIDS to support a community-based organization in Salina, a town on Lake Malawi about 60 miles east of the capital, Lilongwe. The organization, known as SASO, short for the Salina H.I.V.-AIDS Support Organization, offers testing, counseling and moral support.
Mrs. Phiri, who is raising six children -- four of them adopted AIDS orphans -- operates without her own blood-testing equipment and never has enough money to provide good meals more than once a week for 1,500 AIDS orphans under her organization's supervision. "When we have money, we give them food only on Saturday," she said. "We are supposed to give them food every day."
Mrs. Phiri said she tries to focus as much time as possible on counseling victims of the disease, and on teaching schoolchildren, who can be very cruel with H.I.V.-positive classmates, about living with the virus and understanding others who have it.
"Since I founded this organization in Salima, I've seen many women, children and men die in the epidemic," Mrs. Phiri said, describing how others, worried about their fate, wait weeks for blood samples to be tested by uncooperative hospitals. Her center lacks basic antibiotics, and even aspirin, to treat opportunistic infections or aches and pains, let alone AIDS drugs, she said.
"We have been trying to get through to the government," she said. "I hope that we will be recognized by being given the award, and that the government will now have something to do with us. I hope when I go back home I'll be able to see our president. I've been writing him proposals that have never been answered."

HEADLINE: Supreme Court Roundup;
Debating Reach of Arbitration Law in Workplace

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6

 BODY:
The question of whether employers can require workers to give up their right to a day in court was before the Supreme Court today, but the justices were not debating whether mandatory arbitration of workplace disputes was efficient or fair.
Rather, the issue was how to interpret what Congress meant when, 75 years ago, it passed the Federal Arbitration Act and made agreements to arbitrate commercial disputes generally enforceable in federal court. 
 Given the law's age and widespread use, its meaning in the context of employment disputes proved, on close examination, surprisingly elusive. The justices' response to the arguments today, in an employment discrimination case from California, raised at least the prospect that the growing use of arbitration in the workplace was about to be curbed substantially.
The Federal Arbitration Act of 1925 applies broadly to any "transaction involving commerce," but a separate section of the law contains an oddly worded exclusion to that general rule. The law shall not apply, Congress wrote, to "contracts of employment of seamen, railroad employees or any other class or workers engaged in foreign or interstate commerce."
Until a year ago, all federal appeals courts to have interpreted this exclusion did so narrowly. Arbitration agreements were generally enforceable in the workplace except for maritime and railroad workers and others who, like those, were engaged in the actual, physical movement of goods across state lines.
But last November, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, took a sharply different position. It interpreted the exclusion to mean that the arbitration act did not apply to employment contracts, at all.
Circuit City Stores, an electronics retailer that does business nationwide and that requires new employees to sign arbitration agreements, appealed the ruling to the Supreme Court. The Ninth Circuit had refused to require a computer salesman for Circuit City to arbitrate, rather than go to court, his claim that he had been harassed because he was gay.
David E. Nagle, Circuit City's lawyer, told the justices today that employers and employees have entered into "untold numbers" of arbitration agreements in reliance on the dominant judicial view that these agreements were enforceable.
If that view was wrong, Mr. Nagle said, Congress had ample opportunity to correct it.
Several justices were openly skeptical of Circuit City's argument, which was supported in briefs from the United States Chamber of Commerce and other employer groups.
Answering questions from Justice John Paul Stevens, Mr. Nagle said the arbitration act covered ticket agents who worked for railroads, but not employees of travel agencies who sold train tickets.
"Do you think that's what Congress had in mind?" Justice Stevens asked.
That was what Congress said, Mr. Nagle replied.
While many Supreme Court cases require the interpretation of opaque statutory language, this case, Circuit City Stores v. Adams, No. 99-1379, has an additional layer of complexity stemming from the law's reference to interstate commerce.
The understanding, by Congress and the Supreme Court, of the power of Congress to regulate interstate commerce was much narrower in 1925 than it is today, raising the question of what Congress thought it was doing with its awkwardly phrased set of exclusions.
Michael Rubin, arguing for St. Clair Adams, the plaintiff in the Circuit City case, said that in 1925, Congress had reason to think that its authority over interstate commerce, in the employment context, did not extend beyond seamen and railroad workers.
By excluding these employees, Mr. Rubin said, Congress was invoking what it thought at the time was the full extent of its authority to exclude employment as a whole.
"The underlying concern was the disparity in bargaining power between all workers and bosses," he said. Now that the commerce power is understood to extend across the economy, he said, only a complete exclusion for employment would accomplish the goal of Congress.
Justice Antonin Scalia appeared skeptical. "What you're really asking us to do is change the language" of the law, he told Mr. Rubin. Justice Scalia added that he knew of no case in which the court had decided that Congress "surely would have done it differently if they knew then what we know now."
There were also these other developments at the court today.
 
Voter Information
The court heard arguments on the constitutionality of a Missouri provision to "instruct and inform" voters on whether candidates for the Senate and House have taken steps to work for a federal constitutional amendment for Congressional term limits.
Incumbents seeking re-election who have not taken the steps are identified on the ballot, in capital letters, as having "disregarded voters' instruction on term limits." Candidates seeking office for the first time must take a pledge to work for term limits or be labeled as having "declined to pledge to support term limits."
The provision was made part of Missouri's constitution through a voter initiative in 1996 and was declared unconstitutional last year by the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit, in St. Louis. Similar provisions in a half dozen other states have also been invalidated by federal courts.
The Eighth Circuit found that the provision exceeded the state's authority to regulate federal elections and violated the candidates' First Amendment rights.
Arguing Missouri's appeal, James R. McAdams, a lawyer in the state attorney general's office, said the required labels were little different than labeling candidates on the ballot as Democrats or Republicans. The information helps voters evaluate a candidate, Mr. McAdams said.
The argument was an uphill battle. The label "goes beyond information," Justice David H. Souter told Mr. McAdams, adding that it amounted to "a kind of conclusion of fault, that a person has violated a trust."
Jonathan S. Franklin, a lawyer representing a Congressional candidate who challenged the provision, said it was a "manipulation of the ballot" in the service of "the state's preferred political viewpoint."
Barbara D. Underwood, a deputy solicitor general, also argued against the provision, representing the federal government as a friend of the court in the case, Cook v. Gralike, No. 99-929.
 
Freelancers' Copyright
The justices agreed to decide whether publishers who include the work of freelance writers in electronic databases without their permission violate the freelancers' rights under federal copyright law.
In a ruling last year, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in Manhattan, held that this common practice was a copyright violation.
The appeal, New York Times v. Tasini, No. 00-201, was filed by The Times along with Newsday, Time Inc. and two companies, Lexis/Nexis and University Microfilms International, which sell databases in electronic and CD-ROM form.
The appeals court did not specify a remedy for the violations. The Times warned that the ruling would require "the destruction of decades' worth of articles currently stored in electronic archives."
The plaintiffs, a group of freelance authors led by Jonathan Tasini, maintain that the remedy would be a less drastic renegotiation of reprint rights through a central clearinghouse, similar to the approach used in the music industry.
The legal issue turns on a provision of law under which the owners of a copyright in a "collective work," such as an issue of a newspaper, are entitled to reproduce the individual works in "any revision of that collective work."
The appeals court held that the electronic databases could not be considered a "revision" of the original printed publication.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES;
Europeans Intervene, but Markets Don't Listen

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Is Wim Duisenberg, leader of the European Central Bank, tilting at windmills? That was the question batted about yesterday after the European Central Bank bought euros for the second consecutive trading session in an effort to support the common currency.
With the Europeans intervening alone, the answer was yes. Without support from the United States and other industrial economies, something the European Central Bank had in September in the first effort to prop up the euro, this intervention is not expected to have much effect. 
 More important, the forces behind the euro's weakness -- and the dollar's strength -- do not appear to be turning in the currency's favor. And unless that happens, several analysts said, there is no significant rally for the euro in the offing.
The intervention "doesn't preclude another spike down nor does it mean we are looking for a major euro rally any time soon," said Anne Mills, senior foreign economist at Brown Brothers Harriman.
The first troubling result yesterday was that the intervention helped increase the euro's value only briefly. At the time of intervention, the currency was trading around 86 cents. It jumped as high as 87.27 cents, then fell for the rest of the session in Europe and tumbled further in New York trading, bouncing back slightly to settle at 86.07 cents, down from 86.68 cents late Friday.
The solo intervention also seemed to be interpreted by many traders as a sign of weakness. The United States had been on the sidelines Friday, the first day of the European Central Bank's intervention, and stayed there yesterday. All the United States did, in a statement on Friday from Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers, was to say that it shared Europe's concern "about the implications of the broad movements in the euro for the world economy." Washington still favors a strong dollar, Mr. Summers added.
David Gilmore, a partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics in Essex, Conn., said yesterday's intervention did not scare traders into buying the euro. Instead, they sold as the European Central Bank bought, taking easy profits. James McCormick, a currency strategist at J. P. Morgan Securities, said that on the basis of client trading flows, "no one was short the euro this time around, so no one got hurt." Being short means selling the euro in anticipation that it will decline and then buying it back at a profit at the lower price.
In a note to clients, Karen E. Parker, director of currency research at Chase Securities, said, "One does not get many points for persistence in the game of intervention." She said the European bank was running a risk in saying it intervened alone because it assumed the United States would not join in just ahead of the presidential election. "If Washington does not join in later this week," she wrote, "the markets may be disappointed and sell the euro."
What effect the election results will have on the dollar is unclear. A victory by Gov. George W. Bush with a Republican Congress could give the dollar a lift, especially because Mr. Bush's principal economic adviser, Lawrence B. Lindsey, has opposed American intervention in the currency markets. But the Clinton administration, which has supported a strong dollar, will be calling the shots on intervention until Jan. 20.
More disturbing for the euro's outlook is that the forces that have weakened the currency are still in place. Chief among these are the strong capital flows into the United States from Europe, as portfolio investments or as part of mergers and acquisitions. Mr. McCormick said that as of the end of last week, there was a pipeline of $49 billion in proposed mergers and acquisitions outside Europe -- up from $40 billion on Sept. 22, when the Europeans were joined by the United States, Britain and Japan in currency intervention.
In addition, much of the recent euro gain has come since the United States reported on Sept. 27 that the economy grew at a 2.7 percent annual rate, adjusted for inflation. That was much slower than expected and added to data indicating that the economy was slowing. Such a slowdown would be positive for the euro if it made American investment less attractive to foreigners.
But there are signs that the European economy is also slowing, which would offset the benefit of an American slowdown. Another sign of that came yesterday when Germany reported that manufacturing orders dropped 4.6 percent in September. The decline, in both domestic and foreign orders, wiped out much of the increase recorded since March.

HEADLINE: METRO BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

 BODY:

CONNECTICUT
 
OXFORD: ARSON SUSPECTED IN FOREST FIRE -- A suspicious fire in the Naugatuck State Forest involved more than two-thirds of the forest over the weekend but was under control yesterday, the authorities said. Naugatuck's fire chief, Kerry Flaherty, said the fire was confined to 250 acres of the 365-acre forest, which borders Waterbury to the south. The fire began around noon Friday at the edge of the main access road into the forest, he said. It is being investigated as a possible arson because suspicious fires have previously started in the same area, he said. (NYT)
 
MASHANTUCKET: INDIAN OFFICIALS OUSTED -- The Mashantucket Pequot Indian tribe, which owns the Foxwoods Casino, chose two new tribal council members on Sunday. In the election, for three of the council's seven seats, two incumbents were ousted and a third, Michael J. Thomas, was re-elected. Members of the Mashantucket Pequot tribe elected Charlene R. Jones, assistant executive director of the Mashantucket Pequot Museum and Research Center, and Fatima C. Dames, a tribal council staff member, to the tribe's ruling body. They will replace Gary A. Carter and Antonio M. Beltran. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)
 
HARTFORD: STATE CHANGES DIPLOMA CRITERIA -- The state is revising the test for high school dropouts getting their diplomas under the General Educational Development program, or G.E.D., as school systems nationwide step up graduation standards. Starting in 2002, students will have to write more, solve more complicated math problems and analyze material like economic charts and editorial cartoons to earn their G.E.D. "It's important that the standard be raised and be consistent with what students in high school who do four years are subjected to," said Tom Murphy, spokesman for the State Department of Education. "It should not become an incentive for students to drop out because the test is easy." (AP) 

NEW YORK
 
MANHATTAN: GUILTY PLEA IN PARK ATTACK -- A Brooklyn man charged with taking part in an attack on a teenage girl in Central Park after the Puerto Rican Day Parade in June pleaded guilty yesterday to first-degree sexual abuse. Prosecutors in Manhattan contended that the man, Herbert Negron, 40, was part of a violent mob that ran through the park after the parade, attacking several women. Mr. Negron apologized for his role in the mayhem, saying that he was ready to pay his debt to society. Alan Feuer (NYT)
 
BUFFALO: GRAPE HARVEST DOWN -- This year's state grape harvest has shrunk, but the price for premium grapes has surged because of increasing wine consumption. According to the United States Department of Agriculture, the harvest was projected at 165,000 tons, down almost 20 percent from last year. The reasons for the decline include stress from last year's record yield; drought conditions in 1999, which depressed the 2000 bloom; and heavy spring rains that brought more downy mildew and other diseases. (AP)
 
SARATOGA SPRINGS: RABIES FEAR -- Three middle school students are undergoing a monthlong series of rabies shots as a precaution because they had contact with a dead bat brought to science class last month, said an official at the Saratoga County Public Health office. An unidentified middle school student found the dead bat at her bus stop and took it to her science teacher. Public health officials had the bat tested, and rabies was confirmed on Oct. 26. (AP)
 
AMSTERDAM: MINOR EARTHQUAKE FELT -- A minor earthquake rattled parts of eastern New York yesterday morning. The quake struck at 7:16 a.m. and was centered about 10 miles southeast of Amsterdam, in Montgomery County, said John Minsch of the National Earthquake Information Center in Golden, Colo. The quake was felt by people in Rotterdam, Niskayuna and north to the Great Sacandaga Lake. There were no reports of damage or injuries. (AP)
 
NEW JERSEY
 
TRENTON: MORE FLU VACCINE -- Health care providers who offer influenza shots can now get more of the vaccine thanks to a federal contract, state health officials said yesterday. Because of production problems at the manufacturer, many clinics and other health care providers received only part of their vaccine orders and limited who could get shots. But the State Department of Health and Senior Services said yesterday that health care providers could now apply for vaccine doses that are available through a federal contract. Vaccine delivery will begin Dec. 12 and end by early January. (AP)
 
TRENTON: BRENNAN URGES SPEEDY TRIAL -- New charges filed against Robert E. Brennan, the former financier, have not prompted him to seek a delay of his trial. Mr. Brennan's defense lawyer, Michael Critchley, told a federal judge yesterday that they would forgo pretrial motions to keep a Dec. 5 date, which was set after Mr. Brennan's original bankruptcy fraud indictment in August. The judge agreed. The unusual request was opposed by the prosecutor, an assistant United States attorney, Paul A. Weissman, who said it would be better to have a trial next year. (AP)
 
NEWARK: UTILITY SHUTOFFS CRITICIZED -- A consumer group yesterday urged the State Board of Public Utilities to strengthen protections against gas and electric shutoffs for consumers in compliance with a law passed last year. A shutoff moratorium between Nov. 15 and March 15 covers families on public assistance. Still, there 140,000 shutoffs in 1999, including some during the cold months of the moratorium, said Stacy Berger, a spokeswoman for the group, New Jersey Citizen Action. The next board meeting is scheduled for Nov. 28; a board spokesman declined to comment on what the board might do. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

HEADLINE: Taming the Chinese Hinterland;
Beijing Tries to Lift Economic Standards in Its West

BYLINE: By CRAIG S. SMITH

DATELINE: CHENGDU, China

 BODY:
It was an eerily colonial moment: over the tinkling of wine glasses and the melodic hum of violins in a chandeliered hall here in mountain-ringed Sichuan Province, 300 Western business executives and nearly as many Chinese officials drank not long ago to China's great western development.
But it was not foreigners who led the toast, as they would have in the days when China's far western region was the subject of Russia and Britain's great game over who would dominate Central Asia. The initiative this time comes from Beijing, which is hoping foreign capital will help lift the economy of the ethnically diverse region before the disparity between living standards there and in the wealthier east, dominated by Han Chinese, bolsters fledgling independence movements in China's farthest reaches. 
 "Go West, young Han" is Beijing's message to China's educated youth these days and a focus of the country's next five-year economic plan. An early draft of the plan, which is the blueprint for economic policy through 2005 and will be presented in detail early next year, calls the development of China's west a "herculean, historic task" that must make "breakthroughs in building the infrastructure and preserving the ecological environment" in the next 5 to 10 years.
The government has a long list of projects it wants foreign businesses to finance, including a $14 billion, 2,500-mile natural gas pipeline stretching from the far western Xinjiang region to the country's coastal commercial capital, Shanghai. It is also asking development agencies like the Asian Development Bank, the World Bank and the Official Development Assistance program of Japan to focus efforts on China's west.
So far, though, the campaign lacks cash and cohesiveness. The government will spend nearly $4 billion on infrastructure in the west this year, though it has not said how much an increase that is from last year.
When asked at the Sichuan conference how much Beijing would invest in the west, Li Zibing, vice director of the central government's Western Development Office, would only say "a large amount," and stressed instead the opportunities for foreign investors.
China's western region includes 12 provinces, or autonomous regions, including Xinjiang and Tibet. It is almost as big as Australia, and with its huge deserts, dense mountains and isolated cities, is about as hospitable as Australia's Outback region. The area's population, though, is equal to that of the United States and Mexico combined.
Most people in the western region lead a meager existence on incomes that are a third of those along the coast. The average per capita income in the landlocked Guizhou Province is only 8 percent of that in Shanghai.
"Everybody is talking about the developing west here, but the point is you have to have money," said a middle-aged taxi driver in Urumqi, Xinjiang's capital, where banners extolling western development hang over the streets and from public buses. Droves of unemployed migrant workers gather daily at an intersection on Liberation Road wearing placards advertising their trades. Along the whitewashed wall encircling a construction site, a line of big red characters reads: "Carry out the grand development of the west, speed up the pace of reform."
But unlike America's Westward Ho!, in which the government grabbed land from Indians and gave it to homesteaders, China's ban on private ownership of land means the government has little to offer citizens in its development drive.
And while America's Far West had another coast from which to develop trade, China's western border is a mountainous fence between it and the even poorer Central Asia.
Western executives are mostly watching and waiting to see what policies the government's campaign will bring. Little of consequence has been announced so far. Beijing has said it will extend tax benefits to foreigners who invest in the west, but there are already plenty of more developed parts of the country offering similar benefits. And the government has said it will set up four western special economic zones that will give investors the same preferential treatment as do similar zones on the coast. But after China joins the World Trade Organization and trade barriers fall, such zones will not have as much appeal as when China's economy was more closed.
"The multinationals are looking at the risks and asking, 'Do I invest in Shanghai or Chengdu?', and the answer now is probably Shanghai," said Bruce Murray, who represents the Asian Development Bank in China.
Companies that have invested in western China at the government's behest say poor roads, slow telecommunication lines and a lack of local talent make it difficult to build a successful business there.
To reach On Semiconductor's factory in Sichuan, for example, trucks and factory managers must navigate through a crowded farmers' market each day. And before a new highway was opened last year, truckloads of semiconductors endured a jolting three-hour ride on rough roads to reach Chengdu, the provincial capital.
"For anyone who wants to come to West China, infrastructure is the biggest challenge," said the company's Asia-Pacific chief, Henry Leung.
Another challenge, he said, is keeping good people. Few educated young Chinese want to live in remote Sichuan Province, where On's joint venture partner, a radio factory, was set up in the days when Mao Zedong was moving strategic industries into the mountainous interior to protect them from a potential American invasion.
Many of the Han Chinese who live in the west went there during the earlier western development drive of the late 1950's and early 1960's. Most of them were stuck there even after travel restrictions were lifted in the 1980's because of China's household registration system, which requires that people stay put to receive education and other welfare benefits. Now, the brightest of those people's children are filtering back east. Despite the government's urging, few are likely to choose to move the other way.
Mr. Murray of the development bank and other development experts say China's central government would do best to spend its own money on roads and telephone lines, health care and education to grease the wheels of commerce in western China and strip the red tape from business deals so the market can do its magic. He fears the government will use a heavier hand, nudging the country's state banks to make loans as a matter of government policy, for example, at a time when they are struggling to purge their balance sheets of bad loans made to Rust- Belt-type industries in the 1980's and 1990's.
Already, China's central bank governor, Dai Xianglong, has asked the state banks to support the government's western development program, and one of the largest, the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, has responded by saying it will increase the proportion of its loans to western provinces.
"The government should not use moral suasion, subsidized interest rates or similar policies to force banks to lend for projects in western China," Mr. Murray said, warning that such moves would lead only to a larger bank bailout later on.
Even if the government does start pouring money into the west, many people doubt that it can keep track of all the money. The huge Three Gorges Dam being built across the Yangtze River has been plagued by corruption scandals that have siphoned off hundreds of millions of dollars. And the National Audit Bureau said $9 billion in government money was stolen, misused or wasted last year.
The alternative, though, is too terrifying to consider. Beijing sees the breakup of the Soviet Union as a cautionary tale. And already, the gap between the country's east and west is big enough to fuel discontent among ethnic minorities that complain they are either being exploited or left behind in the expansion.
Beijing recognizes that closing the east-west gap will take time. "If we do a good job in the next 5 to 10 years, we'll have a good start," said Mr. Li of the Western Development Office, "but this is an effort that will take several generations."

HEADLINE: The Court's Clean Air Case

 BODY:
Having failed to persuade Congress on the issue, a coalition of industry groups will be in the Supreme Court today asking the justices to disrupt enforcement of the health-based pollution standards that have been a cornerstone of a quarter-century of progress under the Clean Air Act. How the court responds could have consequences not only for the air Americans breathe, but also for the balance of power between the federal legislative and judicial branches, as well as the functioning of the modern regulatory apparatus.
Before the court is a controversial 2-to-1 decision by a federal appellate panel last year that invalidated tough new air quality standards that the federal Environmental Protection Agency imposed in 1997 to force further reductions in the amounts of ozone and soot in the air. Reviving the arcane "delegation doctrine," in disuse since the New Deal, the quirky ruling said that by failing to give the agency meaningful limits on the setting of standards, Congress had delegated too much legislative authority to the executive branch. 
 There are serious problems with this analysis, not least that it overlooks sections of the Clean Air Act containing guidance that seeks to tie agency action to broad policy principles established by Congress. As a practical matter, however, requiring Congress to go much beyond setting broad policy in a world where regulatory decisions increasingly depend on a high level of scientific or other expertise would upend the modern regulatory regime. Many administrative agencies, not just the E.P.A., operate within broad contours defined by Congress.
For these reasons, the court is unlikely to strike down the standards on the basis of the lower court's non-delegation reasoning. The industry groups know this, which is why they are offering the court another rationale for rejecting the regulations. In brief, they are arguing that the E.P.A. should have been required to take economic factors -- costs and benefits -- into account when establishing the new standards for smog and soot, and indeed should be required to do so in the future.
If accepted, this rationale would effectively overturn an important part of the Clean Air Act as well as subsequent court interpretations of that act. Under the act, the E.P.A. administrator is required to establish "uncompromising" air quality standards that protect public health "with an adequate margin of safety." This language has consistently been interpreted by courts as barring the agency from taking costs into account.
Furthermore, Congress has extensively debated revising the statute to require a cost-benefit analysis at the standard-setting stage, but has declined to do so. Any decision to change course at this point properly belongs with the nation's elected lawmakers, not with the courts.
To a large extent, the fight over this issue relies on a misconception. Far from ignoring costs and benefits, the Clean Air Act is an exquisitely crafted compromise in which costs play no defining role in setting air quality goals, but can be considered by state and local governments in determining the most effective means of achieving those goals. In addition, state and local governments, as well as industry, can appeal to Congress if they find the timetables for meeting standards too onerous. In 1990, for example, Congress gave the states more time to meet existing ozone standards.
This regime, which allows the federal government to set health standards but gives the states flexibility in meeting them, has served the nation well. Absent a decision by Congress to rewrite the underlying statute, the justices have no basis now to alter a system that has worked for 30 years.
