HEADLINE: 25 Years Later, Vietnamese Still Flock to the U.S.

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS

DATELINE: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam

 BODY:
"This present emergency should not last," said the top refugee official at the United Nations as desperate people jammed onto helicopters and small boats to flee the Communist victory in Vietnam 25 years ago.
But it did. It swelled into a vast, clamorous flood of nearly two million people, more than half of whom settled in the United States. 
 It was an unexpected artifact of the Vietnam War and, just as unexpectedly, it continues today. When President Clinton visits Vietnam later in November, in the first trip by a sitting American president since the end of the war, he will arrive in a country that is increasingly linked to the United States by a web of migrants who journey from teeming cities like Ho Chi Minh City, formerly known as Saigon, to cities and towns across America.
One result is that 26,000 Vietnamese a year now emigrate to the United States, helping to shape both countries and forming one of the half-dozen largest flows of immigrants into America from any country in the world.
"It's going to outlive us all," said W. Courtland Robinson, the author of a recent book on the refugee exodus. "I don't think anyone in 1975 thought it would last more than a few months or a few years. But here we are, all these years later, seeing not just the last vestiges but a new manifestation of this migration."
The immigrants say they go in search of an American dream of prosperity and education that shines as brightly here as anywhere in the world.
"I would go too if I had the money," said Nguyen Xuan Hien, 74, who is sending his 11-year-old granddaughter to join her parents in New Orleans. "She'll have a better life there. Conditions here in Vietnam are not perfect, you know."
Most of the immigrants now are part of what one consular official called "an expanding pyramid" of family reunification in which refugee citizens reach back to their homeland to bring their parents, children, siblings and spouses -- who eventually will send for more relatives.
But some, remarkably a quarter-century later, are still technically refugees fleeing the distant echo of a war. At the rate of nearly 2,000 a year, these refugees include the aging survivors of Communist "re-education camps" and the grown children of American soldiers, as well as hundreds of participants in a little-known program that is still cleaning up the last lingering cases of what became a huge refugee-processing bureaucracy.
On their journey, they are crossing paths with some 100,000 Vietnamese-Americans who now return every year to visit or do business in Vietnam.
This human flow will bind the United States and Vietnam for generations to come, but like the war, it also serves to some degree to divide Vietnam.
The migrants and the returnees are mostly from the south, America's former ally against the victorious Communist north. Although Vietnamese attitudes toward the United States are generally cordial today, there is a warmer and more intimate tone to them among many southerners.
And it is mainly the south that enjoys a notable windfall from this relationship: an estimated $2 billion a year sent back to family members from the two million or so ethnic Vietnamese who now live in the United States -- double the total amount of foreign aid received by the government.
Paradoxically, that cash amounts to a far greater contribution to Vietnam's economy than the former refugees could have made had the police caught them, years ago, and prevented them from fleeing the country.
In another twist, the same authorities who once imprisoned people trying to flee now appear to be encouraging the last refugee cases.
"The Vietnamese government occasionally hassles us about the slowness of our processing of these cases," said Charles A. Ray, the American consul general in Saigon. "I have on at least four occasions gotten a letter from the external relations office complaining that our processing is taking too long. It's an odd transaction: these are people going on refugee programs."
Many of those cases involve people who have spent much of their lives in refugee camps, trying for decades to reach the United States or other countries. When the camps around Asia closed down in 1996, more than 100,000 people who had failed to gain asylum were obliged -- sometimes forcibly -- to return to Vietnam.
As part of the deal, the United States promised to interview the returnees one more time. Though they are still required to prove "a well-founded fear of persecution" long after hostilities have ended, the Vietnamese are often given the benefit of the doubt by immigration officials, diplomats say.
In numbers of people resettling in America, Vietnam now ranks behind only the giants Mexico, China and India as well as two traditional sources of immigrants, the Philippines and the Dominican Republic.
Among the applicants at the consulate here the other day was Vu Nguyen, 25, an Amerasian who knows nothing about his father but still holds a hope of finding him. He is taking with him his 4-year-old son, the grandson of an American soldier he may never know.
Le Thi Thu Ngan, 33, was heading to join her new husband, a Vietnamese-American who returned here recently, as many do, to find a Vietnamese bride. She is a mathematics teacher but speaks no English.
Le Thi Minh Trang, 28, was going to join her father, a former inmate at a re-education camp, taking her two small sons along. "I don't know if I'll like it there, but I'm going for the future of my children," she said.
Over the years, the United States accepted close to one million people from Vietnam, beginning with the first rush of 130,000 who fled by helicopter, boat and airplane when Saigon fell in April 1975.
Then came the flood of "boat people," perhaps 10 or 15 percent of whom died at sea, with some 400,000 finding asylum in the United States. The United States took another 20,000 "land people" who fled on foot through neighboring Cambodia.
That emigration was curbed after 1979 when Vietnam agreed to an Orderly Departure Program, in which refugees were processed in Ho Chi Minh City and flown to receiving countries. Altogether some 400,000 people arrived in the United States in that program.
About a decade ago, the United States inaugurated special programs to accept the Amerasian children of servicemen and the survivors of re-education camps, where high-ranking South Vietnamese officials and military officers were incarcerated.
About 90,000 people have been admitted in the Amerasian program since its inception, including 902 in the last year. About 165,000 people have been admitted in the program for re-education camp survivors, 1,021 of them in the last year.
Vietnam also has become one of the leading sources for adoption by Americans, with 717 children going to the United States in the last year. And about 25,000 Vietnamese received non-immigrant visas last year, like visitors from any nation, as students, tourists, government officials and business travelers.
The last vestiges of the war have become the domain of clerks, processing paperwork and stamping visas. It is necessary work, Mr. Robinson said.
"We are simply acknowledging our continued commitment to the people who at one time sided with us and with the South Vietnamese cause, and we are all the better for it," he said. "So let's see it through to an honorable conclusion.
"One hopes that at some point it will conclude. But I'm not holding my breath."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE TEXAS GOVERNOR;
Bush's Finishing Day Includes Tennessee and Arkansas

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI

DATELINE: BENTONVILLE, Ark., Nov. 6

 BODY:
Nearly 17 months after he first issued his call for a "fresh start after a season of cynicism," Gov. George W. Bush ended his quest for the presidency today on a nearly identical note, pledging to purge Washington of what he characterized as a crippling discord.
The course Mr. Bush charted over his final hours on the campaign trail, plotted with as much concern for symbolism as for raw electoral arithmetic, left no doubt about where he placed the blame for that atmosphere. 
 The Texas governor's first major rally was in Tennessee and his last before heading home late tonight was here in Arkansas, the states that gave political birth to Vice President Al Gore and President Bill Clinton.
Mr. Bush's words made equally clear that he saw himself as the country's best hope for bridging ideological divides, healing partisan wounds and making sure Americans could gaze upon the White House with unfettered respect.
"It's time for new leadership in Washington, D.C," Mr. Bush told the crowd here late tonight in Bentonville, a Republican stronghold with its own significance. It lies in the district where a young Bill Clinton once ran a failed campaign for Congress, and it is now represented by Asa Hutchinson, one of the House Republicans who presided over Mr. Clinton's impeachment.
Indeed, Mr. Clinton was the person Mr. Bush seemed to have in mind as he told a cheering crowd of thousands, "The next leader of the United States must understand the awesome responsibilities of the office."
Just before Mr. Bush began and just after he ended his remarks on a stage inside a local airport hangar, his campaign played a new tape of music. It featured snippets of the Fleetwood Mac song "Don't Stop (Thinking About Tomorrow)," which Mr. Clinton used as the theme for his 1992 campaign, followed by The Who song "Won't Get Fooled Again."
Almost 12 hours earlier, in Chattanooga, Tenn., Mr. Bush told supporters there was "a better day ahead" if the country chose to elect someone who would "elevate the people's business above everyday politics." Supporters' chants evoked the nearness of the moment of decision.
"One more day!" they roared.
What the nation needed, Mr. Bush told them, was "a president who can unite this nation, a president who puts aside the endless partisan bickering that seems to gridlock our nation's capital, a president who puts the people first, a president who lifts this nation's spirits."
"I'll be that president," he added, a sentence that was equal parts promise and prediction. It underscored the optimism that Mr. Bush had, from the very beginning, sought to project to voters.
His schedule for a 16-hour day was also an expression of that. Between stops in Tennessee and Arkansas, his plane touched down in Wisconsin and Iowa, and while any one of those four states could provide the key to a Bush victory, none has as many electoral votes as battlegrounds like Michigan and Pennsylvania.
But the states are genuine tossups that were initially expected to be much more hospitable to Mr. Gore. By visiting them today, Mr. Bush emphasized the breadth of his appeal and the sometimes surprising vulnerability of the vice president.
He did not let his assertion of strength and confidence distract him from the business of beseeching supporters to grant him victory. With 24 hours before Election Day, Mr. Bush stripped campaigning to its essence: coaxing and cajoling, pleading and persuading.
"I want you to understand that I can't win without you," Mr. Bush told a crowd of about 1,000 in Green Bay, Wis. "I hope you redouble your efforts to make sure people get out to the polls." Minutes later, he added: "When you go out there and tell the folks where we stand on the issues and where we stand when it comes to bringing people together to get things done, and you tell them that the core of this campaign is the inherent trust in the American people, I believe it doesn't matter what political party they're in. They're going to come our way."
At a theater in Davenport, Iowa, he took a similarly blunt tack.
"Not only do I want your vote," Mr. Bush said, "I want your help. I hope you continue to man those phones, and for those of you who are calling on my behalf, thanks from the bottom of my heart."
"Don't let up," he said. "It's a close election."
Mr. Bush repeatedly needled Mr. Gore, which was much of the point of going to Tennessee, where Mr. Gore is not at all certain to prevail. The Texas governor used the location to claim that Mr. Gore's decades of experience in Washington had estranged him from the rest of the country by making him too trusting of federal government and too fond of federal spending.
"My opponent vows to carry his home state," Mr. Bush said from a stage at a Chattanooga airport. "He may win Washington, D.C., but he's not going to win Tennessee."
"He forgot his roots," he said. "He trusts Washington. We trust the people."
Here in Bentonville, Mr. Bush was jubilant, clearly reveling in the way his appearance, and the choreography of it, tweaked Mr. Clinton. But at the rallies in Chattanooga and Green Bay, Mr. Bush had come across as slightly less ebullient than usual. He seemed serene, his demeanor in keeping with the events, which were less crowded and shorter on gaudy pageantry and eye-popping fireworks than previous rallies.
Maybe Mr. Bush was after an aura of simple earnestness. Maybe he understood that there was only so much a candidate could do at this late stage. Or maybe he had sacrificed some of his energy to the hundreds of thousands of miles that it took to get to this point. His hair was grayer than when he started. But his message, an answer to the challenge of campaigning against an incumbent administration during peace and prosperity, was mostly unchanged.
Mr. Bush was careful to dwell on positions with appeal in the places he visited. In both Iowa and Wisconsin, where agriculture is an important part of the economy, he called for an end to the inheritance tax, which farmers find especially onerous.
Mr. Bush referred to it as "the death tax," although he slipped in Wisconsin and labeled it "the death penalty." Falling prey to scattered flubs, he also said in Iowa that cash-strapped elderly people should not be forced to choose between "prescription drugs and medicine," meaning prescription drugs and food.
But what stood out today were broad themes and emotions, and he wrapped his events -- and himself -- in patriotic colors. There was no balloon drop or confetti in Davenport, but there was a giant American flag behind Mr. Bush. His outfit was red (tie), white (shirt) and blue (suit).
"The greatness of the country lies ahead," he told the people in Chattanooga. "I strongly believe that this nation can accomplish anything -- anything -- we set our mind to."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: PROGNOSTICATORS;
Experts, Once Certain, Now Say Gore Is a Maybe

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6

 BODY:
Political scientists who two months ago predicted victory for Vice President Al Gore acknowledged today that they were much less sure now. And they said it was not their thinking but the candidate's campaigning that had been wrong.
"It was Gore's election to lose," Christopher Wlezien, an associate professor of political science at the University of Houston, said today. 
 And has he lost it? "It's a coin flip," Mr. Wlezien said. Two months ago, at the 96th annual meeting of the American Political Science Association here, he predicted Mr. Gore would get 55.2 percent of the popular vote.
Thomas M. Holbrook, of the University of Wisconsin at Milwaukee, went even further out on a limb in September, forecasting a Gore landslide of 60.3 percent. An outcome like that, of course, would make Gov. George W. Bush a latter-day Alf Landon or Barry Goldwater.
Did he still think Mr. Gore would win? "Yes," Mr. Holbrook said, but narrowly. The candidate has done "just about everything he could do to blow what should have been a sure thing," he said. Most important, Mr. Holbrook thought, Mr. Gore failed to make this era of prosperity the linchpin of his campaign.
Mr. Wlezien, Mr. Holbrook and several others at the Washington gathering used various statistical models in reaching their predictions. In general, they used equations based on the current president's approval rating and economic trends over a good many months leading up to this autumn.
On the face of it, the experts said, Mr. Gore looked like a sure winner. The economy is a politician's dream, and President Clinton's job-approval rating (notwithstanding his indiscretions) has remained high: 62 percent by one poll in early September, 58 percent in another in late October.
Mr. Wlezien, who worked with Robert Erikson of Columbia University in devising his model, said its calculations matched the outcome of the presidential elections from 1952 through 1996.
Perhaps, the experts agreed, Mr. Gore had been unable to resolve a central dilemma of his candidacy: how to claim credit for the good economic times that coincided with the Clinton presidency while campaigning as his own man.
James C. Garand, a political science professor at Louisiana State University, said "Clinton fatigue" might be the kind of "idiosyncratic occurrence" that derails even the best statistical models.
Taken together, the experts' comments are a reminder that success in politics demands art as well as science, knowing whose advice to listen to -- and having a little luck.

HEADLINE: Lazio and Clinton, Both Upbeat, Rally Troops on Last Day;
First Lady Stresses Issues, From Upstate to Midtown

BYLINE: By DEAN E. MURPHY and ADAM NAGOURNEY

 BODY:
Hillary Rodham Clinton closed out her 16-month quest for elective office last night at a boisterous rally in a union hall in Midtown Manhattan, saying the outcome of her bid for the United States Senate should be determined by the issues, not the name-calling that dominated the final weeks of the campaign.
Mrs. Clinton was joined by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the retiring incumbent she hopes to succeed, in one of their few joint appearances since she formally announced her candidacy in February after a seven-month exploratory campaign. Mr. Moynihan was also featured in a two-minute television advertisement broadcast last night on three New York City stations, in which Mrs. Clinton thanked New Yorkers of all political leanings for an "extraordinary year and a half" and asked that "the truly important things" in the race do not "get lost in the shuffle." 
 Mrs. Clinton was escorted into the hot and sweaty union hall on West 43rd Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues by Mr. Moynihan as well as Senator Charles E. Schumer, who had joined her on a daylong push for upstate votes that took them to Buffalo, Albany, Jamestown and Rochester before the Manhattan rally.
"Eleanor Roosevelt would have loved Hillary Clinton," Mr. Moynihan said. "If she were alive today, she would be on this platform."
The rally was not quite as energetic as the one Mr. Schumer did with the first lady in the same hall two years ago on the eve of his own election. There were a few empty spots on the floor and some "shushes" to quiet some people who chattered as Mrs. Clinton spoke. Yet she plunged ahead.
"If you will fight for me, if you will work for me for the next 24 hours, I will go to the Senate and fight for you in the next six years," she said, her voice nearly gone.
The campaign finale in Manhattan came at the end of a day in which Mrs. Clinton made a final drive for votes upstate, where her apparent inroads into traditionally Republican territory had helped build a growing optimism in her campaign.
"There are so many issues at stake in this election, but the core issue is the upstate economy," Mrs. Clinton said at Buffalo State College. "I am making it a top priority. I will be a leader. I will be there for you, and I will be back here so many times you will be sick of seeing me."
Invoking little of the partisan rhetoric that had dominated much of the final week of the Senate race, Mrs. Clinton called for New Yorkers to vote Democratic, but never mentioned her opponent, Representative Lazio, by name and only occasionally made references to the Republican Party and its policies.
Her message and mood were positive throughout the day, ending with the rally last night and the release of the two-minute television advertisement. In the advertisement, Mrs. Clinton spoke directly to New Yorkers for 90 seconds. The rest of the ad had testimonials to the first lady from Mr. Moynihan, Vice President Al Gore and Senators Schumer and Joseph I. Lieberman.
"Tonight I ask for your vote," Mrs. Clinton said in the ad. "I want you to know if you send me to the Senate, I'll work my heart out for you. Now this election ends where it belongs, in your hands."
In Albany, she told about 1,500 supporters gathered in the afternoon cold outside the front steps of City Hall that upstate has "some of the most beautiful countryside in the entire world" and that she is committed to both "growing the economy and protecting the environment." In her remarks, she gave a broad summary of the other issues she considers most important to New Yorkers, including protecting Social Security, paying down the national debt, providing targeted tax cuts, improving access to health care and helping to ease the financial burdens on families caring for elderly relatives.
The comedian Bill Cosby, who joined Mrs. Clinton on her fly-around tour of the state, said in Albany that he could not imagine wanting to hold elective office, but he predicted that Mrs. Clinton would do just that beginning in January.
"This is another joke we are going to play on Hillary," Mr. Cosby said. "We are going to vote her into office. She wants it, she is going to get it."
At the early morning rally in Buffalo, Mrs. Clinton appeared jubilant and confident as she kept the beat with the band, 10,000 Maniacs, and then used a string of football metaphors in her speech to make sure her audience of 1,000 had no doubts that she knows what is important in Erie County.
Doug Flutie, the Buffalo Bills quarterback, took the stage first, speaking glowingly of the first lady's commitment to children and health care, and even taking a turn at the drums as 10,000 Maniacs welcomed her to the microphone with a deafening version of "These Are Days."
"He is there, he never gives up," Mrs. Clinton said of Mr. Flutie, whose team won in overtime on Sunday. "I want to use that as an inspiration. I will never give up on Buffalo, western New York or Erie County."
Mrs. Clinton also said she was eager to work with Mr. Schumer in the Senate.
"I believe the two of us will be an unstoppable team for New York because we will never give up, just like Doug Flutie," she said. "We will be there day in and day out, throwing long and going down the field to bring prosperity and progress to New York."

HEADLINE: State Proposals Will Decide The Pace of Construction

BYLINE: By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr.

 BODY:
Across the nation voters will decide today whether to enact anti-sprawl laws in hundreds of referendums that will show how far residents of fast-growing regions are willing to go to slow the pace of construction in the suburbs.
Statewide measures in Arizona and Colorado are the most prominent responses yet to residents' concerns in places like Denver and Phoenix that the quality of life is being harmed by congestion and crowding caused by rapid construction of subdivisions, shopping malls and other suburban development. At the local level across much of the nation, efforts to limit sprawl have already picked up strong momentum, with some communities implementing moratoriums on building permits or using other tactics to halt growth. 
 Hundreds of antigrowth proposals are on local ballots across the nation, including measures that could slow the pace of development in parts of California.
In 23 states there are at least 33 other statewide growth-related initiatives, including many calling for transportation improvements, said Phyllis Myers, president of State Resource Strategies, a consulting firm in Washington that just finished a report for the Brookings Institution on growth-control ballot proposals.
As recently as September, polls showed that the proposals in Arizona and Colorado enjoyed strong voter support. But business groups, led by the building and construction companies which stand to lose the most financially if the antigrowth initiatives pass, have poured more than $4 million in Arizona, and close to $6 million in Colorado, into television commercials and other efforts to defeat the measures.
That spending, as well as opposition from advocacy groups including Habitat for Humanity, which is concerned that the proposals could cause housing prices to jump, appears to have turned the tide in Colorado, where recent polls indicate that most voters now oppose the plan. In Arizona, both sides say they believe that most residents now oppose the initiative.
Among other things, both statewide proposals would require many towns to create growth boundaries approved by voters. New development outside the boundaries would be sharply limited, and any changes to allow significant new growth outside those confines could occur only with new voter approval.
The initiatives are the most wide-ranging growth-control measures ever proposed on a statewide ballot, and they would give residents unprecedented direct power over new development, Ms. Myers said.
Supporters contend that the voter approvals will serve as a check against the power of the building and construction industries to lobby for favorable regulations, but critics say the measures will sharply slow new development, hurt the regional economy and cause home prices to soar.
Businesses fear that the proposals would make it harder for employees to find reasonably priced housing, while housing groups, who are already having trouble coping with rising costs for land, worry that the measures will further worsen shortages of cheaper housing.
This is the first time in 21 years Habitat for Humanity's affiliates in Colorado have taken a position on any political issue there, said Lori Vaclavik, executive director for Habitat for Humanity of Metro Denver.
"It is extremely rare for us to do this," Ms. Vaclavik said, "and we only did so because we feel this amendment so threatens our mission and the future of affordable housing in Colorado."
The environmental groups that have played a major role in getting the initiatives on the ballot say fears of higher housing costs are overblown. Growth restrictions do play a role in higher housing costs, but other factors have a bigger impact, said Deron Lovaas, a Sierra Club official who is helping coordinate the anti-sprawl initiatives.
Development has spiraled out of control in many Western regions, including in Colorado and Arizona, Mr. Lovaas said, because they "have been growing at a phenomenal rate, coupled with a very libertarian system of government and land use." Mr. Lovaas called this year's election a watershed for these sorts of issues and said he hoped strong support at the ballot box would encourage legislators in other states to take steps to control growth.
Noting that the Arizona and Colorado proposals -- and initiatives in other places -- were the result of citizen petitions, Ms. Myers of State Resource Strategies said pressure for such referendums had been growing because residents felt that lawmakers were not doing enough.
"They reflect years of frustration and lots of debate, and depending on who you are, action or inaction on these issues" by state legislators, she said.
Regardless of how the votes go on Tuesday, Ms. Myers added, "the political and elected leaders have gotten the message of how important these issues are to voters."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
Campaign Ends; Now the Voters Will Have Their Say

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK

DATELINE: MIAMI, Tuesday, Nov. 7

 BODY:
Focused to the end on his message, Vice President Al Gore persevered Monday through a 30-hour, seven-city assault on the closely contested states that will determine whether his 13-year pursuit of the presidency culminates in a "cold driving rain" or a "shaft of golden sunlight."
Throughout the campaign, Mr. Gore has portrayed himself as more vigorous than his Republican opponent, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, and he drove that theme home today with the help of a manic schedule. After a rally at the airport in Waterloo, Iowa, that ended at 1 a.m. Monday, he began again at 5:30 a.m. at a John Deere factory there, where he shook hands with workers and gave interviews in the dark to three television networks. 
 Mr. Gore's sleep-deprived schedule then took him to a rally in St. Louis, to a United Auto Workers union hall and a black church in Flint, Mich., and to a midnight rally with the musicians Stevie Wonder and Jon Bon Jovi in Miami's South Beach. It was to conclude with a 4 a.m. speech to late-shift health care workers in Tampa, a flight to Nashville just past sunrise and a drive to his hometown, Carthage, to vote at midday and then share lunch with his 87-year-old mother.
In an interview with a Tampa television station on Sunday night, Mr. Gore pointedly noted that he would hold his last campaign event "after my opponent's gone to bed."
By the time he arrived in Flint, Mr. Gore was punchy from exhaustion, his face puffy and pink, with rivulets of sweat meandering down his cheek. He sucked on lozenges as he spoke, but they did little to soothe his hoarseness.
"There are only a few hours left before the polls close," Mr. Gore said, meaning of course that they were about to open. On Sunday night, at a rally in Dearborn, Mich., he twice acknowledged Bruce Hornsby, the rock musician who had warmed up his crowd, as Rogers Hornsby, the long-dead St. Louis Cardinal.
At the midday rally in St. Louis, Mr. Gore dusted off the rain-or-shine allegory that he has used to close countless events. In it, he presents two Wednesday-morning alternatives to his supporters. The first, he tells them with the gloominess of Eeyore, is that they can wake up to a splitting headache and a cold driving rain and find that their waterlogged newspaper announces a Bush victory. Or, he says, they can awaken to golden sunlight, the sweet sound of songbirds, the aroma of fresh-brewed coffee and their favorite song on the clock radio.
"You leap out of bed," Mr. Gore said, sashaying to his right, "and you dance your way to the front door and you fling open the door to the warm rays of that sun, and you pick up that newspaper and it says: 'Gore-Lieberman Win!' "
Mr. Gore can only hope that Monday's weather was not ominous, as the cold driving rain he spoke of dampened his travels in Iowa and Missouri.
When he arrived at the Black Hawk County Democratic headquarters in Waterloo Monday morning, Mr. Gore found only about 60 die-hards gathered under a canopy of striped umbrellas.
In brief remarks, he sounded like a precinct captain charging his troops, telling his listeners that their ability to knock on doors, make telephone calls and drive people to the polls is "what is going to win this race."
In fact, Democratic strategists are deeply concerned about the weather, fearing that rain could suppress turnout in crucial Midwestern states like Michigan and Wisconsin.
"The weather will always be a factor in turnout in Democratic neighborhoods," said Donna Brazile, Mr. Gore's campaign manager and meteorologist for the day. "There's a Canadian cold front, there's some rain, there's a storm that started in the Pacific, there's a storm that came out of Texas."
Ms. Brazile said the campaign would be prepared for the worst, and had requisitioned more vans to transport inner-city voters in places like Detroit and Milwaukee. Last-minute radio and telephone messages would provide phone numbers for people to call for rides, she said.
In stressing the importance of turnout, Mr. Gore has spoken repeatedly in the last two days of the historic tightness of this year's race.
"It is close, close, close," he said in Flint. "They say this is going to be the closest race since 1960 when John Kennedy won by a margin of one vote per precinct. I need each one of you to get me one more vote if you can do it."
Mr. Gore's aides seem neither confident nor despondent. While they acknowledge that most national polls show Mr. Bush with a small lead, they have been heartened by positive poll results in states like Florida, Pennsylvania and Michigan with crucial Electoral College votes.
"It's creeping momentum," said William M. Daley, Mr. Gore's campaign chairman, who placed great faith in the Democratic field operation. "Whoever thinks there is big movement, there isn't."
Mr. Gore, who first ran for president in 1988 and then joined President Clinton's ticket in 1992 and 1996, offered no valedictories and no broad reflections on his campaign or career. Instead, he demonstrated the imperturbable discipline that has marked many of his campaigns, delivering virtually the same speech he has given hundreds of times.
In St. Louis, Mr. Gore stood with Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House minority leader, and pleaded with voters to make their native son speaker by giving the Democrats a majority in the House. In Flint, he stressed his pro-union stands, and also tried to calm fears that he would take weapons away from hunters and sportsmen. "It never will happen," he said, "if I have anything to say about it."
Mr. Gore continued to bash Mr. Bush on his proposals for tax cuts and Social Security and for his record in Texas on the environment and health care. In a Sunday night speech in Milwaukee, he found a new, if offbeat, cause for derision: Texas, he said, has the country's highest rates for homeowners insurance.
But for the most part, Mr. Gore spoke of his devotion to middle-class families and his determination to bring along those who have yet to enjoy the recent prosperity. The Democrats' economic record, he asserted, stands far above that of the previous Republican administrations.
"It's ironic to me," he said, "that the folks on the other side are still living on a reputation of being good managers and having a good sense of the economy when actually they drove the economy into the ditch."

HEADLINE: EUROPEANS SUING BIG TOBACCO IN U.S.

BYLINE: By SUZANNE DALEY

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 6

 BODY:
The European Commission said today that it had filed a civil lawsuit in the United States against the Philip Morris Company and the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company seeking damages for what it called their involvement with organized crime in smuggling cigarettes into Europe.
In announcing the suit in Brussels today, the executive body of the European Union accused the two tobacco companies of using money laundering, wire fraud and other activities in "pursuit of a massive, ongoing dd <page Officials at Philip Morris and R. J. Reynolds said they had not reviewed the suit, which ran 188 pages, but they denied any involvement with smugglers. They also raised questions about why the suit had been filed in the United States. 
 The case is only the latest sign of frustration among government officials in Europe who believe that they are losing billions of dollars in customs and tax revenues because of illicit sales of American cigarettes that officials believe involve American manufacturers.
The British government has opened an investigation into British American Tobacco, the world's No. 2 tobacco company, which it suspects of illegally importing cigarettes into Britain. And officials at the European Union said several of the 15 Western European nations that make up the union would probably file suits of their own over the loss of revenue. Italy said today that it planned to join the suit, which was filed in Federal District Court in Brooklyn on Friday.
Nor has the issue escaped the notice of Justice Department officials in the United States. A federal grand jury in North Carolina has been investigating allegations that tobacco companies have been knowingly selling to dealers who resell American cigarettes to smuggling rings that infiltrate European countries.
Faced with little or no growth in sales in the United States, American tobacco companies have been aggressively expanding their overseas sales and marketing. But American brands, subject to various taxes and import duties, are expensive -- as much as $6.67 a pack in Norway -- and smugglers are increasingly avoiding duties by illegally bringing cigarettes into markets like Spain and Italy and selling them for 20 to 30 percent less than the legal price.
The European Commission said it was seeking financial compensation for what the suit claimed was billions of dollars in tax loses the European governments have suffered, as well as injunctive relief to prevent further smuggling. It did not claim a specific amount of damages.
But experts have estimated that the countries that make up the European Union lose about $1.5 billion a year in taxes and duties because of black market cigarettes.
In a statement, the union's budget commissioner, Michaele Schreyer, said the suit represented a new strategy to fight fraud and financial irregularities. It maintains that the two companies breached the United States Racketeering Influenced and Corrupt Organization Act (RICO) by involvement with smuggling rings.
Industry analysts say the vast discrepancy in taxes on cigarettes in Europe makes the Continent an easy target for smugglers. In 1999, for instance, American cigarettes were selling for $1.75 in Spain and $5.25 in Britain. Since the European Union has open borders, transporting cigarettes from low-tax to high-tax countries is easy, the analysts say.
European governments have also blamed American manufacturers, saying they have sold cigarettes to distributors who admit that they are selling them to smugglers.
The lawsuit announced today repeats that claim and provides some detailed descriptions of smuggling activity that has brought thousands of cases of American cigarettes to Spain during the 90's. It also maintains that company officials have devised elaborate schemes to move cigarettes into Europe and accused top Philip Morris executives of ordering the systematic destruction of documents related to smuggling.
In one example, the suit claims that R. J. Reynolds would sell cigarettes from its offices in Miami to a Panamanian company that would arrange for the cigarettes to be shipped to a warehouse in Rotterdam. There, paperwork would be generated to show that the cigarettes were intended for the Canary Islands. In fact, they went by truck to Barcelona.
American tobacco companies have consistently resisted efforts to obtain the names of international customers, European prosecutors have said.
Some health advocates applauded the decision to file the case. "I think it is long overdue," said Dr. Ron Davis, the former editor of Tobacco Control, a British scientific magazine. "There is growing evidence that the cigarette manufacturers are involved in the smuggling."
But whether the strategy will succeed is unclear. Some industry analysts said the suit would be thrown out on jurisdictional grounds.
"What are they doing in Brooklyn?" said David J. Adelman, a tobacco industry analyst with Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "Obviously, the E.U. wants to take advantage of the American legal system. But what is the connection? This is a little like taking a murderer from France and wanting to try him in Texas because it has the death penalty."
Others said the American lawyers who filed the suit were looking for a sympathetic judge. The Federal District Court in Brooklyn has several liability cases pending against American cigarette companies, and Jack B. Weinstein, a senior judge, is known for handling cases seeking damages from the companies. The European case has been assigned to Judge Viktor V. Pohorelsky.
Analysts said the union would have great difficulty proving how much money had been lost, and still others suggested that the lawsuit was at least partly a result of the European Commission's frustrations in dealing with the cigarette industry as a whole. A recent initiative to curb cigarette advertising in Europe was struck down by a European court.
In its brief statement, R. J. Reynolds said that to suggest that it has been involved in smuggling in Europe or elsewhere was insupportable and untrue.
Philip Morris Europe said it questioned why the Europeans sued in the United States. "We are convinced that the far better approach would be for the commission and all other interested parties to work together in the fight against trade in contraband, including counterfeit products, and we remain ready to cooperate with the European Commission and the member states in that regard," said David R. Davies, the company's vice president for corporate affairs.
In his statement, Mr. Davies also said Philip Morris "would vigorously contest the commission's unprecedented attempt to utilize American courts to impose liability upon us."
Trying to use the American courts to address smuggling has been tried before by Canada. Last year, Canada sued R. J. Reynolds for $1 billion in Federal District Court in Syracuse, maintaining that the company conspired to smuggle tobacco products into Canada to avoid taxes.
The lawsuit contended that the company had set up a network of smugglers and offshore companies to flood Canada with cheap cigarettes after the government doubled taxes and duties on tobacco. Canada later lowered the taxes after it said it could not combat a wave of smuggling from the United States.
The case was dismissed in July by a judge who ruled that American courts cannot be used to collect another country's taxes. Lawyers for Canada have appealed.

HEADLINE: WORLD BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

 BODY:

EUROPE
 
GERMANY: COMMUNIST APPEALS -- East Germany's last Communist ruler, Egon Krenz, 63, will be freed from prison today until Thursday so he can appeal a 1999 manslaughter conviction to the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg, France. Mr. Krenz, who is serving six and a half years for issuing shoot-to-kill orders to border guards at the Berlin Wall, says he was only following orders from Moscow. The former Soviet president, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, has supported Mr. Krentz, saying his prosecution broke agreements that ended the cold war. Victor Homola (NYT)
 
BRITAIN: STORMS CONTINUE -- Two people died when their car was struck by a tree as storms continued to batter much of Britain, bringing extensive flooding and causing widespread chaos to the railroad system. Much of western Europe was also struck by severe weather, including deep snow and winds of up to 160 miles per hour in Switzerland and heavy rainfalls that caused flooding along the Mediterranean coast in France. Sarah Lyall (NYT) 

FINLAND: APOLOGY TO JEWS -- Prime Minister Paavo Lipponen officially apologized to the Jewish community for the extradition of eight Jews to Germany in 1942. "The extradition was a shameful moment in Finnish history," Mr. Lipponen said on Sunday at the unveiling of a memorial to the victims. Only one of the eight survived after they were sent to Auschwitz in 1943, said newspapers in Finland, now home to about 1,500 Jews. (Reuters)
 
ITALY: ANCIENT BONES IN QUESTION -- Florence has called off a plan to rebury the bones said by a local journalist to be those of Giotto, the early Renaissance painter, after an American archaeologist disputed the findings, a Florence newspaper said. Franklin Tokler, a professor of art and architecture at the University of Pittsburgh who oversaw the original excavation, wrote to the cardinal of Florence imploring him to stop the ceremony, saying, "You may well end up honoring the bones of some fat butcher." Alessandra Stanley (NYT)
 
ASIA
 
INDONESIA: U.S. EMBASSY SECTION REOPENS -- After a two-week suspension of consular services due to a security threat, the United States Embassy in Jakarta reopened its visa section today. The embassy was shut to the public on Oct. 25. The partial closure coincided with a sharp downturn in relations between the two countries. Indonesian lawmakers have demanded that Ambassador Robert Gelbard be replaced for meddling in the country's internal affairs. Mr. Gelbard has alienated some leaders with his recommendations for economic and political reforms in Indonesia. (AP)
 
INDONESIA: PLEA TO SUHARTO SON -- Lawyers for Hutomo Mandala Putra, one of the millionaire sons of former President Suharto, called on him to come out of hiding and begin serving an 18-month prison sentence for corruption. The son, known as Tommy Suharto, was convicted in September of involvement in a land scandal. Seth Mydans (NYT)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
IRAQ: TRIAL IN U.N. DEATHS -- A man appeared in a Baghdad court charged with killing two United Nations staff members and wounding seven others in the Iraqi capital last June. Fuad Hussein Haider is accused of killing two Food and Agriculture Organization employees when he burst into the their Baghdad office and opened fire. (Reuters)
 
IRAN: PRO-DEMOCRACY PROTEST -- More than 1,000 students denounced hard-liners and voiced support for pro-democracy reforms at a rally on the Tehran University campus. Several hard-line vigilantes tried to disrupt the gathering, which ended without violence. Plainclothes security forces, however, arrested a few students after they left the university grounds. (AP)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
NICARAGUA: A SANDINISTA VICTORY -- The Sandinista Party scored its first major electoral victory since being thrown out of power in 1990 when Herty Lewites, a former minister of tourism, was elected mayor of Managua in municipal elections held Sunday. While candidates for the governing Liberal Constitutionalist Party were expected to win a majority of local posts, the Sandinista victory in the capital places the former revolutionary rulers in an influential position for the presidential race next year.David Gonzalez (NYT)
 
CANADA: NECK AND NECK IN QUEBEC -- Three weeks from a national election, the governing Liberals and the secessionist Bloc Quebecois are neck and neck in Quebec, the second most populous province, according to a new poll by Leger Marketing. In the contest over Quebec's 75-member parliamentary delegation, the poll gave each party 43 percent. In the poll, held last week, the Canadian Alliance, the new conservative party, supplanted the Progressive Conservatives as the province's third party, winning preferences from 8 percent of the 3,514 people polled. James Brooke (NYT)
 
AFRICA
 
ZIMBABWE: WHITES SUE MUGABE -- Challenging President Robert Mugabe's land reform program, lawyers for white commercial farmers went to the Supreme Court to argue that the government did not have the right to seize land without compensation. The farmers are challenging the government's plan to resettle blacks on more than 3,000 white-owned farms. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)
 
MALAWI: 3 TOP AIDES DROPPED -- President Bakili Muluzi has dropped three influential ministers from his cabinet after firing the previous administration over accusations of graft. A 32-member cabinet announced Sunday did not incude the former ministers, Cassium Chilumpha for education, Brown Mpinganjira for transport and public works and Peter Chupa for labor and vocational training. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
A 'Serpent' Lives to Give His Testimony

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:

SPEAK YOU ALSO
A Survivor's Reckoning
By Paul Steinberg
163 pages. Metropolitan Books. $21.
Our knowledge of the Nazi genocide against the Jews continues, remarkably, to increase, and with it the intimacy of our own vicarious confrontation with human iniquity. Among the most illuminating recent additions to the store of unwelcome but necessary knowledge are the two volumes of diaries by Victor Klemperer, a Jew who survived the war years in Germany itself, and the more recently published journals of the Romanian writer Mihail Sebastian. But it is unlikely that there will be a memoir of more terse power than Paul Steinberg's "Speak You Also," a testimony from within the chamber of evil itself that performs the duty of memory with a special kind of pain and meaning. 
 Long before he sat down to write and to remember, Steinberg was an acidic symbol of endurance in the Nazi death camps. Primo Levi, the first great chronicler of Auschwitz, wrote about him in his magisterial "If This Is a Man," published in the United States in 1969. Levi called Steinberg "Henri," and described him with an embittered awe as a kind of savage for survival -- "hard and distant, enclosed in armor, the enemy of all, inhumanly cunning and incomprehensible like the serpent in Genesis."
In "Speak You Also," Steinberg, who died last year at the age of 73, makes his own sort of apology for the life he led, and in so doing he has produced an important and unforgettable document. I do not mean that it is a faultless document. Steinberg's economy of gesture takes this account of spiritual and psychological attrition and strips it to its essentials, dispensing with self-pity and self-justification. Steinberg does not deny being the man whom Levi compared to the biblical snake. His purpose, as he states it, is not to provide a "litany of atrocities." It is, as he says: "To follow the process, the degradation of human beings before annihilation. The death of feeling, the death of thought, then the death of the man."
It does that, even if it also leaves us yearning to know more about Steinberg himself, for example, about his father -- an early Russian revolutionary who knew Lenin and Trotsky but failed to give fatherly love to his son -- whom he dispenses with in a few lines. We would like to know more about other members of the family, not just their contribution to the author's makeup, but the practical details: how did they manage, if they did manage, during the war? While Steinberg introduces himself as the Henri of Levi's account, he tells us very sparingly about his own encounters and thoughts about Levi, and about the different means used by the two men to survive.
Steinberg does recount his arrest in 1943 at the age of 16 at a bakery in Paris, and he tells us enough to demonstrate that he was a tough kid, more or less already on his own, interested in chemistry and in the horse races and gifted in the ways of the street. He presents his story with a kind of disillusioned eloquence, almost a gallows humor, as when he wonders whether the two French policemen who turned him over to the Germans ever "gave a thought, once or twice, to the kid they sent off to hell with his chemistry book." Steinberg continues: "The virus of conscience is present in all of us, but only a few people fall ill or develop an itch from it. The rest get off scot-free."
Steinberg felt the itch for half a century. His book is first of all a recollection of human abasement: "Our flesh and muscles melt away, our teeth loosen, our guts liquefy, our wounds fester, and we die, we die, we die." It is also an agonized coping with the selectivity of memory -- why certain faces have remained etched in his memory while others, including his best friend at Auschwitz, who died early, have been effaced. Steinberg puzzles over his own survival even as he pieces together the rare combination of personal traits and apparent sheer luck that went into it.
Born in Berlin, Steinberg spoke perfect German, which helped, and he knew English, which enabled him to ingratiate himself with some English prisoners of war who were able to offer him some crucial protection. He knew enough chemistry to be of use.
He quickly understood the power of life and death held by the block bosses, ordinary criminals whom the SS trusted to run the barracks, usually with Nazi-like brutality, and he sucked up to them: "Each one of these monsters had a flaw, a weakness, which it was up to me to find: this one needed flattering, that one had a repressed paternal instinct or the need to confide in someone who seemed to take an interest in him."
When he comes down with a debilitating fever known as erysipelas, a Jewish infirmary doctor finds two doses of a newly discovered sulfa drug, and, while others are dying, Steinberg is saved. Every month, the SS comes through the barracks selecting prisoners for immediate transport to the Auschwitz gas chambers, and he is still amazed never to have been among them.
"The sole common denominator of the survivors seems to me to be an inordinate appetite for life -- and the flexibility of a contortionist," he writes. "I don't believe in the steadfast hero who endures every trial with his head held high, the tough guy who never gives in. Not in Auschwitz."
There are extraordinary scenes depicted in this book of the amazing brutality of the Nazis. Steinberg is gripped by a little-known episode. Near the end of the war there was a final call-out of Jews in Buchenwald, which, owing to his savvy ways, he did not heed. Those who did, about 1,000 to 1,200 men, were sealed into cattle cars and left there to die of hunger, thirst or exhaustion. And then there is a contrasting memory of Czech workers seeing carloads of prisoners passing beneath an iron bridge, and opening their satchels and tossing down their lunches "without a moment's hesitation, without even thinking about it."
The mystery deepens, why some men are beasts, why most are not, and how, to survive, one has to have a little of the beast in oneself. Steinberg's book is saturated with those questions, which haunted this unlikely author for decades and now, thanks to his remarkable little volume, translated from the French by Linda Coverdale and Bill Ford, will haunt us as well.

SECTION: Section G; Page 1; Column 1; Workplace 

LENGTH: 981 words

HEADLINE: Genies for Hire Cash In on Worker Stress

BYLINE: By ABBY ELLIN 

 BODY:
Peter London has the biggest to-do list in all of New York. Bigger than Rosie O'Donell's. Bigger then Mayor Giuliani's. Possibly even bigger than Hillary Clinton's.
A few weeks ago, Mr. London was in charge of sorting 9,000 compact discs, picking up a prescription at a local pharmacy and driving a parrot to Boston. 
 Mr. London, 32, is the founder of N.Y. Errands, a concierge service in Manhattan. No job is too small for him and his 28 employees, who earn $9 to $11 an hour to cater to the needs of the overburdened.
Need a snake transported across state lines? He's your man. Do your giant stuffed teddy bears need their innards cleaned? For $45, one of Mr. London's trusted lieutenants will take them to the New York Doll Hospital (cleaning costs are extra).
They will also buy stoppers for your sinks or deliver lunch to your children in school. (Their most recent food run: a chicken fajita, small fries, Diet Coke, small chocolate sundae, courtesy of McDonald's.)
"Our goal is to take people's to-do list off their hands and give them back their most precious asset: time," Mr. London said from his spartan office on Lexington Avenue, which operates like a dispatch center. "We offer peace of mind."
Clients include supermodels, supermoms and superegos; college students who are too harried to wait at Kinko's; and businesses like the law firm of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson and Highbridge Capital, an investment firm.
It is all part of a trend, of course. Motorola, Hewlett-Packard, Microsoft and Oracle offer corporate concierge services so that employees will not have to fret about the minutiae of their everyday lives on (God forbid) company time.
There is even a national association, the American Errand Runners Organization, which lists errand services nationwide on its Web site, www.errandinfo.com.
In Los Angeles, Denise Van Zant, the 36-year-old founder of Chores-N-More, has been hired as a tour guide at Disneyland, Universal Studios and Sea World and as a companion on a Rodeo Drive shopping excursion, a job she branded "nice."
"When I first started out, I had a request from someone to take their dog to the dog park and let it run around for four hours," Ms. Van Zant recalled. "They didn't even want me to play with the dog or throw a Frisbee or a ball. I made $25 an hour to sit on a bench and do my paperwork."
Such is life in the new economy, where many Americans are overworked and overstressed and simply cannot afford to take a break. This is hardly surprising: who can risk an ulcer or stress headache when there is work to be done?
"People are strapped for time and they have extra money and just want to relax and be with their family during their free time," explained Anne Bentley, 28, founder of an errand service in Dallas called the Runaround.
Customers who responded to a questionnaire that Mr. London distributed, for example, said they would be willing to part with up to $35 for somebody else to wait for the cable guy to show up at their home, and pay $10 to $15 for a hired hand to make a run to a nearby drugstore or florist.
Some N.Y. Errands clients call four to seven times a day, he said.
Sue Marcus is one of them. A broker at the William B. May real estate company in New York, Ms. Marcus uses N.Y. Errands "100 times a week sometimes," she said. "I have a standing order with them once every three to four weeks for Costco; they've taken my car in to be serviced; they've picked up my fish at the Midtown market I love. I send them to my favorite dry cleaners and they pet sit for me sometimes. I'm an addict."
N.Y. Errands divides tasks into four categories: waiting (at the Department of Motor Vehicles office, for example), local shopping (at the corner deli, say), specialty shopping (at stores like Costco or Zabar's) and create-your-own services (think breakfast in bed). Employees are screened extensively, and Mr. London says letting them into strange homes is not a problem.
He refuses all X-rated requests, he says, though he did once deliver an inflatable doll to a bachelor party. And once -- just once -- he spied on someone, he says, though he declines to give details. "We will provide anything as long as it's legal and doesn't jeopardize the integrity of our company and the companies we work for," he said.
Mr. London came up with his time-relieving idea as an M.B.A. student at New York University. He got a B- for his business plan, his worst grade in business school, though he cannot remember why (he thinks it was late). After graduating in 1996, he had a brief stint at the National Hockey League and then decided to revisit his errand idea. He did the research and discovered that while there were many concierge services in the city, few companies offered everything under one roof.
The "your wish is our command" concept has been around a long time, of course. For ancient kings, it was a way of life. For modern luxury hotels, it is a marketing tool. And for secretaries everywhere, it is a job description (though the feminist movement has curbed somewhat such demeaning tasks as picking up the boss's dry cleaning).
Surf the Web (or flip through the yellow pages, if you have the time), and you will discover service providers willing to organize a party for you, buy a car for you, even write an angry letter to the editor for you.
And then there are online companies like Kozmo.com that make home deliveries. Trouble is, customers can only order from these companies' inventories, whereas N.Y. Errands will go out and shop for you.
Founded in July 1999, N.Y. Errands expects revenue to approach $1 million this year, Mr. London says. Dealing with all that growth keeps him pretty busy, which raises the question: Who does his chores?
He sighed and laughed at the query, but not too heartily. "I hate to say it, but I'm lucky," he said. "I have a wife."

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 6; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 164 words

HEADLINE: Paths to Learning

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Richard Rothstein is correct: while more Americans should attend college, a higher education alone will not solve the growing problems of economic equality (Lessons column, Nov. 1). 
 The increasing demand for workers with precise technical skills has actually led to a growing number of options for high school graduates. Borough of Manhattan Community College and Cisco Systems offer qualified high school graduates in northern Manhattan the opportunity to become certified networking specialists during a six-month training program.
We are now placing people in entry-level jobs with average starting salaries of $49,000.
I am not suggesting that short-term courses like ours serve as an alternative to college. At the same time, institutions of higher education must ensure that their programs keep pace with the changing demands of the work force.
 
ANTONIO PEREZ
President, Borough of Manhattan
Community College, CUNY
New York, Nov. 2, 2000 
http://www.nytimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Signs of Investor Worry in Sale of Argentine Debt

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 7

 BODY:
Argentina sold $1.1 billion in treasury bills today at rates that reflected investors' worries about the government's ability to finance its growing debt.
Today's auction was crucial as Argentina, Latin America's biggest borrower, is being forced to meet more of its financing needs at home with short-term debt. Access to international markets is limited by growing concern about the country's weak economy and a debt load equal to nearly half of its gross domestic product. The country has $123.5 billion in public debt. 
 "It shows that they can finance themselves at home, but the question is at what price," said Simon Nocera, who helps manage $6 billion in fixed income at Dresdner RCM Global Investors in San Francisco. "It's a very difficult situation because they cannot continue to fund themselves at this rate."
Argentina sold $500 million of one-year treasury bills priced to yield 16 percent, up from 8.89 percent when similar bills were auctioned on July 12. On foreign markets the nation's bonds sank to the lowest levels since Brazil devalued its currency 22 months ago, before recovering later in the day.
Argentina also sold $250 million of 91-day treasury bills to yield 13 percent, compared with the 9.47 percent yield when bills were sold Oct. 24. Argentina sold $350 million of 182-day bills to yield 14.51 percent, compared with a yield of 8.64 percent when similar bills were last auctioned Oct. 11. The rates, however, were below what some had expected.
Investors have shunned Argentine debt on concern that the government, weakened by political scandal and a series of resignations, will have trouble paying the interest on its debt next year. That might require a large loan package from lenders like the International Monetary Fund to avoid default, some investors say. Argentina needs to meet more than $19 billion in financing needs next year.
Concerns about Argentina rippled throughout Latin America, raising the yield on $256 million of Brazil's treasury bonds by 76 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, from 17.42 percent last week.

HEADLINE: Consumer Credit Slowed in September

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7

 BODY:
Consumer credit increased in September at the slowest pace in five months, a sign consumer spending could start to cool, Federal Reserve statistics showed today.
The rise of $6.4 billion in September followed a revised increase of $12.3 billion in August. The annual rate of borrowing rose 5.2 percent in September, about half of the 10.1 percent increase a month earlier. 
 The increase in September credit, the slowest since $6.4 billion in April, suggests consumers may be pulling back to pay off debt.
"Things aren't quite as good as before" in the stock market and the economy, said Cynthia Latta, an economist at Standard & Poor's DRI in Lexington, Mass. "There are more layoffs going on and consumer confidence has slipped."
Revolving loans, which include credit cards, rose $3.6 billion in September after rising $6.7 billion during August. Auto and other personal loans increased $2.8 billion in September after rising $5.6 billion during August.
Before today's Fed report, analysts anticipated that September borrowing would rise by $10.5 billion after a previously reported August increase of $13.4 billion, according to a Bloomberg News survey.

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
Get as much information as possible before heading to potential trouble spots.

BYLINE: By Joe Sharkey; The Business Travel column appears each Wednesday. E-mail: jsharkey@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
LONDON, Paris, Tokyo, Frankfurt, Milan. These are the sorts of places you think of instinctively when considering international business travel.
Not much to worry about if you're headed there -- and if there were, you'd be reading about it on the front page. But what about all those less-familiar destinations that are being increasingly added to international business-travel itineraries thanks to rapidly expanding economic globalization? 
 Let's say the boss suddenly asks you to look after some business in, say, Indonesia. Assuming your corporate travel agent hasn't done so already, you would probably want to be given a heads-up on the following before you start packing:
"The cities of Jakarta and Medan, in addition to other locations, have been struck by a number of bombings in recent months. The Jakarta Stock Exchange, foreign diplomatic facilities and Indonesian government buildings have been targeted. Some foreign travelers in troubled areas of Indonesia have been subject to arbitrary arrest, detention and deportation and, on at least one occasion, false accusations of espionage. In the central Java city of Solo, groups opposed to U.S. policy have undertaken or threatened 'sweeps,' trying to identify American citizens and order them to depart the country. There also have been a number of acts of intimidation and violence directed at American companies and U.S. diplomatic facilities."
That information is excerpted from a United States State Department travel advisory issued last week. It is available, along with a detailed list of travel advisories for other countries and regions (including a recommendation that Americans "defer all travel to Israel, the West Bank and Gaza"), at a government Web site (www.travel.state.gov/travel warnings.html), that many wide-ranging international travelers bookmark.
Travel agents and online travel sites that book corporate and leisure travel say, meanwhile, that they are paying more attention these days to the fact that increasing numbers of travelers, especially business travelers, are touching down in parts of the world where trouble may be brewing or exploding.
"Statistically we know we have people planning business trips to places beyond the traditional, both domestic and international, destinations," said Suzi LeVine, the marketing director at Expedia.com, one of the leading online travel sites, where business travel accounts for about a third of its sales. On its main page, Expedia.com has a "health and safety" link that contains current updates on trouble spots. One posted this week, for example, described a severe malaria outbreak in Burundi.
Far more people use online sites to gather travel information than actually book on them. Online sites, however, including those that are managed by outside travel agencies and used in-house by companies, typically provide a lot of up-to-date travel-destination information.
"Very few if any of our customers are actually booking travel to hot spots online, because they already know there's issues and they want to talk to professionals," said Thom Nulty, the president of Navigant International Inc., a leading domestic supplier of corporate travel-management services. He added that the company's online portals might handle some simple bookings like New York to London, but for "the complex international reservations, or the reservations to third world or difficult areas, live agents are probably always going to be involved" because people feel more secure dealing with a professional.
Incidentally, besides the State Department site, here are two other government sites with useful information for international travelers: www.odci.gov/cia/publications/factbook, containing an annual factbook with basic geopolitical information about world nations, and www.cdc.gov/travel, which has information on things like immunizations, disease outbreaks around the world, and cruise-ship health and safety violations.
On another note, more than a dozen readers reacted with skepticism to an item in this space a couple of weeks ago about the CNN Airport Network. The item quoted an official at the network, which broadcasts CNN airport programming on televisions in departure lounges, as saying that CNN goes to great lengths to ensure that those passengers who don't want to have a television blasting at them while they wait for their planes are provided with quiet zones where the bellow of the beast can't be heard.
"May I challenge them to provide locations in, say, the Denver or Chicago United terminals where the terminal is quiet?" wrote one reader, Gary Cohen of Sacramento, Calif.
Come to think of it, I was involuntarily subjected to 45 minutes of too-loud, in-your-face CNN just two weeks ago while waiting in the invincibly sluggish Continental Airlines baggage-claim area at Newark International Airport.
Marea Battle, a spokeswoman for CNN Airport Network, said that about 10 times a day the network puts on a programming announcement encouraging viewers to forward questions or comments via e-mail to airport.network@cnn.com. Viewer feedback is also solicited on the network's Web site, www.CNN.com/airport.
When major news is happening (last night's election returns, for example), the CNN service is of course wildly popular in airport lounges. But in slower times, some passengers just want to get away from a television and read or think in peace, and the network says that it designs its monitor installation in departure lounges to ensure that there are quiet, TV-free zones.
The spokeswoman said the network had technicians in airports to maintain "quality control standards" that include making sure the sound isn't too loud. "It is our objective to provide an informative, entertaining and free passenger service that is discretionary to passengers," she said.

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk; Education Page

LENGTH: 1045 words

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Graduate Students Disagree on a Union at N.Y.U.

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
Jonna Perrillo is one of the army of about 100 New York University graduate students who teach the writing workshop -- or the "writing sweatshop," as it is sometimes called -- that is required of all freshmen.
She selects readings for her class, plans the curriculum, teaches two 75-minute classes a week and corrects an endless stream of essays. She also helps to mentor some of the other graduate student teachers. 
 For that, Ms. Perrillo, a 29-year-old third-year doctoral student in English education who almost always has a bagful of student essays that need grading, receives an annual stipend of $13,000. To help meet her living expenses, she also has to work one day a week outside the university, at a publishing company. "I get $13,000 a year to live in a city where that's just impossible -- and a quarter of that goes back to the university for health care and fees," she said.
But last week, she and many -- though not all -- of her colleagues finally began to feel that their threadbare situation was about to change. For the first time, the National Labor Relations Board had given a green light to the formation of a union for research and teaching assistants at a private university, theirs. A union would let the graduate assistants bargain for higher stipends, health benefits and other terms of employment.
There is at least one important hurdle, however. It is not certain yet that graduate students want a union. About 1,500 students voted last spring on whether to accept the United Auto Workers as their bargaining agent, but the election results were impounded while the university, which had lost an earlier ruling by the board's regional director, was allowed to appeal to the labor board in Washington. Today the labor board will count ballots to see whether the students approved the U.A.W. as their union.
As they waited for the results of the election, Ms. Perrillo and many of her pro-union classmates were optimistic. But not all graduate students at the university were so pleased. In the sciences and at the business school, areas of the university where financial support for graduate students tends to be higher than in the humanities and arts, many students saw a union as an encroachment, an outside body that would shape the agreements they struck with their professors and interfere with their relationships. They also said that union dues would be an extra cost without much benefit.
"I was dismayed when I heard about the union," said Abigail Hornstein, a second-year doctoral student in economics and international business who helped lead an antiunion group on campus last spring. As a second-year doctoral student at N.Y.U.'s Stern School of Business, she receives an annual stipend of $21,000 -- far more than Ms. Perrillo gets. In return, she is expected to work 20 hours a week as a research assistant.
In Ms. Hornstein's view, however, such inequities should be addressed by individual departments rather than by a universitywide union. Another solution, she said, is for students who are paid poorly to go elsewhere. "If conditions are that bad," she said, "there are plenty of universities in the country that offer an equally good education and better compensation. People don't choose academic careers to become millionaires."
David Chesler, a research assistant in a viral immunology laboratory in the biology department, was equally uninterested in a union. Last year, he earned $20,000 for teaching the laboratory sections for an introductory biology course. He spent 20 hours a week preparing and teaching the sections and grading quizzes and papers.
This year, as a research assistant, he is putting in far more time -- often 50 or 60 hours a week -- but is still happy. His professor, Carol Reiss, is often only steps away, and he consults with her constantly about his research, his courses and even his private life.
"My biggest fear is that a union is going to hurt us in the sciences," said Mr. Chesler, a fourth-year graduate student from Scarsdale who hopes to attend medical school after he receives his Ph.D. He was concerned that the department might become less competitive in vying for top students. "To take union dues from a stipend that is already small would not be helpful," he said.
"I don't think a union has a place at a university," he added. "Unions are for people who have a career and need protecting."
Graduate student stipends had begun to rise even before the union surfaced at N.Y.U. as the university tried to compete with other universities that were increasing aid to graduate students. But many students believe that the aid effectively amounts to wages and that a union is necessary to make them more generous. They note that students who cannot live on the stipends they receive often turn to outside work, which slows their progress toward their degrees.
Paul Jackson, an art history doctoral student in his ninth year at N.Y.U., said that stipends in his department were about $9,000 when he started (N.Y.U. said it now has a $13,000 minimum) and that he has taken out loans, accepted teaching assignments at other universities and worked four days a week in the Jackson Pollock-Lee Krasner house in East Hampton.
Ms. Perrillo, the doctoral student in English education, said that between her teaching and her one-day-a-week work at a publishing company, her own schoolwork often got pushed to late nights and weekends. Her boyfriend is in a similar situation, she said, and instead of going on dates, the two often spend their time at the library studying. "It's just lame," she said.
Although university officials have expressed concern that negotiating with a union over the terms of graduate student work could interfere with faculty-student relationships, union supporters like Kimberly Gladman, a seventh-year doctoral student in comparative literature who was working at the U.A.W. office on University Place, near N.Y.U.'s campus, dismiss such arguments.
"A lot of my professors would be very pleased and relieved if we were covered by a union, because very often the faculty want better conditions for us but are not in a position to create them," said Ms. Gladman, taking a break from faxing notices of the labor board decision.
